HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ELECTORATE;
Bush Loses Luster in a Poll As Gore Sheds Poor Image

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
As Gov. George W. Bush of Texas finds himself in a rancorous primary struggle, voters' impressions of him nationally have diminished so substantially that now as many people dislike him as like him, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
These findings are particularly striking given that for months Mr. Bush towered over the Republican and Democratic fields in poll after poll. But Mr. Bush's Republican challenger, Senator John McCain of Arizona, is in a markedly improved position after his 19-point victory in the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 1. In November, voters knew little about Mr. McCain; now, more people like him than do not, by nearly 3 to 1. 
 In contrast to Mr. Bush, Vice President Al Gore has enjoyed some success in overcoming a decidedly negative image and has benefited from a huge proportion of Americans who credit President Clinton for a flourishing economy.
The most heartening news for the vice president and for the Democratic Party were several signs in the survey that Republicans might find it daunting to compete with Democrats next November on both the presidential and Congressional levels.
During the Republican debate in South Carolina on Tuesday night, both Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain presented themselves as best prepared to steer the country out of the Clinton era. But that may not be such a prudent selling point, especially among Democrats and independents, because the poll found that the president still draws high marks for his job performance.
Although only 43 percent of those polled said they liked Mr. Clinton personally, his job approval rating stood at 60 percent and his stewardship of the economy drew a 73 percent approval.
This is all encouraging for the vice president. When registered voters were asked why they liked Mr. Gore, the highest proportion, 22 percent, said it was because of the Clinton administration's record, more than double since last November. An additional 17 percent said it was because of Mr. Gore's experience as vice president.
The results are quite a turnabout from last year, when Mr. Gore was struggling to contain the surge by his Democratic opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, while also keeping a distance from the scandals at the White House.
Mr. Clinton remarked on the Democrats' good fortune at his news conference in Washington yesterday. Asked why the two Republicans had condemned him in the debate, he said: "I have a lot of sympathy with Governor Bush and Senator McCain. It's hard for them to figure out what to run on."
Complicating Mr. Bush's challenge is that registered voters polled are now as likely to hold a negative view of him as a positive one, a pronounced shift from late last year, when he was far more popular. Mr. Bush has suffered in part, the poll found, because voters do not link him with a particular set of policies and are not enamored of his tax-cut plan.
As Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush compete ferociously in the run-up to the primary on Saturday in South Carolina, the Democratic contest nationally seems to have evaporated in the eyes of many voters. Mr. Bradley's losses to Mr. Gore in New Hampshire and Iowa have made him less of a factor in the Democratic race; the vice president has enlarged his lopsided lead among Democrats.
About as many people have a favorable image of Mr. Gore as unfavorable, not an altogether enviable position, but a notable shift from last December, when a far higher proportion viewed him negatively.
The nationwide telephone poll of 1,225 adults, including 979 registered voters, was conducted Saturday through Monday. The entire sample has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Because of its broad national scope, this survey is not a reliable measure of the Republican contest in South Carolina.
If the general election were held today, the survey found, it would be a dead heat, with Mr. Bush drawing 45 percent and Mr. Gore 44 percent. Last November, Mr. Bush was ahead of Mr. Gore, 50 percent to 41 percent.
Despite Mr. McCain's surge in popularity, he would do no better against Mr. Gore than Mr. Bush would. Mr. McCain would receive 42 percent; Mr. Gore, 41 percent.
But in a sign of Mr. McCain's potency, and success in courting independents and Democrats, he would beat Mr. Bradley, 45 percent to 31 percent. In November, Mr. Bradley led Mr. McCain, 47 percent to 30 percent.
In the primaries, Mr. Bush is still favored by more than half of the Republican voters. But Mr. McCain has cut into Mr. Bush's once-tremendous lead. The poll shows that Mr. Bush is now the choice of 53 percent of those who plan to vote in Republican primaries, and Mr. McCain, 33 percent. In November, Mr. Bush was the favorite of 68 percent, and Mr. McCain was the choice of only 8 percent.
Still, many registered voters said they are only beginning to focus on the race. Only one-third of Mr. Bush's backers, and of Mr. McCain's, said they had decided for certain.
On the Democratic side, Mr. Gore's national lead has grown. Sixty-four percent of Democratic voters back Mr. Gore; 25 percent support Mr. Bradley. In November, as Mr. Bradley was drawing national notice as a threat to the vice president in New Hampshire, 56 percent favored Mr. Gore and 30 percent supported Mr. Bradley.
Another comforting sign for Mr. Gore is that the voters polled said they no longer expected a Republican victory in the presidential race. Now, they say, it is a tossup.
In many ways, Mr. Clinton's popularity is helping Democrats in the same way it did when Washington was distracted by the impeachment proceedings: The public likes the policies of the administration despite the reservations about Mr. Clinton's personal qualities.
"As vice president, he's had a part in the success of the economy," said Kelly Rinaldo, an independent who was questioned for the poll and explained in a follow-up interview yesterday why she liked Mr. Gore. "He's on the right track. And if he follows through on Social Security and health care, he'd be great."
Ms. Rinaldo, 36, a homemaker from Patchogue Village, N.Y., added, "When you're a vice president, you always play second fiddle, but he has the upper hand because of this experience."
The danger for Mr. Bush is that the more people get to know him, the more he seems to lose support.
"Bush seems to waffle more on the issues," said Mark Giloican, 27, a poll respondent who is a student in Savannah, Ga., and plans to back Mr. McCain. "All of the candidates tend to say what we want to hear. But Bush seems to do it more. My opinion has changed recently simply because I've heard more about him. He seems to have a little more charisma than McCain, but that's not what matters to me."
Indeed, the findings suggested that Mr. Bush's positions were a growing vulnerability. Registered voters in the poll said they were more drawn to Mr. McCain's campaign reform mantra than to Mr. Bush's signature tax proposal.
Asked what any budget surplus should be used for, 56 percent of the respondents said it should go to Social Security; 17 percent to pay down the debt; and only 13 percent to cut income taxes.
But respondents seemed more interested in campaign finance reform, which has been Mr. McCain's major theme, although Mr. Bush announced a campaign finance proposal of his own this week.
Forty-two percent of the respondents said the campaign finance system had so much wrong with it that it needed to be completely overhauled. Another 44 percent said fundamental changes were needed.
Of course, Mr. Bush's tax-cutting message still appeals to many Republicans.
Louise Cassan, 78, a retired clothes presser who backs Mr. Bush, put it this way: "McCain has come out for campaign finance. But if it was passed the Republicans wouldn't have a chance because the media leans heavily Democratic. He's also more liberal than Bush. He doesn't support as big a tax cut that Bush does, which the people need and deserve." She added that Mr. Bush "wants all the things I want, such as tax cuts and smaller government."
On the Democratic side, Albert McCloud, 63, a retired shipworker from Hampton, Va., said he would back Mr. Gore. "It appears that Bill Clinton is going to try to win the election for Al Gore, and it appears that Al Gore is going to try to continue some of the successful policies of the Clinton administration, like paying down the debt, keeping the economy steady by working with the Federal Reserve, and strengthening the education budget."
Beyond the presidential race, the poll found that Democrats were better positioned for the November elections than Republicans. Sixty-one percent of registered voters said they had a positive view of the Democratic Party; 31 percent had a negative view. By contrast, 49 percent had a positive view of Republicans; 41 percent a negative view.
While national polls have little predictive value for the outcome of local House races, they do offer a sense of public sentiment about the parties. In the poll, 33 percent of registered voters said they planned to vote for the Republican candidate in their district; 44 percent for the Democrat.
More than anything else, Democrats are buoyed by the roaring economy. In 1992, when Mr. Clinton triumphed over President George Bush, only 23 percent of those polled said the economy was in good shape. Now, 88 percent hold that view.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: REGION;
PATH Trains Continue To Gain Passengers

 BODY:
Ridership on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey's PATH trains was 67.3 million last year, a rise of 3 percent over 1998 and a continuation of a steady increase in passengers since 1996.
Michael P. DePallo, general manager of the trans-Hudson tubes, attributed the increase to the strong economy in the region as well as to sharp rises in weekend traveling on the rail line, which runs between Newark, Jersey City, Hoboken and five Manhattan stations. 
 With its fare set at $1 since 1987, Path remains a money-losing operation. In 1998, the PATH lines had a net loss of $184 million.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
ShrinkingTreasury Debt Creates Uncertain World

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Lawrence H. Summers, secretary of the Treasury, is clearly relishing his role as the man who put the nation on a no-debt diet. In Congressional testimony last week, Mr. Summers predicted that by 2013, the $3.6 trillion in Treasury debt held by the public would be eliminated, repurchased by funds from budget surpluses that the roaring American economy has wrought. The result, he said, will be an even stronger economy and lower interest rates for all.
Maybe so. But in the meantime, the Treasury's plan to reduce its debt is roiling the financial markets and raising the prospect of far-reaching, unintended effects on the economy and investors. 
 One immediate effect of the shrinking Treasury debt market, economists say, is to make it tougher for the Federal Reserve Board to cool the economy because as it raises short-term interest rates, long-term rates are not rising in tandem.
In addition, the debt securities that remain in the shrinking market are expected to be much more prone to wild swings in price and thereby riskier for investors.
Finally, corporations will probably issue more debt to fill the public demand for bonds, creating a debt burden that could make it much more difficult for the nation to shake off a downturn in the economy.
"The surplus has forced the Treasury to change the way they do business, and we are looking at the consequences," said Ward McCarthy, principal at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "It affects everybody."
Because the market for Treasury debt is the largest and most heavily traded in the world, and because investors evaluate almost every other type of bond using a Treasury security as a benchmark, even the smallest change in the government's financing has effects at home and abroad.
"One of the reasons the U.S. has been the dominant factor in the world is we were the only place with a deep, liquid debt market," said Stan Jonas, managing director at FIMAT U.S.A., a brokerage firm in New York. "We would not be the leader in the financial marketplace if we hadn't had the advantage of a huge, rich Treasury market. Now that market is disappearing."
The ripples from a vanishing public market for Treasury debt have begun to hit investors who buy bonds and the companies that issue them. Last month, when the Treasury outlined its aggressive plan to reduce the debt it issues and to buy back debt already in investors' hands, the market went haywire. There was a mad rush for long-term government bonds, driving down interest rates on long-term government debt even as the Federal Reserve Board was raising short-term rates to try to cool down an overheated economy.
This created significant losses for investors, who had bet that the Fed's increases in short-term rates would cause rates at the long end of the market to rise as well. Instead, the effective rate on 30-year bonds fell well below that of 2-year notes. Normally, investors are given extra incentive in the form of higher rates to lock up their money for a longer period.
More important, economists and market strategists say, the Treasury's plan and the ensuing rush to long-term bonds are throwing sand into the gears that the Fed uses to keep the economy perking while protecting against inflation.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, who is scheduled to testify today as part of his twice-a-year report to Congress, has raised short-term rates three times since last June in an effort to slow the economy. But rates on long-term Treasury securities have fallen.
"It poses a little bit of a challenge for monetary policy," said Henry Kaufman, the noted Wall Street economist.
Few economists say the Treasury's overall plan to reduce the nation's debt is wrongheaded. Last year's budget surplus of $124 billion, the largest ever, was a direct result of a supercharged economy and a roaring stock market, which generated huge tax receipts. As long as the economy and stock markets remain hot and Congress keeps a lid on spending, budget surpluses will continue. Reducing debt, the government argues, is a natural use for these funds.
To be sure, the government will still issue debt to be held by the Federal Reserve and the Social Security trust. It is the publicly held debt that is set for extinction.
Although the Treasury securities market is the world's largest and most influential, it wasn't always thus. In the 1960's, for example, when an investor asked what the bond market was doing, the answer usually involved the price action in an AT&T bond or an obligation of a highly rated electric utility.
But as the United States government grew and the Treasury began to borrow more to finance the growth, the significance of the Treasury securities market rose as well. In the 1980's and 1990's, the Treasury raised trillions of dollars each year from investors by issuing bonds, notes and bills; the peak came in 1996, when the Treasury auctioned $2.5 trillion in securities.
By fiscal 1998, according to the Treasury, federal debt held by the public had risen to $3.7 trillion, up from $2.1 trillion just 10 years earlier.
But the days of ballooning Treasury debt are over. Eliminating the publicly held Treasury debt by 2013, Mr. Summers said, will put downward pressure on all interest rates, helping to reduce consumer payments on home mortgages, car loans and other forms of credit. This has not happened yet. Most consumer borrowings are based upon shorter-term interest rates -- even 30-year mortgage rates are based on shorter-term rates because homeowners typically pay off their loans well before their term is up -- and these are rising because of the Fed's recent actions.
Where the effects have been felt sharply are in the corporate bond and mortgage markets. A 30-year corporate bond is usually judged against a 30-year Treasury. But with Treasuries being hoarded ahead of a possible shortage, the rates on the bonds no longer represent a good comparison. As a result, the private debt market has lost its anchor.
Wall Street will undoubtedly create a new security to use as a benchmark for bond issues soon. But until then, uncertainty will rule the market.
As a result, investors are having trouble assessing new bond issues and are acting with caution. "I think everybody has thrown up their hands at the moment," said Carol Levenson, editor of Gimme Credit, a research service that analyzes high-grade corporate bonds. "The market is waiting to see if things are going to return to normal."
Trading has also dropped off recently in the vast market for mortgage obligations, which are backed by consumer loans, according to Mickey Levy, the chief economist at BankAmerica. "With higher risk in this market, it could make rates higher on the margin," he said, for the moment, just the opposite of what Mr. Summers has predicted.
Some strategists suspect that the bond market may never return to normal. "One byproduct of a consequential shrinkage of the Treasury market is that the U.S. debt markets will be increasingly comprised of a variety of securities that are riskier than Treasury debt," Mr. McCarthy said. "So in addition to increased volatility, we are dealing with almost by definition a riskier bond market as well."
This is quite a change, given that much of the bond market has been a refuge for investors seeking safety and security in their holdings. Few are confident that investors have recognized the increased risks they will need to take when they invest in bonds as the Treasury bows out of the market and corporate issuers take its place.
Moreover, investors may not recognize the implications of a big increase in corporate debt when the nation experiences a recession. "When you go into an economic slowdown and there is a large amount of government debt outstanding and a small amount of corporate debt outstanding, that's not a problem," Mr. Kaufman explained. "All you need is an easing in monetary policy and off we go again. But when the private sector is heavily burdened when we slow down, that will require more stimulation. This is a concern."
One economist worried that using the budget surplus to finance a buyback of existing Treasury debt could cause inflation. Robert H. Parks, a professor of finance at the Lubin Graduate School of Business at Pace University, said: "This increases the money supply, and it also increases the reserves of private financial institutions. It is highly expansionary and potentially inflationary in an economy that is roaring ahead."

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
Europeans Celebrate Their Freedom to Dwell in Hollywood's Shadow

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 16

 BODY:
For its 50th-anniversary edition the Berlin Film Festival has moved its headquarters from the former West Berlin to Potsdamer Platz, a new urban complex that symbolizes the unification and rebirth of this long-divided city. Yet while the festival now has a home fit for the 21st century, the Berlinale, as it is widely known, is still struggling to find a new identity 10 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Yes, things were often easier in the past. Veteran movie directors from Eastern Europe can still be heard lamenting that capitalism has proven to be a stricter censor than Communism. It was always possible to find obtuse or allegorical ways of telling the truth under Communism, they say, but there is no way of circumventing the restrictions imposed by commercial budget and distribution systems. 
 And there is a parallel in the Berlinale. When this was a divided and occupied city, the West Berlin festival had a clear political mission, first as a showcase of democratic freedom, then as a cultural bridge between East and West. Now, with Berlin reunited and the Soviet bloc a thing of the past, the festival seems to be adrift in the no man's land that divides the global movie industry between the United States and the rest of the world.
This year's 10-day festival, which ends on Sunday, is therefore a less than satisfying compromise. It is presenting a half-dozen big-budget American movies, which have been released in the United States and are merely using this festival as a springboard for European distribution. But the Berlinale needs the glamour of Hollywood stars: the world learns about it only because photographers are willing to mob the likes of Leonardo DiCaprio (here to promote "The Beach") or Gwyneth Paltrow (here for the showing of "The Talented Mr. Ripley").
This in turn reflects a reality beyond the festival's control: the United States so dominates world cinema that it leaves little room for anyone else. In most of Europe, including Germany, American films account for 80 to 90 percent of ticket sales; only in France, where government subsidies have kept the movie industry alive, does the American share drop to around 70 percent. Thus if few foreign-language movies reach the United States, few also find markets elsewhere.
In presenting scores of smaller movies from around the world, the festival offers ample evidence that cinema is alive and well outside the United States. Actors and directors from Spain to Japan may wander around Berlin unnoticed, although even winning the festival's awards, known as Bears, is no guarantee of wider recognition. The talents and concerns of moviemakers working outside the glare of Hollywood can nonetheless be seen here. Perhaps surprisingly, politics are still an issue. A comedy from Croatia called "Marsal" (known in English as "Marshall Tito's Spirit"), directed by Vinko Bresan, illustrates that country's confused transition from Communism to capitalism by telling of an apparition of Marshall Tito on a Croatian island. The mayor, having privatized government properties and bought them on the cheap for himself, now spots a new business opportunity: he invites veteran Tito loyalists to contact the ghost and turns the island into a Communist theme park.
Certainly the Balkans have proven adept at tackling their recent tragedies with dark humor. "Nebaska Udica" ("Sky Hook"), which was made by the Serbian director Ljubisa Samardzic during NATO's bombing of Belgrade last April, tells of a group of beer-swilling layabouts, including Kaja (Nebojsa Glogovac), whose 7-year-old son has been struck mute by the bombing. Their main concern is to rebuild their devastated basketball court, but the underlying theme is their inability to influence the conflict disrupting their lives.
"Piao Ling Ma Ma" ("Breaking the Silence"), directed by Sun Zhou, also deals with contemporary events, this time in a China hurriedly embracing the profits and perils of capitalism. This serves as the background to a touching tale of a divorced mother, played by the Chinese star Gong Li, as she struggles to have her deaf 8-year-old son accepted in a regular school. Even with cuts demanded by the Chinese authorities, the film captures the hardship faced by many ordinary Chinese with the arrival of a market economy and unemployment.
In contrast, "Russkij Bunt" ("The Captain's Daughter"), directed by Aleksandr Proshkin and adapted from two stories by Pushkin, is a "Dr. Zhivago"-like epic set in the 18th century. It blends a love story with an account of the peasant uprising led by an impostor posing as the czar, Yemelya Pugachev (Sergei Machovecki). For all the film's snow, beards, swords and horses, however, the director believes it to be topical. "Our age, like the times of Catherine II, is an age where morals have lost their value, an age of swift career making and instantaneous downfalls," he said.
A certain nostalgia also permeates Akira Ogata's first film, "Boys' Choir," which is set in a Japan of the early 1970's where a student movement with revolutionary dreams is facing defeat and leaving an entire generation feeling pessimistic about the future. The story focuses on two boys in a Christian boarding school where a young pastor is trying to create his own version of the Vienna Boys Choir. His past as a radical, however, catches up with him.
Volker Schlondorff's new movie, "The Legends of Rita," also goes back to the radical movement of the 1970's, this time in West Germany. When the movement collapses, Rita Vogt (Bibinana Beglau) flees to East Germany, is given a new identity as a factory worker and confronts the grimness of life under Communism. But when East Germany finally implodes, she cannot escape responsibility for her earlier terrorism in the West.
Still, most new movies from Europe show little interest in politics, although several reflect the gradual blending of European culture. Francois Ozon, an up-and-coming young French director, has adapted an unstaged 1970 play by the German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder, "Water Drops on Burning Rocks," for the screen. Even more of an international cocktail is "Signs and Wonders," a new film by the American director Jonathan Nossiter: it was financed by a French company, made in English and set in Athens. It stars a Swede (Stellan Skarsgard), a Briton (Charlotte Rampling), an American (Deborah Kara Unger) and a Greek (Dimitris Katalifos).
These films also offer human close-ups rather than social statements. Mr. Ozon's movie, for instance, tells of a middle-aged man who takes a young male lover only to find their menage a deux disturbed by their former girlfriends. In "Signs and Wonders" a man leaves his wife for a younger woman; when he decides to return home, his wife has found happiness with another man, but his pre-teenage daughter proves to be a perverse ally.
Rudolf Thome's "Paradiso" tells of a composer who celebrates his 60th birthday with the seven most important lovers in his life. Some critics described the film as a male fantasy; Mr. Thome said he was being ironic.
Apart from the festival's Hollywood imports, which also include "Three Kings," "Magnolia," "The Hurricane," "Any Given Sunday" and "Man on the Moon," there are other English-language movies, not only small independent films from the United States but also fare from the British Isles, including "Saltwater," an impressive directing debut by the young Irish playwright Conor McPherson ("The Weir"), who also wrote the screenplay.
Kenneth Branagh's latest Shakespeare, "Love's Labour's Lost," though, seems closer to Hollywood in the 1950's than London in 1600. Starring Alessandro Nivola as the King of Navarre and Alicia Silverstone as the Princess of France, with Mr. Branagh's Berowne busily wooing Natascha McElhone's Rosaline, the film is peppered with songs by Cole Porter, Irving Berlin and George Gershwin and dance numbers inspired by Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. In a nod to Esther Williams, one scene even has the princess and her ladies in waiting performing synchronized swimming. All of which goes to prove that Shakespeare can survive anything.

A picture caption last Thursday with an Arts Abroad article about the Berlin Film Festival misidentified the actor who plays an impostor czar in "Captain's Daughter." He is Vladimir Mashkov, not Sergei Machovecki.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 26; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2214 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AMERICAN BEAUTY," starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin).
 
"THE BEACH," starring Leonardo DiCaprio, Tilda Swinton and Robert Carlyle. Directed by Danny Boyle (R, 120 minutes). Mr. DiCaprio plays Richard, a young American vacationing in Thailand who is given a map that leads him to an island paradise. All of Mr. DiCaprio's charisma and the director's savvy are used to divert us from the fact that there's not much going on here. While Mr. DiCaprio shows some talent, the movie is simply a Colors by Benetton take on "Lord of the Flies," with the imperious paradise ruler (Ms. Swinton) holding court as the Promised Land crashes around her. Richard finds himself living the aphorism that has ruined the life of so many film protagonists: paradise breeds callousness, a marginal rethinking of beware of the things you want, for you shall have them (Elvis Mitchell). 
 
* "BOYS DON'T CRY," starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of last year's best (Maslin).
 
* "THE CIDER HOUSE RULES," starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 1940's "David Copperfield" (Stephen Holden).
 
"EYE OF THE BEHOLDER," starring Ewan McGregor and Ashley Judd. Directed by Stephan Elliott (R, 105 minutes). Mr. McGregor is a British surveillance expert and Ms. Judd the serial-killing femme fatale he falls in love with (while observing her kill a boyfriend) in this ludicrous psycho-thriller. As Mr. McGregor's character, known only as the Eye, follows the object of his obsession from city to city, the movie tries futilely to capture some of the mystique of "Vertigo." But the film, by the director best known for "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert," is so garish, disjointed and incoherent that it feels like an extended music video posing as a movie (Holden).
 
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The millennial version of Disney's 1940 groundbreaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite), in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Celebrity introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street (Holden).
 
 "GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by James Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a college-age girl who lands in a Massachusetts mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir.) The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms. Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this long film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectedly good that it's redundant to say so (Maslin).
 
* "GUN SHY," starring Liam Neeson, Oliver Platt, Jose Zuniga and Sandra Bullock. Written and directed by Eric Blakeney (R, 102 minutes). Last spring saw both a film comedy ("Analyze This") and a cable series ("The Sopranos") about gangsters forcing themselves to unload to a shrink. This year, in "Gun Shy," we get a shaken undercover fed, Charlie Mayo (Mr. Neeson), seeing a psychiatrist on the down-low. Charlie, a wreck who has lost his nerve after he was exposed during an undercover operation, is assigned to a job that involves his acting as an organized-crime envoy. He moves between the preening Fidel (Mr. Zuniga), a yuppie Colombian thug, and Fulvio (Mr. Platt), whose vulgar pride in his violent streak is perverse. Mr. Blakeney has come up with one of the subtlest and most inspired comedies you'll see this year in his feature-film writing and directing debut (Mitchell).
 
"HOLY SMOKE," starring Kate Winslet and Harvey Keitel. Directed by Jane Campion (R, 95 minutes). Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in "Hideous Kinky," Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth Barron, a headstrong young Australian seeking enlightenment. Eventually Ruth's mother coaxes her home, where a "cult exiter" named P. J. (Mr. Keitel) is waiting to wean Ruth from her Indian guru. But as the film moves from its early mix of rapture and humor into this more serious, confrontational stage, it runs into trouble. It doesn't help that Ms. Winslet's obvious strength and beauty leave Mr. Keitel's P. J. looking overmatched (Maslin).
 
* "THE HURRICANE," starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Hurricane Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic co-defendant, John Artis, from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).
 
* "SCREAM 3," starring David Arquette, Neve Campbell and Courteney Cox Arquette. Directed by Wes Craven (R, 116 minutes). At this point it goes without saying that the "Scream" movies are like episodes of "Scooby Doo." Like the others, "Scream 3" belongs on the Cartoon Network. This time for a better reason: the film is funny and brisk, with enough good lines to make the comedy more satisfying than the somewhat routine but still unsettling jolts to the spine. Mr. Craven and his group recognize that the franchise's real competition is not the recent hit films "The Blair Witch Project" or "The Sixth Sense" but rather "Scream" itself. "Scream 3" doesn't skimp on jacked-up scares, but it's as much a personality show as it is a slasher film (Mitchell).
 
* "THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY," starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of "The English Patient" was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia High smith's fascinatingly reptilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role, the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by John Seale (Maslin).
 
* "TITUS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in "The Lion King" and "Juan Darien," has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and American film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymor's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).
 
* "TOPSY-TURVY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvy" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
KURT WEILL FILM FESTIVAL. In celebration of the Kurt Weill centenary and in conjunction with a rare staging of his "Eternal Road" later this month at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Howard Gilman Opera House, a Kurt Weill Film Festival is in progress at the BAM Rose Cinemas, at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in Fort Greene. Today's attraction, at 4:30, 7 and 9:30 p.m., is the 1945 Gregory Ratoff film "Where Do We Go From Here?," with music by Ira Gershwin and Weill and a story about a writer taken by a genie on a journey through American history. The stars include Fred MacMurray, June Haver and Joan Leslie. Tomorrow's attraction, at 2, 4:30, 7 and 9:30 p.m., is "The Threepenny Opera" (1931). George Wilhelm Pabst's adaptation of the Bertolt Brecht-Weill musical set in 19th-century London stars Rudolph Forster and Lotte Lenya. The series ends on Sunday, with screenings at 2, 4:30, 7 and 9:30 p.m. for a new print of Fritz Lang's "You and Me" (1938), with a score by Weill and a story about an ex-con unaware that the woman he marries once also served time. The stars are George Raft and Sylvia Sidney. Admission to the film festival is $8.50 for adults and $5 for people over 62, children under 12 and students with valid identification. Information: (718) 623-2770 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 53; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Texas-Style Bashing: Double-Teaming 'Dubya'

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

SHRUB
The Short but Happy
Political Life of George W. Bush
By Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose
179 pages. Random House. $19.95.
"Shrub," the title of this new book about George W. Bush, says it all: the dismissive nickname, first coined by former Gov. Ann Richards of Texas, is a tip-off that this isn't going to be a nonpartisan assessment of this Republican presidential candidate; it's going to a sassy, sarcastic indictment of Mr. Bush and his policies. In fact the book reads like a long, editorial rant against Mr. Bush's political record, a rant that's sometimes persuasive, sometimes unfair, if almost always entertaining.
Molly Ivins, a columnist for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, and Lou Dubose, editor of The Texas Observer, make no secret of their liberal bias in the pages of this book. "The dirty secret of Texas government," they write, "is that we keep our 'low tax, low services' tradition going by cheating the poor." 
 They depict Mr. Bush as a "wholly owned subsidiary of corporate America": "We don't think this is a consequence of political calculation; it is more a consequence of his life experience, political thinking and party affiliation. We can find no evidence that it has ever occurred to him to question whether it is wise to do what big business wants. He is perfectly comfortable, perfectly at home, doing the bidding of big bidness."
Using the legwork of other reporters from both the national and Texas press as a springboard for their commentary, Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose argue that as a candidate Mr. Bush benefited, at crucial points in his career, from family influence and the largess of corporate interests. They observe that most of the money for his failed oil business ventures was raised during the years when his father "was either running for president or serving as Ronald Reagan's vice president," and contend that he sold his stock in one of those companies shortly "before news of the company's precarious health was made public." He "walked away from the whole mess," they coyly add, "with more money than Bill Clinton ever dreamed of making on a little real-estate deal now known as Whitewater."
As for Mr. Bush's foray into baseball, which enabled him to turn a $600,000 investment in the Texas Rangers into a $15 million profit, Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose write that "the team increased its book value from $83 million to $138 million by convincing the city of Arlington there would be no more baseball unless local taxpayers sprang for a new stadium." In short, they observe, this anti-tax politician personally benefited when residents of Arlington, worried about losing their franchise to another city, voted "to add a half-cent to one of the highest sales taxes in the nation in order to raise the $191 million needed to build the Ballpark at Arlington."
It is the view of Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose that George W. Bush -- or "Dubya," as they call him -- has successfully straddled "the divide between the Christian right and the economic conservatives in the Republican Party" by giving the members of the Christian right "just enough to keep them in line."
"He talks the talk but rarely walks the walk," they write, and still gets the support of the Christian right because it wants to be on the side of a winner. These observations, needless to say, went to press before Mr. Bush's loss to John McCain in the New Hampshire primary, a loss that has not only put Dubya's front-runner status in question but has also heightened his tilt toward his party's right wing.
In any case, Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose argue, Dubya's real concerns have less to do with "God, guns and gays" than with the issues "dearest to the business community," namely "tort reform, lax regulation of industrial polluters, tax cuts for the oil and gas industry, electricity rates that place the interests of industry far above the interests of consumers, and privatizing welfare for huge profit." Taking care of business, they argue, is Dubya's No. 1 priority, a position that has had particularly serious consequences, they contend, in the area of environmental protection.
As governor of "the state with the highest volume of air pollution in the nation," Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose write, Mr. Bush "accommodated the state's biggest polluters" by implementing a program of "voluntary compliance." The companies that helped to design that voluntary program, they add, showed their support for Mr. Bush by contributing $260,648 to his 1998 gubernatorial campaign, and $243,900 to his presidential campaign within a month of the opening of his exploratory committee.
They argue that even more financial support (as much as $4.5 million by one estimate) has come to Mr. Bush from business, medical and real estate groups intent on promoting tort reform that would help insulate "corporate interests from lawsuits filed by consumers, workers, injured parties and the survivors of those killed through malice or negligence."
In depicting Mr. Bush as a friend of big business, who is "blind to the difficulties of life in the nation's underclass," Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose rely upon a blend of sarcasm and down-home Texas invective to make their points. Though this makes for a highly readable narrative, it can also backfire on the authors when they overstate their points. In discussing Mr. Bush's reported distaste for reading policy books, for instance, it seems quite gratuitous to add that "people who have read only one book can be quite dangerous -- witness Timothy McVeigh and all those poor citizens who read Ayn Rand and are stuck like Saul of Tarsus on the road to Damascus."
The one area in which Ms. Ivins and Mr. Dubose give Mr. Bush high points is education, writing that "he has been attentive, consistent, and a hard worker to make public schools a higher priority for the state." But they add that the weakness of the Texas governorship -- the office, they write, ranks "behind lieutenant governor, attorney general, comptroller and land commissioner" in terms of actual power -- means that "it is impossible to give him the lion's share of the credit for any single initiative -- too much of the heavy lifting has been done by others."
For that matter, they argue, Mr. Bush's record as governor indicates that "he doesn't know much, doesn't do much, and doesn't care much about governing." So much so, they conclude, that "it's kind of hard to figure out why he wants a job where he's expected to govern."

SECTION: Section C; Page 8; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 347 words

HEADLINE: Producer Price Index Is Flat As Cost of Cigarettes Drops

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers were unchanged in January as the cost of cigarettes unexpectedly fell, the government reported today. Other prices were tame, a sign inflation is being kept in check.
The Labor Department's Producer Price Index held at the same level last month as in December, when it had risen 0.1 percent. The core index, which excludes food and energy, fell 0.2 percent after growing 0.1 percent in the prior month. 
 "There is still no general inflation problem in the U.S.," said Christopher Low, chief economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
The producer index was held down by a 4.9 percent drop in wholesale cigarette prices. The data was collected before midmonth price increases of 13 cents a pack by Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds Holdings, the two largest United States cigarette makers, a Labor Department spokeswoman said.
Because of different survey methods, those increases could be reflected in the Consumer Price Index for January, which the department issues Friday. Today's report also did not pick up an increase in the federal tax on cigarettes.
Excluding cigarettes, the overall index would have risen 0.2 percent and the core rate would have increased 0.1 percent.
The Labor Department, in annual revisions this week, had lowered the December increase from 0.3 percent. The core rate for December was left unchanged.
Even with tame inflation, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told the House Banking Committee today that interest rates would have to rise further to prevent the economy from overheating. He expressed concern that consumer spending was growing at a faster pace than incomes.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported today that regional manufacturing expanded at a faster pace in February and that its index of prices paid by regional manufacturers was close to a five-year high. The general economic index rose to 13.3 this month from 9.1 in January. The prices-paid index leaped to 40 from 29.9, for the highest reading since 42.5 in March 1995.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Twilight Of Turboprops?;
Passengers Go Out of Their Way To Catch Jets

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
Like many other airline passengers, Michael Gallagher has gone out of his way to avoid flying a turboprop plane. When he attended an Orbital Sciences shareholder meeting a few years ago in Washington, for example, he changed his schedule at the last minute to fly on a jet.
"I have always been a nervous flyer," said Mr. Gallagher, who lives in Cortland, N.Y. "On a turboprop plane, you just get bounced around too much." Mr. Gallagher and others may soon find an easier path to a smoother flight. The battle to attract more passengers from smaller markets has become so intense that airlines are now scrambling to replace their turboprop planes with jets. 
 Within the next three years, Continental Airlines will spend around $2 billion to supplant all its turboprops with regional jets: twin-engine planes carrying up to 70 passengers. Delta Air Lines will pay $4 billion for 200 regional jets and start service to 100 cities.
Virtually every major airline is stocking its fleet with regional jets. According to estimates by PaineWebber, American, Continental, United and Northwest Airlines will more than double the number of regional jets operated by their feeder airlines in the next three years, giving passengers in smaller markets more flight choices than ever.
The orders are going primarily to the two big makers of regional jets, Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embraer, of Brazil and Bombardier of Montreal.
Though the average regional jet costs $20 million, nearly double the price of a comparable turboprop, the airlines feel the switch is well worth it. "Turboprop planes are not an attractive product," said Leo F. Mullin, chief executive of Delta. "Passengers view them as second-rate service. With a regional jet, passengers are more comfortable, and we can use them to serve more markets."
An informal survey by Delta recently found that its passengers hate turboprops so much that most are willing to drive two to five hours to avoid flying in them. Most major carriers depend heavily on their regional fleets for feeder traffic -- passengers from a smaller market who connect to the major carrier at a hub airport. American Airlines, a unit of AMR, and Delta, for example, each receive about $1 billion in annual revenue from their regional fleets.
There will still be a place for turboprops, primarily on short flights provided by independent regional carriers. At the end of last year, in fact, there were about 1,350 turboprops in use compared with about 410 regional jets, according to the Regional Airline Association.
The switch to regional jets should, however, significantly increase the major airlines' sales in smaller and midsize markets.
Turboprops have a flight span of only 500 miles, about half that of regional jets, which can serve markets that had been beyond a turboprop's reach. They are also cheaper to operate on longer routes. And they are expected to attract passengers close to small airports who have been reluctant to fly primarily because of a fear of turboprops.
"The important thing about regional jets is not that they are more cost efficient than turboprops," said Samuel Buttrick, an airlines analyst with PaineWebber. "The airlines expect to get more revenue from regional jets by selling more seats in what is a preferred product."
The major carriers also hope to swap larger jets with regional jets on flights that do not sell out. But that is not likely to become a common practice anytime soon.
The Airline Pilots Association, which covers most major carriers in the United States and Canada, is so fearful that regional jets could take work away from its members that most labor contracts with the airlines restrict how many such aircraft an airline can own as well as the number of seats on each plane. After receiving its shipments for 26 new regional jets next year, for instance, United Airlines, a unit of UAL, will not be able to buy another without permission from its pilots.
Assuming that the pilots' resistance and other barriers could be overcome, the airlines would like to develop "on-demand dispatch," industry code for a last-minute equipment swap. If a flight from La Guardia to Chicago on a Boeing 737 was, say, only a quarter full, the airline could substitute a regional jet. Such a swap, of course, is likely to irritate passengers.
Airline executives are confident, however, that regional jets will become popular alternatives to their propellered predecessors, though there is less consensus on what constitutes a regional jet. Most industry executives agree that its flight span is 1,000 miles or less, but they are less clear on the number of seats the plane can contain. Some said regional jets could have as many as 100 seats, while others deferred to their pilots' contracts, many of which dictate no more than 70.
"The definition of a regional jet can get fuzzy," said Tom Bacon, a senior vice president at American Eagle, the regional carrier of American Airlines. "But we're beginning to think of regional jets in terms of the new service with the cities that we can connect."
The number of passengers on regional jets has begun to surge, increasing 20 percent in the first nine months of 1999 over the corresponding period a year earlier, according to the Regional Airline Association. The number of seats available increased 18.2 percent, while the length of the average trip rose 9.1 percent.
"Passengers have clearly decided that they do not want to fly on turboprop planes," said Susan Donofrio of Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "But the regional jets offer other advantages. The airlines can make sure that they have quality feeder service. When passengers start a trip, they are more likely to stay on that airline to make connections."
In the scramble to gain more passengers from smaller cities, the regional jet is fast becoming the airlines' most effective weapon.
Airline executives have known for decades that passengers avoided turboprops like the flu, but used them anyway, in part because second-tier cities were not important enough for the $20 million capital investment required to buy a new regional jet.
In the last decade, however, markets that were once shunned as too small have grown rapidly. And executives from these smaller markets had the same turboprop complaints as their big-city counterparts.
"There is the perception among some passengers that turboprops are not safe," said Glen Hauenstein, a vice president at Continental. "Turboprops vibrate and the passengers can see the propellers. "
(The rate of accidents involving turboprops in 1996, the latest year data are available, was small, only 3.62 for every 100,000 miles flown, but more than twice the accident rate of turbojets, according to the National Transportation Safety Board.)
Regional jets can also fly farther, faster and more smoothly than turboprops. But even more important for attracting passengers from smaller cities is that the airlines can use them to create more nonstop flights. Executives, who buy only 20 percent of the airlines' tickets but account for about half of the industry profits, avoid multistop flights as much as they shun turboprops.
An example of the scuffling over smaller markets has been playing out in Greenville-Spartanburg, an area of two counties with about 650,000 people in the South Carolina foothills. Years ago, Spartanburg was known primarily as the hometown of Claudia Turner-Wells, the first runner-up in the 1970 Miss America Pageant, and the textile mogul Roger Milliken.
But in the last 10 years, the area has become a manufacturing mecca, where Michelin, the tire maker, is planning a big expansion and where roadsters are built for BMW.
The area was served primarily by Delta, through its hub in Atlanta, until Continental began nonstop Continental Express service to Newark from Greenville a few years ago and then between Greenville and Houston. The combination of more flights from the Northeast and an opening to the West lured many passengers away from Delta. Within a year, Delta's share of the Greenville-Spartanburg market plunged from 84 percent to 23 percent.
Delta has not taken its massacre in Greenville-Spartanburg lightly.
Through its regional fleet, Delta Connection, it has begun a push to expand its presence in smaller markets. After spending $2.6 billion last year to buy two of its regional carriers -- Comair and Atlantic Southeast Airlines -- Delta recently replaced American Eagle as the nation's largest regional carrier, according to the Regional Airline Association.
By the end of this year, Delta Connection will own more regional jets than any other airline. And it is wasting no time deploying them. The airline recently started service between Worcester, Mass., and nine cities, including Denver, Atlanta and Myrtle Beach, S.C. Within the next two months, it will start regional jet service with daily flights from La Guardia to six cities, including Richmond and Savannah, Ga.
"What happens with a regional jet is that you can give some smaller cities big-market access," said Frederick W. Reid, Delta's chief marketing officer. "The next step in our expansion will be to start connecting some of the smaller cities with each other."
The connections are some of the least expensive deals the airlines have been able to make. Because they are very fuel efficient once they reach cruising altitude, regional jets cost only 10 cents an air mile on longer routes, those that are 500 to 1,000 miles long, compared with 19 cents for turboprops. (Turboprops are, however, a lot less expensive to operate on shorter hops.)
When replacing larger jets, regional jets can also save money at the gate. Delta said it could park three regional jets in the space that it uses to park, say, a 737. Analysts estimate that could reduce gate fees by some 10 percent a year.
Delta recently made such a swap on its routes between Atlanta and Grand Rapids, Mich., after too many seats on the 737's were left unfilled. To draw more people, Delta added three daily flights.
Given the advantages of regional jets, airline executives may soon be more irked that they cannot deploy more. But they are not likely to press the issue too hard, at least for now, with the airline pilots unions.
In any case, the love affair with regional jets is not shared by some passengers.
"I don't fly turboprops or regional jets," said Paul Tauger, a lawyer in Costa Mesa, Calif. "I took a regional jet from Fort Lauderdale to Dallas, and the luggage compartment was not big enough for my carry-on bag. After that, with airplanes, I don't downsize anymore."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Greenspan Remarks at Congressional Hearing

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, presented his semiannual report on the economy to the House Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts from his testimony and an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and the chairman of the committee, in a question-and-answer session that followed the testimony, as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription agency:
There is little evidence that the American economy, which grew more than 4 percent in 1999 and surged forward at an even faster pace in the second half of the year, is slowing appreciably. At the same time, inflation has remained largely contained. . . . 
 Underlying this performance, unprecedented in my half-century of observing the American economy, is a continuing acceleration in productivity. . . . Yet those profoundly beneficial forces driving the American economy to competitive excellence are also engendering a set of imbalances that unless contained threaten our continuing prosperity. Accelerating productivity entails a matching acceleration in the potential output of goods and services and a corresponding rise in real incomes available to purchase the new output. The problem is that the pickup in productivity tends to create even greater increases in aggregate demand than in potential aggregate supply. This occurs principally because a rise in structural productivity growth has its counterpart in higher expectations for long-term corporate earnings. This, in turn, not only spurs business investment but also increases stock prices and the market value of assets held by households, creating additional purchasing power for which no additional goods or services have yet been produced. . . .
Imbalances in the labor markets perhaps may have even more serious implications for inflation pressures. While the pool of officially unemployed and those otherwise willing to work may continue to shrink, as it has persistently over the past seven years, there is an effective limit to new hiring, unless immigration is uncapped. At some point in the continuous reduction in the number of available workers willing to take jobs, short of the repeal of the law of supply and demand, wage increases must rise above even impressive gains in productivity. This would intensify inflationary pressures or squeeze profit margins, with either outcome capable of bringing our growing prosperity to an end. . . .
The recent good news on the budget suggests that our longer-run prospects for continuing this beneficial process of recycling savings from the public to the private sectors have improved greatly in recent years. Nonetheless, budget outlays are expected to come under mounting pressure as the baby boom generation moves into retirement, a process that gets under way a decade from now. Maintaining the surpluses and using them to repay debt over coming years will continue to be an important way the federal government can encourage productivity-enhancing investment and rising standards of living. Thus, we cannot afford to be lulled into letting down our guard on budgetary matters, an issue to which I shall return later in this testimony. . . .
However, to date, interest-sensitive spending has remained robust, and the F.O.M.C. Federal Open Market Committee will have to stay alert for signs that real interest rates have not yet risen enough to bring the growth of demand into line with that of potential supply, even should the acceleration of productivity continue. Achieving that alignment seems more pressing today than it did earlier, before the effects of imbalances began to cumulate, lessening the depth of our various buffers against inflationary pressures.
MR. LEACH: If I could turn to another subject, oil is on the minds of many people, with the price of oil going above $30 a barrel. And you've indicated that in a percentage basis, some of that was factored into the last half of last year's inflation index. Are you concerned that another oil shock could have deterring effects on our economy?
MR. GREENSPAN: Mr. Chairman, I've been through too many oil shocks to take them unseriously, even if the evidence does fairly conclusively indicate that the proportion of both the American economy, and indeed the rest of the world, that is dependent on oil for energy sources, is declining and has declined very measurably.
The problem that I think we have is that even in its reduced status, it is a very important element within an industrial system. And if the price changes fairly rapidly, it has a major impact on the structure of our economy. I think we're all acutely aware that the inventory levels of oil, both crude and products, in the United States has been driven down very substantially, well below normal. Indeed, some are joking that we need to measure the fumes to get any measurable inventory at all these days.
And what we know about very low inventories of any commodity is that if an untoward pressure, an unexpected pressure of demand, surges there is no buffer. And the result is a very substantial spike in prices with fairly substantial negative consequences to the economy.
I don't forecast that; I merely recognize that the inventory levels worldwide -- the so-called commercial stocks, which is those stocks available as a buffer to unexpected demands -- are exceptionally low. And even though we are moving into a period when the normal pressures begin to ease, we're starting from a very low base. And the simple answer to your question is, yes, I am concerned about what's happening to oil prices. . . .

HEADLINE: Web Access Panacea

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "World Bank Unit to Join in Internet Start-Up Finance" (Business Day, Feb. 14): The claim by James Wolfenson, the World Bank president, that the lack of Internet access is "one of the greatest impediments to development" trivializes the complex and enduring problems in developing countries. 
 The first world has tried to "develop" the third world since the 1960's, with little success. Problems of tribal warfare, exploitation and corruption and lack of educational opportunities vastly outweigh the new problem of the digital divide.
In Pessare, the village in Togo where I lived for two years, people farm by hand. There is no electricity or running water. The junior high school has only one book, a dictionary. How would Internet access help?
 
KATHERINE MELCHER
Baton Rouge, La., Feb. 16, 2000

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS;
Nasdaq Surges as Dow Drops After Greenspan Comments

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Shrugging off the ever-more-likely prospect of additional interest rate increases this spring, technology stocks powered the Nasdaq market to a new record yesterday as turnover surged past two billion shares for the first time.
The Nasdaq composite index jumped 121.27 points, or 2.74 percent, to 4,548.92. 
 Other stocks, however, particularly those of the so-called Old Economy, languished once again. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 46.84 points, or 0.44 percent, to 10,514.57, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index barely managed to stay in positive territory, rising 0.59, or 0.04 percent, to 1,388.26.
The latest government report of minimal inflation spurred a general early rally, but Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, soon dampened sentiment with an unusually direct warning that higher rates would be needed to slow an overheated economy.
"For once, I thought I understood what he was saying -- that he will continue to increase interest rates until job creation slows," said Robert Bloom, president of Friends, Ivory & Sime, an investment management company. As a result, Mr. Bloom added, stocks are now on the defensive and 2000 is "a year to try to preserve gains."
The blue-chip index, which had been up more than 110 points, swung to a loss of nearly 107 points at midday and then clawed back part way in the afternoon.
Wal-Mart Stores and other retailers were once again prominent casualties; the discounter dropped 3 15/16 , to 48 15/16 , 30 percent below its Dec. 31 peak. Gap lost 6 7/8, to 42 1/8, and American Eagle Outfitters 4 15/16 , to 20 15/16 .
Financial stocks were also weak, especially American Express, which sank 5 29/32 , to 147 15/16 . Bank of New York, at the center of a money laundering case, fell 2 7/16 , to 35 1/16 .
But technology, both in the Nasdaq and the small-cap Russell 2000 -- the latter up 1.95 percent, to a second consecutive record -- was largely untouched by concern over rising rates.
Microsoft, which introduced Windows 2000, climbed 2, to 99 5/8; Intel, 2 13/16 , to 110; Qualcomm 8 1/8, to 130; Cisco Systems 3 21/64 , to 130 1/2; Juniper Networks 20 3/4, to 241 1/4; and eBay 4 9/16 , to 145 1/4.
DoubleClick, though, skidded a second day as the online advertising company faced a federal investigation into its collection of data on Internet users. The shares fell 15 3/4, to 90 3/4.
Cablevision Systems, the cable TV operator in the New York City area, fell 2 5/8, to 68 3/8, after reporting a widened fourth-quarter loss.
Rite Aid, facing a fraud investigation, fell 5/16 , to 6 5/8, down from more than 45 a year ago.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	Treasury Prices Mixed
By Bloomberg News
Treasury prices were mixed after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the Fed would keep raising interest rates as long as the economy showed no sign of slowing.
"We're apprehensive of rising inflation and interest rates," said Randy Bateman, who helps manage $1 billion for SunTrust Private Capital Group in Orlando, Fla.F
Two- and five-year Treasuries led the decline, with two-year yields rising to 6.67 percent, and five-year yields rising to 6.74 percent.
The 30-year bond rose 17/32 , to a price of 1007/16 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.22 percent from 6.26 percent on Wednesday. Two-year yields are now 45-hundredths of a percentage point above their longer-term counterparts -- the biggest gap since 1989.

HEADLINE: Schwarz Sues Chief for Move To Toys 'R'Us

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
In what amounts to a grown-up toy war, F.A.O. Schwarz is suing John Eyler, its former chairman and chief executive, for jumping to the rival Toys "R" Us last month. The complaint says Mr. Eyler violated the terms of his employment contract, which required him to provide a year's notice before any departure and barred him from working for a competitor for two years.
The suit, filed on Jan. 26 in state Supreme Court in Manhattan by Schwarz and its parent company, Vendex KBB of the Netherlands, also faults Mr. Eyler for walking away with $2.4 million that, it contends, was paid in essence to keep him around. Mr. Eyler, 52, who became the top executive of Schwarz in 1992, was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment. Schwarz is seeking a preliminary injunction to prevent him from working at Toys "R" Us. A hearing has been scheduled for Wednesday. 
 A Toys "R" Us spokeswoman denied wrongdoing by the company and on behalf of Mr. Eyler. "We firmly believe the case has no merit whatsoever, and we will, of course, vigorously defend the matter," the spokeswoman, Rebecca Caruso said. Janis Meyer, a lawyer with Dewey Ballantine, which is representing Schwarz and Vendex, said her clients declined to comment.
Among the interesting details in the court papers is that Toys "R" Us and Schwarz held merger talks last year. The suit names Toys "R" Us, of Paramus, N.J., as a co-defendant and says it violated an agreement reached last June not to solicit or hire any Schwarz officers or senior employees for two years. At the time, Toys "R" Us was negotiating a possible purchase of the chain or an Internet partnership. Though no deal resulted, Toys "R" Us agreed not to court Schwarz employees for two years, according to the complaint.
While the toy sellers engage in their own wrestling over how far an employment contract can go, companies of all types are using "noncompete" and other restrictive employment contracts. And increasingly, in a vigorous economy and a tight labor market, companies are taking a tough stance on these agreements.
"I assume there might be more impetus, as a practical matter, to keep people on the reservation if they are harder to replace," said Don Collins, a New York University Law School professor. "I don't think that matters to the court much."
For some companies, the goal is to send a message to executives considering jumping ship. Other employers are seeking to prevent executives' expertise from benefiting a competitor for as long as possible. "The theory of it is to starve you into submission," Mr. Collins said.
The enforcement of such contracts varies greatly by state, with spurned companies finding their cases stronger if they can show harm or the loss of confidential company information.
In the toy case, Schwarz contends that Mr. Eyler's move gives Toys "R" Us an unfair competitive edge because he departed with knowledge of trade secrets and other confidential information.
The big payment that Mr. Eyler received in January was intended as a "golden parachute," should he leave after a change of control at Schwarz. Vendex merged with the toy seller's former owner in November 1998. Under his contract, he was entitled to $2.4 million if he left within 12 to 18 months of that change, the suit says.
Because of the potentially rich severance package, Mr. Eyler expressed "serious concern" to Vendex that he would have no choice but to leave to collect it, according to the court filing. Eager to keep him, the company agreed to give him the money by the end of 1999 to negotiate a new employment contract.
Toys "R" Us hired Mr. Eyler to help revive its business after five months without a chief executive. The company said at the time that it had hired Mr. Eyler for his "passion and energy for the toy business" as well as his experience in electronic commerce and catalog businesses.

HEADLINE: Technology Investors Tune Out Greenspan

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
When Alan Greenspan speaks, the Old Economy trembles. But the new one thinks it is impervious to higher interest rates, and shrugs off warnings from the Federal Reserve chairman.
That has been the pattern since the Fed began to raise interest rates last summer, and it continued yesterday. Mr. Greenspan's stark warnings that short-term interest rates would continue to rise had only a brief effect on the Nasdaq composite index, which is dominated by high-technology companies that are benefiting from the digital revolution. 
 That index then shot up 121.27 points, or 2.7 percent, to a new high of 4,548.92, as the Nasdaq market traded two billion shares for the first time. The index is up 69 percent since June 30, the date of the first of the Fed's four rate increases.
But the story was different for the Dow Jones industrial average, which is far more dependent on stocks that are liable to be hurt as higher interest rates slow the economy.
It fell 100 points within minutes after the Fed chairman began testifying; while it recovered some of that, it ended down 46.84 points, or almost half a percentage point, at 10,514.57. It is down about 4 percent since June 30.
The consensus reaction on Wall Street seemed to be that little was new in the chairman's testimony. "Maybe he's raised his own estimate" of how high interest rates have to go to slow the economy, said Robert DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney. "But he didn't say we needed to get there faster."
For some time the fixed-income markets have been expecting at least two more increases in short-term rates by the Fed, with the first one, of at least a quarter percentage point, expected next month.
"The chairman's comments did not trigger any massive re-evaluation of where the Fed is going," said Louis Crandall, the chief economist of Wrightson Associates, a bond market research firm. "If anything, it may have made people a little more nervous" that the next increase might be a half percentage point, rather than the quarter-point raise seen in the previous increases.
Short-term interest rates rose moderately yesterday, though it is unclear how much of that was caused by Mr. Greenspan's remarks and how much by other factors, including a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia that indicated rising price pressures for manufacturing companies.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan noted the willingness of many stock investors to shrug off the risk of higher interest rates.
"To date, rising business earnings expectations and declining compensation for risk have more than offset" the effect of higher rates, he said. But he forecast that, at some point, rates would rise enough to have an effect on the expectations of stock market investors.
"Greenspan seems dead-set on taking the punch bowl from the party," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief equity strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The market is understanding that interest rates will continue to head higher."
Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, agreed. Mr. Greenspan, he said, "is committed to ending, for a time, outsized gains for the equity market."
Stocks, though, do not stop going up just because interest rates rise. They stop going up because investors stop bidding them up. So far, it appears, higher interest rates have alarmed investors in many industries. General Electric, Coca-Cola and Citigroup were among the Dow stocks that fell at least $1 yesterday.
But those losses were partly offset by gains in Microsoft, Intel and I.B.M. Technology stock investors are not worried about higher interest rates, and yesterday's forceful testimony from Mr. Greenspan did not change that.
