HEADLINE: Iran Election Today a Referendum on Reform

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran, Feb. 17

 BODY:
At the age of 19, Abdi Manoumshah found himself at the epicenter of revolution. An Iranian Army officer, he was on guard duty outside the United States Embassy in the fall of 1979 when student firebrands seized what they called the "nest of spies" and took American diplomats hostage. Loyal to the new Islamic Republic, he stepped aside.
In the years since, he has fought in the war with Iraq, abandoned a law practice because it could not provide for his family, and tried to sustain the hopes kindled in those heady days when the powerful were humbled by the powerless. 
 "I thought the revolution would change things, but in a different direction, not where we have ended up," said Mr. Manoumshah, a pensive man of 40 who runs a tiny three-table restaurant shop near Tehran's central bazaar. "We wanted freedom to think and act as we liked. That is very much what people are asking for now."
The parliamentary elections on Friday have emerged as a referendum to define just whose ideals were at the heart of the Iranian revolution 21 years ago. The vote has become, as well, a popularity poll for President Mohammad Khatami, the reformist theologian who was swept into office in 1997 but has yet to realize much of his liberal social agenda or achieve his stated goal of improved relations with the United States.
For Iranians like Mr. Manoumshah, who is a Khatami supporter, the election for the Parliament, or Majlis, is a way to release the religious monopoly's brakes on everything from a free-market economy to a free press. "If the president has the Majlis behind him, nothing can stop him," he said. "And if he can achieve just 50 percent of what he has talked about, he will be a great success."
But the Old Guard that has resisted all reconciliation with the West and Western culture remains a powerful force. It lost the presidential election two and a half years ago, but has not lost power -- yet.
Mr. Khatami's promises to open Iranian society have already alarmed those right-wing forces, which include elements in the security forces blamed for killing several reformers last year, the state-sponsored vigilante groups that attacked student demonstrators last summer and the conservative clerics who have closed down a succession of independent newspapers.
"The election of President Khatami opened a vista, and from that time on, people started to criticize the system more objectively," said Hermezans Vavand, a professor of international relations at Tehran University. "The conservative movement then hardened its positions and reacted with violence toward anyone who was critical.
"But a great number of them are time-servers and opportunistic," he added. "They might end up getting on the bandwagon."
Whichever ideological faction wins control of Parliament, it will face the same mundane problems that have dogged Iran for years. Its economy has not grown fast enough to keep up with its ballooning population growth, with unemployment and poverty rising. Nearly 38 percent of its population is 15 or younger, a group that will also strain the job market. Much of Iran's production, meanwhile, is in the hands of secretive religious foundations that pay minimal taxes.
Mr. Khatami has proposed widespread privatization of industries that were nationalized after the revolution, and he has had some success in pushing his economic plans through Parliament.
"In general the Majlis has been fairly cooperative with him," said Ardavazd Baghoomian, who has served in Parliament for 16 years in one of two seats allotted to the country's 200,000 ethnic Armenians. "But if Khatami had a majority, he might have been able to push through more fundamental changes."
None of the political factions vying for seats in Parliament have talked about an economic plan, either for or against Mr. Khatami's. But the reformers have said they want to open the way for a frank public debate on all matters of public policy.
They have talked of reforming the court system, encouraging the formation of a range of political parties, and openly permitting satellite dishes and other elements of foreign culture that are officially prohibited but widely embraced.
Still, the powers of Parliament are limited, although in many ways untested. It approves and can impeach ministers. It approves the budget and economic policy. But no law is enacted unless it is also affirmed by the 12-member Council of Guardians, experts in Islamic law who have acted as a damper on change.
But a victory for the reformers in Parliament could upset even this venerable institution of the religious right wing. While half of the council's members are appointed by the Supreme Leader, the other six are selected by Parliament itself.
"Reforms will be done slowly, step by step," said Mohammad Reza Khatami, the brother of the president and one of the reform candidates for the Parliament in Tehran. "It's hard to say now in what order they would happen."
The one-week election campaign has skirted some of the more volatile issues that many Iranians avidly discuss in private, particularly the Constitution designed by the revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini that assigns ultimate authority over religious matters, foreign policy, security and much of the judiciary to a nonelected Supreme Leader. The current leader is Ayatollah Ali Khameini, who has condemned liberals, although not the president, as the agents of evil foreign powers.
The campaigns of all factions have dealt with generalities: helping the young, improving the economy, upholding Islam. Many candidates have also tried to capitalize on Mr. Khatami's image as an intellectual and a good-natured man, unlike the stern ayatollahs of the revolution whose pictures adorn buildings all over the country.
The Iranian news agency IRNA reported this week that 12 candidates in the northern city of Meshed were arrested on charges of election fraud because their campaign materials understated their ages.
Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president and Parliament speaker, has also tried to present a kinder face. He sent flyers to more than 2 million households in Tehran that show him bareheaded, without his black clerical turban, lounging in a garden with a little boy. "I will stay with you in winter and deliver you to the spring," the leaflet said.
Even the conservatives have flung around the word "freedom."
"We have no problems with the idea of freedom," said Mohammad Reza Bahonar, a member of the current Parliament and a key strategist for the conservative faction. "Our main slogans during the revolution were independence, freedom and an Islamic republic. After all, God created people as free beings."
Mr. Rafsanjani has become a pivotal figure in the campaign because he has been endorsed by several conservative factions even as the reformers vilify him as a man with no ideals. But for many Iranians he represents stability and a familiar face for a transitional time.
"People are tired of this right-left fight, which is really among the clergy and not relevant to the general public," said Sohrab Alizadeh, who is running a lonely and underfinanced race as an independent environmentalist in Tehran. "But Rafsanjani has been in power since the revolution, so in a way people feel like he has to be kept in the game."
More than 38 million Iranians are eligible to vote, and strategists in several parties have said a high turnout will favor the reform candidates, as it did Mr. Khatami in his presidential race.
The government first announced that the ballots from 36,000 polling stations across the country would be counted by computer, but the clerical body that oversees the elections said this week that they would be counted by hand. The final count may not be known for at least a week.
Some 6,000 people are running for the 290 seats, although the exact number was not known today because hundreds of candidates dropped out during the campaign week. And the day before the campaign began, a council of clerics dropped 777 candidates from the ballot, citing their views on the relationship between religion and government. Still, with so many candidates -- up to 100 for each seat in some districts -- pinpointing their positions based on their backgrounds has been difficult.
Those running as pro-Khatami candidates or making speeches in their support include former government officials forced out for espousing a free press, a film director who hopes that economic reform will revitalize the struggling Iranian cinema, a cleric whose job is to safeguard the writings of the late Ayatollah Khomeini, a post-revolution intelligence chief, a writer who led the student hostage-takers in 1979, and some high-ranking religious figures.
No one exemplifies this jumble of pedigrees better than Zahra Eshraghi, a 37-year-old employee of the Ministry of Interior. She is married to the president's brother and has campaigned with him. She is also the granddaughter of Ayatollah Khomeini, known as the Imam and the virulently anti-Western hero of the revolution and founder of the Islamic Republic.
"What is important is that if the reformers win, there will be a good balance between the Majlis and the Government," Mrs. Eshraghi said. "We have had a Majlis that was very monotone, with all the same kind of people. We should have a Majlis that is in keeping with the times."
She has campaigned for her husband and the reform list of candidates and said her grandfather would approve of her husband's bid, just as he had encouraged her to marry into the Khatami family.
"The government of President Khatami," she said, "is the same as the governments of the period of the Imam. The Imam himself had a high degree of trust for Mr. Khatami."

HEADLINE: Nassau Has Worst Credit Rating in Nation Among Wealthy Suburban Counties

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 17

 BODY:
The downgrading of Nassau County's bond rating to the level just above junk-bond status leaves it with the worst credit rating of any New York State county and makes it the lowest-rated wealthy suburban county in the nation, analysts said today.
When Moody's Investors Service downgraded Nassau's bonds on Wednesday from Baa2 to Baa3, it put the county's bond ratings more in line with those of poor rural counties in Mississippi and Alabama than those of similar rich suburbs. 
 "This is a spanking," the county comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, said of the downgrade. "They are fed up with lip service, and I think they are right."
Now, as the county prepares to sell more than $200 million in bonds at the beginning of next month, it will most likely face significantly steeper costs for insuring its bonds and be forced to offer higher interest to entice buyers to take the risk. Just how much that will cost the struggling county remains to be seen.
"We're not going to have any trouble borrowing, but it makes it more expensive," Mr. Parola said. "That is just more money we'll have to spend on debt service."
Nassau has become a paradox: a county with a well-heeled populace and fat tax rolls that consistently runs up deficits. The 2000 budget is already projected to fall between $120 million and $190 million short.
"From a resource standpoint, it has always been one of the mysteries of the municipal market," said Brad Gewher, the director of the municipal research group at PaineWebber.
As the latest downgrade sent jitters through county government circles, county officials took aim at government waste in the form of county cars.
Democrats on the County Legislature said today that they would work to root out waste in the government by auctioning off one-third of what they counted as the county's 486 cars, which does not include the Police Department's fleet.
Judith A. Jacobs, the presiding officer of the Legislature, said her staff had found that county cars were being used by a mail clerk in the Parks Department, the commissioner of jurors and people in the county's Cultural Development Office, among others.
She noted that even the Legislature gets eight cars. "There's no reason for that," she said.
So the Democrats proposed selling some cars to produce an estimated $1 million, not to mention savings in fuel costs and maintenance.
They also proposed a law that would reduce the fleet by one-third. And they called for every county car not used in undercover operations to be marked with a sticker, to discourage people from using their cars on personal business.
County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, meanwhile, said that he had already told his staff to turn in seven cars that had been deemed unnecessary and that he was evaluating whether or not the county's cars were needed.
A county vehicle should not be a perquisite, he said, adding that he agreed with the Democrats' motivation but questioned whether new laws were needed.
But an auction of county cars, while of symbolic importance, would bring in less than 1 percent of what the county needs to balance its books. Both the county executive and the Democrats in the Legislature have hired consultants to help them come up with recovery plans.
Ms. Jacobs warned that the solution would not come overnight. "It took years to get the county into this mess," she said.
County officials said it was difficult to quantify how much the latest downgrade was likely to cost the county. Peter White, the county's bond counsel, said it would be impossible to guess what it would do to the county's interest or insurance costs. But most analysts said those costs could only rise.
It is a strange situation for any wealthy suburb to find itself in. Even Orange County, Calif., home of one of the best-known fiscal crises in recent memory, has a much better bond rating now than Nassau does.
Unlike other fiscally troubled municipalities, Nassau County has not suffered a significant loss of population, industry or tax base. Rather, analysts say, it has consistently mismanaged its finances with unrealistic budgets in which the revenues do not cover the costs.
In downgrading the county's bond rating, Moody's signaled that it was not impressed with the measures the county had taken so far to cut costs. It singled out the loss of a $60 million land transfer tax that the old, Republican-controlled County Legislature enacted last year to balance the budget but then repealed after losing its majority on the Legislature to the Democrats in November.
And it noted in a statement that "the county faces a difficult political environment within which any plan for financial recovery will have to be formulated."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Hints That Fed Will Increase Rates More
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the economy showed few signs of slowing despite four interest rate increases in eight months, and he warned in unusually direct terms that the central bank would probably raise rates further to avert inflation.
In testimony to the House Banking Committee, he also set what amounted to a speed limit for Wall Street, saying that wringing the risk of inflation out of the economy would require that stock and other asset prices rise no faster than household incomes. Page A1. 

Daft Heads Coke Ahead of Schedule
Douglas N. Daft, left, became chairman and chief executive of Coca-Cola as M. Douglas Ivester moved up his retirement date. Mr. Ivester said in December that he would retire after two years in the company's top job, but agreed at the time to remain until April to smooth the management transition. Mr. Daft quickly took charge, eliminating the need for Mr. Ivester to remain. C9.
 
Nasdaq Breaks Record as Dow Falls
Technology stocks powered the Nasdaq composite index to a record, as investors shrugged off the ever-more-likely prospect of additional interest rate increases this spring. The Nasdaq jumped 121.27 points, or 2.74 percent, to 4,548.92. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 46.84 points, to 10,514.57, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose fractionally, to 1,388.26. C9.
 
Accounting Firm to Separate Units
The accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, which audits and advises many of the world's biggest corporations, announced that it planned to separate its auditing and consulting businesses into at least two free-standing organizations. C8.
 
G.E. Plans Energy Announcement
The Energy Department and General Electric will announce a breakthrough in natural-gas-powered generating plants today that will result in the production of electricity using 5 percent less fuel than current technologies. C10.
 
Waiting for Research on AOL Deal
Almost six weeks after America Online and Time Warner announced their combination, the major securities firms have failed to produce a comprehensive look at the combined company's prospects. Supporters of the merger say the paucity of research is at least part of the reason America Online's stock has lost nearly a third of its value since the combination was announced on Jan. 10, although it was up slightly yesterday. C2.
 
Germany Delays a Tax Measure
A tax proposal aimed at dismantling the cross-shareholdings of corporate Germany will become effective one year later than originally planned, the government said, a move that sent down stock prices of German banks and insurance companies. But economists and political experts said the proposal did not appear to be in any fundamental danger. C4.
 
Chairman of a Czech Bank Resigns
The chairman of the Czech Republic's Komercni Banka has resigned during an investigation into a suspected fraud at the ailing state-controlled bank. C4.
 
Sears to Drop Benetton Apparel
Sears, Roebuck said it would stop sales of Benetton USA apparel and remove the products from its stores because of objections to a Benetton advertising campaign called "We, on Death Row" that features interviews with convicted killers. C2.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
America's Rags-to-Riches Myth

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Americans cling to the conceit that they have unrivaled opportunity to move up and, alas, down the income ladder. This notion, that families that occupy the bottom rungs of the income ladder readily exchange places with those that occupy higher rungs, breeds indifference to the most glaring economic fact of the past quarter-century: widening inequality. The gap in earnings, for example, between college and high school graduates has more than doubled.
Yet in a recent Op-Ed piece in The New York Times, W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm acknowledge that the wealth of poor families has been falling at the same time that the wealth of rich families has been rising, and ask, "So what?" 
 Mr. Cox and Mr. Alm suggest that mobility along the income ladder is serving as an antidote to inequality. But exactly how much mobility is there? According to them, quite a lot. "America isn't a caste society," they say, citing a study by the Federal Reserve that shows that only 5 percent of the poorest 20 percent of people stayed in that lowest income group over a 17-year period. Everyone else moved higher.
But this stunning statistic is stunningly misleading. Prof. Peter Gottschalk of Boston College points out that the Fed study counts teenagers and young adults from upper-income families who work part time while in school as moving upward when they find higher-paying jobs after graduation. This upward mobility of students hardly answers the enduring question: How many grown-ups are trapped in low-paying jobs?
The answer is, a lot. America's conceit is just that -- a conceit.
Mr. Gottschalk and Prof. Sheldon Danziger of the University of Michigan have looked at the plight of children during the 1970's and 80's. They separate children into five groups according to their family's income. About 6 in 10 of the children in the lowest group -- the poorest 20 percent -- in the early 1970's were still in the bottom income group 10 years later. Almost 9 in 10 children in the bottom group remained in the bottom two income groups 10 years later. Neither of these figures budged in the 1980's, providing solid evidence that mobility did not rise over the 20-year period. About 70 percent of poor black children in the early 1970's were still poor a decade later.
The upshot is that few families occupying the low rungs of America's income ladder get rich.
Economists provide no rule for figuring out how much mobility a society needs to counter the impact of any given amount of inequality. But there is indirect evidence that mobility is not high enough in this country to provide an adequate safety valve for those on the bottom rungs. Even if mobility was high enough 30 years ago to justify a so-what attitude toward inequality, it seems improbable that it could be high enough today, given that mobility has remained constant but inequality has reached extreme levels. Another sobering indicator: Mobility is no higher in the United States than in Western Europe, where living standards are comparable and there is only a fraction as much inequality.
Some inequality is essential for capitalism. High incomes are the reward for studying long hours, working hard and investing in risky businesses. But high incomes can result for reasons that have little to do with merit, reflecting rich parents, luck or manipulation of the political process. Inequality driven by such factors can breed social division, anger and a politics of resentment. It also belies the notion that America gives everyone a fair chance.
Economists are in general reluctant to tamper with market-driven incomes. The risk of squashing incentives and innovation can be great. But there is a compelling case for eradicating one virulent form of inequality: poverty. The richest country in the history of the universe tolerates a poverty rate of about 20 percent among its children, and about 35 percent among its black children. No conceit about mobility, real or imagined, can excuse that unconscionable fact.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1471 words

HEADLINE: GREENSPAN WARNS OF ANOTHER RISE IN INTEREST RATES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the powerhouse economy shows few signs of slowing despite four interest rate increases over the last eight months, and he warned in unusually direct terms that the central bank would probably raise rates further to avert a buildup of inflation.
In testimony to the House Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan was also blunter than normal in suggesting that one of his primary targets in raising interest rates was the stock market. 
 For the first time he set out what amounted to a speed limit for Wall Street, saying that wringing the risk of inflation out of the economy would require that the prices of stocks and other assets rise no faster than household incomes.
Last year, household wealth -- a broad measure that captures the persistent gains in most stock prices -- grew twice as fast as income, according to figures often employed by economists at the Fed to gauge the effects of the market on the economy.
Mr. Greenspan did not specify what his arcane equation meant for popular measures of stock prices like the Dow Jones industrial average or the Nasdaq, although he emphasized that it would "not necessarily imply a decline in asset values."
Investors in blue-chip stocks seemed to heed the Fed chairman's warning, sending the Dow industrial average down 46.84 points, to 10,514.57. But investors in technology stocks -- as they have done repeatedly over the last few years -- thumbed their noses at Mr. Greenspan by driving the Nasdaq index up 121.27 points, to 4,548.92, another record.
The Fed next meets to consider monetary policy on March 21, and economists said the tone of Mr. Greenspan's testimony today all but ensured that the central bank would act then to raise its benchmark federal funds target rate by another quarter of a point, to 6 percent. They said additional increases could follow through the spring and into summer if the economy did not slow.
In a nod to the good news the nation has enjoyed now for years, Mr. Greenspan said the current combination of strong growth, low inflation, declining unemployment and improving efficiency among businesses and workers was unprecedented in the half-century he has spent monitoring the economy.
But he stressed that the good times could fall victim to gradually mounting inflation pressures if the Fed did not act to take some steam out of the expansion, which this month became the longest on record at eight years and 11 months. The previous record period of economic growth without a recession lasted through much of the 1960's.
In an appearance that touched on a wide array of topics, Mr. Greenspan brushed aside concerns that the recent turmoil in the bond market was making the Fed's job harder. Yes, he acknowledged, investors had driven down the interest rate on 30-year government bonds at a time when the Fed was trying to use higher interest rates to slow the economy. But the important thing, he said, was that rates paid by private-sector borrowers, especially corporations, had risen substantially. Mortgage rates, too, while not yet significantly slowing home building, have now reached a three and a half year high.
But in the formal report on monetary policy that he submitted to Congress today, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that aspects of the economy were making the central bank's job more complicated. In particular, the report said, the rise in the growth rate of productivity -- the amount that each worker produces per hour -- made the economy so resilient that the scale of interest rate increases needed to bring inflationary growth under control "may have increased substantially."
Mr. Greenspan reiterated his position that the federal budget surplus should be used to reduce the national debt rather than for tax cuts or new spending. And he said he was somewhat worried by the recent sharp rise in oil prices, but advised against selling the government's oil reserves to try to bring the price down, saying such a move would be ineffectual.
But his focus was on the risk that the economy was simply too strong for its own good.
The strains on the economy might soon become evident in the labor market, he said, where a rapidly declining pool of jobless workers could force employers to begin raising wages at a pace that could ignite a widespread and destabilizing rise in prices. The nation is also bumping up against the limit of how much it can afford to import from other countries, he said.
But he traced the underlying problem to the stock market. Buoyant stock prices, he said, were fueling consumer spending and business investment to such a degree that overall demand in the economy was outstripping supply. The only way to resolve that fundamental imbalance, he said in so many words, was to sharply curtail the relentless rise in equity prices.
"There is little evidence that the American economy, which grew more than 4 percent in 1999 and surged forward at an even faster pace in the second half of the year, is slowing appreciably," Mr. Greenspan said at the beginning of his twice-a-year testimony to Congress on monetary policy.
Some of the very factors underpinning the nation's remarkable economic performance -- falling joblessness, accelerating productivity, an improved outlook for corporate earnings -- "are also engendering a set of imbalances that, unless contained, threaten our continuing prosperity," Mr. Greenspan said.
The pressures on the economy have been eased so far by a surge in imports, which have made up for the inability of domestic producers to keep up with demand, and by the willingness of people who had not previously been in the labor force to get a job.
But those "safety valves," he said, could not contain inflationary pressures forever, especially since the rate increases so far have done little to rein in growth.
The Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee "will have to stay alert for signs that real interest rates have not yet risen enough to bring the growth of demand into line with that of potential supply, even should the acceleration of productivity continue," Mr. Greenspan said.
"Achieving that alignment seems more pressing today than it did earlier, before the effects of imbalances began to cumulate, lessening the depths of our various buffers against inflationary pressures," he added.
Part of rebalancing the economy, he said, would be limiting or ending the rise in stock prices.
The remarkable run-up in stock prices over much of the last decade has been tempered or even reversed by some measures over the last six months, though it remains almost as breathtaking as ever by others. Mr. Greenspan made clear that he was not predicting a downturn in the market, emphasizing only that it would be difficult to achieve the kind of moderation he wants to see in the economy without a leveling off of stock prices.
"This does not necessarily imply a decline in asset values, although that, of course, can happen at any time for a number of reasons," he said, "but rather that these values will increase no faster than household incomes."
G. David Orr, an economist at First Union Securities, said, "If that is not targeting the stock market, what is it?"
Mr. Greenspan has long worried aloud about what economists call the "wealth effect," the idea that rising stock prices translate into higher spending levels by consumers. In his testimony today, he said historical evidence suggests that three to four cents of every dollar in additional stock market wealth is reflected in increased purchases by consumers.
The Fed chairman said he tracked the wealth effect by looking at the ratio of household net worth, or wealth, to income. According to data collected by the Fed, net worth was 4.88 times disposable income in 1988. By 1998, net worth was 5.95 times income.
The Fed has not yet released figures for 1999. But economists said wealth last year grew at about 11.3 percent, while income grew about 5.7 percent.
While the Fed's interest rate increases so far do not appear to have slowed demand, the inflation that Mr. Greenspan fears has also been a no-show. Just today, the government's report on prices at the producer level showed that inflation remained tame.
Indeed, the Fed's own forecast, submitted to Congress today as part of the monetary policy report, concludes that consumer prices this year will rise 1.75 percent to 2 percent, compared with 2 percent last year.
The report also forecasts that the economy will expand 3.5 percent to 3.75 percent, down from 4.2 percent last year. That implies that the Fed now believes that the economy has the capacity to grow at better than 3.5 percent a year over the long run without producing inflationary pressures, well above what economists believed possible not that long ago.

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: Country's Time of Plenty Leaves Some States Behind

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo.

 BODY:
The nation's record economic expansion has left most states so flush with tax revenues that lawmakers argue over how to spend a surplus.
Not here. 
 These days, Wyoming's elected officials are debating how large the budget deficit could become and what services might be cut if dramatic new measures -- including taxes -- are not passed to raise revenues.
Did someone say new taxes? That is almost incomprehensible to people in Wyoming, who pay no personal income tax to the state and, overall, a lower percentage of their income in taxes than residents of any other state. That is why many of them live here.
But Wyomingites are not alone confronting difficult choices. While many Americans are growing wealthier and Congress debates how much of the federal surplus should be returned to taxpayers, a handful of states are facing choices that more commonly arise during recessions. Their lawmakers are deciding whether to raise taxes or cut spending because their state economies are not diversified enough to reap the full benefits of the boom.
In Louisiana, unstable oil prices and marginal increases in tax revenues have left the state facing a potential deficit of $540 million for the fiscal year beginning in July, state officials said. Mark Drennen, the commissioner of administration, said spending caps and cuts, including the dismissal of recently hired state employees, could offset much of it.
But a deficit of $275 million left after the cuts, he said, would require new revenue sources, including the possibility of a new business tax, which is supported by Gov. Mike Foster, or a penny increase in the 4 cent per dollar sales tax..
In Tennessee, Gov. Don Sundquist has been fighting for more than a year for tax changes to help cover increased spending in areas like education. After the Legislature rejected his proposals last year, he tried this year with a package that includes a 3.75 percent flat-rate state income tax. He challenged lawmakers to adopt his plan, find other revenue or cut spending by $342 million.
A slow rate of economic growth in Iowa caused by depressed farm prices, nearly full employment, a lack of new industries and an aging population forced Gov. Tom Vilsack to cut $30 million in spending from the current fiscal year budget of $4.5 billion.
"There is not a lot of room for growth if you are not able to add new jobs," said Randy Bauer, the Iowa budget director.
Some of the same factors forced the Kansas Legislature to reduce its current fiscal year budget of $4.45 billion by $65 million. "Actual revenue collection came up short of revenue forecasts, and that is what caused us to go back and reduce the level of spending," said Duane Goossen, the state budget director.
No state faces a more precarious economic situation than Wyoming, the least populated state with just 479,000 people, about the population of Denver. It is one of seven states with no personal income tax levied by the state and one of four with no corporate taxes, major windfalls in other states.
In addition, almost two-thirds of Wyoming is owned by the federal government, which means only a small part of the state budget comes from property taxes. The largest single source of tax revenues is from mining, as much as 60 percent in some years, followed by revenues from sales tax.
But state officials say Wyoming has grown too reliant on global markets for commodities that are found in vast abundance around Wyoming, including natural gas, coal and minerals.
When natural gas prices are booming, for example, Wyoming's budget is stable. The only reason the state is not facing a deficit for the fiscal year beginning July 1 -- after deficit projections of $127 million a year ago and $183 million six months ago -- is a recent surge in coal prices.
Those kinds of gyrations have forced state leaders to cut many programs, like services for the elderly, from the state's $4.1 billion two-year budget. They have also prompted Gov. Jim Geringer, a second-term Republican, to lead efforts to wean the state off the uncertainties of volatile markets.
"He's been out front on this, with the need to do something," said James King, a professor of political science at the University of Wyoming in Laramie.
"He realizes you can't put a Band-Aid on this. But whether he can truly get a long-term solution ... remains to be seen."
Part of Governor Geringer's campaign has been traveling the state, selling "a sense of responsibility" to people who have grown accustomed to low taxes. As he said in his state of the state address this week: "In order to create a long-term solution, we must make some difficult choices."
They may be on the way.
After state lawmakers returned on Monday for the 20-day budget session that is held every other year, House members approved one major revenue-raising measure for introduction as legislation, an extension of the state's 4 percent sales tax, which was scheduled to expire in 2002.
Votes on another proposal, a new tax on services, were held back until Friday to give lawmakers time to generate more support. But a raft of other proposals failed, including ones that would have created a personal income tax and a tax on electricity production and separate measures that would have increased taxes on fuel, cigarettes and property.
Still, in tax-loathing Wyoming, even one new tax is dramatic.
"I'm an optimist," said House Speaker Eli Bebout. "I think we're on the path toward long-term solutions."
Mr. Geringer said the Legislature is "a little bit gun shy" about long-range solutions. But he held out hope, saying it was just a matter of finding mutually agreeable approaches.
But even new taxes might not be enough to keep Wyoming stable in the long run. Other than scenic beauty, recreation and the tax base, Wyoming has few advantages for prospective residents and businesses over neighboring western states. Only one airport in the state, Jackson's, accommodates commercial jets..
Two years ago, a new state agency, the Wyoming Business Council, was formed to attract businesses, but some lawmakers are trying to eliminate its $21 million budget.
Leslie A. Ball, a council board member, says that would be a mistake. A former executive with Macy's who moved from New York to Cheyenne six years ago to become chief executive of a western wear company, he said the council has already landed eight new companies, bringing in 800 new jobs, and has prospects for more.
"There are a lot of obstacles here, but the state is starting to move a little bit," Mr. Ball said. "For the first time in a long time, all the economic categories are moving; I think the state has a fairly positive future."

HEADLINE: The Other Oil Economy;
Barrel Costs $30 but the Benefits Aren't Trickling Down

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Oil may not hold sway over the nation's economy the way it once did, but in places like Houma, La., it still, to a large degree, is the economy. Houma, 50 miles southwest of New Orleans, is a major center for oil drilling and oil field services -- the work of helping oil giants like Exxon Mobil find and produce oil.
So with oil prices surging, these should be boom times, right? Not necessarily. "It's picked up to some degree, but it's definitely not reflecting $30-a-barrel oil," said Robert Bergeron, Houma's mayor, who spent 40 years in the oil business, starting as a roughneck. "You hear more conversations about the positive future than any actual increase" in activity. 
 Even as oil prices hover at the highest levels in nine years, pushed by OPEC production cuts and recovering global economic activity, companies plan only modest production increases.
Worldwide capital spending for exploration and production will rise no more than 10 to 15 percent from last year's depressed levels, according to several predictions.
"This is probably the longest sustained, dramatic upturn in price not followed by a dramatic upturn in investment," said Joseph A. Stanislaw, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a research firm in Cambridge, Mass. "It's a degree of caution that hasn't been seen in the industry before."
The tepid spending means that oil-patch economies that rely on drilling and services, like parts of Louisiana, Texas and Oklahoma, are not getting the lift they normally do when prices rise.
"I probably don't answer any question as much as, 'Gee, with oil prices high, shouldn't we be seeing the economy and oil patch take off?,' " said Timothy Ryan, dean of the University of New Orleans college of business. For us, it's the worst of all worlds. We end up with high crude oil prices, and high gasoline, but we don't get the positive effects that at least some states get from the boost in the economy that generally results from high oil prices."
Oil service stocks also reflect uncertainty about whether big oil companies will greatly increase capital spending soon. After OPEC announced production cuts last March, indexes that track the oil service industry nearly doubled in six months, as fears of cheap, $5-a-barrel oil evaporated. But lately oil service stocks have fluctuated wildly, only recently returning to their September highs, as investors try to figure out just how much the price surge will help. Yesterday, they fell sharply, along with the rest of the market.
There is always a lag between prices beginning to rise and companies committing greater sums to find more oil. But as large producers report their anticipated capital expenditures for this year, with some even disclosing decreases, many analysts and executives say the industry's muted reaction to this price spike is highly unusual.
A big reason is that a lot of companies appear unconvinced that oil can stay close to $30, the current price for crude, or even the low $20's. Their skepticism derives from a belief that OPEC cannot keep member nations from cheating on production limits for long when prices get this high. Moreover, pressure from the United States and other countries to lift output appears to be having some effect. On Thursday, the Saudi oil minister said oil should ideally trade between $20 and $25, while his counterpart in Venezuela said action needed to be taken to stabilize prices.
That would be good news for consumers squeezed by costly heating oil and gasoline. But even if OPEC decides at its March meeting to increase production, it could be too late to lower gas prices by summer, as inventories have fallen sharply in recent months.
Some analysts say that even if OPEC lifts production, oil prices could still rise. Philip K. Verleger, a senior adviser to the Brattle Group, an economic consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., said $40 oil would still be feasible later this year if Iraq cut off its supply to protest United Nations sanctions. "It's almost too late to avoid this impending dependence on Iraq, barring an economic slowdown," Mr. Verleger said.
And even if domestic oil producers reverse course and seek out new sources aggressively, it would not have much of an effect on world supply and demand anytime soon: Total domestic oil production is about 6 million barrels a day, out of more than 70 million worldwide.
Aside from skepticism about OPEC's resolve, other temporary factors have led oil companies to rein in spending, like the rapid pace of mergers forcing producers to focus on integrating newly bought companies.
But the restraint also has deeper reasons, analysts and industry executives say. Some producers, rethinking the growth-at-all-costs strategy, now preach "capital discipline."
That means giving careful consideration to options like debt repayment and stock buybacks. Investors, meanwhile, have shut off the flow of fresh capital to many exploration and production companies. And some producers say the huge recent price swings have shaken out many longtime drilling and service workers, leading to labor shortages.
All that could change quickly if oil prices keep rising, or if OPEC continues to curb production and the industry persuades itself that this time the cartel can keep its members from cheating.
But for now, signs are that capital spending growth will be soft. John S. Herold Inc., an industry researcher in Stamford, Conn., forecasts that worldwide spending on oil and gas exploration, development and proved acquisitions will rise 14 percent this year, to $86 billion -- far less than the $108 billion spent as recently as 1998. The number of active rotary drilling oil rigs in the United States has risen 38 percent in the last year, to 153, according to Baker Hughes, a Houston oil services concern, and is still far below its highs for the decade.
"What you're seeing is companies being a whole lot more discriminating in the projects they pursue with excess capital," said Bobby S. Shackouls, chief executive of Burlington Resources, a large independent exploration and production company in Houston that expects to lift capital spending this year by about a quarter, to $1 billion.
A number of independent companies, his included, have abandoned strategies that focused mostly on production growth, Mr. Shackouls said. "Companies have delivered volume growth in the past," he said, "but many times that volume growth has been delivered with returns that were less than the cost of capital required to generate it. The market just doesn't like that."
The same is true at some larger companies. "The major companies that spend most of the money have been recently focused more on returns," said J. Michael Talbert, chief executive of Transocean Sedco Forex, in Houston, the nation's largest offshore driller.
Many of Mr. Talbert's customers have been undertaking big projects only after deciding they would still make financial sense even if oil fell to $13. "They've heightened the bar," he said.
But Mr. Talbert added that his company was beginning to see an uptick in activity. "I'm surprised that some of the capital plans seem to be as limited as they are," he said. "If prices stay at $30 a barrel, somebody is going to draw an awful lot of new wells."
The push to make producers rethink capital allocation is also coming from Wall Street. A Goldman, Sachs analyst, Donald Textor, suggested in a report this month that many independent exploration companies would benefit from large-scale stock buybacks to soak up profits rather than pouring the money into the ground. "Higher sustained share prices," Mr. Textor concluded, "will depend on management's ability to invest cash flow wisely, either in their respective businesses if opportunities are present or alternatively in their own shares if valuation justifies this capital allocation."
For the moment, most independents, still recovering from the earlier era of cheap oil, are focused on paying down debt, and otherwise improving their finances.
On Wall Street, only the larger exploration and production companies are finding investors willing to buy shares or lend money. Last year, just $125 million was raised in initial public offerings, while debt issuance fell sharply, the Herold firm reported. Not long ago the spigots were wide open: In 1997 and 1998, financing from Wall Street helped exploration and production companies make capital investments $40 billion higher than their operating cash flow, the firm reported. In contrast, 1999 was the first time in five years that capital spending did not exceed cash flow -- in other words, companies did not binge on easy money.
To be sure, the Internet craze has drawn money from oil and other slower-growth industries. But so has oil's sister business, natural gas, a fuel used to power everything from power plants to kitchen stoves. To many investors, demand for gas is easier to quantify than oil, and is not dependent on the whims of OPEC ministers half a world away.
"Natural gas prices are quite strong and the percentage of capital dollars being directed toward gas is greater today than at any other point," said Ken Hersh, managing director of Natural Gas Partners, a $950 million venture equity fund in Fort Worth focusing on oil and gas.
Paradoxically, some oil producers that do have money to spend say they have been hamstrung by a shortage of skilled oil services workers. Danny Biggs, vice president of Pickrell Drilling, in Wichita, Kan., said longtime oilfield workers had been taking jobs that pay less, like hospital maintenance. "We just can't find the help," Mr. Biggs said. "These guys working on the rigs, they get laid off, then they work, then they get laid off. A lot of them have decided they want steady work."
The talent outflow has been speeded by demand for labor in other fields. "With the economy outside the oil industry doing quite well, it's awfully difficult to convince someone to stay on and count on this business to feed and support their family," said Stephen Layton, chief executive of Equinox Oil, a private concern in Woodlands, Tex. "Six months or a year from now we could be right back where we were in 1998," he said, making it "a very hard sell."
Still, demand for workers would be greater had the industry not suffered through $12-a-barrel oil, said Mr. Layton, who likens a typical independent producer to a man standing on the foundation of his recently demolished house: "The storm has passed, the sun is shining. Aren't things wonderful? No. He's got to rebuild his house."

SECTION: Section A; Page 9; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: A Year in Which Political Bluebloods Are Leaders of the Pack

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C.

 BODY:
For a country like the United States that has kings only on chessboards, where nobility is a trait rather than a social class, where pedigrees typically concern dogs, there are a couple of peculiar things about this presidential contest.
The first is that most of this year's major presidential candidates arose from a privileged elite vaguely reminiscent of the nobility that the United States has always forsworn. This is easily the most patrician cast of contenders in many decades, and the November general election could pit George W. Bush, a third-generation politician who is the grandson of a senator and son of a president, against Al Gore, the son of a senator. 
 The second thing is that nobody seems to care.
"My dad was a truck driver," said Robert Despres, a truck driver who watched a speech by Mr. Bush in New Hampshire. "When I was 6 years old, I knew I was going to be a truck driver, too. So if he wants to follow his dad and he does well, it doesn't matter to me."
In Delaware, a white-haired welder named Fred Dobrzynski said that he worked for a company that had been passed down from father to son and said of the political dynasties: "That's America! I don't really have a problem with nepotism."
Halfway across the country in Iowa, a retired teacher named Larry Hamilton shrugged at the thought of political dynasties in the United States. "We have this idea in the U.S. that anybody can grow up to be president, but we also know that's not quite right," Mr. Hamilton said. "It doesn't really bother me."
And in the hamlet of Wolfton, in central South Carolina, Wanda Reese stood at the counter of her little general store and put it this way: "You can't hold it against them, just because they got some advantage. If somebody came in here and gave me a sack of gold, I'd take it."
In interviews in recent weeks, many voters said that the candidates had enjoyed a leg up because of their parentage. But instead of being uncomfortable with this, some regarded a candidate's blue blood as a plus.
"It would probably be an asset that his father had been president," Debra L. Devine, a former nurse who is now a stay-at-home mother, said after a Bush rally in New Hampshire. "Maybe he's had more firsthand experience."
It is not just Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore who grew up with famous names that helped them launch political careers. Senator John McCain's father and grandfather were both well-known admirals and public figures. Steve Forbes, who recently dropped out of the race, inherited his wealth and fame.
Among major candidates, only former Senator Bill Bradley is an exception. His father, a banker, was a big man in a small town but not a politician.
Paradoxically, although Americans sometimes poke fun at political nepotism in countries like Japan or at the doddering heirs who until last year filled Britain's House of Lords, it is probably the United States that throughout its history has had the most political dynasties.
John Adams and his son John Quincy Adams were both president and three other Adams descendants sought the presidency or vice presidency. William Henry Harrison was the grandfather of Benjamin Harrison, and Theodore and Franklin Roosevelt were distant cousins.
Stephen Hess, a scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington, calculated in a 1965 book, "America's Political Dynasties," that, until then, 17 percent of members of Congress had come from families that had sent at least two members to the House or Senate.
"It's fascinating to see this in a country that in its Constitution prohibits titles of nobility," Mr. Hess said in a telephone interview. "Of course we have created a nobility."
Yet he cautioned that while a famous name helped, a rule of thumb was that it simply allowed a candidate to start a career one rung higher than would otherwise be possible -- for a Congressional seat, say, instead of one in the state legislature. Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore may have been initially helped by their names, he suggested, but since then have emerged as contenders largely on their own strengths.
The success of second- and third-generation politicians this year may also reflect the good economic times and less resentment of privilege. Certainly none of the candidates seem bashful about their family backgrounds, and Mr. Bush in particular refers to it in speeches in ways calculated to win applause.
"When it comes to selecting parents, I did a fabulous job!" Mr. Bush sometimes tells audiences, and they roar back in approval.
Still, there has been speculation that former President Bush's campaign appearances for his son in New Hampshire may have undermined the younger Mr. Bush, by reinforcing the perception among some voters that he is a lightweight riding on his father's shoulders. Since then, Mr. Bush has been more restrained about having his father make campaign appearances.
Some voters said that they thought there was something vaguely undemocratic about a system that produced so many second- and third-generation politicians, but they said it lightly and did not seem much perturbed.
"It bothers me, because it's not democracy," said Bradley J. Wilson, an Iowa farmer. "But I realize that you can be from that background and still have good views."
While it may be that neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Gore would have entered politics had their fathers not been politicians, there are also liabilities associated with the genes. Mr. Bush wrote in his autobiography that when he ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 1978, Ronald Reagan endorsed his primary opponent -- possibly because of fears that a victory would have helped Mr. Bush's father if he had challenged Mr. Reagan in 1980.
It is difficult to describe the political aristocracy in this election as a trend, both because of the historic strength of political dynasties and because the last presidential election featured a race between two self-made men, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole.
So why are this year's candidates so drawn from the Social Register?
Perhaps it is a fluke, or perhaps it reflects the importance of money and name recognition in campaigns today.
Scott Harshbarger, the president of Common Cause, said that the prevalence of familiar names underscored the pressures these days of campaign fund-raising and, in his view, the need to change the system for financing campaigns.
"If you don't have the money, you can't compete," Mr. Harshbarger said. Noting that several credible candidates had dropped out even before the primaries, he added, "The presidential selection process was bypassed."
Bill Sousa, a social studies teacher in Merrimack, N.H., said that this year's election might make it a bit more difficult to teach students that anyone can become president. But, he quickly added, he already emphasizes to students that the political playing field tilts here and there.
Mr. Sousa said that today's political aristocracy was not unlike the situation a couple of centuries ago in America, when wealthy plantation owners regarded themselves as an elite who would serve the country with honesty and dedication. Referring to today's second- and third-generation candidates, Mr. Sousa said, "That's what the founding fathers intended."

HEADLINE: Chechnya: Steps To Peace

BYLINE: By Andrew Bennett; Andrew Bennett, a professor of government at Georgetown, is the author of "Condemned to Repetition? The Rise, Fall and Reprise of Soviet-Russian Military Interventionism 1973-1996."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With the inevitability of a Greek tragedy, Russia's military intervention in Chechnya has followed the script rehearsed in the war in the mid-1990's.
As in February 1995, Russian soldiers are picking over the ruins of Grozny, the Chechen capital, after a costly fight and are facing a vicious battle in the mountains of southern Chechnya. Russia must now decide if it wants to repeat the closing act of the previous war, when it rejected negotiations with the Chechens after taking Grozny. It only conceded to a peace agreement in 1997, after two years of guerrilla warfare and terrorist attacks by Chechen rebels. 
 Negotiations would require both sides to take political risks and face down their hard-line factions. But there are good reasons to think that this time both sides may try to make a deal.
Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president, is in a stronger position to seek negotiations than Boris Yeltsin was in 1995. Mr. Putin's ruthless offensive in Chechnya has won him much higher approval ratings than Mr. Yeltsin had after his ill-prepared assault on Grozny five years ago. Mr. Putin also knows that recent polls have shown that the Russian public's support for the war has softened as casualties have increased. And some Russian leaders, including Sergei Stepashin, a former prime minister, and Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow have begun to criticize the continued use of force in Chechnya.
The greatest risk to Mr. Putin's election as president next month is not a backlash from hard-liners for negotiating an agreement, but a terrorist attack or counteroffensive in Chechnya.
The Chechens, too, might be more likely to seek a truce this time around. President Aslan Maskhadov does not control all of Chechnya's factions. But he remains the republic's most legitimate leader, and he is far more reasonable that Dzhokhar Dudayev, the breakaway republic's leader five years ago. Mr. Maskhadov has never supported terrorist tactics, and has criticized radical Islamic leaders like Shamil Basayev. Last fall he even said that he might be willing to part with Mr. Basayev, but couldn't do so as long as he faced a Russian invasion.
It would be politically risky for either Mr. Putin or Mr. Maskhadov to be the first to seek a settlement. Thus the first tentative steps toward negotiations might depend on the unlikely person of Malik Saidullayev, a Chechen who made his fortune running Moscow's largest lottery. Mr. Saidullayev is the head of the Chechen state council, a shadow government appointed by Moscow, which is viewed by many of the republic's leaders as a puppet regime. But Mr. Saidullayev has established some credibility with the Chechen people by forcefully criticizing Russian atrocities in the recent offensive. Speculation is that he might make a legitimate intermediary between Mr. Putin and Mr. Maskhadov.
It is clear what the outlines of any mutually acceptable agreement must be. Russia will demand security from Islamic terrorism, including a buffer zone in northern Chechnya manned by Russian troops. A new Chechen government would likely insist on autonomy for the rest of its territory, as well as reconstruction assistance from Moscow and possibily military help in getting rid of extremist holdouts.
And both sides would likely demand the expulsion of the hard-liners from Chechnya -- meaning not only Mr. Basayev and other warlords but also the most overeager of Russia's generals.
What can the United States do to tip the scales toward peace?
President Clinton has until now wisely avoided a confrontation over Chechnya. He has delayed several loans from the International Monetary Fund and the Export-Import Bank but has cited Russia's economic mismanagement and corruption as the reason rather than explicitly mentioning the war in Chechnya. Perhaps now is the time to inform Russia's leaders that American-backed loans will become inextricably linked to Chechnya if Russia fails to seek a settlement. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: RUSSIAN FEDERATION (99%); UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Donations to Needy Fall Behind Last Year's Tally

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Since The New York Times Neediest Cases appeal of 1994-95, the amount of money readers have given to the fund has increased year after year.
But in a turn of events that bodes ill for the fund, for the first time this season, the amount of money received to date has fallen well behind the total at this point during last year's campaign. 
 By March 8, 1999, when the Neediest Cases Fund closed its coffers for the 1998-99 appeal, it had received $6,701,122.57 in donations.
This year, the fund has $539,370.93 less than the amount that had been raised by this point a year ago, $6,148,774.55.
At the seven agencies that are supported by the fund, the news that there may not be as much help for them this year was greeted with sadness.
"It would be a blow to us," said Donna Santarsiero, executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of the agencies. "Across the board, our programs for children and disabled adults rely heavily on the proceeds from The New York Times and its generous readers. If there were a reduction in funding from last year's level, we would have to take a careful look at all our programs, all of which are critical."
Among other things, the bureau helps deaf and mentally retarded New Yorkers find meaningful employment, prevents children from going into foster care by assisting parents who are struggling to make ends meet, and provides homeless women with a place to live.
At the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, another of the agencies supported by the fund, worries about the shortfall were equally poignant.
"Since the money we get goes to individuals and families," said Megan McLaughlin, executive director, "it means that fewer individuals and families would get the direct assistance that they need to help them over the hurdle that they're facing. Fewer families in crisis would get the help they need."
The federation uses money provided by The Times to prevent struggling families from becoming homeless, usually by giving them a one-time rental assistance check to tide them over.
"In this time of plenty, we're all blessed," Ms. McLaughlin said. "The economy is humming. Employment rates are higher. But the reality is that there are still those among us that need our help."
One family from Great Neck, N.Y., recently took a step toward helping the less fortunate. Jon R. Cohen and Karen M. Kostroff, both surgeons, held a black-tie millennium party for 150 friends and relatives in tents set up on their lawn. Guests were encouraged to make a donation to the Neediest Cases Fund instead of giving a gift to the hosts.
"We have always been impressed with the heartwarming stories about those people helped by support from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund," Dr. Cohen and Dr. Kostroff wrote in a letter to the fund on Jan. 1.
Guests were asked to give $200, but many gave hundreds more, Dr. Kostroff said. All told, the party raised $12,500.
"It went above our greatest expectations," Dr. Kostroff said.
The fund needs more than $1 million to match last year's total, but that goal could be reached before the campaign concludes in early March if enough readers contribute.
"We're hoping for a burst of generosity that will permit us to do better than last year," said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases Fund.

HEADLINE: A Rebuke for Mr. Mugabe

 BODY:
When Zimbabwe achieved independence from white minority rule in 1980 in what had been Rhodesia, its newly elected leader, Robert Mugabe, held out the promise of transforming a state that was not only racist but brutally authoritarian. Many hoped he could make Zimbabwe a model for what was then still an apartheid-ruled South Africa, on its southern border. The former guerrilla leader made progress in dismantling the legacies of racism, but he maintained the machinery of authoritarianism that he inherited from Rhodesia's last white leader, Ian Smith, including sweeping emergency powers.
It has been two decades since independence, and President Mugabe has long since grown accustomed to autocratic power. He presides now over a corrupt, sclerotic and repressive state that is rapidly driving Zimbabwe into economic ruin. But Mr. Mugabe's disappointing dominance of Zimbabwean politics is now under attack by his countrymen. This week they convincingly defeated a constitutional referendum that would have strengthened his executive powers and allowed him to confiscate white-owned land without compensation. The vote was both a stinging rebuke to Mr. Mugabe's leadership and a victory for democracy. 
 The fledgling opposition Movement for Democratic Change is led by trade-union activists, church leaders and domestic human rights organizations. It cuts across racial, ethnic and class divisions. It had abundant ammunition with which to attack Mr. Mugabe's leadership: fuel shortages, 60 percent inflation, more than 50 percent unemployment in urban areas, and pervasive corruption. His costly military intervention in Congo is deeply unpopular.
The referendum did not signal the demise of Mr. Mugabe's government. It still enjoys extensive powers of patronage and coercion, as well as a monopoly on broadcast media. But Mr. Mugabe now faces the prospect of elections for Parliament in April in which his dominant ZANU-PF party will probably encounter its toughest challenge since independence. He is expected to seek a fifth five-year term as president in 2002. He has reason to cling to power. In today's climate of prosecutions against former heads of state, he could face criminal liability, both at home and abroad, for abuses committed by his security forces.
The precipitous decline of Zimbabwe's economy and fears of political turmoil could undermine the hard-won stability of its closest neighbors and trading partners, notably Mozambique and South Africa. The United States and other democracies can help by using their influence to discourage Mr. Mugabe from manipulating the democratic process. This week he sounded a conciliatory note and promised to "respect the will of the people." Perhaps he has gotten the message that his countrymen have lost patience with his autocratic rule.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Set Record in '99, But Narrowed In December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit in goods and services narrowed in December, as rebounding economies abroad kindled record demand for American goods, government figures showed. Still, the trade gap for all of 1999 set a record.
The December deficit slipped to $25.5 billion from $27.1 billion in November, the Commerce Department reported. While imports rose 1 percent to a record, they were outpaced by a 3.2 percent jump in exports, led by commercial aircraft. 
 The 1999 deficit totaled $271.3 billion, almost two-thirds larger than the previous record of $164.3 billion in 1998, as imports surged 12 percent. Economists say the gap showed how goods made elsewhere played a role in meeting consumer demand in the United States during a record expansion that is now in its 107th month. This year, rising exports will increase United States factory output, they said.
"Certainly as the global economy recovers, this is going to provide increased export markets for U.S. manufacturers," said William Sullivan, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. That and the damping effect on consumer spending of further interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve Board should reduce the deficit this year, analysts say.
The trade imbalances with Japan, China, Western Europe, Canada and Mexico grew to their widest ever last year.
In December, imports of goods and services rose to $110.7 billion, reflecting demand for consumer goods, autos and parts, and industrial materials. Exports increased to a monthly high of $85.2 billion in December. For all of last year, imports rose to $1.23 trillion, the largest increase in five years. Exports in 1999 climbed 2.6 percent, to $958.5 billion.
Auto imports rose 3.4 percent in December after gaining 2.9 percent in November, the Commerce Department reported.
Oil prices had a role in the wider trade gap as well. The United States imports more than half its crude oil.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last year agreed to limit output in an effort to eliminate a global oil surplus. That caused crude oil prices to more than double from a 12-year low of $10.35 a barrel in December 1998. This week, they topped $30 a barrel. The trade deficit with OPEC's member nations narrowed to $1.2 billion in December, from $2.8 billion in November, while rising from $109 million in December 1998. For all of last year, the deficit with OPEC nations rose to $21.7 billion, the highest in three years.
The deficit with Japan grew to a record $73.9 billion for all of 1999. The trade deficit with China last year expanded to a record $68.7 billion.
Few people express alarm over the trade deficit the way they did in the 1980's. "In the 80's, we worried about the trade deficit because foreign production was displacing domestic employment," said Christopher Low, an economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York. "Now it is offsetting a shortfall of domestic workers."

HEADLINE: Prices Show A Small Rise For January

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index, the nation's best-known inflation measure, edged up only 0.2 percent in January -- the fourth consecutive mild increase -- undercutting numerous forecasts that the booming economy is creating shortages that must inevitably show up in more rapidly rising prices.
Apparel and cars helped to keep inflation in check in January. Prices fell in both categories, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday, with apparel prices dropping 1.1 percent, the biggest one-month decline since February 1989. Energy prices jumped, of course, rising by 1 percent, but that was a smaller increase than many analysts had expected given the steeply rising cost of crude oil. 
 "Other than petroleum-based energy -- mainly gasoline and heating oil -- there has been no steady price acceleration in any sector of the economy," said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist at the bureau's consumer price division.
The Commerce Department, in a separate report yesterday, said that the nation's trade deficit had narrowed to $25.55 billion in December from $27.1 billion in November, largely because exports jumped. The export rise suggested that the economy had expanded more rapidly in the fourth quarter than the government had originally thought. The gross domestic product may have grown at a 6 percent annual rate, some analysts said, rather than the 5.8 percent estimate announced last month by the Commerce Department. A revision of this estimate is to be published next Friday.
Several Wall Street economists reacted to the inflation report with more alarm than Mr. Jackman did, seeing in the details signs of accelerating inflation. Since October, consumer prices have risen each month at the same mild 0.2 percent, and over the previous 12 months the rise has been only 2.6 or 2.7 percent. The annual rise is much less when two elements that fluctuate considerably -- food and energy -- are excluded. Then the increase in "core inflation" was 2.1 percent in October and November, falling to 1.9 percent in the last two months.
But service sector prices and housing costs have edged up after falling during the summer and fall, and several economists pointed this out, among them Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at High Frequency Economics, a Wall Street firm. "There are some things in the C.P.I. report that I really do not like," he said. "The overall numbers are still mild, but there are bits and pieces that suggest an upward push."
The latest C.P.I. report was issued the day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress that the demand for goods and services had been rising faster than the supply, a condition that cannot continue indefinitely. The stock market has played a big role in generating so much consumption, he said, and he suggested that the Fed would push up rates to slow the economy, and the market, until supply and demand were once again in balance. "Real long-term rates will at some point be high enough to finally balance demand with supply," he said.
Real interest rates have already risen steeply in the last year. Real rates are what people pay for a mortgage, for example, minus the inflation rate. The reasoning is that inflation offsets the cost of a loan because the value of the home purchased rises with inflation. So does the debtor's income, which means that loan payments become a smaller percentage of the person's income. Real rates then represent the true cost of a loan.
They are up a steep one percentage point in less than a year. The Fed has raised short-term loan rates by that much, to nearly 6 percent, while the core annual inflation rate has remained at 2 percent. Mr. Greenspan's Congressional testimony suggested that the Fed's policy makers planned another rate increase for March 21, their next meeting. The Consumer Price Index report for February will be published four days earlier.
That next report is likely to show higher gasoline and heating oil prices, and higher cigarette prices, just on the basis of price increases since late January, Mr. Jackman and other economists said.
The January report showed the same scattered mix of higher and lower prices that has characterized the monthly reports since last summer. New and used car prices, for example, fell mainly because of a $500 "loyalty" rebate that was offered by General Motors, Mr. Jackman said.
Education costs jumped in January primarily because encyclopedia companies eliminated a price discount that drew buyers in December. Apparel prices almost always drop sharply in the weeks after Christmas, although last month's decline was greater than usual. "These are your post-holiday sales," Mr. Jackman said.
Cigarette prices rose a steep 1.7 percent, partly because of recent tax increases. Airline fares, however, fell in January despite temporary surcharges to cover rising fuel prices. Supersaver discount fares more than offset the surcharges.
"If you are looking for trouble, you can always find items that suggest that inflation is rebounding," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Alex. Brown. "But inflation is defined as a broad increase in prices, and that has not happened."

HEADLINE: What I Saw at the Revolution

BYLINE: By Donald J. Trump; Donald J. Trump is the president of the Trump Organization.

 BODY:
Don King, the boxing promoter, has stated that my recent presidential exploratory campaign was one of the greatest promotions of all time. Sadly, many have agreed with him and have thought that my foray into presidential politics was done for the purpose of further heightening the Trump name, helping to sell my new book and building even greater awareness of my various real estate developments.
That, however, is not the case. I seriously thought that America might be ready for a businessman president, someone with an eye for the bottom line, someone who has created thousands of jobs and isn't part of the "inside the Beltway" buddy system. I also thought that Americans might be ready for straight talk and that they would find an unscripted candidate appealing. 
 Jesse Ventura's victory in Minnesota served as my model. A nonpolitician celebrity who spoke uncommonly straight to the voters, Mr. Ventura came out of nowhere to beat two experienced, big-name politicians at a time of economic prosperity, and he did so as the nominee of a fledgling third party.
The Reform Party was my chosen vehicle because its nomination process does not involve a long string of early primaries, but instead culminates in one national primary conducted by mail and e-mail in August. Refreshingly democratic, the Reform Party process would lend itself to a candidate with national name recognition and the financial resources to flood the process with new people.
A presidential exploratory campaign is the greatest civics lesson that a private citizen can have. In the course of my exploration, I met dozens of talented, dedicated Reform Party members who were involved, with little reward or recognition, solely because of their commitment to cleaning up the American political system. I marveled at the long and thankless hours put in by people like the New York Independence Party chairman, Jack Essenberg; the former national chairman, Russ Verney; and the Minnesota Reform Party chairman, Rick McCluhan.
I also saw the underside of the Reform Party. The fringe element that wanted to repeal the federal income tax, believed that the country was being run by the Trilateral Commission and suspected that my potential candidacy was a stalking horse for (take your pick) Gov. George W. Bush, Senator John McCain or Vice President Al Gore.
When I held a reception for Reform Party leaders in California, the room was crowded with Elvis look-alikes, resplendent in various campaign buttons and anxious to give me a pamphlet explaining the Swiss-Zionist conspiracy to control America.
Three things happened to destroy any viable chance that I may have had to run an insurgent candidacy in the fall. The Commission on Presidential Debates, made up solely of Republicans and Democrats, produced debate criteria specifically designed to keep the Reform Party's candidate out of the fall debates. I felt confident that I could sell the American people if I could get into the debate, but my lawyers told me that was unlikely.
I preferred a race against Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore, two establishment politicians whose nominations looked certain and whose issue positions seemed virtually indistinguishable; both support America's current trade policies, including Nafta and the World Trade Organization.
I felt confident that my argument that America was being ripped off by our major trade partners and that it was time for tougher trade negotiations would have resonance in a race against the two Ivy League contenders. The rise of John McCain, running on a reform message, made the opportunity for this contrast difficult, and depending on the outcome of the South Carolina primary, perhaps impossible.
Finally, the fratricide in the national Reform Party drove the party's most prominent star, Jesse Ventura, out of the party and culminated in a nationally televised meltdown at the national meeting last week, in which the proceedings grew so unruly that someone called 911 to ask the police to restore order.
Although I am totally comfortable with the people in the New York Independence Party, I leave the Reform Party to David Duke, Pat Buchanan and Lenora Fulani. That is not company I wish to keep.
In the days before I decided to end my presidential exploratory effort, I was watching CNN and saw Vice President Gore trudging through the snow in subzero temperatures, knocking on doors in New Hampshire -- an obvious look of drudgery on his face. My experience was quite different. I had enormous fun thinking about a presidential candidacy and count it as one of my great life experiences. Although I must admit that it still doesn't compare with completing one of the great skyscrapers of Manhattan, I cannot rule out another bid for the presidency in 2004.
