HEADLINE: Oregon's Governor Favors Breaching 4 Major Dams

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Lending political momentum to an idea that would have been unthinkable in a different era of Pacific Northwest history, Gov. John A. Kitzhaber of Oregon announced today that he favored breaching four large federal dams on the Snake River in Washington State in an effort to restore endangered salmon populations.
Mr. Kitzhaber, a Democrat, became the first major political figure to endorse the controversial dam-removal proposal, which is passionately favored by many environmental groups, American Indians and commercial fishers, but opposed with equal fervor by farmers and many others in the interior Northwest who now rely on the tamed Snake River for barge shipping and electricity. 
 The debate will almost surely wind up in Congress, sometime after the Army Corps of Engineers, which operates the dams, issues its own opinion on the proposal next year.
Just how much influence Governor Kitzhaber's stand will have remains to be seen, but it is nonetheless an intriguing reflection of change in man's relationship with the rivers of the Northwest, where some hydroelectric dams generate enormous amounts of power but have also proven lethal on a major scale to the region's fabled salmon runs.
"In the end, the answer will be a political one -- informed by good science -- but based on a set of values and on the degree of economic and ecological risks the region is willing to accept," Governor Kitzhaber said in a speech to the American Fisheries Society in Eugene, Ore. "It is time that we shoulder our responsibilities and develop a blueprint for action."
Construction of Northwest dams was an undeniably epic engineering achievement, celebrated in Woody Guthrie's songs more than a half-century ago. But for the last several decades, the Corps of Engineers has been laboring under federal requirements to help dams and the salmon coexist on the Snake but has met little success.
Despite spending more than $3 billion on projects like fish ladders, hatcheries and even a truck-and-barging system that a Corps brochure describes as "custom-made to make the trip as safe and comfortable as possible" for the fish, the salmon populations have declined.
The Snake's coho salmon have already been declared extinct, and every other species of salmon and steelhead in the Snake River is now listed under the Endangered Species Act. In the early 1800's, when the explorer William Clark discovered a river crowded with salmon, about 2 million adult salmon a year completed the trip back to their spawning grounds, biologists estimate.
Ed Bowles, Idaho's manager of anadromous fish, those that hatch in fresh water and migrate to the sea, said today that 3,276 Snake River adult spring and summer chinook returned last year, down from 8,426 in 1998. Fall chinook returns were estimated to be about 400, slightly up from 306 in 1998.
Under the dam-breaching proposal now being considered by the Corps, earthen portions around the dams would be removed, rendering the dams themselves inoperative and restoring 140 miles of the Snake River in eastern Washington to a wild, free-flowing condition. Many scientists and biologists have endorsed dam breaching as the step that would have the greatest odds of saving the salmon from extinction.
The dams -- Ice Harbor, Lower Monumental, Little Goose and Lower Granite -- would be the biggest federal dams ever slated for removal. But there is no guarantee that the plan would work, and it would take out of service dams that provide about 4 percent of the Pacific Northwest's electricity. (Unlike other dams in the region, the Snake dams are not used for flood control.)
The dams were also constructed to turn Lewiston, Idaho, in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains and nearly 500 miles from the Pacific Ocean, into the West's most inland seaport. But virtually all barge traffic to and from Lewiston would stop if the dams were breached.
Lawmakers in eastern Washington have opposed any breaching. Republican lawmakers throughout the region have been generally united against the idea. Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican who is running for re-election this year, said taking down the dams would be "an unmitigated disaster and an economic nightmare" for the region.
Many Democrats have been noncommittal, but in his speech today, Governor Kitzhaber said that the region was required to try to save the fish under the Federal Endangered Species Act, and he warned that if dam-breaching were not tried, other alternatives might be even more expensive and disruptive.
"All I am saying to you today is that we have to stop deluding ourselves into believing that our choices will be easier and cheaper if we just leave the dams alone," he said. "Our choices won't be easier. They'll be just as tough."
Mr. Kitzhaber, who was elected in 1994 and re-elected in 1998, also criticized, by implication, a range of state and federal officials who have called for more study of the issue.
"Some will say that we have not done enough science," Mr. Kitzhaber said. "I say that we can always play that card as an excuse for inaction and as a justification for avoiding tough choices. But exactly what additional scientific experiment is necessary to demonstrate that it is easier for salmon to migrate in a free-flowing river than to negotiate a several-hundred-foot-high concrete barrier?"
Environmentalists praised Mr. Kitzhaber. "The governor is providing what the Snake River salmon need most right now, and that is political leadership," said Rob Masonis, regional director of dam programs for American Rivers, a group that favors dam removal on many of the nation's rivers.

HEADLINE: After Pushing Oil Prices Up, Mexico Has Second Thoughts

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: VERACRUZ, Mexico, Feb. 18

 BODY:
For two years, Mexico has worked with other oil-producing nations to lift prices, and their efforts have borne fruit. But in an about-face, senior Mexican officials are now trying to talk prices down.
The problem is that lofty oil prices conflict with Mexico's new economy, propelled by exports of cars, televisions and other manufactured goods. 
 "Mexico is now so integrated into the U.S. economy that it's no longer in Mexico's interest to rock the boat on oil prices," said Eduardo Lopez, a Mexican who is an analyst at the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a consulting firm in Washington.
The turnabout has put President Ernesto Zedillo's government in a ticklish predicament. Leaders of the industrial world are glaring at Mexico, complaining that petroleum prices are aggravating inflation. But the Mexican left is accusing the government of relinquishing a bonanza and giving in to the imperialists.
That is the incendiary context for Energy Secretary Bill Richardson's visit to Mexico on Saturday.
The Clinton administration has promised to take a variety of actions to alleviate a big increase in heating oil prices in the Northeast. Mr. Richardson will discuss the higher oil prices with the man who helped shape the trend, Energy Secretary Luis Tellez.
At an oil industry convention today in Veracruz, on the gulf coast, Mr. Tellez said he hoped that oil prices, now above $30 a barrel, would soon drop below $25. And he paused to dwell on the new reality: that manufacturing is a star performer and oil a bit player in his country.
"Mexico is mainly an industrial producer and a provider of services," Mr. Tellez said at a news conference. "We're not a petroleum country anymore."
The oil equation for Mexico used to be simple: the higher the world price the better. Oil production contributed nearly 6 percent to Mexico's total economic output in 1983, but during 15 years of economic modernization, including the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, oil's contribution has withered to just 1.7 percent.
So although high world petroleum prices mean that Mexico will receive billions of dollars in unexpected revenues this year, they also threaten to worsen inflation, drive up interest rates and slow world growth.
If that happens, economists say, Mexico's losses from forfeited exports will far outweigh the short-term profits from $30-a-barrel oil.
"That's what many Mexicans don't understand," Mr. Lopez said. "People are still thinking in terms of national sovereignty and national interest. And those concepts are out of touch with the changes that have taken place."
Oil remains a potent patriotic icon because a high point for Mexican nationalists came in 1938, when President Lazaro Cardenas expropriated the country's petroleum industry. The identification of oil with popular well-being was strengthened in the 1970's, when high prices and discoveries of huge petroleum reserves led President Jose Lopez Portillo to predict an end to poverty. Mexico's new challenge, he said, was to "administer abundance."
If oil revenues have never eradicated poverty, they still finance the government: 33 percent of the government's operating funds come from oil taxes. And when the Asian economic crisis in 1997 cut world demand for energy, prices for Mexico's extra-heavy oil plunged to below $7 a barrel, causing a crisis here.
When price levels are so depressed, "We as producing countries have every right to defend our national interests, and that's what we did," Mr. Tellez said in an interview today.
In those circumstances, Mr. Tellez established secret contacts with the Venezuelan and Saudi Arabian oil ministers, initiating talks that eventually included the 11 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and Norway. The countries announced an agreement in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, in March 1998 to raise prices by slowing production.
Early last year, prices began to rise sharply, but only since December have dangers become apparent. In recent days the Federal Reserve and central banks in Europe and Japan have warned that petroleum prices may contribute to inflation, and Mr. Tellez, along with the Saudi and Venezuelan energy ministers, have done their policy pirouettes.
"These prices are too high," Mr. Tellez said today. He said a consensus had formed among the ministers who had forged the Riyadh agreement that production should now rise, allowing prices to pull back.
But how soon? The ministers are to meet on March 2, but the commitments to cut production are to continue through March 31. Might the ministers decide on March 2 to short-circuit the Riyadh agreement and boost oil output immediately?
"Whatever I say would be very delicate," Mr. Tellez said. "But let me put it this way: we need flexibility."
Mexico's role in influencing world oil prices is surprising, given its trade partnership with the United States, its repeated previous refusal to take part in OPEC and President Zedillo's outspoken advocacy of free markets.
"Mexico's economic policies had been been well known," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economic consultant based in Mexico City. "Mexico stood for free trade and had spoken out against price volatility.
"Now the government has helped restrict the market to raise oil prices, and suddenly officials are getting messages from Washington: 'Hey! You're hurting us. You're fueling inflation. You're playing with fire!' And they're trying to back out of this with the least embarrassment possible." But the discomfort already appears intense.
"It seems absurd, idiotic and contrary to our national interest that there could be more revenues and the government says they don't want them," Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the presidential candidate heading a leftist coalition, told 10,000 supporters at a rally in Monterrey on Thursday.
"If there was nothing to spend the money on," he said, "I could think that increasing the oil exports could be logical. But I've never seen anybody whose product is selling at a high price say, 'I want you to pay me less.' "
Mr. Cardenas is the son of the former president.
"The man in the street thinks Cardenas is right, that we need that money to build schools and pave streets," said Jorge Montano, a former ambassador to Washington.
"They don't understand," Mr. Montano said, "that weeks from now, if these high prices continue, the interest rates will rise, our stock market will fall and we'll all sink."
Political cartoons have lampooned Mr. Tellez as a puppet manipulated by the United States. "Richardson Comes to Pressure Us Over High Crude Prices!" said a headline in the leftist daily La Jornada.
But if Mr. Richardson intends to urge higher production to ease prices, he will be preaching to the converted.
"We're going to tell Mr. Richardson that we'll take measures that are good for Mexico, not only for the oil sector, but also for the growth of the rest of our economy," Mr. Tellez said.
Mr. Tellez is hoping that Mr. Richardson will help him convince 100 million Mexicans of the wisdom of forgoing short-term profits for the greater economic good.
"It's important that the Mexican public understand that there is a real possibility that world economic growth will slow," Mr. Tellez said. "I hope Mr. Richardson will say this loud and clear."

HEADLINE: South Carolina's Showdown

 BODY:
Rarely in recent presidential elections has there been a more pivotal vote than the one in the South Carolina primary today. The entire Republican presidential selection process seems balanced on a knife's edge, with a possibility of either Gov. George W. Bush or Senator John McCain emerging as the overwhelming favorite to win the nomination. The verdict in South Carolina could also shape the party, its demographic composition and perhaps even its philosophy for a long time. Yet the outcome on the eve of the election is entirely unpredictable.
Until his disastrous defeat in New Hampshire two and a half weeks ago, Mr. Bush was the prohibitive favorite to win in South Carolina. But Mr. McCain's Granite State triumph fired up his campaign, and for a time he surged ahead of the Texas governor in South Carolina opinion polls. Now the polls are extremely close, with some showing Mr. Bush ahead again. At the least, the governor's barrage of negative attacks appears to have stopped the stampede to Mr. McCain. A sweeping Bush victory might revive his status as front-runner. A big victory for Mr. McCain might well make him unstoppable, as he said this week. But a squeaker might redouble both men's efforts in other states where Mr. McCain has been moving upward with his brand of maverick and moderate politics. 
 As many analysts have noted, the uncertain factor in South Carolina this year is turnout. Mr. McCain has stirred support among independents and Democrats who say they plan to vote in the Republican contest, many for the first time. If their participation swells the turnout above normal levels, it could put the Arizona senator over the top even though he is well behind among Republicans alone. The contest has thus evolved into a curious clash of two visions for the party. Mr. McCain's encompasses the old Reagan-era coalition, which brought in people not normally Republican in the past. Mr. Bush's vision is more exclusively focused on the party's traditional base.
Lately Mr. Bush has also begun to complain about Democrats voting in the Republican primary, as state rules allow, presumably to choose a weak nominee for the fall. That interpretation is probably a misreading of a phenomenon that could bring new voters into the G.O.P. fold. It is also an ironic switch for the Texas governor, who started out last year by presenting himself as the one who could broaden the party to include minorities and others.
Although South Carolina is not especially representative of the ethnic and ideological mix in the rest of the country, its primary election offers a fascinating snapshot of what could become larger trends this year. Like voters in much of the country, South Carolinians have become more prosperous, high-tech-oriented and moderate in their political and economic views. Both Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush have had to move beyond tax cuts to emphasize education and retirement benefits, a rising theme among suburban voters in the post-segregation South and in other parts of the United States. In Washington, Congressional Republicans are taking note of the trends and moderating their own positions, to the point of promising to spend more money on education than President Clinton proposed in his State of the Union Message.
The political forces ebbing and flowing in South Carolina are making the Republican race unsettled and exciting. Even for Democrats and others who do not agree with much of what either Mr. McCain or Mr. Bush say, this is a healthy contest of ideas that is likely to clarify the choice that voters will be making in November. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: GORE BACK IN STEP WITH WHITE HOUSE OVER CHINA TRADE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Just a day after reassuring union leaders that he would negotiate a tougher trade deal with China if elected president, Vice President Al Gore felt obliged to write a letter today to reiterate his support for the trade agreement that President Clinton is trying to push through Congress.
The letter, to a leading business lobby, underscored the difficult position Mr. Gore finds himself in as he tries to mollify two groups he desperately needs in the election, business executives who have pressed for the accord and union members who want to defeat it. 
 In trying to court both, Mr. Gore has in the last few days led each side to believe that it has his support in one of the nation's most contentious debates over a trade agreement.
Mr. Gore's letter was sent after White House officials had been left fuming by his appearance before the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Thursday in New Orleans. Although Mr. Gore told the union officials that he supported the China deal, the labor leaders said he had also affirmed that, if elected, he would negotiate tougher accords that include guarantees that countries like China would respect labor rights and environmental standards.
The Gore campaign played down any apparent conflict in Mr. Gore's positions, but it was clear that his statements had unsettled the White House, which was eager for him to clarify his position. But campaign officials did not elaborate on any political considerations behind the letter.
As Mr. Gore's comments in New Orleans circulated here on Thursday, some administration officials who are working to win passage of one of the biggest trade deals in history expressed fears that his implicit criticism of the shortcomings could give ammunition to those looking to sink the pact.
"It wasn't exactly deft," an economic adviser to Mr. Clinton said today. "There was a clear argument to make about the national security importance of this agreement, and he failed to make it."
A Democratic leader who has spoken to Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton said: "He's in an agonizing spot. He can't afford to alienate the unions, and they've made this deal public enemy No. 1. And he can't break with the President. So he's all over the place."
Even in the letter to the National Association of Manufacturers, he tried to walk a fine line. "As I have said publicly and privately," he wrote, "I support the agreement reached by our administration on the terms under which China will be permitted to accede to the World Trade Organization."
But in an effort to keep union supporters from bolting, he added: "I agree with President Clinton that future trade negotiations ought to include in the fabric of the agreement both labor and environmental components."
"In the future," he added, "I will also insist on the authority to enforce workers' rights and environmental protections in those agreements."
A spokesman for the business group, Michael E. Baroody, said: "Gore's comments made a tough job even tougher. We were worried that people who were looking for a plausible way out or even to delay the vote could draw some aide and comfort from Mr. Gore's comments. The letter removes that worry."
It remains to be seen how actively the vice president will push the accord, because he cannot afford to alienate organized labor. But the manufacturers lobby was thrilled that the letter put him on the record as clearly supporting the Clinton agreement.
Although Mr. Gore insists that he would revisit China's adherence to labor and environmental standards, as a practical matter he will have little leverage. After China is a member of the W.T.O., Washington will have lost its main negotiating leverage over Beijing, entry to the organization of trading nations.
And after China is a member, it will join the other developing nations that argue that "labor rights" and "environmental standards" are simply code words for a Western conspiracy to force them to pay higher wages and spend billions of dollars on environmental measures.
Arguments about whether the W.T.O. should even examine the links among labor standards, environment and trade sped the collapse of the trade talks in Seattle in December. Administration officials now concede that that meeting was among their biggest blunders of Mr. Clinton's second term. Mr. Gore, sensing the clash, carefully skipped the event.
But the A.F.L.-C.I.O., among other groups, was greatly emboldened by the Seattle demonstrations, where the protests led by union members "shifted the debate about globalization," John J. Sweeney, the president of the union federation, said this week in New Orleans. "Coming off of Seattle, we are at a historic turning point."
Sinking the China deal is clearly the next objective, he said.
Tonight, Mr. Sweeney, who received a copy of the letter, disagreed with those who believe that Mr. Gore had said anything to the unions that undercut Mr. Clinton or the trade agreement.
"The vice president has been consistent," Mr. Sweeney said. "His letter reiterates the position he took at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in Los Angeles in October. When the vice president addressed the Executive Council on Thursday, he took pains to tell the council that he supported the president on the deal with China."
In October, even before the China deal had been signed, Mr. Gore had called for enforceable labor protections in trade agreements.
Union leaders are focusing on members of Congress in pivotal districts, an effort that makes many Democrats wary of signing up with the White House. And for the first time, the unions are trying to create alliances of convenience with conservative Republicans who oppose the China deal on the grounds of national security.
The unions are clearly overjoyed by Mr. Gore's vacillation. No one expected him to break publicly from the White House, and in fact he has repeatedly said he favors China's admission to the W.T.O. But his willingness to talk about the need for a tougher deal sends a signal that this one is flawed.
The White House disagrees. "This is an agreement that helps American workers here and that ultimately lifts the standards of workers in China over time," Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, said in a recent interview. By gradually enveloping China in a system largely run by Western standards, Mr. Berger argued, China will see the benefits of changing its ways. In any case, he added, "this agreement can't be renegotiated."
Clearly the unions hope that it can be. The president of the United Steel Workers, George Becker, who has been pressing Mr. Gore for two years to stop low-cost steel imports, said this week his union would do its best to sink the efforts to win approval of the trade deal. Then, he said, "We're going to give the Gore administration an opportunity to deal with it."

HEADLINE: Seeking Green in a Concrete Jungle

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Here I sit overlooking the Presidio in San Francisco, one of the most extraordinary urban spaces in the world, reading "Death of a Garden" (editorial, Feb. 17), which condemns Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent order to demolish Esperanza Garden on Manhattan's Lower East Side. You are right: green spaces make cities livable, and housing and open space should not be seen as competitive. 
 Enhanced public spaces increase the economic stability and property values of a neighborhood. Just look at Bryant Park in Manhattan, Metrotech and Prospect Park in Brooklyn, and Juniper Valley Park in Queens. The property owners adjacent to the now-destroyed Esperanza Garden should be as distraught as the park users.
 
GRETCHEN DYKSTRA
San Francisco, Feb. 17, 2000
 
The writer is a former president of the Times Square Business Improvement District.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Carlstadt, Industrial Space for Cyberspace

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IN an area around Central Boulevard in Carlstadt dotted with low-slung warehouses and manufacturing complexes the steel skeleton rising on a 12-acre site at the far western end of the thoroughfare is an anomaly. For it has more to do with cyberspace than industrial space.
Comdisco, the company that will occupy the site, will use the new building to house its clients' duplicate files to provide continuity services, formerly called disaster recovery services. If a client's computer files are wiped out or if the client's business results in an overload at its office the client can transmit data without interruption from the Carlstadt building. 
 The 302,000-square-foot building will be the Northeast technology services center for the international technology management company, based in Rosemont, Ill. Comdisco provides data services to businesses that range from banks and stock brokerages to dot-com companies and manufacturers.
The new structure will use raised floors to run the tangle of wires required by the high-tech equipment that will fill much of the space.It will also have enhanced heating and air-conditioning systems and a substation for additional electrical power -- as well as an independent power source with six diesel-fueled generators -- to keep the machines humming.
The Russo Development Company of Hackensack, which owns the development site within its 44-acre industrial park, is constructing the shell of the building and will lease it to Comdisco for 15 years with two five-year renewal options. Comdisco will pay to improve the interior space. No one involved with the project would disclose the overall cost but commercial brokers estimate it to be between $42 million and $63 million.
Brokers say the project is indicative of the appetite for industrial space -- and to a lesser degree office space -- by companies like Comdisco that are involved in servicing the technological and telecommunication needs of today's businesses.
A booming economy and the growth in technology-based companies have all combined "to bring more cerebral white-collar users into the industrial setting," said Jonathan S. Meisel, associate director at in the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the international commercial brokerage.
This is "only the beginning" of the activity, which "will grow exponentially as the use of the Internet grows," he said.
According to state figures, the number of high-tech related jobs in New Jersey, including telecommunications and computer software development and services, have grown by 25 percent from 1994 to 1999. As a result the number of such jobs grew by a total of 59,000 to 295,000 as of last year.
AMONG the companies that are taking or are expected to take industrial or commercial space are those that will provide Internet data centers, also called "server farms." Such centers manage Internet sites for businesses.
One such company, brokers said, is Exodus Communications, based in Santa Clara, Calif., which set up such a center in about 230,000 square feet at 300 Boulevard East in Weehawken. The 311,000-square-foot building, once used by the Metropolitan Opera for storage, is near the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel.
Other uses, they said, are so-called "telecommunications hotels," which are outfitted with the requisite equipment and electrical power for telecom companies to set up operations, including switching stations. One such "hotel" has taken shape on the upper floors of the former 1.2-million-square-foot Macy's department store building at 165 Halsey Street in downtown Newark. Tenants such as Level 3 Communication, and MCI/Worldwide have leased a significant amount of space in the building over the last 18 months, according to Cushman & Wakefield's year-end 1999 market report.
Now a group of Manhattan developers want to set up other telecom hotels in the state. The group -- comprising Young Woo, a principal of Young Woo & Associates, and a venture of Angelo Gordon & Company and Belvedere Capital -- has closed on a 240,000-square-foot warehouse off Exit 12 of the New Jersey Turnpike in Carteret. It also has signed a contract to buy a nearly 900,000-square-foot warehouse on Jersey Avenue in Jersey City, said Mr. Meisel, who with James Quinn, a senior director at the brokerage, is representing the group in the transactions.
Such users, in turn, are helping "to fuel the state's industrial real estate market by reducing the supply of properties and making a tight market even tighter," and Paul E. Giannone, a principal at Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman Company, L.L.C, a Woodbridge brokerage which represented Comdisco in the Carlstadt project.
For instance, in the Meadowlands region where Comdisco's center is situated, his firm put the industrial vacancy rate at 6.37 percent at the end of 1999, down from 7.8 percent the year before. Over the same period, average asking annual rents rose to $5.50 a square foot, from $4.75; the rental rate for new buildings is $6.50 to $7.50 a square foot.
Mr. Giannone added that while such users conduct different businesses they are drawn to the high ceilings and raised floors that industrial properties provide, in order to accommodate "the high-powered guts in a building" needed to support their operations, which run 24 hours a day, seven days a week. In addition, he said, they also need to be situated near a high-speed fiber-optic network.
THOSE factors were involved in Comdisco's decision to go forward with the build-to-suit project in Carlstadt, Mr. Giannone said. The company, he said, surveyed 25 properties, some as far west as Parsippany, but "none had everything the company needed."
Patricia M. Knoll, director of global real estate for Comdisco, said the Carlstadt site was chosen because it had all its approvals in place, was suitable for the size of structure the company wanted to build and its location. It is within a few miles of four of Comdisco's existing operations elsewhere in the Meadowlands, close to its client base in Manhattan and the rest of the New York metropolitan area and accessible to a fiber-optic network, she said.
Comdisco will consolidate operations that are now in the four nearby structures, together totaling just under 200,000 square feet, into the new building and still have 100,000 square feet left "to grow in the future," said Steven Harris, Comdisco's director of project planning.
With the growth in dot-com and e-commerce companies, which "are looking to back up their data, we have a new market segment," Mr. Harris said. The building, which 65 employees from the other locations will move to in phases from next December through July 2001, will be the largest of the 32 centers Comdisco operates in North America.
Mr. Harris said the centers his company operates have in the last three years moved away from the "old model" of such buildings being used only in the event of a disaster.
The new model, he said, is that businesses will also use the center to test their data systems or as a back-up data site.
Since computers are now a common workplace business tool the centers "also have evolved to be more people friendly," places and no longer have that bunker-like look of the past, Mr. Harris said.
As now envisioned the outside of the Carlstadt center will be faced in brick on three sides and have large windows to allow natural light inside. Also planned is a nearly 42,000-square-foot mezzanine at the front of the building. "We want it to look like an office building not like a concrete box," said Ms. Knoll.
Inside, along with the data center, the building will be divided into rooms for testing systems or conducting business, including a work and trading floor area with 1,000 seats and personal computers. There will also be conference rooms, lounges, T.V. rooms and canteens, Mr. Harris said. He added that his building would be "completely up and running" by July 2001.

HEADLINE: Warm Welcome in the Jungle

BYLINE: By CONNIE ROGERS; CONNIE ROGERS is a book editor in New York who is studying primatology.

 BODY:
SURINAME'S rain forest, one of the least traveled places in the world, spread out beneath my airplane like a great green sea with island mountain ranges and gray granite outcrops rising like surfacing whales. Water glinted through the trees. Few people had been here, and the immensity of it was exhilarating and daunting.
While rain forests all over the world are imperiled, Suriname's has been protected until recently by its remoteness and inaccessibility -- and the country's low profile. Tucked between Guyana and French Guiana on the northeast coast of South America, it's known as the Alternative Caribbean by those who don't venture beyond the coast. 
 But that's like judging Brooklyn from the bridge. Four-fifths of the country, an area about the size of New England, is roadless, pristine jungle with much of the biodiversity of the Amazon. The people who live here are as interesting as their natural setting, but their cultures are threatened as they become part of the 21st century.
In late August, Russ Mittermeier, a friend who is president of Conservation International, a Washington-based organization concerned with preserving biodiversity, was headed on a weeklong trip to visit some of its field programs. He knew of my interest in the area and said that if I could sleep in a hammock, I was welcome to come along. Since tourism is in its infancy in Suriname and tours are rare, I quickly accepted.
We arrived in Paramaribo, the coastal capital, at night and I was surprised by the dim outlines of Hindu temples that lined the road into town. Suriname's population of 412,000 is an odd mix of Hindus, Africans, Javanese, Chinese and Europeans whose ancestors arrived over the last 300 years to work in a plantation economy under the Dutch. More than 90 percent of the people, who gained full independence in 1975, live in in or near the capital. Our driver boasted that they prided themselves on getting along. He detoured to show us a mosque and a synagogue standing side by side and said that they shared a security guard.
We flew the next day to Asindohopo, a village 135 miles south in the interior. Its African founders had fled slavery on the Dutch sugar, coffee and timber plantations in the 17th century. They learned how to survive in the forest from the Indians and fought pursuers until they won their freedom in 1762.
Living in relative isolation, slaves who escaped from the same plantation became families, which grouped themselves into tribes like the Saramaccans we were visiting. Now numbering 50,000, the slaves' descendants have knitted customs from different homelands into a Pan-African culture.
It takes at least a day to get to Asindohopo by land from Paramaribo, but I arrived in an hour. From the air, the settlements look like barnacles fastened to the rivers. In two and a half centuries, they've barely made a dent in the forest. We landed on a loosely defined grass airstrip near town and came to rest halfway up a hill, narrowly missing a woman harvesting peanuts. Two men and an eager troop of youngsters greeted us and took us by boat to our lodging on an island in the Pikin River. The island stretched the length of a city block, with a cluster of tree-shaded, one-room wooden bungalows, which mirrored the village on the opposite bank.
With only the briefest pause to tidy up, we went to meet the Granman, or paramount chief, an essential courtesy in the jungle, where the chief would be responsible for a search party if we didn't arrive when expected. The chief sat in a palm thatch meeting house framed by photos of an African statue, Dutch royalty and the Surinamese president, Jules Albert Wijdenbosch.
As lengthy introductions were routed through his headmen and circled the room in a language I couldn't understand, my attention wandered to the nine bats hanging upside down in the palm thatch eves. It was hot in the hut and I was sleepy but the longer the ritual went on, the more securely I felt bound into the community.
That's a comfortable feeling in the middle of a wilderness. The river serves as the only road here and is the center of village life. Within hours, I was floating in its blissfully cool current trying not to think about the stingrays, electric eels and piranhas that were sharing the water. We retreated to our island in the evening, and I faded into sleep listening to African drums in the village.
The next morning, I woke to the sound of someone sweeping leaves on the ground outside my bungalow. A few yards away, the river was in full voice, with women washing pots and doing laundry on the rocks and children bathing on steps carved out of the riverbank. Outboard motors roared.
Within the hour we were in our own boat, heading upstream to explore the Gran Rio, which meets the Pikin at Asindohopo to form the Suriname River. Seven of us, including our crew, were packed into a pencil-thin 30-foot canoe. Petrus, our navigator, sat in the bow signaling directions to Sami, who was steering in the stern and couldn't see around us or hear above the aged Evinrude. We rocked alarmingly as we threaded through the rocks, and I wasn't encouraged to see the river pulsing though a hole in the side of the boat. A boy at Sami's feet bailed with a gourd.
Very shortly, we came up to some magnificent falls and rock-strewn rapids with swaying pink flowers growing out of the water. This was the tamest of a gantlet of rapids that are typical of Suriname's rivers and guard the interior as effectively as castle ramparts. Sami asked us to carry our things around them and we watched as the three of them motored and muscled the sliver of boat through the current.
In the peaceful interludes, the jungle closes in on the river. Yellow orchids and purple flowering lianas mix with the trees in hanging tapestries. Chattering squirrel monkeys jostled them from behind like a troupe of children eager to perform. White-banded swallows skimmed the water in front of us, passing electric blue butterflies that flashed like river beacons.
A hammering noise announced the village of Cayana. We landed and slid up the muddy steps. Almost immediately, we ran into the headman, humming to himself as he used an adz to shape a boat out of a tree trunk.
He was hugely amused by our admiration. Art is an integral part of Saramaccan life. Women draw designs on their cassava cakes, embroider capes and sew a kaleidoscope of color patches into the cloth they wear. The men are wood carvers, and when we asked to see some of their work, a flood of decoratively carved peanut boards, paddles, stools and stirrers was unleashed.
I wandered off to look at the individually carved door frames on each hut. The ground in the village was immaculate; it's swept several times a day. In a clearing, I ran into a life-size, cotton-draped ancestor figure with cowry shell eyes standing like a ghostly guardian over this quiet sense of order.
Tradition is dying faster in Kwamalasamutu, an Indian village 25 miles north of the Brazilian border in southwestern Suriname. We flew to this nearly impenetrable corner of the country the next day in a cargo plane. Kwamala, as many refer to it, appeared suddenly, a bald spot in the boundless green canopy where dozens of acres of forest had been cleared. The Tirio Indians normally live in small family groups, but since the 1970's, missionaries bent on efficiency have gathered them in a supervillage of more than 1,000 people.
The airstrip ran downhill, and we came to a halt in the bosom of an eager crowd. They unloaded our duffels, hammocks and food to make room for the macaws, monkeys, reptiles, headdresses and handiwork that they were sending to the capital for sale.
We headed off to our allotted house, which was famous for the tarantulas that were once found nesting in its roof. It was a flimsy looking two-story wood-and-thatch building on stilts. By now our group had grown to 10, and we all raced for a space upstairs, crowding out the breeze and threatening to overload the support poles with our hammocks. I sorely missed my bed, but took comfort in the ear plugs someone lent me.
Nine tribes -- some from Brazil -- live together in this village, though their differences are not immediately apparent. A few years ago, the missionaries gave out T-shirts and shorts from some global wardrobe and everyone was dressed alike. Kamanya, a shaman in a baseball cap, came to our house offering to give us a tour of medicinal plants.
We followed him past a huge conical palm thatched meeting house, where young voices piped out hymns, and past boys shooting arrows at lizards. After walking more than a mile through abandoned fields, we reached some new-growth forest. Because of language problems, I missed the fine points of the botanical tour, though it was clear from Kamanya's pantomime that he could cure most any part of my body -- or poison me, if he chose. He was fastidious about his jeans and polo shirt, and I wondered how much longer his people would care about this botanical treasure house.
By now, I was ready to see uninhabited rain forest, and we flew the next day to Raleigh Falls in the Central Suriname Nature Reserve. Last year, the government expanded this park, making it possibly the largest protected area of rain forest in the world -- four million acres, bigger than New Jersey.
The view out the Cessna window was primeval. Outcrops of the Guayana Shield, a two-billion-year-old geological formation, rise above the rain forest in tabletop mountain ranges where scientists believe unidentified plants and animals are waiting to be discovered. Vertiginous waterfalls pound down their slopes and are swallowed up in the forest. Poised above the treetops at the edge of a cliff sits an eerily eroded land form called the Devil's Egg, seemingly left behind by a giant pterosaur.
We landed on a barely visible grass strip, and as we prepared to carry our gear to a camp three miles away, we heard some strange hooting in the forest. Recognizing a monkey when I hear one, I raced down the muddy path and off into the woods, only to stumble on three researchers, who'd been signaling each other. They were gathered around a mixed troupe of squirrel monkeys and tufted capuchins waking up from an afternoon siesta in a swamp.
A diminutive fur ball with a long loopy tail sprang into a nearby tree. It flashed its white face and gray cap in our direction, and I was captivated. Suddenly, the trees began to dance, and shapes flew around like spitballs in an unsupervised classroom. On the ground, the two kinds of monkeys wrestled together in a ball before disappearing into the jungle.
I rejoined the others to climb the towering, granite Voltzberg -- 750 feet straight up -- in time to see the sunset. The top afforded us a view of rain showers and sun, and mist and clouds competing for domain over different parts of the forest. Immediately below us, spider monkeys called to each other as they fed in the treetops. Flocks of emerald parrots and screeching scarlet macaws flew by.
Then the unearthly roar of a howler monkey rose up from the forest, and I felt as far away -- and yet as much at home -- as I could be.
 
A land of deep jungles and friendly people
Guidebooks to Suriname are hard to come by, but a few good ones are "Tales of a Shaman's Apprentice" by Mark J. Plotkin (Penquin, 1994, $11.95), "Maroon Arts" by Sally Price and Richard Price (Beacon, 1999, $37.50) and "The Guide to Suriname" by Roy Tjin and Els Schellekens (Brasa, 1999), $15 from Sranan Sari, Post Office Box 6545, San Rafael, Calif. 94903 or by e-mail at sranansani@aol.com.
When going to any tropical rain forest, you should consult with a doctor about taking malaria medicine, and that is the case as well in the Suriname interior.
 
Getting There
All flights to Suriname from the United States leave from Miami. Suriname Airways, (800) 327-6864, and Air ALM, (800) 327-7230, fly to Suriname via Curacao every Sunday, Tuesday and Thursday in a code-share arrangement. Round-trip fares, based on a week's stay, start at $655.
A visa is required and costs $45 from the Suriname Consulate, 7235 Northwest 19th Street, Suite A, Miami, Fla. 33126, (305) 593-2697, or the Suriname Embassy, Van Ness Center, Suite 460, 4301 Connecticut Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20008; (202) 244-7488.
The Oceanic Society, Fort Mason Center, Building E, San Francisco, Calif. 94123, (800) 326-7491, fax (415) 474-3395, offers package tours to Suriname. One to the interior is planned for March 2 to 17. Others to the coast are hands-on research trips offering the chance to escort turtle hatchlings to the sea. The cost of a 15-day trip is $2,590, including air fare from Miami and in-country travel and lodging.
There are no roads in 85 percent of Suriname, so independent travel requires flexibility and time. Travel agencies in Paramaribo organize visits to the nature reserves and villages in the interior for roughly $100 a day, including air and boat travel and lodging.
The best-known of these agencies in Paramaribo are the Movement for Ecotourism, known as Mets, Anton Dratenweg 7, (597) 477-088, fax (597) 422-332, www.metsresorts
.com, and the Foundation for Nature Preservation in Suriname, or Stinasu, Cornelis Jongbawstraat 14, (597) 476-597, fax (597) 421-850, www.stinasu.sr. Trips take place when there enough participants, and river excursions depend on water levels.
 
Where to Stay
Kumalu is a well-staffed tourist lodge at Asindohopo that is run by Mets. It has comfortable basic accommodations in six tree-shaded bungalows with small porches. Each house has two beds with mosquito netting. Take a flashlight; the only light is a single kerosene lantern. Showers and toilets are in a spotless separate building. Meals are served in a palm-thatched patio dining room, where we ate good, but nondescript chicken-and-rice dishes with fresh cucumber and fruit. Mets also runs the accommodations at Palumeu and other Indian villages.
Visits to Kwamalasamutu can be arranged through Roderic Mast at Conservation International, 2501 M Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20037; (202) 429-5660, fax (202) 887-5188. Prices vary, but a week's trip would cost at least $6,000 a person to cover charter flights, village visitation fees, and food, lodging and travel in the interior.
Stinasu runs the accommodations at Raleigh Falls, in the Central Suriname Nature Reserve. Near the airstrip is the Foengoe Island Lodge, with two long houses having two or more beds per room.
A house has just been built three miles away at the base of the Voltzberg, where hammocks are needed. There, a Javanese cook made us a delicious dinner of chicken pot pie, cassava puree and Cajun green beans. Again, flashlights are required, toilets are separate and washing is in a nearby stream. HEADLINE: The Belle of the Soft-Money Soiree

BYLINE: By Jill Abramson; Jill Abramson is the Washington editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
The gentle ladies on both sides of the political aisle are finding that killer fund-raising is one of the surest ways to be taken seriously in politics. John McCain, who must still raise money while denouncing raising money, has a woman as one of his chief fund-raisers: Georgette Mosbacher, the flame-haired New York businesswoman and socialite who is divorced from Robert Mosbacher, the Texas oilman and financial maestro of Bush p<heart>re's campaigns. While McCain brags about his small Internet donations, Georgette Mosbacher is gathering a windfall of $1,000 checks. Bill Bradley's financial Rolodex was built by Betty Sapoch, a New Jersey grandmother. Her fund-raising team surprised everyone last year by keeping pace with Al Gore's money machine. Beth Dozoretz, a top Clinton-Gore fund-raiser, became the Democratic Party's first female finance chairman early in 1999, though she left the job 10 months later after a reshuffling of the Democratic National Committee's leadership.
Men have traditionally dominated fund-raising because they have traditionally dominated everything, but Bob Strauss, the former Democratic Party chairman and a legendary fund-raiser, says women are probably better at it than men, because they are better at making people comfortable -- comfortable with signing very large checks. "It takes a lot of care and feeding," he says. 
 Julie Finley would disagree with Strauss about a lot of things, but not about that. Finley is the co-chairman and top fund-raiser for Team 100, the elite club of $100,000-plus donors for the Republican Party. She is, you might say, the queen of soft money -- soft money being the large and unrestricted contributions that flow from the rich and powerful to the political parties, to be used for things like voter-registration drives and party advertising, much of this being barely disguised television spots for candidates. Even as Senator McCain is trying to break his party and the system of its dependence on soft dollars, Republicans are counting on Finley to help build a record war chest -- tens of millions of dollars -- to help the party maintain control of the House and Senate and win back the White House.
One Saturday earlier this month, Finley could be found going about her work at the exclusive Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, Fla. Yachts sailed by. Washington players -- Senator Pete Domenici, for instance, who wields enormous influence over taxes, appropriations and most other matters having to do with the federal budget -- strolled around in yellow-and-purple resort duds. Wealthy donors wore silver-and-black Team 100 name tags. And Finley made sure everyone mixed and mingled while she worried about the victory of John McCain -- and, by inference, his brand of campaign finance reform -- in New Hampshire.
With strawberry blond hair and piercing blue eyes, and wearing a demure blue cardigan and pressed white linen slacks, Finley, who is 62, doesn't quite fit the description of what used to be called, in the Nixon era, a bagman. Between delicate bites of her turkey club sandwich at an umbrellaed outdoor table, she dismisses the idea that soft money is "sewer money," as some reformers call it. And she characterizes McCain's talk about Big Money's corrosive influence as "strident." The vast majority of her $100,000 recruits, she says, want nothing more for their money than a Republican back in the White House.
Finley hopes that Republican will be George W. Bush. Although officially neutral until the nominee is selected -- by law, she raises money for the party, not for any particular presidential candidate -- she tells just about anyone who asks, "Privately, I am with Bush." She blames his recent problems on handlers, noting mournfully, "Where is Paul Laxalt when we need him?" Finley's lunch companions this day -- John Payson, an art dealer who has a winter home near Finley's in Hobe Sound, Fla., and Robert Herbold, chief operating officer of Microsoft, and his wife, Patricia -- are Bush loyalists, too.
Until the meltdown in the snows of New Hampshire, Finley was counting on Bush to be a check-magnet. "I see a flood of people giving money," she crowed at the Republican National Committee's winter meeting in San Jose in January. "We just better have enough staff to process all the checks." But in Key Largo, her mood was different. In impromptu remarks to the Team 100 members, she said that should McCain win the nomination, "we're out of business."
McCain has promised to instruct the party not to raise or spend any soft money on his behalf if he is the nominee. His campaign-finance-reform proposal would ban soft money entirely, but his bill has been stalled in the Senate. Meanwhile, the Democrats, led by President Clinton, a tireless fund-raiser, are busy building up their own large bankroll of soft money, all the while paying lip service to McCain's reform efforts.
Finley doesn't see what all the fuss is about. "Why is it dirty?" she asks, her voice smoky with Marlboros and, as Fitzgerald wrote of Daisy, full of money. "Every dollar is reported. It's not like it comes slipping under the door in a bundle."
Julie Finley is sometimes referred to as the Republican Pamela Harriman. Like Harriman, who conjured up millions for the Democratic Party, Finley has raised millions of dollars for the G.O.P. But there are no Churchills or storied Broadway producers in Finley's past. She is the widow of a prominent attorney (though a Democrat) and has lived most of her life within the confines of northwest Washington.
She lives grandly near the National Cathedral in a chintz-filled house with a swimming pool. Her fund-raising hub is a cozy room on the second floor, the yellow walls of which are adorned with English hunting prints. There she sits, using a green telephone and working her way through a pack of Marlboro Lights. Still, there is only so much you can do by phone in her line of work. "When you are asking for money at this level," she says, "they like the individual attention."
That means she must adhere to a road schedule nearly as punishing as that of a presidential candidate. During one stretch last fall, she spent a week traveling from New York to San Francisco to Chicago to Atlanta, the days filled with one-on-one meetings with Team 100 prospects and some lapsed members of the club. Then she returned to Washington to usher, along with her co-chairman Stuart Bernstein, Team 100 members around as part of their annual Washington gathering -- two and a half days of issue briefings, luncheons and cocktail parties with the likes of Speaker of the House Dennis Hastert and Jim Nicholson, the Republican National Committee chairman.
At one Team 100 cocktail gathering, dressed in an elegant taffeta skirt, she rushed about making sure that everyone was popping cheese canapes and sipping chardonnay. She checked that a big, blue Tiffany box was ready to be presented to the hostess. She chatted with Mel Sembler, the party's finance chairman, who warmly credited Finley with raising $8.5 million in 1999, and then introduced Jim Nicholson. As the party wore down, she raced home to oversee a fund-raising dinner for Senator Bill Frist, a moderate from Tennessee who is up for re-election in the fall.
Finley is herself a moderate, and she would like to see her party show a more compassionate face to the have-nots and to shed the strident, right-wing image that has put off many female voters. This can be lonely work. On a recent wintry night in Washington, Finley could be found mixing with 40 or so Republican supporters who braved the cold to raise money and find recruits for the district's tiny Republican Party, which she has been chairwoman of since 1992. Finley also gathered signatures so that she could represent the local party at this summer's Republican National Convention in Philadelphia.
The venue was the living room of Margaret Alexander Parker, a friend of Finley's who is the finance director of the Republican National Committee. Before a roaring fire, Finley greeted the two G.O.P. members of the City Council, Carol Schwartz and David Catania. Schwartz, who is firmly for abortion rights, has run unsuccessfully for mayor. Catania, a rising star, is one of two openly gay members of the council.
It may seem odd that Finley works so hard to raise soft money that in no small measure will be used to try to keep the House under the influence of those who run against homosexuals and abortion rights. But Finley has never been anything but a loyal soldier. Although members of the Christian right helped thwart her campaign to become co-chairman of the Republican National Committee three years ago, branding her a "baby killer," she says, calmly, "I don't regard that wing of the party as the enemy."
According to several of Finley's allies within the party, her defeat for co-chairman at the R.N.C.'s winter meeting in 1997 showed that no matter how loyal a Republican you are, no matter how much money you've raised for the party, the conservative wing of the G.O.P. will not tolerate a pro-choice woman in the leadership ranks. "If you don't pass the abortion litmus test, you don't have a chance," says Tanya Melich, a onetime G.O.P. official and author of "The Republican War Against Women." "Julie, bless her heart, didn't recognize how much importance the Christian right places on control of the Republican National Committee."
Finley went into that meeting three years ago with promises of support from 72 R.N.C. members. Her credentials seemed unassailable. She was a Republican delegate at party conventions in 1992 and 1996, and played an important role on Bob Dole's finance committee. Before the vote, however, some Christian conservatives spread the word that she strongly favored partial-birth abortions. (Finley says she did not and does not.) She needed 82 votes to win, but on the first ballot she received only 58. She wound up losing to Patricia Harrison, a Virginian who had worked with Finley on the Dole campaign.
It was a few weeks after that bruising election that she agreed to take the helm of Team 100. When asked how she feels about the fact that much of the money she is raising will help elect candidates who don't share her views on abortion and other social issues, she politely steers the conversation to different topics. She talks of how she is passionate about many Republican positions, especially the party's economic agenda and its priority of keeping up America's strength in the world. "I am not," she says simply, "a single-issue person. I believe in the Republican Party."
It is nonetheless true that abortion has not faded away as an issue within the Republican Party, as George W. Bush had wished it to. And the G.O.P. abortion wars do make Finley's goal of recruiting more women to become Team 100 members tougher to obtain. Jilian Manus-Salzman, who lives in California and is the president of a literary agency and a Republican, recalls how Finley tried to coax her to become a major G.O.P. donor. Manus-Salzman says she considered giving, but ultimately ruled it out because of the party's anti-abortion stand. "The party does not yet represent what I do," says Manus-Salzman. "We have to let go of the shackles the right wing has us in." Manus-Salzman has contributed to Bush and McCain. If Bush is the nominee, she says, "I want to give him the benefit of the doubt." If either Bush or McCain chooses a running mate who supports abortion rights, Manus-Salzman says, she might reconsider joining Team 100.
But if the Republicans again have a hard-line, anti-abortion platform, Manus-Salzman says she will not give money to the party. "I'm not sure Julie Finley understands my generation of women," says Manus-Salzman, who is in her late 30's. "We don't identify ourselves as Democrats or Republicans first. And if you don't get this generation on the train, the Republican Party has no future."
Women are beginning to write big political checks for both major parties, though their sluggishness on this front is a source of frustration to Finley and to other female fund-raisers. "I can't figure out why women don't get it," says Finley, who is one of only a half-dozen female Team 100 members, a club whose initiation fee is $100,000 the first year, with $25,000 due in each of the three subsequent years. "When they are asked, they say, 'Gosh, $100,000 is a lot of money.' But these are women on yachts in the Mediterranean and buying their clothes at Chanel. If I can figure it out, why can't everyone else?"
Maybe the women have been scared off by the men doing the asking. For decades, raising money was strictly alpha territory: a bitterly competitive, turf-conscious, testosterone-filled game, marked by a "my Rolodex is bigger than yours" attitude. The kings of the hill were Maurice Stans, Nixon's campaign finance chairman, Bob Mosbacher in the Bush era and Terry McAuliffe, the first pal of President Clinton who has raised a staggering and unprecedented $275 million.
"There were not women Terry McAuliffes until recently at the national level," observes Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic political consultant. "Within the next five years you'll see it change."
As someone on the cutting edge of that change, Finley seems to combine equal parts alpha and beta. She trained last summer to become a Formula Three driver, and her Christmas card had a picture of her sunk inside a spiffy blue race car. (She plans to race competitively for the first time next month in Scottsdale, Ariz.) At the same time, she can sound flirtatious softening up fat cats. Think Scarlett O'Hara trying to wheedle the money to pay Tara's taxes out of the jailed Rhett.
"Part of being successful at it is to make it fun and not be so tough and stiff," says Katie Boyd of San Francisco, one of only about a dozen female Pioneers, the top fund-raisers for George W. Bush, who together (there are about 140 of them) have helped raise an astonishing $68.7 million for him. Women are now "using our own networks to raise money," says Bonnie Reiss, a New York lawyer who is raising money for Bradley. "It used to be more of a husband's thing."
Female fund-raisers have different networks too. Nancy Brinker is helping haul in cash for Bush and is well known nationally for raising millions to fight breast cancer. She is trying to recruit more women to be fund-raisers. (She prefers to call them "friend-raisers.")
Still, political fund-raising is a rough, competitive sport that isn't for everyone. Beth Dozoretz says the best training for her job as the top money collector for the Democratic Party was working in the rag trade in New York City. "The garment center was the war zone," she says. "That's where I learned a lot of my survival skills."
Bonnie McElveen-Hunter, a North Carolina publishing executive, headed Elizabeth Dole's finance team until Dole withdrew from the race. The Republican Party has asked McElveen-Hunter to establish a fund-raising arm directed at businesswomen, modeled on the Democratic National Committee's successful Women's Leadership Forum, which has raised millions from Democratic women. If she takes the job, McElveen-Hunter will join a team that is already dominated by women, and led by Parker and Finley.
Even with their growing networks and numbers, "women are often afraid to ask for money," says Georgette Mosbacher. But she isn't. Looking like a million in a beige-on-beige ensemble, right down to her beige mules, Mosbacher makes her round of calls for McCain each day, using a list of names that her portable computer spits out each morning. The author of a financial guide for women called "It Takes Money, Honey," Mosbacher thinks women take rejection too personally. "A man isn't fazed when he hears, 'No,' when he asks for a check," she says. When she's soliciting for McCain, she says, "I don't hear a 'No.' I just talk right through it. If it's really a 'No,' I put a line through the name and move on to the next one. I don't take it personally."
Interestingly, women are diving deeper into the political money game at the very moment that some of its longtime champions are deserting the field. Dozens of corporate executives have recently endorsed the Committee for Economic Development's efforts to ban soft money. The scandals involving Lincoln Bedroom overnights and a Buddhist temple fund-raiser have scared off some prominent Democrats. And McCain, of course, wastes no opportunity to denounce the entire campaign finance system as dirty and corrupting.
Finley would like to see the campaign finance overhauled, too, but not in the way McCain would. "I'm strictly for taking off the limits and reporting everything," she says. "It's simple. You can see who's trying to influence whom and when votes are taken, who's been influenced."
There is a new club that Finley is excited about -- the Republican Regents, which is even more exclusive than Team 100. To get in, donors must contribute $250,000 over two years to the party. She says there are already 44 members, and the goal is to have at least 75 by the end of the year.
She does have one reservation about the pricey Regents Club, however. "I don't like the name," she says. "It sounds too regal."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk
