HEADLINE: The Assault Of the Salonistas

BYLINE: By Helen Thorpe; Helen Thorpe lives in Austin, Tex., and has written for Texas Monthly, George and New York.

 BODY:
When the internet magazine Salon went public last June, nobody got obscenely rich. But the I.P.O. did underwrite a few perks that give the company the appearance of new-economy prosperity. Its swank new office in downtown San Francisco includes a communal kitchen with an impressive stainless-steel fridge and a balcony where the staff gathers for cocktails every Friday night.
On a recent day, at noon, David Talbot, Salon's chairman and editor in chief, emerges from the weekly business meeting, his blue eyes showing signs of bleariness. Driving to work earlier this morning, he heard the news that AOL was merging with Time Warner. The deal sent tremors through the whole Internet establishment, but for Salon, it's the equivalent of a full-blown earthquake. The homespun, seat-of-your-pants era of the Internet -- the era in which Salon rose to prominence and which it, in some sense, grew to symbolize -- is history. Forging strange alliances, old and new media giants seem poised to carve up the Internet for themselves, leaving maybe a few table scraps for independent outfits like Salon. 
 In his 15th-floor office, Talbot is happy to talk business. Specifically, he is intent on dispelling a myth that he fears is depressing the price of his company's stock (which has been languishing around $7 per share, about half of its peak price).
Salon is not, Talbot says seriously, a magazine.
Frankly, that's what it looks like to most people. On its Web site, Salon covers culture, technology and politics; Garrison Keillor writes a quirky advice column, and Camille Paglia fires out antifeminist provocations. At its best, it mixes polished writing and a healthy disregard for the conventions of print journalism. At its worst, the writer Dan Savage tries to infect Gary Bauer with the flu. But we'll get to that later. The point is, if Salon is not a magazine, what is it?
Talbot grabs a red marker and starts drawing a chart on a white board that stands beside his desk. It is a routine that he has probably performed countless times, but he does it with enthusiasm and vigor. He lists the key components of Salon's business, and, conspicuously, Print Content is merely one of five.
The others are as follows: Broadband, under which Talbot writes Salon TV and Salon Radio. Salon now broadcasts programming put together by the Dial, an online radio company, and later this year will introduce an original mix of talk and music. A TV program is set to make its debut in the fall on the Bravo channel.
Next on the list is E-commerce, which is essentially the site's gift shop, where it sells T-shirts, coffee mugs, Salon compilations and -- coming soon -- high-end writing utensils.
Then there's Media Sales, which means the hiring out of Salon's ad sales team to other Web ventures. This arm of the company is a work in progress, too; so far the only client is a ticketing outfit called CultureFinder.com.
And finally, there's Tech Projects: the design of Salon's Web site is highly regarded, and Talbot wants to license this architecture to other Internet companies.
So there it is, the Salon media empire. It still looks an awful lot like a magazine. But it's easy to see what motivates Talbot. As the new brand names of the industry seek to monopolize more and more of the traffic on the Internet, Talbot is fighting to prevent Salon from being marginalized as a virtuous bit player. "What I want Salon to be is a smart tabloid," he says. "I don't want to be publishing a highbrow zine for the literati. To me, the great cultural models are the Beatles, Dylan, Francis Ford Coppola, Martin Scorsese. These are people who have a very strong creative vision but want a big audience. They didn't just want to stay in art houses."
As it is, Talbot is already at the mercy of forces much greater than himself: last year, he paid $250,000 to be featured on AOL, a deal that provided Salon with its greatest source of readers. Talbot declines to confirm any hard figures, but word in the industry is that when Salon approached AOL about upgrading its placement, the new price for a two-year deal was in the mid-seven figures. Given that AOL is acquiring all those Time Warner magazines, eventually Salon may not be able to rent space on AOL for any price.
Talbot's response to all this is to set Salon on a do-or-die course to get big fast. And despite his elaborate pitch about branching off into new ventures, his greatest project will be transforming the magazine itself. Steadily, he has been devoting more and more resources to flashier news, celebrity coverage and gossip to attract a wider audience. But his nascent empire -- and along with it the whole idea of an independent Internet media company holding its own against the conglomerates -- will amount to very little if he can't strike the right balance between rewarding his loyal readers and pandering to the masses.
The first thing everybody mentions about Talbot is his charisma. There is a Clinton-like aspect to his character -- I like an audience that claps," he says at one point -- and in his presence, it's hard not to be won over by nearly everything he says. He thrives on creative tension, a talent he probably learned from being brought up in a highly polarized household. Talbot's father, a talented Hollywood actor who never made it big, was a Goldwater man and used to drag the children to Nixon rallies. His mother, an ex-showgirl, supported Kennedy, Johnson and the Great Society. (His sister, Margaret, is a contributing writer for The Times Magazine.) In terms of political leanings, David took after his mother -- he grew up into a lefty journalist, collaborated on a book about Americans' sexual habits and eventually went to work as an editor at Mother Jones. But he never did quite fit the mold; one of his articles in the early 1980's suggested that the emerging entrepreneurial culture of Silicon Valley might have socially liberating effects.
In 1986, Talbot was recruited to The San Francisco Examiner by the publisher, William Randolph Hearst III, who wanted him to shake up its arts coverage. He did just that, but to a degree that often created problems. "If you got two or three angry letters, it caused huge ripples," Talbot recalls. "I think the Internet came along at this marvelous time, because the media had become so timid, so politically correct, so dumbed down, so marketing driven." Talbot discovered the Web during a rancorous strike when Scott Rosenberg, then a film critic for The Examiner, helped publish a union paper on the Internet. It required no newsprint, no ink, no pressmen, no trucks and no drivers.
In search of liberation, that eternal California soundtrack, Talbot made the jump to the online world in 1995 -- along with Rosenberg, now Salon's technology columnist and managing editor, and Gary Kamiya, its executive editor -- and eventually he hired away some of The Examiner's most talented writers and editors. Start-up money came from Apple: first $60,000, then another $40,000 -- meager sums by today's standards, but enough to finance a modest weekly Web zine that was primarily about books. The business side evolved slowly. "In those days, you would sit down with somebody, and you weren't sure if you were supposed to pay them or if they were supposed to pay you," remembers David Zweig, Salon's first publisher. "It was like being in outer space. You had no way of getting your bearings."
Over the next two years, John Warnock, the C.E.O. of Adobe Systems, steered $5 million to Salon. The editors took advantage of freedom they never had before. A peculiarly West Coast sensibility reigned. Laura Miller, who worked for a feminist erotica cooperative in San Francisco before joining Salon (and is now the New York bureau chief), says that the staff defined itself in opposition to the "status-obsessed culture" of New York. Talbot lured new readers with coverage of family matters, technology, academia, media and sex. Courtney Weaver's Unzipped column was an early hit: it was sometimes erotic, sometimes just plain dirty. Talbot also provided an outlet for unusually intimate memoirs and stark confessionals. Anne Lamott, writing about everything from parenthood to spirituality, developed into a star attraction. So did James Poniewozik, a media columnist who was eventually hired away by Time magazine. Talbot assembled a fiercely loyal team of editors and writers -- and along with it an equally committed readership. By the time of its I.P.O., Salon was drawing 1.2 million visitors a month.
The glorious naovete of salon's early days could not last, however. Virtual magazines started popping up all over the place, and some had real business plans and ideas about making money. Salon had to get with it. Back in 1996, after Zweig and Talbot split over which commercial alliances to pursue, Talbot brought in Michael O'Donnell, a former salesman of software and computer games. O'Donnell is an evangelist of growth, and he describes Salon's target audience as "upscale mass market," a term that no one would have taken seriously until a few short years ago. "We're not really aiming to be The New Yorker of the Web," O'Donnell says. "The market we're going after is the market that watches 'Seinfeld."'
One of O'Donnell's first moves was to hire an enterprising young man named Alexander Hughes as Salon's circulation manager. Hughes viewed the Internet as "the ultimate Skinner box," by which he meant a highly accurate gauge of human behavior. Borrowing concepts from HotWired, he redesigned Salon's architecture to track the way traffic moved through the site in stunning detail. With Hughes's system, Talbot can tell exactly how many readers visit Salon, and by what means they arrive. He can tell what departments readers go to, which articles they click on and whether they make it to the last page. Most content providers have access to some traffic information, but few know as much about their flow as Salon does. "What we built allows you, on a daily, weekly, monthly or annual basis, to analyze whether you are breaking even on any given piece of content," explains Hughes, who now works at C/Net, a site for high-tech products. "For each story, you can answer the question, Did we pay for this?"
Having access to this information had a huge psychic impact on Salon's writers and editors. Suddenly they were privy to the print equivalent of Nielsen ratings. "At The Examiner, I thought: Aha, I work at a newspaper with a circulation of half a million people! Therefore, half a million people read my stories," Rosenberg says. "Of course, it wasn't true, but we never got our faces shoved in it." Lately, an average of 110,000 people have been visiting Salon per day; perhaps one-fifth of them click on Rosenberg's technology column. Knowing precisely how many people read his column "is a shock at first," he admits. "But once you know the numbers, you can't imagine doing without them."
Salon's editors have learned to be vague when speaking to writers about traffic stats. But everyone understands how the system works -- that if the word "breasts" is used in a cover link, traffic will go off the charts, and that articles about foreign news go virtually unread. The tabloidy stuff almost always scores high. The two articles Salon ran about the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in August 1997 attracted record numbers of traffic. Last year, an unremarkable article about the death of John F. Kennedy Jr. was Salon's most widely read item -- it got more than 250,000 hits.
These numbers make Talbot's job easier in obvious respects, but a lot more complicated in others. "It's daunting, because, you know, if Anne Lamott's page views are going down, what do you do?" he says. "I think you don't necessarily pull the plug on someone. Garrison Keillor, for instance, started out slow, and now his column is one of our top page-drivers. Sometimes you have to be patient. Other times, if you see some long trend, it does give you a warning signal. You say, 'Well, does this jibe with your sense that the writer is running out of steam?"'
Talbot got his first real taste of what would happen if he broke news in the midst of the impeachment hearings in 1998, and he was hooked. It started with an unsolicited manuscript, an investigation into a 30-year-old extramarital affair involving Representative Henry Hyde, a Republican. A number of major publications had already seen the manuscript and passed on it, deeming it irresponsible and an invasion of Hyde's privacy. Talbot thought otherwise; he and his staff reinvestigated and rewrote the story, and he put it up on Salon under his own byline. In defense of the article, he maintains that Hyde's hard line on the president's infidelity left the congressman wide open to this type of inquiry. But it is difficult to imagine that Talbot wasn't also swayed by the publicity he knew the article would generate. When it was published, members of the Washington news corps -- including Salon's own Washington bureau chief, who quit in protest -- were outraged by what they considered Talbot's shoddy, meretricious standards. High-minded Salon suddenly seemed to be imitating Matt Drudge -- doing anything for buzz. But as stinging as the criticism was, the episode also brought Salon traffic and name recognition on an unprecedented scale. The obstreperous Web site had interjected itself into the middle of the year's biggest story.
Moving into the news-breaking business separated Salon from its traditional online rivals. The editors of sites like Feed and Word quietly cultivate their own niche audiences in the hope that someday the content business will be profitable. At Slate, the editor, Michael Kinsley, can theoretically afford to do whatever he wants because Microsoft finances his operation, but he has opted not to try to beat news organizations at their own game. Instead, Kinsley says, he tries to exploit the "Webiness" of the Web, with reporting and commentary that's more conversational.
Salon's decision to venture into news and entertainment means going head to head with Goliaths like CNN and ABC on a regular basis, which is not easy to do with an editorial staff of just 56. But Salon has had some impressive moments: last month, a freelancer, Daniel Forbes, broke the story about the collusion between network TV producers and White House policy makers to embed antidrug messages in prime-time shows. Every other media outlet in the country played catch-up, and in a matter of days the practice was halted. It went a long way in establishing Salon as a reputable news organization.
But weeks later that momentum was squandered when Dan Savage, who writes a nationally syndicated sex column, was assigned to write about the Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer. Savage describes himself as deeply offended by Bauer's anti-gay rhetoric, and he set out to retaliate. Masquerading as a volunteer for the candidate, he tried (unsuccessfully) to infect Bauer with the flu by licking doorknobs, pens and coffee cups in the campaign office. When Savage's bizarre account was published in Salon, Talbot was hit with a barrage of criticism; he responded in curious fashion, posting this disclaimer on Salon: "We still believe publishing the article was the right choice, but we also feel compelled to say: We didn't assign Savage to infect Bauer. We don't condone or endorse what he says he did." Salon editors, in other words, not only disavowed responsibility for their reporter's conduct, they also wouldn't vouch for the veracity of what he had written.
Toward the end of last year, Salon experienced a surge in traffic. In December, the number of people who visited Salon jumped to 3.4 million, up from 1.9 million in September. Advertising is up sharply, too: total revenues rose to $3 million last quarter, a 193 percent increase over the year before. Plus, the I.P.O. last June brought in $26 million, and just before that O'Donnell raised $15 million from private sources. But money is still going out faster than it is coming in. Salon has only enough cash on hand to survive for a year and a half.
At the moment, Talbot is pouring his time and energy into the TV program for Bravo. To produce it, he has hired Daniel Richler, the stepson of the Canadian novelist Mordechai Richler, who created a program in Canada called "Big Life," a free-form news program that Talbot describes as "60 Minutes' meets Monty Python." Salon's program should be something similarly hybrid. Richler wants to shoot most of it either on location or in the Salon offices. In addition to news segments, cultural reviews and panel discussions, he plans to follow around Salon writers as they report their stories and roll the tape at editorial meetings. Sort of MTV's "Real World" visits an online magazine.
"We believe American TV needs a good kick in the pants," Talbot says.
The program is intended not only to build Salon's brand -- rival Slate is doing its own program for the same purpose -- but also to prepare its print-oriented staff members for a multimedia future when they might produce video for the Web site. Another important consideration is romancing Wall Street. Talbot will have great difficulty keeping his expansion drive going if he can't change Wall Street's dim view of content. "Small Internet media companies that produce magazine-style content will have trouble over the long run, because that isn't what people do online," says Henry Blodget, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who has been credited with sending stocks like Amazon.com into the stratosphere. "What people do online is look for information, communicate by e-mail or in chat rooms and interact with a wide variety of content, such as news, games, shopping, pornography or travel."
Salon, of course, is trying to offer most of these things, but in the eyes of stock watchers, it's still just a magazine. The only analyst who has studied Salon closely at all is Carolyn Trabuco of First Union Securities, a former art history major. She recently issued a highly optimistic report about online content in which she suggested that Salon's stock was worth $15 a share. "I think the idea that content has no value is changing," Trabuco says. "But I'm very early, in terms of getting on this bandwagon."
Worrying about stock prices, poring over traffic numbers, hawking fancy pens online -- is this what liberation is all about? "To me, it's fun," Talbot maintains, sitting forward in his chair, ignoring the bleeps of his Macintosh. "I'm combative by nature, and I want to show the world that we can pull this off, on our own terms."
Meanwhile, takeover rumors circulate. In the past, both Amazon.com and Time Warner have tried to buy Salon; last year, Bravo expressed interest in a bigger piece of the company. So far, Talbot and O'Donnell have rebuffed all offers. This may be because the bids were low: for a while, Salon's market capitalization was stuck at two times revenues (the average for content companies is 15 times revenues), which must have made it hard to get a sweet price. Or perhaps Talbot is stubborn enough to hang on to his creation. "My dream is that I would pass it along to the next generation, and that they would keep it independent," he says. "It would be a shame if Salon were gobbled by a major media company." Yes, it's not too hard to imagine what a bunch of suits would do with that artfully constructed "Skinner box."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 3061 words

HEADLINE: Hip Vs. Stately: The Tao Of Two Museums

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

 BODY:
AS two of the most prominent figures in the New York art world, Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and Thomas Krens, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, oversee distinct and often opposing museum models. The Manhattan-bound Met, ensconced in Central Park, and the global Guggenheim, with branches in four countries. The encyclopedic Met, whose territory covers five millenniums, and the contemporary Guggenheim, an evangelist for modern art. The stately Met, which attracts huge crowds for exhibitions on Impressionism, ancient Egypt and Renaissance art, and the hip Guggenheim, where spectacles like "The Art of the Motorcycle" and jazz on Fridays are as big a draw as scholarly shows.
When they met over breakfast recently at The New York Times to talk shop, it was not, as Mr. Krens suggested, "because we're the two oldest guys around." Mr. de Montebello, 63, has run the Met for 22 years, and Mr. Krens, 53, has headed the Guggenheim for almost 12. Their views on expansion, exhibitions, financing, the Internet -- excerpted here -- matter in what some call a golden age for art museums. JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

Q. Philippe, you have said that there will be no satellites for the Met. Do you still feel, in this era of mergers and linkups, that the Met will remain only on Fifth Avenue?
DE MONTEBELLO. We have vast collections, the strength of which is the ability to move from one civilization to another under the same roof, and that we don't want to lose. Dispersal would be a great weakening of the institution.
Q. Tom, what are the benefits of a global museum?
KRENS. It's access to audience. In New York we have about a million visitors a year. In Bilbao there are now about 1.3 to 1.4 million. In Venice, it's about 300,000. And then in Berlin, our limit's a little less than 200,000. So you have almost 3 million visitors, which makes it a fairly substantial cultural force. And it's still a fairly small space. Now, you can argue that maybe we shouldn't be programming as aggressively as we are, but the growth of the collection is related to programming. Donors are drawn to more challenging institutions.
Q. Do you see a limit on the number of branches? Can you bring us up to date on South America and Liverpool and wherever else you're looking?
KRENS. We're not really looking. If I were to show you a list of proposals or letters, it probably would be more than 50, but they're not solicited. We don't have any plans for any further expansion. There is a kind of public relations bounce to this. We were doing an exhibition project in Brazil, and I went to Brazil with a team of three. It was a major story in every newspaper. There were calls from governors of at least seven states in Brazil. But that doesn't translate into anything.
Q. The Met is constrained by its footprint in Central Park. How does it maintain its pre-eminence when it is so constrained?
DE MONTEBELLO. Well, I don't think you measure pre-eminence by square footage. We already are, with the Hermitage and the Louvre, the largest museum structure in the world. We have 2 million square feet. And our collections fit, if not capaciously, at least comfortably, in the building. I don't think it's necessarily a bad thing to have to develop plans that call for amelioration rather than aggrandizement. The public has demonstrated that it likes a sense of vitality and change in any institution, even one encased in stone as we are.
And there are any number of configurations that you can give to collections within a place as large as the Met. This fall, for example, to celebrate the millennium -- we had to do something to celebrate the millennium; I caved in -- we're doing a show called "The Year One," calculated as 50 B.C. to A.D. 50. "The Year One" is rich in South America, the Mediterranean world, India, China. So we're regrouping what man created at the highest level of visual perception in the Year One.
Q. How much of your collection can be shown at any one time?
DE MONTEBELLO. I would say 90 percent of what you'd like to see.
Q. Do you ever feel the temptation to just spread it all out and say this is everything?
DE MONTEBELLO. No. The Met was already too big a museum in the time of J. P. Morgan. The moment you're too big, you might as well get much better, because what you are is a series of individual destinations within the same place.
With major collections that we might be interested in, we might consider working with other institutions. Maybe, in the future, strict ownership of a work of art will be an outmoded concept. A kind of a general global understanding of trusteeship for works of art rather than ownership may develop.
Q. Museums all over the country are expanding, and yet surveys show that only about 10 percent of the population goes to art museums. Does enlarging the audience mean changing the kinds of shows you do?
DE MONTEBELLO. The predisposition to come to something as recondite as an art museum requires a whole set of things that a museum itself cannot give. We can help -- we can have as many educational programs as possible, we can promote, we can introduce artists in the schools, and so forth, but society has to do its bit as well.
KRENS. If you look at a snapshot of a museum audience, it tends to be tourist-driven. Why? Because we're all busy. Visiting a museum tends to be a leisure-time activity, so to the degree that education stimulates awareness, and prosperity stimulates mobility and the desire to experience these cultural activities in different places, potentially the audience is very, very large.
Q. Some theorists believe that museums are going to have to get people participating in the museum's life. One museum had visitors vote on which of two African sculptures to buy, another had ordinary people writing museum labels. Is that the way museums are going?
DE MONTEBELLO. The notion of opening to popular suffrage decisions that require a great deal of knowledge and discrimination is one that I don't understand.
Q. Yet people are voting with their feet. If there is a show of the Impressionists, it will become a blockbuster and that will look good on the balance sheets. Isn't there a danger in having popular suffrage determine blockbusters?
DE MONTEBELLO. A terrible danger. Do you realize how it limits your options? Picasso, Matisse, Impressionism and Egypt -- is that a way to represent the world? Our obligation is to broaden appetites, to cause more people to come in and see the show we have on Tilman Riemenschneider. One of the reasons I speak a lot about the need for our institutions to become better capitalized, to have larger endowments, is for us to be able to have the integrity and the independence to continue to present things that are not obvious subjects for the public.
KRENS. Our attendance is stronger than it's ever been. It's hard to say exactly why. Is it a function of general prosperity? Of a larger institutional awareness? Bilbao has been such a successful enterprise in Europe -- does that translate to, "Well, when I'm in New York, I'll go to the Guggenheim"? There may be some of that.
As much as I would hesitate to say that the motorcycle exhibition is symptomatic of anything, it attracted a lot of attention, and it wasn't designed to stimulate audiences. We did the same kind of research for that project that we would do for any. It was presented in a very elegant way. And it generated a new audience for the museum.
Q. Are any of them coming back?
KRENS. We don't tag them like whales and find them. But I do have a general sense that increased attendance may be a combination of the programming, the prosperity and image awareness.
DE MONTEBELLO. To me, audiences are second. What distinguishes an art museum from a university or a hospital or any other kind of institution is that we collect works of art. Works of art are the tangible manifestation, the highest aspirations, of man as he expresses himself in visual terms. Our primary responsibility is to the works of art. We are responsible for the guardianship, for scholarship. Then comes the matter of bringing it to the public. The public is the ultimate beneficiary of our primary purpose.
Q. Does an institution like the Guggenheim have a special relationship with its hometown? Would it bother you to see works of art go from here to Bilbao permanently?
KRENS. I find myself lining up with Philippe, referring to what he said earlier about how issues of ownership might be changing. There may be, finally, a community of institutions that, because of standards and compatibility in collections, decide, in effect, to pool their resources. It's a fairly different concept from outright ownership. But right now, our strength as an institution is very much a function of what we do in New York City. If we are to consider serving our collection, we have to consider doing it in New York first.
Q. What are you doing with the Internet?
KRENS. In 10 years it's going to be so different that there is a huge challenge as to how to use this. In terms of Web sites, probably the best I've seen right now is the Met's.
DE MONTEBELLO. I view the Web site and most technological initiatives as forms of marketing, promotion. I want it as marvelous as possible. I want as many images on it as possible. Just as audiences after World War II swelled in part because of those wonderful little Skira books, I'm convinced that Web sites that provide an enormous amount of information will tip the scale for thousands of people who are thinking, "Maybe I'll visit a museum someday," but have never done it.
KRENS. The Internet's a curious thing. It doesn't at all replace the experience of the museum as we know it. Yet there are certain things you can do with the Internet that you can't do for a work on view. One is, with the proper photography and the right bandwidth, you can look in extraordinary detail at various parts of a work of art and have access to the scholarship, stories, histories and conservation records and provenances that surround it.
On the other hand, it still is a screen in a room, and people, at the end of the day, are social beings, and part of the attraction of going to a museum is being in the presence of the actual object.
Q. If the technology continues to improve and the image is virtually 100 percent, what remains to keep the original original?
DE MONTEBELLO. The notion of authenticity. Take a Rembrandt like "The Man With the Golden Helmet" in Berlin, which everybody admired but which is no longer attributed to Rembrandt. The picture hasn't changed. It was beautiful before. Why isn't it beautiful now? The answer is simple: you've changed. The day before, you were admiring something painted by Rembrandt. The moment you know it's not painted by Rembrandt, you changed toward it. And so the picture does change.
Q. The public was surprised, during the "Sensation" show at the Brooklyn Museum, at how museums raise money from people who have commercial interests in the art being shown. Do you think there need to be new conflict-of-interest rules?
DE MONTEBELLO. I cannot answer that in the negative since it is known that the Association of Art Museum Directors has appointed a committee to review and tighten its guidelines on private collections and funding of exhibitions. There's no question that a higher alertness as to what might be conceived as a possible conflict of interest enters our minds.
Q. But the association said virtually nothing about it before.
DE MONTEBELLO. It may not say much more afterward. As far as I'm concerned, most museums have shown, over the last decades, a great deal of wisdom and care in how they've done things.
I have to caution everyone against the puritanism of a newfound sense of ethics, which to me sounds more like righteousness. One has to be very pragmatic and remember that the interests of the many should dominate over the foibles of the few.
Q. But if a fashion designer makes a major contribution and, before or after, you put on the show of that designer, doesn't that create the impression that you're caving in to financial interests?
KRENS. You're making a big leap between the reality and the impression. Hypothetically, there may appear to be danger in lots of things. If something segues from appearance into common practice, then you have a situation that may become more complex. But the fact that there is a debate, that you do have the A.A.M.D. considering tightening these guidelines, confirms the general sense of ethical operations.
Q. Why wouldn't Charles Saatchi, or whoever, want it known that he contributed to the sponsorship of a show of his works?
DE MONTEBELLO. You're going to have to invite Arnold Lehman the director of the Brooklyn Museum to answer that.
Q. Is disclosure the answer?
DE MONTEBELLO. No, but disclosure is an answer. One of the key questions is does the public benefit from the exercise? You have to weigh the degree to which such perceptions, were they to be taken too seriously, ultimately damage the public. We don't print money. And so we have to find some middle-of-the-road way that is ethical but pragmatic.
I was quite amused to read that we were taken to task because we asked Tiffany to fund the Tiffany show and Cartier to fund the Cartier show. Should we have asked Tiffany to fund Cartier and Cartier to fund Tiffany? Let's be logical. First of all, the work of Tiffany was created at the turn of the century, not any of which is still sold by the firm. The Cartier show ended in 1930, so Cartier didn't benefit. This is pushing to an extreme. This is what I call righteousness. And it's silly.
You could even make the outlandish argument that in contemporary art, whenever you show an artist, you're benefiting the artist and the gallery. You might as well close shop if you can no longer deal in that way.
Q. I wonder about the impact of "Sensation" on programming. We spoke of how Impressionism and Egypt bring in crowds. In other media, shock brings in crowds. Are we going to see this more and more in museums?
KRENS. If the material holds up over time, and there develops behind it an intellectual support, you'll begin to see it. But I don't see it as an issue, like all of a sudden there's a special space in storage for the sexually explicit imagery.
We deal with this in a certain way. For example, we received a gift of 200 images from the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation. And we've done small exhibitions selected from this collection. Some were obviously sexually explicit. We deal with that through signage, basically saying to people in advance that they're going into an area where there is some sexually explicit imagery and that parental guidance is encouraged.
Q. How do you deal with the crowds?
KRENS. There were no crowds, believe me. Would that there were.
Q. I was a little surprised to see there was an A.T.M. in Bilbao, inside the museum. I can't imagine one at the Met.
DE MONTEBELLO. Why not? I've always found it curious that we didn't have one inside our shops. We have phone booths.
Q. Are you fighting commercialism, the gift shops right next to the entrance?
DE MONTEBELLO. This is a question of aura. People who make the conscious decision to visit a museum do not want a promulgation of their daily existence. They want something different, conceivably uplifting, or at least challenging, and therefore there has to be kind of a caesura. Shops support the institution, but I certainly wouldn't put them first. I think that would defeat that impression of awe and wonder that museums should provide.
KRENS. To a certain extent, the retail activities are a necessary burden. It's absolutely for sure that museums cannot survive on admission alone. If you were to look at either of our budgets and divide by the number of visitors, the average ticket price would have to be around $75.
DE MONTEBELLO. When we had the exhibition of van Gogh in St. Remy and Auvers -- the last 18 months of the life of van Gogh -- you ended on the very moving set of the final pictures and the crows over the wheat fields. In the next room were all the catalogs and postcards. We had a flurry of letters saying, "We walked out of the exhibition in tears, a great experience ruined by the shops." And I had to say: "Look, I'm sorry we had to have the shops. Would you have preferred not to have an exhibition at all?" Because without the shops, I couldn't have afforded to do the show.
In the end, it's a matter of weighing public benefit with the evils. We are in a capitalistic society where earned income increasingly, as governments cut back, is an important part of our life. That's just the world.
 
Different Perspectives
At a 1999 lecture, Thomas Krens of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum listed "the components of a great 21st-century museum." Without knowing the contents of Mr. Krens's list, Philippe de Montebello of the Metropolitan Museum of Art agreed to compile his own.
 
Mr. Krens:
 
* A great location, with urban in teraction.
* Great collections.
* Great architecture.
* A great special exhibition.
* A great second special exhibition.
* Two shopping opportunities.
* Two eating opportunities.
* A high-tech interface via the Internet.
* Economies of scale via a global network.
 
Mr. de Montebello:
 
* Great works of art.
* Intelligent and seductive presentation with good lighting and labeling.
* Highly accomplished, public-spirited curators.
* Substantial acquisitions funds.
* An endowment large enough to ensure integrity and independence from market-driven decisions.
* Fully committed trustees.
* Staff members who believe in authority and discrimination in judging and presenting art.
* Ease of access, physically through amenities, and intellectually, through programs that deepen the experience and understanding of art.
* Ease of access fuori le mura outside the walls of services and information through the latest technol- ogy.
* An unwavering belief in the primacy of the experience of art over that of "museum as agora," mindful of Hector's exhortation in Shakespeare's "Troilus and Cressida": " 'Tis mad idolatry to make the service greater than the God.' "

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO;
It's Ben Stein's World; the Rest of Us Just Watch It

BYLINE: By JOSEPH HOOPER; Joseph Hooper is a New York freelance writer who reports on music and culture.

 BODY:
We're not afraid / We're terrified / We're not alone / We're petrified / Talk to me / Walk with me / . . . Shut up and talk.
THIS neurotic bit of free association is the theme song to Comedy Central's new talk show, "Turn Ben Stein On." Those familiar with the strange arc of Ben Stein's career will not be amazed to learn that Ben Stein wrote the song and Ben Stein sang the song, in a more gravelly version of the famous nasal drone that enabled this young Nixon speechwriter and journalist to become a deadpan comic actor and, most recently, a basic cable icon.
"My voice," Mr. Stein mused over the phone from his Comedy Central office in Los Angeles, "once my curse, now my fortune." 
 For the last three years, Mr. Stein, 54, has starred as the host of the Emmy-winning quiz show "Win Ben Stein's Money," Comedy Central's highest-rated daily show. But this winter, the cable channel decided that even 300-plus episodes of Ben Stein imperiously intoning, "I'm putting up $5,000 that says I know more than you," was not enough Ben Stein.
To date, seven installments of his talk show have run, to a mixed critical reception. Mr. Stein is a raconteur who moves best at a deliberate pace, and he sometimes seemed rushed or distracted trying to fit two guests into a half-hour slot. The mood was further ruffled by Mr. Stein's German short-haired pointer, Puppy Wuppy, who had a knack for nuzzling guests like the ex-rocker Grace Slick and the futurist Alvin Toffler just when they were finding their chatty groove. ("Get down, you fool," Mr. Stein would scold Puppy Wuppy, then in a baby voice, "Oh, she knows when I say 'fool,' it means I love her.") Ben Stein fans were not put off in the least. The show did as well as the quiz show in the ratings, and a second batch of 12 episodes has been ordered and will begin running in June.
Al Burton, the creator and co-producer of "Turn Ben Stein On" and the television executive who lured Mr. Stein to California 24 years ago, vows that the show's kinks will be worked out. At the moment he is busy putting what he says are finishing touches on a deal that will bring an interactive variation of the Stein quiz show to the Shockwave.com Web site. The show is as yet unnamed, but you don't have to be as smart as Mr. Stein -- and he was the valedictorian of his 1970 graduating class at Yale Law School -- to know that it will have "Ben Stein" in the title.
Clearly, Mr. Stein has mastered a self-reflexive style of televison in which everything revolves around a slightly absurd, slightly pudgy know-it-all named Ben Stein. But the two programs illustrate, even drive, television trends that are Bigger Than Ben Stein success of "Win Ben Stein's Money" that set in motion the current renaissance of high-profile network quiz shows. Michael Davies, the television producer who originally greenlighted "Win Ben Stein's Money" when it was just four words in Al Burton's head, persuaded ABC two years later to remake a British show into what is now the most popular program in American television, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." "Regis Philbin has not offered to pay me a cent," Mr. Stein noted.
The rekindled rage for quiz shows is but one element in the television industry's push for the "reality" shows that are less expensive to produce than standard sitcoms and drama series. Here again, Mr. Stein got in on the ground floor -- it doesn't get any more real than "Turn Ben Stein On," which Mr. Stein stocks with his own friends and conducts as if it were his own personal clubhouse. Picture a "Wayne's World" for highbrows.
"It's like that MTV show where they hire six kids to live together," said the journalist Carl Bernstein, a recent guest on the program and a Stein buddy since their childhood days in Silver Spring, Md. "Ben is really sort of 'out there' in terms of his needs, likes and dislikes. He has formed this persona that is so fabulous because it is who he is. It's quite a franchise."
Fortunately for Comedy Central, it is its core younger audience that most vociferously responds to the gentle mockery of Ben Stein, the person and the persona.
"You should see what it's like when I go to a college campus," Mr. Stein said. "The kids go berserk. They start screaming. I think I represent the cool father they never had." An even younger audience has apparently become susceptible to Mr. Stein's monotonal charms as well. "Mothers tell me that their small children like to watch me," he said. "They cry if they don't hear my voice." Andrew Golder, the co-producer of "Win Ben Stein's Money," confirmed as much: "Ben's calming voice plays well to the toddler crowd."
Mr. Stein's transformation into the thinking child's nonpurple Barney or baritone Teletubby is all the more remarkable considering that, before his career-altering role as the boring economics teacher in the 1986 movie "Ferris Bueller's Day Off," Mr. Stein was known in Hollywood -- persecuted, he says -- for his conservative political views. Those, and a stream of confessional books and magazine articles that detailed his lustful feelings for attractive young women.
"Turn Ben Stein On" is Mr. Stein's loosest forum for getting in touch with the different sides of his personality. Extolling the subtle humor of his guest and friend, the comic actor Fred Willard, he can sound aggressive, even macho: "You zing it in just below the radar screen until someone says, 'Wow, what happened to my gonads?' " Pushing a clearly uncomfortable Alvin Toffler to reveal his annual income or ogling the charms of the Playboy playmate Jodi Ann Paterson, Mr. Stein strikes a naughty adolescent tone. And lapsing into baby talk while scratching Puppy Wuppy's stomach, he seems almost alarmingly connected to his inner child.
"When I was young, I was incredibly repressed and buttoned-down and lonely," Mr. Stein explained. "So I've been letting that inner child out a lot. Unfortunately, that child gets very frightened and upset when he loses a game show, but in every other circumstance, he has a pretty good time."
In contrast to the talk show, "Win Ben Stein's Money" is a precision piece of reality television. It is designed to highlight not only the host's intellectual gifts as he competes with guests for $5,000 -- Mr. Stein earns most of his paycheck by winning -- but also the underlying insecurities that are exposed when he loses. (That happens about 30 percent of the time.) Closeted in his final-round isolation booth, Mr. Stein, swigging stomach medicine and blowing answerable questions, is not pretty, but he is real.
IN his own mind, Mr. Stein is always being judged by somebody. Originally, it was his parents who held him to a high standard. ("They were a tough act in the praise department," he said.) In later years, Mr. Stein said, his father, Herbert Stein, President Nixon's chief economic advisor, became more overtly supportive. "I would call him from my dressing room after every show," he said, "and I'd ask, 'Did you know this question, that question,' and he would almost always say he didn't know the answer. I think he was being polite."
Although "Win Ben Stein's Money" might seem like a quiz show invented by Philip Roth, both of the Comedy Central shows are, in their way, reflections of, even extensions of, Ben Stein's life. However charmed that life may be, it is not immune to real sorrow. Just as "Turn Ben Stein On" was set to start shooting last September, Mr. Stein's father died. Not long after the shooting was complete, Puppy Wuppy was fatally run over by a car. Mr. Stein had her stuffed, but now can't bear to pick her up from the taxidermist. "She was my best friend," he said mournfully.
Mr. Stein will work through his losses, on television, with plenty of viewers for company. It is suggested to him that his life has come to resemble the movie "The Truman Show," but a Truman Show where the Jim Carrey character is at peace with the fact that reality is a television show about him.
"That's the thing I never understood about the movie," Mr. Stein replied. "When he found out it was all about him, why wasn't he ecstatic? If that Truman guy were me, I'd be ecstatic."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 41; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1583 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
From an Era When Equality Mattered

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
OH, whoop-de-do and rah, rah, rah! Things are so great in New York right now! So much more excellent than before! Unless they're not. The death, last month, of the legendary city planner Ed Logue came as another grim reminder that New York's current triumphalist mood is as hollow as a plastic party horn. For many New Yorkers, Logue's name evokes an era when the quality of urban life was measured by something more than skyrocketing real estate prices, the banishment of homeless people from public sidewalks and the glitter of confetti falling from the sky. The ideal of social equality also figured in the equation.
Logue, born in Philadelphia in 1921, was among the last of the master planners to practice urban renewal on an epic scale. When he started out in the late 1950's, master planning, subsidized housing and architectural innovation had not yet become discredited concepts. They were the most effective tools used by older urban centers to reconfigure themselves in the era of mass suburban exodus. 
 Urban planning is inherently imperfect. It is also a creature of politics as well an instrument of design. Logue's failures thus attracted more attention than his successes. Because of his work, however, New York and other cities could continue to regard themselves as engines of democracy. This overarching achievement transcended the highs and lows of mid-20th-century urban renewal. It gave our dirty towns the tattered semblance of a soul.
It would take volumes to chronicle Logue's achievements, in a career that took him first to New Haven, then Boston and eventually to cities throughout New York State. Roosevelt Island, perhaps his best-known New York project, deserves a book in itself. Or, you could hop aboard the island's aerial tramway and write one in your head.
The project was conceived by Logue in 1971 when he was head of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. That agency was founded after the death of Martin Luther King, partly to honor the slain leader's memory: the word urban had already come to denote the concentration of minorities in the inner cities. Seeking to avoid the creation of high-rise ghettos, Logue envisioned Roosevelt Island as an economically and racially integrated new town of subsidized, market-rent and co-op housing. City planning, architecture, landscape design, historical preservation, technological innovation: all combined to produce Southtown, the first phase of what was originally foreseen as a much larger community of 18,000 people. The place looked good 25 years ago and has improved with age.
But I have a particular affection for a project that was widely regarded as a failure, Marcus Garvey Village in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. Completed in 1975, Marcus Garvey is a good illustration of Logue's efforts to fuse architecture's social and artistic dimensions. The group of infill row houses, distributed over seven city blocks, was designed by Theodore Liebman, an architect on the development agency's staff, along with Kenneth Frampton and other members of the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies, a nonprofit think tank that flourished in the 1970's under the direction of Peter Eisenman. Working drawings were prepared by David Todd and Associates.
Frampton, born in England, was an advocate of ideas developed by the British architects Peter and Alison Smithson in the early 1960's. Garvey Village adapted these ideas for American use. Instead of the towers-in-a-park format embraced by postwar architects of subsidized housing, Marcus Garvey employed the concept of low-rise, medium-density housing. The retention of the traditional street wall and sidewalk, the inclusion of front door stoops and the enclosed mews areas echoed ideas advocated by Jane Jacobs in her epochal 1961 book, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities." In 1973, the design was displayed in a show at the Museum of Modern Art called "A New Chance for Housing."
Logue and his contemporaries struggled against the winds of changing opinion. After Jacobs's assault on conventional planning, and with the preservation movement on the rise, planners could no longer count on the public to be grateful for their inventions. People were as likely to react as victims of government high-handedness as they were to react as beneficiaries of enlightened largesse. By the end of the decade, even many architects and planners had come to doubt the value and the intentions of urban renewal. In 1971, Robert Goodman, a Boston architect, published a book called "After the Planners." Describing planners as soft cops, Goodman pummeled his profession for undertaking projects as a means to prevent radical change and to perpetuate oppression in the cities. He accused Logue, in particular, of removing the poor to redevelop central city areas for a more affluent clientele.
Forty years after Jacobs, however, a different set of issues must be confronted. The insights of Logue's critics, however fresh they once were, have hardened into a set of assumptions that have impaired New York's capacity to reckon responsibly with change. The decentralization of authority in the planning process, for example, began with the virtuous goal of empowering local communities to shape their own futures. It has resulted in the capitulation of city planning to the private sector and its market-driven pressures. So-called contextual design, which began in part as a way to ward off invasion by urban master planners, has become a camouflage that enables the free market to conduct more tasteful invasions.
In the present dispensation, we're supposed to applaud the collapse of planning as a victory for freedom. No more big government oppressors are moving in to trash old neighborhoods and put up bleak towers to warehouse the poor, tah-dah! In this climate, the failures of postwar city planning are to be gloated over. See, government can't do anything right. Look at these awful towers with their high crime rates, busted elevators and filthy lobbies. Of course, these conditions are due more to lack of maintenance than to architectural design. But this is a mere detail to be brushed aside as neighborhood gentrification proceeds apace. And with a hard cop for mayor, who needs soft cop planners?
What's dropped out of the picture, of course, is the ideal of social equality and the energy that ideal brings to modern democracy. In the classic de Tocqueville formulation, democracy is contingent on the tension between the competing forces of freedom and equality. Without both, there is no tension. Without the tension, democracy dies.
Logue's achievement can be measured in quantitative terms. So many units of housing built. So many created. So much concrete poured. Architecture, however, exists on the symbolic as well as the material plane. The physical reality and the metaphoric value of buildings reinforce each other. In public works, architecture becomes part of the social contract. Some people can be housed. Others can see that people are being housed. From both, an entire city can derive a sense of civic pride.
SO what if Marcus Garvey was a flop? The project nonetheless embodied a faith in the city's talent for continuous reinvention. Success is a relative concept. Accusations of failure can arise from measuring new buildings against a pre-existing standard, often nostalgic, of what constitutes success. But experimentation is also a measure of success. It is a standard that gauges our willingness to venture into the unknown. This, too, is a source of civic pride.
Logue and his generation of planners can be faulted for embracing too uncritically the postwar mythology of progress. But the entire culture was trapped within that myth. It was a powerful symbolic language, drawn on by appliance manufacturers, nuclear scientists, the Mickey Mouse Club, progressive architecture and modern art. Like cultural workers in other fields, Logue and his contemporaries manipulated the symbols of their time toward the needs of an evolving present.
Today, of course, the climate of opinion has shifted to the opposite pole, trapping the city in a theme park mythology of its past. Market pressures have cultivated a demand for ersatz prewar apartment buildings. The status quo is sacred. Kneel but don't touch. Architectural preservation began as an expression of liberal conscience. It has devolved into a deeply reactionary mode of self-deception. It masks the failure of the liberal imagination to address the social justice side of the democratic equation. Who cares about housing when we can rescue a landmark building, throw a fabulous party inside it and toast our sense of public spirit?
Logue's generation can also be critized for relying too heavily on the analogy with disease. Routinely, they compared slums to cancer, and saw themselves a surgeons attempting to cut out or arrest tumors. This attitude helped to solidify the popular image of the city as a victim, a permanent casualty of the postwar decades. In fact, due in no small part to Logue's efforts, the city might better have defined itself as a survivor, a victor entitled to infinite self-esteem.
If it works, break it! That subversive message is struggling to be heard today, as the city confronts the continuing pressures of urban decentralization. Risk failure, risk criticism, risk losing it all. Rage against inertia. Revel in imperfection. Otherwise, the city risks losing its democratic rationale.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1366 words

HEADLINE: In Philadelphia, a Speculative Office Project Begins

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
THE first speculative office project in almost a decade is under way in downtown Philadelphia, as a 20-story building atop a commuter railroad hub is about to be stripped down to its steel skeleton.
When the renovation at the southwest corner of 16th Street and John F. Kennedy Boulevard is complete, its owners say the building, Four Penn Center, will be a brand-new structure using the steel framework of its predecessor. It will be the first office project since 1992 that was begun without tenants already signed to leases for a significant part of the building. 
 Leggat McCall Properties L.L.C., of Boston, purchased the building for $12.3 million last December from the government of Singapore, according to the contract of sale filed with the office of the city's Recorder of Deeds. Leggat McCall said it had budgeted an additional $70 million for the reconstruction. Downtown office space, in short supply after two strong years of leasing activity, has been further depleted by the removal of 15 older office buildings from the city's inventory. Six have been converted to hotels; the rest have been converted into apartment houses, with developers taking advantage of a 10-year tax abatement program.
These and other losses have depleted 10 percent of what had been in 1990 the city's 40.5 million square feet of office space, according to Grubb & Ellis, the real estate services company. As of Dec. 31, Grubb & Ellis reported, the downtown office vacancy rate was 9.5 percent, compared with 13.1 percent a year earlier.
At Four Penn Center, work began this month on asbestos removal, said C. Craig Guers, a Leggat McCall senior vice president, and the building is expected to reopen in the spring of 2001 with 400,000 square feet of space. The building, which sits above the tracks and platforms of Suburban Station, a hub for regional rail and subway lines, is just two blocks from City Hall and the municipal and criminal courts.
Mr. Guers said he expected annual rents in his building to be about $26 a square foot, nearly 20 percent less than the rents of up to $32 asked in the city's newest buildings, most of which were completed between 1989 and 1992.
There are advantages to not trying to build a new structure, however. "I shave 12 months off the project by the steel already being in place," he said. "Brand-new construction, including approvals and design, would be a 30- to 40-month process. We're doing this in 15 months and we feel that's a manageable time frame and economical because the West Market Street corridor has a 7 percent vacancy rate."
MR. GUERS estimated that the renovation, including new building systems, wiring, elevators and climate controls, would cost about $155 a square foot, adding that he looked for mid-sized law firms to be among his tenants.
He said he knew that some had leases expiring in the coming year because they had signed leases with him a decade ago, when he worked at other Penn Center buildings as a development manager for Radnor Corporation, the former real estate development arm of Sun Oil Company.
"Downtown rents were in the low $20's two years ago," Mr. Guers said. "Then, in 1999, absorption set a record for the decade and vacancy dropped by 25 percent in about six months. Leggat McCall's biggest strength is in renovation -- we do it from Boston to Washington -- and our people went through the building and figured out how to make it work."
Leggat McCall has new construction projects in the Philadelphia suburbs, including Plymouth Meeting, Pa., and Mount Laurel, N.J., that stress quick construction in established markets where there is room for relatively small buildings.
While his company is willing to take small risks for small rewards, he said, it is not willing to overextend itself on huge projects involving large loans. Now, Mr. Guers said, there is a greater emphasis than in the city's last building boom in the late 80's on smaller, more efficient buildings closer to amenities such as hotels, shops and restaurants and outfitted with premium systems such as high-speed telecommunication and computer wiring.
The Four Penn Center project is a major step in recovery for a city still shaking off the hangover of excess space that lasted from 1992 to 1996, said Wayne Fisher, senior vice president at Grubb & Ellis.
For most of those years, the city had a surplus of office space that led to price cutting and costly incentives to lure tenants as brokers worked to sublease or re-lease space vacated by takeover targets such as Conrail. In 1997, most of Conrail's operations were split between two other rail carriers, CSX and Norfolk Southern. It then became a small regional freight carrier in selected cities -- primarily in the Northeast, but including Detroit -- and subleased 100,000 square feet of its former 850,000 square feet of office space. CSX has sublet an additional 650,000 square feet, 250,000 square feet of it to PricewaterhouseCoopers.
Merger announcements unsettled an otherwise positive real estate leasing picture. Peco Energy Company, the region's electric utility, is merging with Unicom Corporation, a Chicago electric utility. And SmithKline Beecham, a pharmaceutical company that last year opened an additional 215,000-square-foot building adjacent to its 598,000-square-foot headquarters two blocks north of Four Penn Center, has agreed to merge with Glaxo Wellcome, a British pharmaceutical corporation. No decision has been made on the site of the Glaxo-SmithKline headquarters, according to Thomas Johnson, a SmithKline spokesman.
More than 1.3 million square feet of downtown office leases were signed in 1999, a record year, more than double the city's average of 553,000 square feet per year, said Fisher of Grubb & Ellis. The flurry of leases leaves many potential tenants for Four Penn Center already committed elsewhere, he added.
"Rents aren't spiking the way they are in Boston or Washington," he said. "But we're getting a steady 10 percent per annum or about $2 extra per square foot. All the background statistics say now is the time if you were ever going to do a renovation."
AMONG the risks Mr. Fisher identified was a shrinking pool of prospective tenants looking to lease more than 100,000 square feet of space; the likelihood that Philadelphia will not repeat the stellar pace of 1999 and the constant exposure to mergers and acquisitions, which might open up space in otherwise fully rented buildings.
The eight-building Penn Center complex, which has a total of about 5 million square feet of space, extends from 15th to 19th Streets, between Market Street and John F. Kennedy Boulevard. It occupies the former site of the old Pennsylvania Railroad's massive rail station and elevated tracks, which were demolished in the 1950's.
Begun in 1953, the Penn Center development initiated a shift of office construction from the city's geographic center of Broad and Market Streets to the Market Street corridor as far west as 22nd Street.
Even at a modest 20 stories, Four Penn Center is not overshadowed by the majority of its neighbors. This is because, for more than half a century, developers observed a self-imposed 500-foot restriction on the height of their office towers so that they would not rise higher than the 548-foot City Hall, which is topped by a bronze statue of William Penn. But in 1986 the restriction was scrapped with the completion of the 945-foot 1 Liberty Place tower.
Most of the office buildings in the central business district built prior to that date have changed ownership in the last five years, Mr. Guers said. The Four Penn Center building has been empty for two and a half years since its last tenant, the Reliance Insurance Company, moved into a tower several blocks north.
One of the greatest challenges for developers, said Glenn Mueller, managing director of Legg Mason Real Estate Research in Baltimore, is finding tenants that are viable over the long term.
"The real risk is not in whether you can rent it today but whether the company will be around two or three years from now, because of the Internet and merger and acquisition activity," Mr. Mueller said.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Divided by Business Outlook, and by Race

BYLINE: By ROBBIE WOLIVER 

 BODY:
PROMINENT black business executives on the Island have a warning for the growing number of black entrepreneurs who choose not to affiliate with established civic and business associations: If you're not in the room, you won't effect change.
But some struggling entrepreneurs, like Charles Sessions of Exodus Computers, a Bay Shore technology company, fire back, "Who says it's their room I need?" 
 Despite the fact that the African-American community is aggressively promoting entrepreneurship, the social and racial integration of Long Island business has not happened.
Mistrust, intimidation, lack of interest, contrasting agendas, strained economics: these are some of the reasons black entrepreneurs give for avoiding traditional, predominantly white business organizations like the Chamber of Commerce, the Long Island Association and the Long Island Forum for Technology.
But longer established African-American business owners say that this is a big mistake, that black-owned businesses must network to survive.
Some black executives say they prefer to concentrate on their own community rather than blend with predominately white business organizations. And the makeup of these organizations reflects the trend. Although the 5,000-member Long Island Association, the area's largest civic association, says it does not track racial statistics, a spokesman, Gary Wojtas, acknowledged that black membership was "very low."
Gary Coley, the president of the Roosevelt Chamber of Commerce, which is 90 percent black, and the editor of Community Journal, which focuses on African-Americans, is one of the few black members of the Long Island Association, and he estimates black membership at 3 or 4 percent.
But Phyllis Hill Slater, one of three African-Americans on the association's 44-member board (Henry Holley and Willie B. Edlow Jr. are the other two) estimated it at 10 percent. (The Census Bureau put the proportion of blacks in Nassau and Suffolk in July 1998 at 8 percent.)
After a recent business breakfast sponsored by the Long Island Forum for Technology, the acting executive director, Patricia Howley, acknowledged that there was no black representation. She noted that LIFT had begun an outreach program to young entrepreneurs, but did not specifically seek out members of minorities. "In the long run," she said, "money has no color."
Still, she said, it is essential to the survival of black entrepreneurs to join such business associations.
Ms. Hill Slater has served on the board of the Long Island Association for nine years and has been chairwoman of its small-business committee for eight.
Her company, Hill Slater Inc., a Great Neck engineering and architectural firm, is what Ken Jenkins, chairman of the Nassau Community College African-American Studies department, calls the type of business that benefits most from traditional networking.
"The young hip-hop entrepreneurs would not be well served joining such an organization," he said.
Ms. Hill Slater disagrees. "I don't care what business you own," she said. "You must network. It's the key to survival. As people of color enter the business world in larger numbers, more people will join organizations like the L.I.A., and they'll feel more comfortable being a part of it. That's how you get contracts, information and important personal affiliations. It's how you get access to capital."
Mr. Holley, who owns Hempstead Transportation, a limousine charter company, supports this view, saying: "I joined these organizations because people do business with those who they become comfortable with. They needed to know me. I wanted to introduce myself to those who could use my services."
But Denton L. Watson, an associate professor of African-American history at the State University of New York at Old Westbury, said: "That's not really the trend within the black community. The trend is to be more individualistic. You won't find too many blacks joining organizations."
Eliza Townsend, owner of Relax for Health, a holistic medical practice in Wyandanch, takes a more personal view: "We're isolated. I never thought about joining an organization. Everything I do is on my own at a community level."
Professor Watson believes independent black entrepreneurs need to keep in mind the civil rights movement of the 1960's. "African-Americans did not get to this point by doing things on their own," he said. "It's always been about group support. No man can open doors for himself; we need some affiliation, some help."
Black civic leaders say business organizations, if they want to successfully attract young African-American entrepreneurs, need meaningful outreach programs. The Urban League of Long Island recognized the need for a technological outreach program, for example, and a state-funded computer technician training program supervised by the league teaches both technical and life skills -- like overcoming intimidation and operating in a workplace setting, tools that provide the confidence that young executives need to approach organizations like LIFT.
"Only black-run organizations operate outreach programs to black people," said Andreaus Guilty, producer of the Afrikan-Amerikan News in Roosevelt and executive director of the African-American Media Network, which plans to train black executives. "These local chambers of commerce and civic groups, they don't target the black entrepreneur. No matter how much they talk about inclusion and diversity, there is inherent racism in their organization."
No, said Eddison Bramble, owner of New Image Media and president of 100 Black Men of Long Island, "it's not necessarily racism."
"It's that our priorities are different," he continued. "Sitting at a breakfast about tourism doesn't address how I can help black men in my community. Our organization is focused on mentoring and outreach. They just have a different agenda."
Mr. Bramble ended his own membership in the Long Island Association but his group, 100 Black Men, keeps in touch through Mr. Holley, who is a member of both organizations.
Both Ms. Hill Slater and Mr. Holley agreed that there needs to be more outreach from traditional organizations. But as Ms. Hill Slater acknowledged: "People of color are intimidated. They don't always feel welcome or comfortable, so they stay away."
Some say the divisions are in fact positive for black entrepreneurs. Professor Jenkins, for example, said, "It's valuable for people to create their own opportunities within their own communities."
And Mr. Guilty, who is also known as Andreaus 13, strongly disagrees with both Ms. Hill Slater and Mr. Holley. "The people who opened the doors didn't do it so we can follow someone else's rules," he argues.
To which Sylvester Wise, professor of sociology and African-American culture at Nassau Community College, responded: "Doesn't that sound a little naive? They don't realize the significance of empowerment of organizational and institutional structures. It's the result of cultural naivete."
Mr. Sessions counters with the accusation, "But those organizations don't want to have anything to do with us." And Ms. Hill Slater comes back with, "Well, if that's true, break those myths by showing up."
Ron Strong's company, Jump Street Beauty Supplies, is in Roosevelt, on a street with many black-owned businesses, and he is not interested in affiliating with traditional organizations. "They're detached from what's going on here in my neighborhood," he explained.
He gets support from Mr. Guilty, who said: "The best way to address this is to start your own organization and push forward your own goals. We didn't break it; we're not going to fix it."
How will black entrepreneurs' opinions be respected by the establishment if they are not offered directly to the establishment? Diversity and networking may be one key to business success, but black business owners like Mr. Sessions are frustrated.
"I understand the worth of networking," he said, "but I don't want to be herded into a certain section -- a member of the black section of a predominately white organization. Most organizations are polarized. I need to be a full constituent, not an enrolled constituent.
"In my field, you see very few black faces. White technologists don't share with black technologists -- period. There is intimidation. It's not said, it's not something you can put a finger on."
But Theresa Sanders, chief executive of the Urban League of Long Island, said the league was training people in the lucrative technology field. "Young black entrepreneurs have to break that barrier," she added. "Being resistant isn't the solution."
In addition to a sense of intimidation and racial resistance, there is another obstacle black entrepreneurs find when dealing with membership organizations: the cost. Professor Jenkins said business owners find the associations a luxury.
This frustrates Mr. Holley, who understands that finances are tight, but says black entrepreneurs must find a way around it. "How will you know a contract exists if you're not networking?" he asks.
"I'm struggling all the time," said Ray Boben, 54, of Ray's Iron Works in Bellmore. "I don't have time to discuss business. Minority businesses aren't really businesses. We are self-made men who make jobs for ourselves.
"I'm nailing all day long, and there's a man who's sitting at a computer all day, and he wants to meet with me? I don't relate to young white boys whose parents put them in business, or old men who have been sitting behind a desk their whole life, people who get credit and loans whenever they ask. What can I learn from them?"
Professor Jenkins says the younger generation has the answer: "There's an energy that comes from young black entrepreneurs, and it affects people around them, not just about how to make a living, but how to make a personal statement. They are not looking for validation from America."
