SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2729 words

HEADLINE: Trek West, Commuters, Trek West

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
IT is not the run-down condition of the western end of Penn Station, nor the suffocatingly low ceilings on the New Jersey Transit platforms, nor the last-minute track information that bothers Kris Martin most about her daily commute to Manhattan.
"You know what the worst part of commuting is?" said Ms. Martin, 39, of Matawan, N.J., a database manager who rides New Jersey Transit every day. "The commuters. Everyone is so rude. Let's say you're standing and waiting for a train -- someone will come up and just push you out of the way. Everyone's jockeying for position." 
 Jeffrey N. Leibell, a lawyer and Long Island Rail Road commuter, agreed. "You become an automaton," said Mr. Leibell, 42, a family man and Little League coach in Great Neck who undergoes a Jekyll-to-Hyde transformation at Penn Station. "It's a rat race, one foot in front of the other. It turns us into unpleasant people."
But transit and elected officials are spending a lot of time and money to make things more pleasant for more than 300,000 commuters from Long Island, New Jersey, New York City, Washington, Boston and elsewhere who squeeze through Pennsylvania Station and the neighboring subway stations every day.
The commuters include about 200,000 rail passengers -- 144,000 on the Long Island Rail Road, 44,000 on New Jersey Transit and 8,200 on Amtrak, the railroads said.
Another 100,000 people use the Seventh and Eighth Avenue subway stations, and 150,000 rail commuters hop from their trains to the subways, according to the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, which was set up by New York State to guide a vast project to build a new station to the west.
The grand expansion projects would convert half of the James A. Farley General Post Office, across Eighth Avenue from Penn Station, into a new hub for Amtrak that will also serve New Jersey Transit and Long Island Rail Road commuters.
The 21 tracks, which are reached along 11 platforms, run east-west, passing below the post office before emerging into the Metropolitan Transit Authority rail yard west of Ninth Avenue. Even now, the post office ships some mail by rail, and, in addition to creating new ticket booths and waiting areas, the Farley project would expand access to the tracks westward. The vaulted Postal Service lobby for the public along Eighth Avenue will remain.
The project will not add any tracks or platforms. But Charles Gargano, chairman of the redevelopment corporation, said the easier access and fuller use of the existing platforms will increase the station's capacity to handle the 30 percent increase in traffice that is projected by 2010.
Transportation experts generally welcome the Farley plan. Lee Sander, director of the Center for Transportation Policy and Management at New York University and member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, called the plan "a terrific project" that would improve conditions for everyone who now uses Penn Station.
But Peter Haynes, a longtime commuter and a former L.I.R.R. employee who founded the Long Island Rail Road Commuter Campaign last August, is doubtful the project will have much impact, particularly since it will not add tracks.
"I'm all for new stations, but if they don't do anything underground, it's going to be very limited in effect," said Mr. Haynes, 42, a computer consultant. "My impression is, it's sort of like window-dressing for people coming up from Washington or Philadelphia. It's a poor replacement for the old Penn Station, and meanwhile, the Long Island Rail Road daily commuters, using the station five times a week, are going to see very little change."
As the Farley project gets under way -- the target completion date is 2003 -- the railroad is also finishing up a new $37.5 million waiting area in the New Jersey Transit-Amtrak area of the current Penn Station. Its modern design is intended in part to reflect Amtrak's sleek, 150-mile-an-hour Acela trains, which began limited service on the Boston-Washington corridor this month.
In one corner of the station, behind plywood barriers, New Jersey Transit is also ripping up huge concrete slabs and taking down heavy I-beams to install new escalators, elevators and ramps to improve access to Tracks 1 through 12. This separate $105 million project -- "a station within a station," Saundra Lautenberg, New Jersey Transit's program manager for engineering and construction, called it -- is scheduled for completion in mid-2001.
In addition, the "Hilton corridor," an existing passageway that links the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit to Seventh Avenue, is to be spruced up to match the new Amtrak-New Jersey Transit space, according to Ken Miller, a spokesman for the New Jersey system.
And on the East Side, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Long Island Rail Road, has approved $1.5 billion in its 2000-04 capital plan to cover about half the estimated cost of linking L.I.R.R. tracks to Grand Central Terminal by 2010. Because 60 percent of Long Island riders head north and east from Penn Station, the Grand Central connection should lower sharply the number who use Penn Station, said Christopher P. Boylan, M.T.A. deputy executive director.
But Penn Station will hardly be empty: the M.T.A. is working on a parallel plan to link the station to Metro North trains, for the convenience of Westchester and Connecticut residents who now arrive at Grand Central but would rather arrive on the West Side.
The current renovation of the New Jersey Transit-Amtrak waiting area and tracks, at the western end of Penn Station, mimics the $90 million project to the north that the L.I.R.R. completed in 1995. It added a fourth concourse near Eighth Avenue for access to Tracks 13 through 21.
As a measure of the improved access, the total number of elevators, escalators and stairways will rise to 160 when the two projects are complete, from 94 currently. The Farley project will add 46, while New Jersey Transit will add 20.
The new areas in the Farley building will not have direct access to Tracks 1 through 4, which do not extend far enough west, said John Gerber, executive vice president of the development corporation. But Farley will be connected to Tracks 5 to 21 by the Long Island Rail Road's west end concourse, which already runs from Track 21 south to Track 13, and will be extended to Track 5.
Reminiscent of the original Penn Station's glass train house, the project will incorporate the post office's vast skylight as the ceiling of what essentially will be a huge atrium. "It's going to be a series of balconies that descend right down to the tracks. So we're going to bring the natural light back down to the tracks," Mr. Gerber said.
Though the Farley project will further ease congestion, Mr. Boylan said, crowding is hardly the station's only problem.
An Amtrak commuter, Christina Sterner, who commutes from Philadelphia twice a week, said that arriving at Penn Station is a numbing experience at best, especially compared with what she calls the spiritual uplift she gets from the 30th Street Station in Philadelphia or Union Station in Washington.
"I think that this is one of the ugliest train stations that exist," said Ms. Sterner, managing director of Baryshnikov Productions in New York, the ballet dancer's production company. "Philadelphia has a beautiful station, Washington has a beautiful station, and New York should. There's no sense of anything at Penn Station. It's nothing."
But the Farley project is something, indeed.
Highlighted by a 150-foot-high framework of steel and glass rising 75 feet above the roof of the Beaux-Arts post office, the new station is envisioned as a return to the grandeur that was lost when the old Penn Station, on the same site, was demolished in 1963 to build Madison Square Garden and the office towers above. The Farley project is a kind of swan song for its main proponent, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, who is retiring in January.
"It's the busiest passenger transportation facility in the world, and growing," Mr. Moynihan said in a recent interview. "It's not just restoring grandeur. It's getting out of that hole in the ground."
Most L.I.R.R. and N.J. Transit riders would actually have to go well out of their way to get a glimpse of the Farley atrium. But officials insist that the Farley project does not snub suburban commuters, who will be able to buy tickets and reach their trains from the new station.
A new station could also be a key element of Amtrak's strategy, which highlights the new Acela service and aims to woo airline shuttle passengers in the Boston-Washington corridor with the convenience of downtown-to-downtown high-speed trains.
Mr. Gargano, the leader of the project, is also commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development and vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, other agencies involved in the Farley project. His close involvement -- he can readily recite precise dollar contributions from nearly a dozen sources of funds at the federal, state and city level -- is one reason the project's proponents are optimistic about its outcome, though some of his Republican political connections have also drawn accusations of cronyism.
The price tag, put at $484 million when President Clinton presented the plan in May, is now estimated at $788 million, including $188 million in improvements to the post office itself and track work. The direct cost of the station is $600 million, said Tony Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff.
Ground-breaking is expected this fall, with completion planned for late 2003.
The sources of money, according to Mr. Gargano, include these:
*The Empire State Development Corporation, of which Mr. Gargano is also chairman, which will issue bonds to be repaid by the lease of retail space, $155 million;
*The federal Department of Transportation, $140 million;
*The United States Postal Service, $120 million;
*Amtrak, $68 million;
*New York State, $75 million;
*New York City, $25 million;
*The Federal Rail Road Administration, $56 million.
Additional funds will come from federal loans and lines of credit. Officials said neither the L.I.R.R. nor New Jersey Transit would contribute and the project should have no effect on fares.
Just what to call the new station -- and the current Penn Station, for that matter -- has not been decided. Senator Charles E. Schumer, New York's other Senator and also a Democrat, has introduced a bill to name the new station after Mr. Moynihan, but Mr. Moynihan said he was embarrassed by the prospect.
The annex and the main lobby of the Farley Building, named for a former United States postmaster general, will continue to be used by the Postal Service, though some operations were shifted to a nearby facility a few years ago. The Postal Service will continue to own the entire Farley complex, but will lease the station portion to the redevelopment corporation for 99 years.
The post office is actually two buildings, the original built in 1913 and an annex dating from 1934, though connecting walls make them appear as one. In the design, by the architect David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the station's main concourse will occupy the space between the original building and the annex, which is now mainly truck bays.
Plans also call for retail shopping and waiting areas on four levels stepping down to the train platforms, most of which already extend below the post office.
The main post office building was designed by McKim, Mead & White, who were also the architects for the old Pennsylvania Station, which was built in 1910, and the firm used a complementary Beaux-Arts style. Its demolition is universally reviled today as a crime against architecture..
Senator Moynihan's hope is to recapture some of the grandeur of the original station, which can be glimpsed in photographs hanging in the Amtrak ticket area near Eighth Avenue and 33rd Street. And on the walls at the foot of the escalators on 34th Street, just west of Seventh Avenue, full-sized terra cotta reliefs of toppled Corinthian columns by the sculptor Andrew Leicester commemorate the old station's bygone classicism. Another of Mr. Leicester's series, "Mercury Man," is in the main L.I.R.R. concourse, near a bakery named, perhaps suitably for the crowded station, Hot & Crusty.
Will the station succeed as a station and ease communters' pain? More tracks are a frequent suggestion, but railroad officials have said the capacity of the East River tunnels has to be addressed first.
Mr. Haynes, of the Commuter Campaign, said an East Side connection to Grand Central would also be a help for Long Islanders, but he doubts it will happen "in my lifetime."
Robert Yarrow, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private organization, also said the lack of new tracks is a shortcoming.
Still, Mr. Yarrow said the new station's striking combination of classical and contemporary architecture, and on such a grand scale, could instill in New Jersey and Long Island commuters the same vaunted feelings that Grand Central does for Metro North riders like him.
"I do it every day," he said. "It's an ennobling experience. It makes you feel good about coming into the city."
But Ms. Martin, the New Jersey commuter, said what she looks for in a rail road is on-time performance, not nobility.
"To be honest, it really doesn't matter to me," she said. "If I had the choice between having a beautiful station and my trains running on time and being clean, I would much rather have my trains run on time."
But she did say her biggest problem with commuting was rude commuters, and proponents of the Farley project say one of its main effects will be to soothe those savage nine-to-fivers.
"People are rude, they're shoving and pushing because they're enduring an unacceptable level of discomfort," said Mr. Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff. "What the Farley project provides is a glorious new setting."
Mr. Leibell, the Long Island lawyer, said he is no student of behavior, but that seems to make sense to him: "If it were a larger space, if it weren't as crowded, if there were more options and easier access to the track level, and maybe just having it posted where your train is, it would make the commute easier, improve the experience, kind of take the edge off."
 
Meanwhile, on the East Side . . .
WITH access from their usual tracks, 13 to 21, Long Island Rail Road commuters now crammed into Penn Station will be able to share in the grandeur of the $788 million extension of Pennsylvania Station west of Eighth Avenue.
But the railroad and its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, are investing on a grand scale in other projects to make life more comfortable and convenient for commuters.
The M.T.A. has approved $1.5 billion in its 2000-2004 capital plan to cover about half the cost of opening up an existing tunnel under the East River to link the Island track network to Grand Central Station by 2010. Because 60 percent of the line's riders head north and east after they arrive in Penn Station, the Grand Central connection will draw away many of them, said Christopher P. Boylan, deputy executive director of the M.T.A.
Penn Station will hardly empty out. The transportation authority, which also operates the Metro North Railroad, is working on a concurrent plan to link Metro North tracks to Penn Station for Westchester and Connecticut commuters who now arrive at Grand Central but who are headed for the West Side.
The Long Island Rail Road has also added 134 double-decker coaches and 23 dual-powered diesel-electric locomotives that were purchased in 1998 for $371 million.
Mr. Boylan said that because the coaches carry one-third more passengers than the aging cars they replace, the railroad has significantly reduced the amount of platform space needed to board the same number of passengers.
Diesel trains are not permitted in Penn Station for health reasons. So a major benefit of the new locomotives, which can switch from diesel to electric power, is to spare passengers who ride the diesel-powered Montauk and Port Jefferson trains the time and inconvenience of switching to electric trains in Jamaica. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: Adopting Teaching as Second Career

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
IT is not quite the same as sitting in a corner office evaluating corporate loans, but Mary Sykes would not trade her current clients for anything.
Mrs. Sykes, a former Citibank lending officer, returned to school to add a master's degree in education in school guidance to her master's in business administration. 
 She is now a guidance counselor at Rye Neck High School -- and one of a growing number of people to make the switch to education after having a successful career in another field.
Mrs. Sykes is quick to point out the similarities in her career choices. "As a lending officer at Citibank, I was making loans to corporations and it was very much an outreach situation," said Mrs. Sykes, a mother of three who has worked at Rye Neck for two years.
As a banker, Mrs. Sykes said: "I had to analyze the clients' needs. In the college realm, I'm also doing outreach to colleges, trying to package a particular student to a particular college. You have to be able to speak well and be presentable, and in both you have to like people. I love what I'm doing. I like this so much more than working in finance."
People who switch to careers in education can easily find jobs because teachers are already in short supply, and the situation is expected to get worse. Within the next decade, it is projected that schools will have to find nearly two million new teachers nationally.
"Fifty percent of our teachers are eligible for retirement in five years," said Rita Golden, president of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association in Larchmont. "The New York State School Boards Association supports incentives to attract teachers in certain subjects like math, science and foreign language, where there are staffing shortages."
Meanwhile, some states like New Jersey and New York have developed alternative certification programs to make it easier for people who have been trained in other fields like law or business to switch into elementary and secondary school teaching.
Some experts say that the teacher shortage -- and proposed remedies -- are nothing new.
Dr. Joan Weber, assistant superintendent of personnel and administration in the Scarsdale school district, said: "Back in the 1980's, when we were also facing a teacher shortage, there was a strong push to encourage folks from other fields to enter teaching. This is not a brand-new initiative. What we're seeing now are people who have been in business and law who have taken a second look at what is meaningful in their lives and have retrained to come in as teachers."
In many cases, second-career teachers work for significantly lower salaries than they did in their previous occupations. New York state's average beginning salary for teachers was $30,204 for 1997-98, according to a survey conducted by the Washington-based American Federation of Teachers. In Connecticut, the average beginning salary for teachers was $29,506 and in New Jersey, it was $28,318, both for 1997-98, according to the federation.
The New York Board of Regents has encouraged efforts to encourage those seeking to switch careers to teaching.
"The Regents do endorse this," said Bill Hirschen, a spokesman for the State Department of Education. "They're working with colleges to develop these people who already have a master's degree."
At the School of Education at Manhattanville College in Purchase, for example, more than half of the candidates for master's degrees are second-career teachers, Dr. Sylvia Blake, the dean of the department, said.
"We have Saturday and Sunday classes to accommodate them," Dr. Blake said, "and one of the strengths of our program is that our advisers are trained to talk to this segment to figure out what they need to do. Districts are extremely interested in these people. They show a degree of seriousness that is impressive."
Dr. Jan McDonald, dean of the School of Education at Pace University in White Plains, said the master's degree program at the university was aimed at people who are changing careers. "They bring a knowledge base of the world and the working world," she said, "and certainly a level of maturity that is valuable."
Concern about attracting qualified professionals to teaching has led to a variety of other efforts to address the problem. Kelly Services, the temporary employment agency, recently began a program to provide substitute teachers to school districts. Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed a series of legislative efforts to encourage people to enter teaching, including tuition subsidies for college students who would work in public schools. One proposal would allow retired state employees to be able to continue to collect their pensions as well as a paycheck for teaching, if they become certified.
Many people have made the transition to teaching. In Scarsdale, former lawyers and bankers and people from other professions are working in the elementary, middle and high schools, a trend echoed in other districts. At Ridgewood High School in Ridgewood, N.J., two former lawyers teach social studies.
Among the career changers is Elizabeth Iadavaia, who, as a candidate for a master's degree in education from Pace University, is an intern in the Pelham school district. Ms. Iadavaia, who has a bachelor's degree in economics from Georgetown University in Washington, spent 15 years in the business world, holding responsible and well-paid jobs with companies like Merrill Lynch and Equitable Life.
"There was a real enjoyment in being in business, and I enjoyed the challenge," Ms. Iadavaia said. "But there was an empty component. We made more money for businesses, but after working for 15 years in business, I knew there's more to life than money. I have a real love for children, and I think there is an altruistic component in teaching."
Another person who changed careers is Sasha Davies, a third-grade teacher at Coman Hill Elementary School in Byram Hills. A former singer, radio show host and recreation therapist at a hospital, Mrs. Davies said she had never considered being a teacher until she had her own children.
"I was at a point of my life where I thought, What did I want to do with the rest of my life?" Mrs. Davies said. "I wanted to give something back. I wanted to teach younger kids, where it's fun and exciting."
Stuart Horlacher, an intern at Rye Neck High School through the University of Bridgeport's graduate program, had been a money market trader at Goldman, Sachs and an assistant trader at J. P. Morgan & Company. His new ambition is to be a high school biology teacher.
Mr. Horlacher said: "I got sucked into Wall Street for three years, but I started to dislike it. I didn't enjoy what I was doing. I love science, and I want to turn other people on to science."
Such enthusiasm is one factor that makes second-career candidates appealing to school districts.
"In my experience, it has always worked well," said Dr. Barbara Ferraro, principal of Rye Neck High School. "We're looking for people with an extraordinary energy level who have sensitivity. Their experiences in the world of work give them flexibility and an ability to do team work. You don't want a staff of all second careers, because you want a staff with different experiences and perspectives. You have to look at the person and the position, to see how they fit into the fabric of the school."
People who change careers often find a welcome in school districts, but cannot be expected to solve the teacher shortage problem by themselves.
"Second-career people will be more than a Band-Aid, but I'm very cautious about saying that this will solve the problem," said Dr. Blake of Manhattanville College, who observed that schools of education are also hard pressed to find qualified faculty members. "I don't know where you'll find the people you need. You have to make teaching attractive. You want to have your finest and your brightest do teaching."

HEADLINE: Towns Maneuver to Protect Scenic Roads

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH MAKER 

 BODY:
IT was a breezy, gray day in January when 21 wild turkeys trotted their prehistoric-looking black bodies down Stilson Hill Road in New Milford, past a large yellow and green diamond-shaped sign that reads "Scenic Road, 15 M.P.H." A few sounds competed with the turkeys: whinnying horses, the wind in the trees, everything one would expect to hear on a back road in Litchfield County.
But drowning out the gobbles was the boom of backhoes and bulldozers. 
 Stilson Hill Road, one of 24 roads in New Milford noted by the town's Scenic Road Ordinance, is undergoing residential development despite the protection the ordinance was supposed to give.
"It makes me weep, what's happened up there," said David Hubbard, director of town planning and economic development for New Milford, pointing out that 15 new houses have been built along the 2.2-mile road during the past 18 months, and scores more are either under construction or being planned there. "Stilson Hill is a charming road that's being burdened by the kind of development that we had hoped the Scenic Road Ordinance would soften. But we've learned that the ordinance itself is not enough."
Across Connecticut, 37 cities and towns have adopted scenic road ordinances since the General Assembly adopted a statute in 1981 allowing municipalities to do so. Preserving rural roads has taken on greater importance as many municipalities face increased development.
Newtown, with 60 square miles and a population of 24,000, has topped the state in issuing residential home building permits over the past three years, about 250 each year, according to William Rodgers, chairman of the town's Scenic Roads Ordinance Committee.
And New Milford, the geographically largest municipality in the state at 64 square miles, issued 168 building permits from fiscal 1999, the busiest home building year in its history, according to the town's Building Department. Ray Foote, vice president of the Washington, D.C.-based organization Scenic America, a nonprofit group that supports the protection of natural resources, said that Connecticut is a pioneer in the preservation of scenic roads.
"States with local scenic road designations are pretty uncommon, actually," Mr. Foote said. "But there's a definite momentum building right now; people are realizing that when it comes to preserving scenic and rural roads, the most effective control is at the local level. And Connecticut is sort of leading the way."
The state ordinance allows towns to designate roads scenic if they meet one of seven or so criteria, like being unpaved, being lined with old stone walls or mature trees, being no more than 20 feet wide, offering views, or running by streams, lakes or ponds. In most towns, residents petition the town to put a road on the scenic list. The ordinance allows municipalities to limit or altogether prohibit alterations to scenic roads.
State law focuses on the preservation of scenic roads, but many towns are using the law to hinder development along the roads. Some developers say that's wrong. Towns have found, as New Milford did with Stilson Hill Road, that the ordinance can't stop development.
While towns including Bethany, Bridgewater, Newtown, Norwalk, Wilton and Washington report varying degrees of success with the ordinances they have passed, some officials said they would like to find a way to strengthen the law.
New Milford is considering a proposal to take scenic road preservation a step farther: working with Harrall-Michalowski Associates, town planning consultants in Hamden, New Milford officials have crafted a proposed ordinance called the Scenic and Rural Country Road District; it would reduce the number of driveways and access ways cut into scenic roads and protect some of the land around these streets. It also calls for any new houses built on a scenic road to have a minimum property frontage along the road of 400 feet or have a minimum frontage of 200 feet and a shared driveway with the lot next door. There are no specific regulations regarding property frontage or front yard set-backs for homes in the current law.
The new proposal would also require a minimum front yard set-back of 100 feet for new houses along scenic roads. "Landscaping of lots along a designated road shall avoid clear-cutting and preserve existing stone walls and natural vegetation along the roadway within the 100 foot setback, which shall be a buffer," the proposal says.
People who want to preserve scenic roads applaud New Milford's proposal.
"It sounds like a good way to protect the land, since the scenic road ordinance only deals with the road itself," said Mary-Michelle U. Hirschoff of Bethany, a chairwoman of Residents for Rural Roads, a group that lobbied the state legislature to enact the statute. "This is an important issue all over the state and we sort of have to all learn from each other," she said.
What New Milford has learned is that flat-out prohibition of changes on these roads can leave towns liable for litigation. It has been fighting for 13 years with Laurie Gonthier of Morris, a stockbroker who develops houses as investments.
"This has been the longest, most expensive, most complicated, most exhausting case I've ever handled," said Jeffrey Sienkiewicz, a former town attorney who represents New Milford in the case.
Mr. Gonthier sued the town in 1988 after the Planning Commission denied his application to build two subdivisions totaling 29 lots on Rooster Tail Hollow Road, a scenic road designated in 1987. The land is zoned for residential use.
The Planning Commission had argued that the road's scenic status prevented it from being widened or improved to handle traffic from the subdivisions.
Mr. Gonthier appealed in Litchfield Superior Court, which ruled in his favor in 1991. But town officials continued to deny his request, until they signed a court-supervised stipulated judgment in 1997, agreeing to relocate part of Rooster Tail Hollow Road and to approve the subdivisions.
But now, nearly three years later, the Planning Commission is still denying Mr. Gonthier's plans, this time because of questions over septic issues.
Planning Commission members declined to comment on the case because it is still pending.
"The entire Scenic Road Ordinance was adopted in New Milford to prevent me from developing that property as it was zoned," Mr. Gonthier said. "They're still trying to throw hurdles at me, despite the court judgment. So I'm suing the town again. My attorney just filed an appeal of the Planning Commission's last decision.
Mr. Gonthier had no problem winning approval for 10 lots he recently subdivided and developed on Stilson Hill Road.
Mr. Sienkiewicz said the case has cost the town close to $100,000 in legal fees and will cost at least an additional $500,000 for road design and construction fees.
The litigation led New Milford to revise its Scenic Road Ordinance in November so it no longer strictly prohibits changes on such roads, Mr. Sienkiewicz said.
The Scenic Road Ordinance was also at the center of a lawsuit in Newtown, only it was the residents living on the road who sued a developer.
The First Selectman, Herb Rosenthal, said that a developer had proposed a nine-lot subdivision on a triangle of land between three roads: Echo Valley, Tamarack and Sanford. But residents on Sanford Road -- the only designated scenic road in town since its ordinance was enacted in 1997 -- sued the developer last year because he had planned to widen the dirt lane from 10 feet to 30 feet and put five driveways onto the road.
Following a series of appeals, the road was left untouched. The subdivision, now in its final stages of construction, has been built with driveways going only onto Tamarack and Echo Valley Roads, with a cul-de-sac accommodating traffic on Tamarack.
Some opponents claim such regulations deny people their rights to develop their land to its full economic potential.
"It's hypocrisy, is what it is," said Thomas Pilla, a New Milford developer. These people have their houses on their scenic roads, but want to keep everybody else out. It's all about exclusivity. That's the travesty of it all.
Mr. Pilla called the proposal to establish a Scenic and Rural Country Road District bizarre and unfair. "People should have a right to develop their land the way its zoned," said the developer, who is building four new houses on Legion Road, which is also has a scenic designation.
"The way the Scenic Road Ordinance stands right now, it does absolutely nothing, at least on this road," said Renee Bradley of Stilson Hill Road. "These houses are going up so fast, you can't even keep track of them. The ordinance was supposed to protect the road from being widened, but Stilson Hill is twice as wide now than when we moved here 10 years ago."
Nancy Mascio of Stilson Hill said her front lawn and garden keep getting eaten away by the widening road. "I used to have a four-foot-deep strip of day lilies in front of the house, but they came and graded most of it away. One day, they're going to knock on my door and say, 'Excuse me, but we're just going to grade through your living room, okay?' "
For New Milford's Scenic and Rural Country Road District to be enacted, it must be approved by the town's Planning and Zoning commissions, which are considering it now, Mr. Hubbard said.
"At the end of this process," he said, "New Milford will have among the most, if not the most thoughtful regulations in the state, preserving our rural roads and invaluable New England charm."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
About Sam Shepard's Kitchen

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
WELCOME to Sam Shepard's designer kitchen in "Curse of the Starving Class."
It's where father (Weston) "passes out on the floor for three days, then disappears for a week." That's mother (Ella) talking. All she wants is to run away; that is not simply her want, it is her philosophy of life. "Everybody runs away," she says. 
 And she wants to do it alone, or with an Anyman who'll pay her way. Leave her son (Wesley) and younger daughter (Emma) to their own devices.
In a daze, Emma walks about carrying hand-painted charts on the correct way to cut up a frying chicken (visual aids for her demonstrations at the country fair). That's Emma's device -- for the moment. When she spreads those charts out on the kitchen floor, Wesley urinates on them.
Which certainly gets Emma out of her daze, just like the time she discovered that Ella took the last of the chickens she raised "from the incubator to the grave" and boiled it.
Wesley, ever the obliging brother, tells Emma that she should have put her name on that chicken, even though the fridge is otherwise and always empty -- "All it's good for is slamming" -- until Weston makes one of his periodic appearances and fills it all up with half-price artichokes. Ella, who calls him pathetic, takes them out and dumps them all over the floor.
In Mr. Shepard's kitchen the stove is grimy, the floor is a receptacle, not just for artichokes, and the table is a resting place, by turns for Weston and for Ella as well as a maggot-ridden slaughtered lamb.
It's no wonder Emma asks, "What kind of family is this?"
And that's way before she's been dragged through the mud by a horse (offstage), shoots a fortunately empty nightclub full of holes from horseback (assumedly another horse, also offstage) and is reported to have been indicted on many criminal charges, including "violation of equestrian regulations."
When Mr. Shepard wrote "Curse of the Starving Class" in 1976, his vision of the spiritual starvation of America and the American family imprisoned in smithereens on a farm, with land developers on the prowl, was an artist's cautionary take on the spreading cancer of consumerism.
Although Mr. Shepard has always been loathe to analyze his work, it's not without reason that the farm is near the freeway. But then one can easily fall into an academic trap, dissecting the playwright's wordplay, innuendos and their implications. Taylor, a lawyer, talks about the marvelous location of the land, about investing in the future of America.
But bear in mind that Mr. Shepard himself remarked, some 20 years ago, that he had no "idea about how to shape an action," so that "the so-called originality of my early work just comes from ignorance."
Now that Mr. Shepard's theatrical techniques are nothing new, and his economic and psychological foretellings are shrugged off by numbed realists, the play's effect is more depressing than prophetic.
"Buried Child," "True West" (the latter now in previews for a Broadway opening on March 2) and "Curse of the Starving Class" are a family trilogy, sort of. The three, with "Fool for Love" (recently revived at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J.), are among the more coherent works by Mr. Shepard.
Only its rock underscoring, at once filmic, integral to the action as well as a commentary upon it, communicates what comes close to a Shepard style. The music, composed and arranged by Steve Bargonetti and Diane Gioia, is played on guitar by Mr. Bargonetti and it is not just a series of riffs. Sometimes, an actor stops or cues the musician to telling effect; when Weston goes to sleep on the kitchen table, the guitar segues into an eerie, dissonant lullabye.
But where's the fun?
Mr. Shepard's loony family occupies a funhouse quite as much as it is ready for a nuthouse. But the director, Jim Simpson, appears to be taking it all too seriously, and the cast too literally. Such idiosyncratic actresses as Olympia Dukakis and Kathy Bates have played Ellas, neither so straightforwardly as Kristine Nielsen who appears resigned to futility all at once, with nowhere for her performance to land.
The other actors are variously in limbo, though Guy Boyd (Weston) reaches an iota of pathos, folding laundry and filling the fridge with real food, in his vain attempts at cleansing and rebirth. It is too late for him, for them all.
An impotent performance of a play that was once prophetic suggests, damagingly, the hopelesness of making a socially essential statement. Is it too late for us all? If a playwright ahead of his time comes off as a voice in the wilderness, why should anyone listen?
"Curse of the Starving Class," Yale Repertory Theater, 1120 Chapel Street, New Haven. (203) 432-1234. Performances through Saturday.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: For 1930's Behemoth, a New Upscale Life

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
TALK about turning the Queen Mary on a dime. The Starrett-Lehigh Building, a leviathan from the 1930's whose titanic proportions rival the ocean liners that once berthed nearby, is rapidly being transformed from a somnolent, $6-a-square-foot industrial loft and warehouse into a home for the likes of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, Hugo Boss Fashions and ScreamingMedia, which are paying rents in the $20's and $30's for bare-bones space with drop-dead views.
It is a measure of the superheated market and the growing allure of Chelsea and the far West Village that such an unlikely structure at such a remote location, 26th Street and 11th Avenue, should be considered the building of the moment. 
 For older tenants, the change has been just as wrenching and surprising as one might expect when a 652-foot-long vessel displacing 26 million cubic feet suddenly shifts course 180 degrees.
Industrial and arts-related businesses whose rents are far below market rates -- including Day for Night, the photo studio that helped put Starrett-Lehigh on the fashion map -- have found themselves moved around the building or bought out of their leases as the landlords consolidate vast tracts of floor area for new arrivals. Some tenants have charged the owners with harassing tactics, alleging that they were denied electricity or elevator service. Lawsuits have been flying back and forth.
For their part, the owners said that no services had been denied to bona fide tenants who paid their rent and abided by building rules and regulations. "Clearly our goal is to get higher-paying tenants," said Mark Karasick, one of the owners. "But anybody who has a lease which is in full force and effect is entitled to all the rights and services that lease provides."
There is no doubt that life at Starrett-Lehigh is more taxing for everyone than it used to be, at least in the short run. Four passenger elevators are not nearly enough to serve the burgeoning population in a 19-story building with 1.8 million square feet of space, so the decrepit little lobby is jammed with crowds. The owners are adding four elevators, beginning in May, and that will help. But two of those new cars are replacing a jumbo freight elevator, meaning that deliveries take more time.
Yet there is undeniably a buzz in the air as the long-neglected landmark -- a memorable sight on the West Side waterfront with its undulating bands of ribbon windows and red brick -- is resuscitated by a team including Harry Skydell, who renovated the Puck Building at Lafayette and Houston Streets and Christodora House on Tompkins Square Park in the 1980's.
The owners say they are spending about $20 million to upgrade Starrett-Lehigh, which they bought for $152 million in 1998. The architect Ludwig Michael Goldsmith has designed a new facade for an expanded lobby. As many as nine new cooling units will be added on the rooftop. Louvers are to be installed in window bays throughout the building to accommodate extra air-conditioning and ventilation.
No amount of renovation, however, not even the 50-by-17-foot wall of etched glass in the new lobby, designed by Maria Hellerstein and Nikolai Katz, will change the raw-edged quality of Starrett-Lehigh, nor will it erase overnight the legacy of years of neglect under the ownership of Helmsley-Spear, like leaky pipes and drafty windows.
None of this discouraged Ms. Stewart. "She understood, with that incredible laser vision she has, that this was the office space of the new economy," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairwoman of Insignia/ESG, who negotiated the 150,000-square-foot, 10-year deal on behalf of Martha Stewart, along with Andrew P. Sachs and Gregory A. Tosko.
Initially, the brokers were put off by the building's grittiness, Ms. Tighe admitted. "The point we were missing was that it was precisely its industrial character that was part of its attraction to creative industries," she said. "It took Martha to say, 'Wow, I can bring my truck up in the elevator.' It was mine to say, 'This is a good idea?' "
"It was not only a good idea," Ms. Tighe said. "It was a fabulous idea."
The Architectural Forum magazine thought so in 1931, when it described Starrett-Lehigh as a "vertical industrial thoroughfare" in which every floor is a ground floor because trucks could be driven from the street right into the freight elevators and hoisted directly upstairs to specially depressed loading pits in which their tail boards aligned with the floor level.
Starrett-Lehigh was a joint venture of the Starrett Investing Corporation and the Lehigh Valley Railroad, whose open-air freight rail yard occupied the block between 11th and 12th Avenues, 26th and 27th Streets.
IN 1930, Starrett made a deal with Lehigh to construct an enormous warehouse and factory on the yard, reserving most of the ground floor for the railroad's use.
The structure was built by Starrett Brothers & Eken, founded by Paul and William A. Starrett, which was simultaneously at work on the Empire State Building, the McGraw-Hill Building and 40 Wall Street. The architects of Starrett-Lehigh were Russell G. and Walter M. Cory, with Yasuo Matsui.
One of the greatest challenges the architects faced was to bring daylight as deep as possible into the massive structure, where floors are up to three acres in extent.
Their solution yielded the building's most distinctive aesthetic feature: sinuous ribbons of steel casement windows that wrap around the curved corners, unbroken by columns. This curtain wall was made possible by cantilevering the facade from within, where mushroom-topped concrete columns vaguely recall the inverted bell capitals of Egyptian architecture.
Recognized immediately as a masterpiece, Starrett-Lehigh was included in the Museum of Modern Art's influential 1932 exhibition on the emerging International style of modern architecture. And it was photographed by Berenice Abbott.
Starrett-Lehigh was designated a landmark in 1982. A year later, rounded corners and ribbon windows turned up on the Saatchi & Saatchi building at Hudson and Houston Streets. "It was truly inspired by Starrett-Lehigh," one of the architects, Lee Harris Pomeroy, recalled.
As an economic model, however, Starrett-Lehigh was less successful. The Port Authority's Inland Freight Terminal at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets, could offer rates that undercut the Starretts. (Owned by Taconic Investment Partners, it too now caters to telecommunications and office tenants.)
The Starrett Corporation, which still exists, sold its interest in the namesake building in 1932. The Lehigh Valley tracks were torn out in 1966, though the pattern they formed can still be traced in the odd plan of the ground floor. The railroad itself was absorbed into Conrail in 1976.
Starrett-Lehigh maintained its industrial character during many years of ownership by Helmsley-Spear. One of the last old-line businesses to arrive was Pollack Graphics, a printing, jobbing, graphic design and office supply concern. It signed a lease in 1992 for 1,400 square feet at $6 a square foot.
At that time, Starrett-Lehigh was still a manufacturers' building, said Glenn Pollack, president of Pollack Graphics. In fact, one of his larger vendors, Dovelin Printing, was in the building, as it had been since 1946.
By the mid-1990's, arts-related tenants were claiming their niche.
Barbara Moore moved Bound and Unbound, a book dealership specializing in avant-garde art, into Starrett-Lehigh three and a half years ago, after a sculptor in the building told her: "They're dying to have people there. They can't give space away."
Ms. Moore combined forces with the artist Larry Miller and another book dealer, Jan van der Donk, to lease 5,000 square feet on the 12th floor for $7 a square foot. "It's a very collegial group here," she said.
Down the hall is Leslie Tonkonow Artworks + Projects, a gallery that arrived in 1997. "At the time, 26th Street was hooker paradise," Leslie Tonkonow said. "It was really unpleasant around here but I fell absolutely in love with this building."
When Posters Please, dealers in antique posters, moved into an 8,500-square-foot space in 1997, the only other big tenant on the 13th floor was a hospital supply depot. "No one came up here," recalled Terry Shargel, vice president of Posters Please.
Not that Starrett-Lehigh was entirely empty. "There were, until recently, virtual shantytowns in the building, people living in the stairwells by the dozens," said Andrew Bordwin, an artist and photographer who moved in 1997 into 1,000 square feet of sublet space, at $12 a square foot.
"The vast, Soviet city-state scale of the place brings with it all sorts of peripheral habitation," he said.
Bob Weinstein, the founder and president of Concrete Brand Imaging Group, said the building felt "very much like a war zone or the set of the movie 'Brazil' " when his company arrived in the summer of 1998, in one of the last deals done at Starrett-Lehigh before Leona Helmsley put it on the block.
Concrete, which develops brand identity programs for fashion companies, took a $25-a-square-foot sublease from the enormous Day for Night photo studio on the 18th floor.
In June 1998, a group of investors headed by David Werner and Mr. Karasick, and financed by Credit Suisse First Boston, won the bidding for the property. Mr. Skydell was brought aboard as a development consultant, followed by Rob Kurtz and Peter Thorsen as leasing and managing agents.
At the time, Starrett-Lehigh was 40 percent vacant and losing money.
"Most everybody thought we were crazy, especially when they heard we didn't have a prime tenant before we bought it," Mr. Kurtz said. "It's literally been on a wing and a prayer. A lot of prayer."
Their prayers were answered with the arrival in January 1999 of Network Plus Corporation, a telecommunications carrier based in Quincy, Mass. Having started at 37,000 square feet on the fourth floor, the Network Plus data center has already grown to 90,000 square feet. Williams Communications has taken 150,000 square feet for its electronic switching equipment and HarvardNet, another telecommunications company, has taken 70,000.
ALL of this equipment must be cooled and ventilated. And that means exterior louvers are needed. The Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved a plan that would allow the replacement of up to 25 percent of the windows above the eighth floor and 30 percent of the windows below that.
"We worked out this formula to achieve a balance so the building would not be overwhelmed by louvers," said Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the commission.
Louvers must be recessed behind the steel window sash, preserving the rhythm of the 20-pane frames. No more than three contiguous window bays may be taken for louvers in any given location. No louvers are allowed on the curved corners.
In any event, Mr. Kurtz said, telecommunication companies will not predominate. "We could have filled the building with telcos," he said. "But that wasn't the dream. The real dream was a coming together of media, art and technology."
Those deals began happening early last year. Met Merchandising Concepts of Chicago took 6,000 square feet on the 15th floor, including a terrace, for its New York showroom. The company designs and manufactures retail installations within larger stores for Tommy Hilfiger, Liz Claiborne, Benetton and the like.
Then came ScreamingMedia, headed by Jay Chiat, founder of the Chiat/Day advertising agency. It signed a lease in March 1999 for 10,000 square feet on the 13th floor. The company, which provides editorial content for Web sites, has since expanded its space needs to more than 40,000 square feet.
The arrival of these tenants seems to dispel the notion that Starrett-Lehigh's fatal flaw is its location, almost three-quarters of a mile from the nearest subway stop. (That's like getting off at Times Square to go to Carnegie Hall; not impossible, but not exactly convenient.) The building operates rush-hour shuttle vans to and from Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal. There is a 300-space garage on the second floor. And cabbies, ever alert for opportunity, now line up on 11th Avenue.
Michael Ippolito, senior managing director of Newmark & Company, who brokered the Hugo Boss and ScreamingMedia deals, discerns a sociological trend, too. "People are spending so many hours in their offices that the quality of the space and the working environment is more important than the general location," he said.
All told, the amount of space under lease at Starrett-Lehigh has increased in the last 14 months from 60 percent to 85 percent, Mr. Kurtz said, and would grow to 95 percent with the completion of three pending deals.
It was the Martha Stewart deal, however, that riveted outside attention.
"The fact that they were interested in the building confirmed our own idea that it was a place where well-known companies could exist," said Marty Staff, president and chief executive of Hugo Boss Fashions.
Hugo Boss is now in Olympic Tower at Fifth Avenue and 51st Street, surroundings that are a bit more opulent and staid than the image it wants to project. It certainly did not hurt, Mr. Staff added, that the company would double its space, get an ample terrace -- and actually reduce its rent by about 20 percent in the bargain. It will occupy 40,000 square feet on the eighth floor, beginning in June, with 65 employees.
About three months later, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia will begin moving in upstairs. Its presence in Starrett-Lehigh goes back several years, since the company used the Day for Night studio not only for photo shoots but for its 1998 holiday party, which attracted about 600 people. "That's how that space stuck in Martha's mind," said Peter Mark, executive vice president for corporate infrastructure development.
The company, of which Ms. Stewart is chairwoman and chief executive, publishes Martha Stewart Living and Martha Stewart Weddings magazines and produces the "Martha Stewart Living" television show and "askMartha" radio show, as well as a syndicated newspaper column, mail-order catalog, online merchandising and Web site (www.marthastewart.com).
The company discussed a broad range of possibilities, from simply consolidating its photo studios at Starrett-Lehigh to moving the entire operation, headquarters and all, from 11 West 42nd Street.
In the end, it settled on moving its studios, and its retail, catalog and online merchandising divisions. The company expects to begin occupying the space this fall and will eventually have up to 350 employees and contributors at Starrett-Lehigh.
The studios will handle photography and digital imaging and include a test kitchen and a kitchen in which food can be photographed, a set construction shop, prop library and flower preparation room.
The architectural centerpiece of the space is a double-height clerestory not unlike the nave of a church, reaching skyward and flanked by column-filled aisles. Almost any spot on the floor commands a panoramic view that runs from the Statue of Liberty to the George Washington Bridge.
"The radical thing we're doing is trying to preserve the essence of that space as you see it," said Daniel Rowen, the architect for Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia. "We are going to make sure that the generosity of light and views is not encumbered."
Mr. Mark said the company sees its operation in Starrett-Lehigh as an extension of the building's utilitarian spirit. "The product is no longer sheet metal," he said. "It's editorial and Web content."
EIGHT or nine tenants have been relocated to make way for Martha Stewart. One tenant, Chelsea Moving and Storage, has thus far refused to move. But the others, mostly printers and bookbinders, are gone.
Mr. Pollack watched as Dovelin Printing, faced with a quadrupling rent, left the building. And he has been told that new leases on his floor run from $24 to $30 a square foot. But he also finds that new tenants are new customers. "We're doing so much business in the building that I may have to stay here, even at $24 a square foot," Mr. Pollack said. "I may have no choice."
Concrete Brand Imaging seems bound to lose its space since Day for Night is out, after a legal battle over the how the space was used. The new owners have refused to accept the studio's subtenants.
Leslie Tonkonow will be gone in November, when her sublease expires. "It's an amazing building and I wish I had a longer lease," she said. Though elevator overcrowding has discouraged gallery-goers, she said, young dot-com employees stop by to visit. "I've had really stimulating conversations," she said. And with more people around, she added, security is less of a concern than it used to be.
With seven years to go on their leases, Ms. Shargel of Posters Please and Ms. Moore of Bound and Unbound can afford to marvel at the rapidly changing scene.
"There's a huge energy," Ms. Shargel said. "Everyone is in black and looks like they're 12 years old." She sees caterers' carts rolling out of the elevators, headed for fashion photo sessions, laden with "gorgeous strawberries and kiwis and whatever else it is that models eat."
The transformation, Ms. Moore said, is "going at 10 times the speed of SoHo."
As happened in that neighborhood, the second-wave settlers at Starrett-Lehigh -- the ones between the factories and fashionistas -- are feeling squeezed by the very forces of attraction, gentrification and colonization they helped unleash.
"The ones who made it look appealing are the ones being forced, in different ways, to vacate," said Mr. Weinstein, of Concrete Brand Imaging. "I really feel the spirit is leaving. I moved here because it was edgy. I'm not sure how edgy it is now."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
He's Looked at Life From Both Sides Now

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
SPENDING half your life among the dead teaches you something about living.
So it has been for Randy Niederer, superintendent for almost 30 years of the Riverview Cemetery, one of the state's oldest and most beautiful resting places, a 40-acre Victorian Garden-style park incorporated here in 1858 on the banks of the Delaware River. 
 "I frequently think of death and dying and my own mortality, and I believe I've been liberated by it," said Mr. Niederer, an amiable man of 53 whose duties include selling burial plots, supervising employees, managing the grounds and overseeing burials.
"About 20 years ago I made up my mind and convinced my wife that there is no point in waiting for retirement to do those things we want to do and go to those places we want to visit and see," he said. "I believe we should make the most of our lives while we have our health and while we can do it."
But on this cold day, when the trees stand gaunt against a February sky over smudgy remnants of snow, Mr. Niederer's heart is light.
He has glimpsed immortality. He and his wife, Deborah, have just returned from a week in Los Angeles, where they saw their first grandchild, Savannah Rose, born on Jan. 19 to their eldest child, Tara Shaw, thus taking their bloodline into the 21st century. They also have a son, Justin, who is a captain in the Air Force, and another daughter, Katherine, who is a freshman at Pepperdine University in California.
"What was really interesting was that her appearance was so similar to her mother's when she was born," he said. "It was just like reliving a moment of our lives."
While he is talking, he is wandering among the 27,000 tombstones, monuments and statues, each representing a life lived.
What causes a person to choose one path over another? Certainly Randy Niederer, descendant of farmers, student of agribusiness, had no intention of becoming a cemetery superintendent.
Born March 20, 1946, he grew up on a farm in Titusville that is now part of Washington Crossing State Park. His father, Herbert, was a farmer, as was Herbert's father, Otto.
"I never really had a date until I was 17 years old, because I was on the tractor all the time," Mr. Niederer said, recalling what life was like after school and on weekends.
He planned to study agriculture at Cook College of Rutgers University, but a mistake by the testing service -- which delayed his College Board scores from getting to the university -- sent him instead to North Carolina State University, where he studied agricultural economics.
Mr. Niederer's grandfather created an egg grader that sorted eggs by size, and he built a business around it, Otto Niederer Sons Inc. On graduating from college in 1968 and marrying Deborah, his childhood sweetheart, Mr. Niederer fully expected to join the family business. But there were already many relatives on the payroll and an uncle who was chief executive stunned him with the news that there was no job for him.
Mr. Niederer spent a year working for a bank and another at an engineering company, but he realized he had no future in either field.
One day, his oldest brother's father-in-law, a director of Riverview Cemetery, advised him to look for a classified advertisement in The Trenton Times that turned out to be for superintendent at Riverview. Despite a lack of experience, he got the job.
"Quite frankly, nobody else applied for the job," he said. "I didn't hear that right away. Of course, when we were negotiating I was told there were many fellows who wanted the job."
At 25, he was the youngest cemetery superintendent of a dozen in the Trenton area.
"The cemetery business is not glamorous, and in fact, until I became used to all of the jokes and the side remarks," he said, "it embarrassed me to tell people where I worked."
In 1971, when he took over the cemetery, graves were still being dug by hand, and he immediately began to buy equipment, including a backhoe, which he had to learn to use himself because no one else could or would. "For the first five or six years," he said, "I opened all the graves."
The current cemetery laws, which were passed in 1971, increased the amount of paperwork. Where he once spent 90 percent of his time working on the grounds, Mr. Niederer today spends 90 percent of his time in the office.
As the cemetery has filled, there have been fewer burials (650 in 1950, 180 in 1971 and 52 last year) and fewer employees (three full-time gravediggers and more than a dozen summer workers in 1971 to two full-timers and three seasonal employees now).
Plots in the older cemeteries are becoming more scarce. A percentage of every plot sale is put into trust funds.
"The older the cemetery is, the greater is the reliance on the trust income to operate it," said Mr. Niederer, who also administers the nine-acre Harbourton Cemetery in Hopewell Township, which Riverview assumed in 1986. "So theoretically, a cemetery -- if it has been healthy and viable-- eventually will sell all of its property, will have no more interments and must rely on the money that has been set aside in trust funds to generate income to maintain it."
Charles D. Webster IV, a former Trenton historian who gives tours of Riverview, said Mr. Niederer took pride in keeping the cemetery pristine "like it's his back yard." Mr. Webster added: "He combs the cemetery every day. You run into him walking the paths or riding his bicycle, inspecting to make sure it is just right."
A major part of his job is helping -- and consoling -- people who have lost loved ones. Often they are angry over the death and find things at the cemetery to complain about.
Edie Spalding of nearby Yardley, Pa., who was visiting the grave of her husband, Carl, on this day, stops into the office to say hello. She recalls showing up in tears to buy a plot for her ill husband two years ago. Mr. Niederer was kindly and patient, she says. Later, she complained about how the stone was placed. He was willing to move it. And as she continued to grieve, he assured her the pain would ease with time.
"He's a very warm and caring person, which you don't necessarily expect to find when you do this kind of thing," Ms. Spalding said.
Mr. Webster saids: "Death is so final and he makes it not so final. He makes people understand, 'Your relatives may be dead, but we're here to take care of their graves and we're going to make sure this stays a beautiful place to honor your loved ones.' And he strives to make that happen."
Of the job he once was too embarrassed to discuss, Mr. Niederer said: "I enjoy it immensely, more now than when I started. I felt I should be more ambitious and go after a job with more potential. But that was a long time ago. We look at life differently when we're young."
"I like the people who I've met," he added. "And I like helping people work through the problems they have with the death of the people they love. It's obvious when they need help and want someone to listen to them."
Mr. Niederer, who is a member of the First Brethren Church in Sergeantsville, believes in an afterlife.
"I am a Christian and I believe there is existence after death," he said. "And I also believe that our body is too complicated to have happened out of mere chance; the world is too beautiful to have been left to that same chance, and there is a purpose to life."
Despite his faith, is he afraid of death?
"I still don't like the idea," he said with a slight chuckle. But, he adds, "Dying is as natural as being born. And it's the pattern of life."
 
A Celebrated Past, but Not Much of a Future
TRENTON'S largest outdoor museum" is how Riverview Cemetery is described by Charles D. Webster IV, who was the city's official historian for eight years.
"It's one of the most historically significant sites in New Jersey," said Mr. Webster, 37, a news anchor for WZBN-TV25, who gives tours of the 40-acre "Victorian garden of stone" that was designed in the 1870's by Calvert Vaux, the landscape architect who with Frederick Law Olmsted created Central Park.
Believed to be built on an ancient Indian burial ground, it dates as a cemetery to 1685 when it began serving as a Quaker graveyard for the Society of Friends. In 1858, Riverview Cemetery incorporated and bought the Quaker gravesite as its first section.
Several well-known figures are buried here, most notably John A. Roebling, the engineer who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, and George B. McClellan, the Union army commander in the Civil War who fell out of favor with President Lincoln, challenged him for the presidency in 1864 and lost, later to became governor of New Jersey.
Buried here too is William Lewis Dayton, the first Republican vice presidential candidate who defeated Lincoln for the position in 1856 but lost the presidential nomination to him in 1860.
Also here are Walter Scott Lenox, the founder of Lenox China; John Taylor, founder of Taylor Provisions Company, which gave the world Taylor Ham and numerous others whose stones tell their stories.
For instance, a memorial to Washington Roebling II, the grandson of John A. Roebling and creator of the Mercer automobile, appears on the gravestone of his father, Charles G., and reads: "March 25, 1881. Perished and lost at sea on the steamship Titanic. April 15, 1912."
Carved in another gravestone, Mr. Webster said, is a letter from a wife to her husband who died during a trip to Baltimore, in which she laments not having had a chance to see him one last time.
Why do these things have the power to fascinate?
"I believe it's our own mortality," said Randy Niederer, the superintendent of Riverview Cemetery. "We have no idea what is beyond the grave, and I believe we like to speculate about people who lived before. And we really don't believe we're going to end up where they have."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Signs of Life Stir in Trenton

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
From the Trenton Convention and Visitors Bureau, Sally Lane can see the parking lot that is supposed to turn into a Marriott and make her job easier. And recently signs appeared there warning of a street closing, the first move on the ground toward the first hotel that Trenton has had since 1985.
"I've always understood why there's a market for a hotel here," Ms. Lane, the bureau's director, said. "I get the calls." 
 And while waiting for the financing to firm up, she has been feeling pressed by some good news: a wave of visitors.
This year, the city expects more than a million, largely because of two new, long-awaited and expensive entertainment anchors. The restored Trenton War Memorial, which opened in March, had ticket sales of 85,000 for its theater in 1999, with thousands more at other events there, and managers estimate that the numbers will double this year. The Sovereign Bank Arena, which opened in October as home to minor-league hockey and basketball teams, is expected to have combined attendance of about 600,000.
These are not numbers that would impress most state capitals. But the signs of life have amazed a city of 88,000 that was happy to land a McDonald's and still doesn't have a movie theater or a bookstore.
In concert with Trenton's thriving baseball stadium, the new attractions have led restaurants to open, brought in suburbanites after dark and generated traffic jams that boosters only dreamed of a year ago.
David Schure, the executive director of the Trenton Downtown Association, said, "We've even had the Gap looking" for space in the city -- space that Mr. Schure is so intent on filling that he gives prospective entrepreneurs tours in his own car.
A few years ago the association would go for months without a single inquiry, Mr. Schure said, "but now, between the arena and the hotel, people are looking at properties all around."
The revival has warmed Chambersburg, the Italian neighborhood near the arena that had clung to life with a handful of popular restaurants. Now, "on any given weekend night when you drive through downtown to get to Chambersburg, you go right past the arena and there are people coming from all around," Mr. Schure said.
Across South Broad Street, the Urban Word Cafe, which opened in the bleak months before the arena was finished, is jammed on weekend nights. Another restaurant, the South Bank, opened in December.
Alan Meinster, owner of Marsilio's restaurant in Chambersburg, said that after a 16 percent increase in business last year, he was moved to write to Mercer County Executive Robert Prunetti to thank him "for creating such a great opportunity."
It was Mr. Prunetti who set out to arrange county financing for the arena, built for $50 million in an industrial complex already under redevelopment. Mr. Prunetti said last week that he was talking to developers who were suddenly interested in neighboring property and that he expected major deals within six months.
Mr. Prunetti was also a godfather of Mercer County Waterfront Park, home of Trenton's minor-league baseball team, the Thunder. The stadium almost immediately drew capacity crowds when it opened in 1994, and last year had attendance of 440,000.
Trenton, it seemed, could be a destination, and the park would become one point of a triangle in a new tourism economy. The second point was the arena and the third was a Marriott hotel and conference center next to the War Memorial.
In three months last year the arena's attendance was about 200,000, the general manager, Scott R. Sloman, said. Mr. Sloman said promoters had drawn some hugely successful events: Tickets for a Shania Twain concert were gone in 90 minutes, he said, and a World Wrestling Federation event sold out in 42 minutes.
The War Memorial has had a rougher start, enough that the state, which owns the building and spent $35 million restoring it, is negotiating a transfer of some operations to Marriott. Still, traffic backs up for performances by the Greater Trenton Symphony Orchestra and the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, and with banquets, meetings and the like, attendance is expected to exceed 200,000 this year.
All the while, Mayor Douglas H. Palmer has spent much of his three terms in pursuit of financing for the hotel. His vision was not just to replace the Holiday Inn that closed 15 years ago but to build a first-class hotel and conference center to compete with those outside the city on Route 1.
The city created a nonprofit corporation to oversee the development, which has a Michigan-based developer and contractors lined up for the 199-room hotel that Marriott International has agreed to manage. The excruciating part was arranging financing for the $46 million project, pieced together with funds from the state and city and $31 million from bonds.
Last week, the preliminary offering statement was distributed, and several members of the development board said they expected a sale this week. Ms. Lane, meanwhile, hears from travel agents trying to find rooms here, mostly for clients who do business with the state but also from tourists. "They look on Web sites and nothing comes up under Trenton," Ms. Lane said. "They don't understand it."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF;
A City Always Reinventing Itself

 BODY:
HERE are two sociological looks at New York City. One examines how political and cultural forces have influenced the development of the Lower East Side; the other is a sober explanation of how and why New York City became a place of continuous rebuilding. In O. Henry's succinct phrase, "It'll be a great place if they ever finish it."
 
SELLING THE LOWER EAST SIDE: CULTURE, REAL ESTATE AND RESISTANCE IN NEW YORK CITY
By Christopher Mele
University of Minnesota Press
(Hardcover, $49.95; Paperback, $19.95) 
 The burgeoning East Village art scene of the 1980's invented new forms of cultural and economic linkages between the avant-garde and urban space. Artist and contributing editor of "Art in America" Walter Robinson claimed that the East Village art scene was "about making an 'art movement' seem more real by anchoring it to a concrete physical area." The commercial art scene that developed in the East Village was short-lived, lasting roughly from 1980 to 1984. In the late 1970's, the East Village's profusion of underground subcultures offered an environment where artists could exhibit work that was experimental, untried, and, consequently, ill suited for the established corporate art market centered uptown in SoHo. The first galleries were makeshift exhibition spaces started by artists or their friends in apartments and eventually in storefronts. By 1984, however, the East Village art scene was fully entrenched within the workings of the New York art world with over seventy commercial galleries located in the space of fourteen blocks.
 
THE CREATIVE DESTRUCTION OF MANHATTAN, 1900-1940
By Max Page
University of Chicago Press
(Hardcover, $27.50)
During his brief return in 1904 from self-imposed exile in Europe, Henry James played an eloquent variation on a powerful theme about New York: The city is "crowned not only with no history, but with no credible possibility of time for history." New York is, always has been, and always will be, wrote James, a "provisional city," defined by a "dreadful chill of change." From the time of nineteenth-century New York's great diarist, Philip Hone, who first declared New York's favorite maxim to be "overturn, overturn, overturn!" to today's Luc Sante and his biting critique that in New York the "past has no truck," New York has lived up to its cliche. It is a city where the physical remnants of early generations are repeatedly and apparently inevitably visited by the wrecking ball. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
