HEADLINE: 'Cats,' Broadway's Longevity Champ, to Close

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
After almost 18 years, $380 million in sales and untold gallons of makeup, "Cats," the longest-running production in Broadway history, will close on June 25.
The musical, at the Winter Garden Theater, will end its run after 7,397 performances, a streak that began while much of the show's current cast was in grade school. 
 The closing, which has been rumored for several months, was confirmed yesterday by Peter Brown, the United States representative for Andrew Lloyd Webber, the musical's composer.
An audience pleaser with seemingly endless appeal for children and tourists, "Cats" will have been seen by more than 10 million people in New York by the time its final curtain falls. Since opening in 1982 it often ranked near the top shows on Broadway in gross sales. It outlasted hundreds of other musicals, and will have come close to outlasting three presidential administrations.
In recent years, however, the well of audiences has slowly run dry, leaving the theater half full on some nights, with the show's producers taking losses during the winter with hopes of making a profit during the tourist-packed summers.
Reached in London yesterday, Lord Lloyd Webber said the closing was bittersweet. "Obviously, I am sad that 'Cats' has to close on Broadway at the end of June, but it is also a day of great celebration," he said. "Eighteen is a great age for a cat."
In the end, "Cats" may have been simply done in by its own success. The musical has been produced in 30 countries worldwide and seen by an estimated 50 million people, or roughly the population of California and New York combined.
Financially, "Cats" ranks as one of the most successful musical of all time, churning millions into the pockets of its investors and making international stars and multimillionaires out of Lord Lloyd Webber and the show's lead producer, Sir Cameron Mackintosh. It also acted as an economic engine for the city of New York; a 1997 study by Audience Research and Analysis said "Cats" had contributed more than $3.12 billion to the city's economy and more than $195 million in state and local taxes.
But more than a financial juggernaut, "Cats" fundamentally reshaped the Broadway landscape by ushering in the era of the megamusicals: big, flashy spectacles that required little theatrical sophistication or knowledge of the English language to appreciate. As such, "Cats"' proved that tourist audiences could drive a show's sales. Tourists filled the Winter Garden long after "Cats" had become passe among New York theatergoers.
But "Cats," with its lavish design and elaborate special effects, also whetted audiences' appetites for increasingly complex stagecraft. Soon Broadway was witness to all variety of expensive stage magic, from falling chandeliers (in Lord Lloyd Webber's 1988 musical, "The Phantom of the Opera") to helicopters landing onstage (in Sir Cameron's 1991 production, "Miss Saigon") to the foundering of the Titanic (in the 1997 musical of the same name).
While visually arresting, these effects raised the cost of producing musicals, making producers' prospect of turning a profit -- always slim -- even more forbidding. Higher production costs led to higher ticket prices.
As the run of "Cats" continued, the musical also became a cultural touchstone, becoming synonymous with longevity -- and, eventually, longueur -- in comedians' routines and among theater gossips. Even its advertising slogan, "Now and Forever," suggested a certain eerie, inevitable immortality.
And in an industry populated by old-time showmen, "Cats" also made its mark in marketing, adopting a text-free and thus internationally recognizable logo. The production also saturated the airwaves with television commercials and made its posters a permanent fixture in New York City subway stations.
It prompted a cottage industry in show-related trivia. More than 1.8 million pounds of dry ice have been used during the show's run to create fog onstage. The sheer poundage of yak hair used for wigs, 3,247 pounds during the run, outweighs a Volkswagen Beetle. One of the musical's most popular songs, "Memory," has been recorded 180 times by different artists around the world. "Cats" has employed 284 actors, 19 of whom have died. One, Marlene Danielle, has been with the show since the beginning of its Broadway run.
"Cats" opened in New York on Oct. 7, 1982, after months of pre-show hype and a sold-old run in the West End of London. (The London production is still running; "Cats" is now the longest-running show in the history of the British theater.)
Based on "Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats," a slim volume of poems by T. S. Eliot, "Cats" follows the tale of a group of alley cats, one of whom, Grizabella, ascends to kitty heaven, known as the heaviside layer, by show's end.
But story was really never the appeal of "Cats." The musical, with a catchy, melodic pop score by Lord Lloyd Webber, had no book and little plot.
Instead, the production's focus was on theatrical spectacle. The actors, directed by Trevor Nunn, are outfitted in feline body suits, foot-long whiskers and swirling face makeup and prowl the theater's aisles, stealing popcorn from children's hands and purring into people's faces. Aiding the illusion is a series of ingenious effects by the designer John Napier, who transformed the interior of the Winter Garden into a overrun junkyard seen from a cat's-eye perspective. At the musical's finale, a giant hydraulically powered tire lifts Grizabella into the sky.
Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times: "Whatever the other failings and excesses, even banalities, of 'Cats,' it believes in purely theatrical magic, and on that faith it unquestionably delivers." He also predicted that "Cats" was "likely to lurk around Broadway for a long time."
His words proved prophetic. "Cats" won seven Tony Awards in 1983, including best musical, and in June 1997 it surpassed "A Chorus Line" as the longest-running production in Broadway history. The occasion was celebrated with a reunion of former cast members and a block party in front of the Winter Garden.
Speaking then, Lord Lloyd Webber recalled how the show, based on unorthodox material, had struggled to find investors before its first run in London.
"We had almost everything going against us," he said. "We couldn't get the investment companies interested." Theater lore holds that Lord Lloyd Webber mortgaged his house to make sure the production was financed, a bet that paid off.
There was no indication of whether similar festivities were planned for the show's closing.
The Winter Garden's stage, which was completely deconstructed for "Cats," will have to be rebuilt. The theater as a whole will probably need a good scrub.
And if Broadway tradition holds true to form, those who have never seen "Cats," or want to see it one more time, will probably buy tickets, meaning one last surge in sales. Only 144 performances now remain.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
Bradley Seeks To Get a Push In Northwest

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Former Senator Bill Bradley's struggle to keep his presidential campaign alive seems to hinge increasingly on this state's primary.
Washington holds a nonbinding vote on Feb. 29 that will be the only Democratic contest before the so-called Super Tuesday primaries in 16 states on March 7. Having lost to Vice President Al Gore in both Iowa and New Hampshire, and trailing badly in polls in almost every state including Washington, Mr. Bradley views this state as a critical proving ground where he must regain some of the political momentum and media attention he has lost over the last month, his advisers said. 
 "What happens here if he beats Gore is that it will resonate across the country that this is a race," said Mayor Paul Schell of Seattle, who is helping Mr. Bradley here. "This is where he's going to make a stand. I think he's decided that."
Mr. Bradley is planning to lavish his time and resources on Washington in the coming week. He has also sent more than 20 aides, including some of his most seasoned organizers, to the state. By next weekend, his aides said, the full-time paid staff will probably grow to 30 people.
The group includes many of Mr. Bradley's top political aides from Iowa and New Hampshire, including Mark Longabaugh, his state director in New Hampshire, and Robert Becker, who was his political director in Iowa. Two of Mr. Bradley's senior advisers, Margy Heldring and Gretchen Crosby, have also moved to Seattle to talk about Mr. Bradley's record and agenda, particularly his plan to extend private health insurance to almost all Americans.
Mr. Bradley himself is expected to spend most of the coming week campaigning along the Pacific Coast and in heavily Democratic cities like Tacoma and Seattle.
Mr. Bradley is also preparing an advertising campaign for local radio stations and newspapers to promote his health care plan as well as his endorsement by The Seattle Times, the state's largest newspaper.
The vote on Feb. 29 will not be used to select delegates to the Democratic convention. That will be done on March 7 in party caucuses, where Mr. Gore is expected to excel because he has the support of most party officials and labor unions, groups that tend to dominate the caucuses.
But Mr. Bradley's advisers are less concerned with delegates than public relations, and they view Washington as one of their last chances to reverse perceptions that the Bradley campaign is foundering. A win here on Feb. 29, they say, could build the kind of excitement they need to go into the March 7 primaries with some sense of positive movement.
"We want this state to be able to send a message to the rest of the country," Mr. Bradley told a group of about 75 supporters this morning outside a health clinic in Seattle.
Mr. Bradley has acknowledged that he must win some states on March 7, when New York, California, Ohio and 10 other states will select 30 percent of the Democratic delegates. But while Mr. Bradley once talked of trying to contest Mr. Gore in almost every state, his campaign is trying to focus its efforts on certain states to ensure that he gains enough victories to justify staying in the race.
Mr. Bradley's advisers say that in addition to Washington, they are counting on doing well in New England, particularly Connecticut, in New York, where Mr. Bradley played pro basketball for 10 seasons, and Missouri, where he was born.
Victories in those states, combined with a strong second-place showing in California, would help insulate Mr. Bradley against pressure from other Democrats to drop out of the race. Performing well on March 7 is also important because on March 14 the campaign turns south, to Florida, Texas, Tennessee and several other states where Mr. Gore is considered the heavy favorite.
Mr. Bradley's advisers say they think he can do well in Washington in part because independents -- a group he does better among than Mr. Gore does -- are allowed to vote in the Feb. 29 primary. Thanks to a booming high-tech economy, there is also a large population of well-educated, higher income residents here, and polls have consistently shown that such voters tend to support Mr. Bradley.
Aides to Mr. Bradley have been concerned that Senator John McCain was drawing independent voters, as well as media attention, away from Mr. Bradley. For that reason, the candidate seemed buoyed tonight by Mr. McCain's loss in the South Carolina Republican primary. "We're back," Mr. Bradley told a crowd of supporters at a rally in St. Louis this evening.
During less than 24 hours in Seattle, Mr. Bradley focused on the two issues his aides think are most important to Washington voters: the environment and health care.
At a meeting with more than 800 people on Friday, Mr. Bradley talked proudly about his work on environmental issues in the Senate.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK ONLINE;
Art, in the Public Vein

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
If you open your mailbox in the coming weeks and find a postcard of eight disembodied heads, don't panic. If you find a MetroCard on the street whose cheery New York City scene has been replaced with a double helix, don't be alarmed. You are in the flow of a citywide art project.
Beginning Thursday and continuing through the spring, a group called REPOhistory, which specializes in public art, will hold a series of events and exhibitions about human blood and its economic, historic and cultural significance. The heart of this project, called "Circulation," is on its Internet site. 
 "The Web site is the only way viewers can see the entire project and how it works," said its creative director, Jim Costanzo. "A lot of the stuff will be ephemeral, or will be done in different parts of the city."
 Why blood? "Blood is a metaphor for our shared humanity and diversity," Mr. Costanzo said. "It deals with direct issues that affect us, like AIDS and ethnicity. Also, we deal with blood as a commodity, something that is sold and circulated throughout the city."
 Mr. Costanzo, who teaches computer graphics at Pratt Institute and Parsons School of Design, said an important aspect of the project is its interactive element. "We've been doing collaborative art for 11 years," he said. "The Web is a way of extending our way of collaboration to a much larger audience."
 WHAT YOU SEE -- The home page gives visitors various options. You can find out about REPOhistory, view the group's past work or check out the "Circulation" project. Click on the "Circulation" icon and there are more options. You can read about the ideas behind the project. You can view individual art works. You can learn about the history of blood.
 You can also send any of a dozen e-cards. In one, eerie cadaverlike mug shots by Tom Klem are identified by blood type to evoke the mythical connection between blood, race and purity. Another, by David Sansone, is red and black and contains the words, "it gives a body life: it gives a body death," referring to the life-giving properties of blood and to AIDS.
 Then there is "Exquisite Corpse," a cyberversion of an early 20th century parlor game played by Surrealists in which participants draw something or add a line of a story to a piece of paper that is folded so that the work of the previous contributor cannot be seen.
 LINKS -- To a literary online magazine called The Bleeding Edge, created by students from the Institute for Collaborative Education, a city middle and high school, and to a Web site affiliated with St. Cloud State University in Minnesota, where there is a continuing dialogue among students about blood and ethnic identity.
 WHAT YOU GET -- A bird's-eye view of our red planet. ERIC V. COPAGE

HEADLINE: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.
Amid the aroma of pita breads baking at the rate of 11,000 an hour, Edward Mafoud stood on the cavernous floor of Damascus Bakeries in Brooklyn and explained how the steeply rising oil prices had taken a significant bite out of his bakery's already slim profit margin. 
The cost of producing and shipping his pitas and other Middle Eastern breads has gone up by about $40,000 in the last 12 months, he said, not only because of higher transportation costs, but also because of the rising price of plastic packaging bags -- a petroleum-based product he uses by the millions each year. Although $40,000 may seem relatively little for a company with about $5 million a year in gross revenues, it is important, Mr. Mafoud said, because "in the bread industry we work with small profit margins" on each item.
"If your profitability margins are basically running 3 percent and you chop off 1 percent, it doesn't leave you that much to operate with," he said. Less money is left to upgrade equipment, expand production or merely remain competitive.
"We're not going to go out of business overnight," he said. But if oil prices remain high or increase still more, and if the costs of ingredients and other items also rise significantly, he said, the squeeze could become more serious.
About 80 percent of the bread made by Damascus, a major pita producer, is distributed nationally, carried by independent truckers who in recent months have added fuel surcharges to the bakery's bills.
Mr. Mafoud, 39, is part of the third generation of his family to operate the 70-year-old bakery at 56 Gold Street, in the Vinegar Hill area of Brooklyn.
As the bakery's president, he was already considering whether to raise prices, a step he said he was reluctant to take, because it would mean risking the loss of some wholesalers and retailers. An increase of 2 or 3 cents on a four-pita package -- to compensate for the nearly 10 percent rise in the cost of plastic bags and the 2 percent to 3 percent truckers' fuel surcharges -- could lead distributors and retailers to say, "No, we'll buy from your competitors," he said.

HEADLINE: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks;
Taking a Toll on Apartments

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.
The spike in oil prices is punching holes in the finances of apartment buildings across the city, from small walk-ups to the giant Co-op City complex in the Bronx. 
 "It's going to bust a lot of budgets -- it already has," said Jordi Reyes-Montblanc, president of the Housing Development Fund Corporation Coalition, which helps limited-income tenants take over and run buildings whose owners default on taxes. To pay soaring oil bills, some co-ops may impose assessments or raise maintenance fees, he said. "Our co-ops operate on a very small margin, and this was totally unexpected. Many buildings can withstand the pressure for a limited time, but with others, it's like living from paycheck to paycheck, and this can break you."
At a 24-unit building he manages on West 134th Street in Hamilton Heights, Mr. Reyes-Montblanc said: "On Jan. 20, we got an 1,800-gallon delivery at $1 a gallon. On Feb. 5 we got another delivery that cost $3,600," or $2 a gallon, "and in the next few days we may have to order again."
At New York's biggest housing complex, Co-op City, the surge in oil prices hit home at an especially inopportune moment. Just getting oil -- regardless of price -- proved hard last month. "One guy had trucks and no oil; another guy had oil and no trucks," said Gary E. Friedland, the executive vice president of Marion Scott Real Estate, which manages the complex.
For many buildings, oil costs have been more of an annoyance than a crisis. "Many of our members are heating with gas, or they have a level billing plan and won't get hit for an adjustment until later on," and others are dipping into reserve funds, said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums.
But not all buildings have a cushion. Amy Rosado, who helps run a tenant-owned building on Shakespeare Avenue in the Bronx, said it could pay only half the $6,000 bill for its last oil delivery. The supplier agreed to extend credit for the rest.
"There's a lot of yelling and screaming, because this is basically a doubling of oil prices, and that's pretty significant," said Jack Freund, executive vice president of the city's biggest landlords' group, the Rent Stabilization Association. BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks;
Big Tanks, Big Bills

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.
The sport utility vehicle has surged in popularity in part because of its size -- taller than a speeding soccer mom, but sometimes more hungry for gas than two compact cars. That's not much of a problem when gas prices are low. 
 Now, however, drivers of sport utility vehicles and minivans are rolling their eyes as they spend as much as $50 to fill their large tanks.
Herb Castro, a stay-at-home father from Manhattan's Lower East Side, said he used to fill the tank of his minivan, a 1996 Plymouth Voyager, once or twice a week. Now, he can afford to buy only $10 worth of gas three or four times a week. When he can, he buys gas in Brooklyn to save a few pennies.
Nevertheless, he could not consider a smaller car, he said: "I have three children and my wife. Anything smaller would drive me crazy."
Mr. Castro was buying gas Thursday morning at the Amoco station on Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, where prices ranged from $1.51 to $1.65 a gallon, generally less than in Manhattan. At a Merit station nearby, where gas was selling for a few cents less, Edward Bell of Flatbush, a mechanic for U-Haul, was filling up a rental truck. He said he has cut down on driving because of the jump in gas prices. "I don't go out of state too much anymore," he said.
To a person, drivers of sport utility vehicles said that while they were disturbed at the jump in gasoline prices, they would remain true to their vehicles.
"I think they should lower the price. If you have to buy a particular car for gas prices, that's ridiculous," said John Brutus, who travels from his home in Virginia to Kennedy International Airport and on to Buffalo to do maintenance on planes. He said it costs him $21 to fill up his 1987 Pathfinder, but because he has four children, he wouldn't be able to use a smaller car. TINA KELLEY

HEADLINE: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks;
A Cooperative Solution

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.
Marion Reinhardt of Rutherford, N.J., works hard to make her 110-year-old house more energy efficient and her heating bills affordable. A few weeks ago, she put weatherstripping around her back door. When she goes to work, she lowers the thermostat. 
 But it was the recent rise in gasoline prices that made her realize that no matter what she did to conserve, it was going to cost more to heat her home this season. "I was driving to work the other day, and I passed a gas station that was selling gasoline for $1.38 a gallon, and I was so astounded at the increase," said Ms. Reinhardt, who is 52. "I went home and called my oil dealer, and they were going to charge me $1.60 or $1.80 per gallon," she said. "I couldn't believe it."
For years, Ms. Reindhardt has been hearing of an oil cooperative from her friends and neighbors. A few days ago, when she realized how oil prices had risen, she called the New Jersey Citizen Oil Group, a nonprofit group that buys oil in bulk and sells it at a discount to its 6,000 members. Through the cooperative, Ms. Reindhardt is paying 50 cents a gallon.
Kendall Miller, the organization's director, said the cooperative sells about nine million gallons a year to its members, saving them about $1.5 million. Prices for the oil vary, but are capped at 99 cents a gallon.
Ms. Reinhardt said the winter would be hard on people with older homes, like hers, who are doing all they can to conserve. "Last month it was pretty cold," she said. "And winter's not over yet. I needed to do something." MARIA NEWMAN

HEADLINE: High Cost of Oil Seeps Its Way Into Everyday Lives, and Pocketbooks;
Cashing In on an Alternative

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
In recent weeks, the jump in fuel oil and gasoline prices has emerged as a potent political issue. Homeowners who rely on oil heat have had to deal with surprisingly high bills this winter, but the impact is more widespread, rippling throughout the economy in many ways. And, as with all economic dislocations, some have actually benefited from the situation.
As the new year opened to mild weather, Mike Ruff struggled to drum up business for his Brooklyn plumbing and heating installation company. Then serendipity struck: the recent increase in oil prices, coupled with an onslaught of bone-chilling temperatures, ushered a wave of customers his way. 
 Mr. Ruff and his company, KeySpan Energy Solutions, are among the few who have profited from the increase in oil prices. As more and more homeowners convert from oil to natural gas, some plumbing companies are finding that what began as a sluggish winter may turn out to be a boom season. "Since the last week or two of January, we've seen a big jump in the number of customers," Mr. Ruff said.
Mr. Ruff said that business has increased by about 60 percent over the same time last year. In an average year, conversions to gas heat account for about 15 percent of the company's total gross revenues, he said.
Mr. Ruff's company is a subsidiary of KeySpan Energy, which, along with Consolidated Edison, provides gas to homes in New York.
Bob Mahony, a spokesman for the parent company, said that while oil prices were hovering about $2 per gallon, an equivalent amount of natural gas cost about $1.15. Converting from oil to gas heating usually runs $3,500 to $4,500, Mr. Ruff said. And if a home does not have a gas line, it has to be installed by the utility.
Of course, those homeowners who have filled up their standard 275-gallon oil tanks will likely hold off switching, said Kenneth Lukaszewski, one of the owners of Komfort Plumbing & Heating, based in Brooklyn.
He said he already has conversion jobs scheduled for March and April, when many people will have used up their oil.
"Business is good right now," Mr. Ruff said. "We just don't know how long the oil prices will stay up. And in this business, you're always at the mercy of the elements." EDWARD WONG

HEADLINE: Productivity's Up, and What of It?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I wish to express my gratitude for Stephen S. Roach's essay ("Working Better or Just Harder?", Op-Ed, Feb. 14). I work in the field of computers (and have done my share of retail and sales), and I cannot recall working a nine-to-five day in many moons.
Over the past years my day has grown to at least 10 hours (sometimes more) and six days per week (if not seven). 
 My situation is not unique; many of my friends and colleagues work under the same pressures. It really amazes me that (according to the experts and futurists) we were supposed to be living like the Jetsons and worrying about our two-hour workdays.
 
KEITH H. MC GRATH
Pueblo, Colo., Feb. 14, 2000

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
By Bus to Luang Prabang, Home of Laotian Kings

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
THE bus looked empty -- but then I spotted the chicken. Tethered in the aisle by a foot of plastic string, it squawked and skittered around my ankles as I hauled my backpack down the row of empty seats. I chuckled to myself and settled in for a long haul: an 11-hour ride through the mountains of Laos on a public bus from Vientiane to Luang Prabang.
The bus is my least favorite mode of transportation, but in many countries it is the only convenient way to get around. To my surprise, I've discovered that bus travel can be almost luxurious -- I've traveled on buses with starched cotton antimacassars, whistle-clean restrooms, attendants serving hot coffee, and movies on video. But as a general rule, when chickens are in the aisles, attendants serving free coffee are not. 
 I'd given some thought to this particular bus trip before arriving in Laos late last November. The State Department has been alerting citizens for about five years to the hazards of traveling the 300-mile stretch of Highway 13 between Vientiane and Luang Prabang, Laos's two major tourism spots. In 1995 a French expatriate travel agent and his staff were ambushed and murdered by Hmong rebels in the mountains just outside the village of Kasi, halfway between the two cities. Since then, United States Embassy personnel in Vientiane have been forbidden to travel to Luang Prabang by road.
But the only other way to get from Vientiane to Luang Prabang is to fly on Lao Aviation, an option that also carries a caveat (the embassy says that its maintenance is not up to international standards).
I was keen to get to Luang Prabang. In every account I had read, from Norman Lewis to Lonely Planet, it was described as one of the highlights of Southeast Asia. The former capital of the Laotian Kingdom, Luang Prabang commands a spectacular setting on a hilly peninsula on the Mekong River. Dozens of ancient, glittering Buddhist temples share space with elegant French-Laotian colonial buildings from the 20's and 30's that are being restored by Unesco World Heritage architects.
But I didn't want to take a foolish risk. So I made it my mission while in Vientiane to gather information. I asked all travelers and expats I met if they'd traveled to Luang Prabang recently, and by what means. Most of the backpackers had taken the public bus, and were puzzled by my questions about security. A sun-baked Australian said, with a snort, "The biggest danger on the ride is claustrophobia," explaining that there are more passengers than seats. A couple from England described the security measures the Laotian Army had put in place north of Kasi since the 1995 attack: checkpoints, patrols and an entire village of army personnel living alongside the highway.
At the U.S. Embassy in Vientiane, I learned that once a day Lao Aviation flew a French-built plane to Luang Prabang. Embassy officials occasionally flew on it. The fare was $55 each way, cash, no discounts.
I decided, finally, to go by bus and fly back on the French plane. I liked this plan -- I'd get a good look at the Laotian countryside and avoid retracing my steps by flying back to Vientiane. I'd save half the plane fare. The bus cost only $4 one way.
Actually, it cost me $8, because I bought two seats. The Australian's warning about claustrophobia struck home -- flying economy class from New York to Asia, I'd spent 15 hours crammed next to a Chinese grandmother with a squirmy 4-year-old and a five-gallon jar of pickles balanced on her lap. I didn't want a repeat experience, and so, waving the two tickets at the attendant in charge of seating people on the bus, I grabbed a window seat and placed my pack on the seat next to me.
The bus was full, and I figured we'd be off any moment. But then the attendant leaped into action, producing a stack of child-sized plastic stools. I realized then that this guy's job wasn't to collect tickets but to figure out how to jam as many people into the bus as possible (while waving them away from the empty seat that I'd bought). The aisle filled up with stools, people (mostly Laotians and about five other foreigners), packages. I could no longer hear the chicken, muffled under a sack of rice.
In Vang Vieng, a river town about three hours up the road that's become a backpacker's haunt, the flat farm scenery of lowland Laos transformed into a bizarre landscape of enormous, mountain-sized rocks that tumbled across the river plain like geological dice. After a while we entered the foothills of the mountains that range across Laos's interior, and the asphalt road began to bend and twist. This is the point, during bus trips, when my stomach generally starts to tighten, but the driver handled the dead man's curves so slowly and carefully that I relaxed -- he was a pro. The mountains, intricately terraced and patchworked farmland in the lower areas, fading out to bare rock at the top, became more gorgeous with every mile.
With each change of elevation, the village huts altered architecturally. Laos is a nation cobbled together from dozens of ethnic groups, and the ethnicity changes with altitude. So, it appeared, did the economy -- the higher we rode, the more difficult life seemed. At the very top of the ranges, I noticed that the roadside billboards advertising toothpaste and soft drinks disappeared completely. Such basic commodities were out of reach for the Hmong who live in the highest, least fertile, parts of the mountains and scratch out a bare-bones living.
After about six hours we stopped in Kasi for a lunch of sticky rice and laap (a Laotian dish of marinated beef and vegetables) at a roadside hut with outdoor tables. Then we reboarded and moved through the zone where the ambushes had occurred. The English couple's report had been accurate -- the next 15 miles were a gantlet of military checkpoints, patrols and barracks. Beyond this stretch, the mountains grew steeper, and the last four hours to Luang Prabang were all downhill. The passengers relaxed, and the driver turned on a cassette of Laotian folk songs, music soothing and plaintive, like an old country crooner's or an Irish lament. The sun set in shades of red and purple over a lumpy blanket of fog-misted mountains. I fell asleep and awakened to a put-put of motorbikes and shadows of mountains against a moonlit sky: Luang Prabang.
At 8:30 the next morning, Thanon Xieng Tong, Luang Prabang's main drag, had the bustle of a college town in September. Backpackers chain-smoked in sidewalk cafes, meandered in and out of tourist gift shops, headed down to the Mekong to bargain for passage on rice boats. I was in minor shock over the scene. Because travel in Laos is problematic, I'd figured that Luang Prabang would be nearly empty of tourists. But foreigners were everywhere, and on the main street they outnumbered locals. I sat down for a cup of cappuccino and eavesdropped on the conversation. The travelers were coming in, by sixes and sevens, on rice boats from the Thai border to the north, and by the dozens on a direct flight that operated several times a week from Chiang Mai, Thailand.
The night before, I'd arrived at the Villa Santi, the guest house where I'd booked a reservation by phone, only to find that my reservation had evaporated. Profuse apologies from desk clerk and manager increased my suspicions that the hotel had given my room away. Hot and irritable from the road, I insisted the manager call to find me a room in another hotel -- but every place he tried was full. Finally I dug in my bag and found the number of a place recommended by an expat in Vientiane, a guest house too new to be in the guidebooks. That is how I ended up in the Villa Xieng Mouane, in a sweet, tidy and spacious room with high ceilings and large wooden shutters that opened to a view of the temple across the street. My hosts, all women, lounged in the tiny lobby all day watching Thai soap operas, and smilingly collected my rent -- $25 a day, cash.
I could see how Luang Prabang had gotten its reputation as the Shangri-la of Southeast Asia. Every block of the peninsula it occupies had something to see: an enormous temple complex with low swooping gold-leafed roofs, or an ornately decorated wooden French colonial house. I spent the cool of the morning walking around the perimeter of the peninsula, on dirt streets that offered fabulous views of the Mekong far below. What I noticed, though, is that the local folk, unlike the citizens of Vientiane, did not automatically smile and say hello when one passed -- a casualty of tourism.
LUANG PRABANG is a small town, with a handful of resident foreigners, most working in projects related to tourism and restoration -- so small that when I wandered into the Unesco office I was able to chat with one of the French architects. He showed me their giant map of the town, pointing out that my guest house was a 1920's French-Laotian landmark building. Almost all the buildings in the downtown area had been cataloged and guidelines for preservation had been developed. "Our goal is to keep the historic area as a living city," he said with a sigh, "but families are selling their houses, moving out, and converting them into guest houses."
There was much to discover beneath this bustle of development and restoration, but I had only five days. I was resigning myself to a routine of sightseeing and backpackers when I remembered the other bit of information I'd collected in Vientiane -- the name of an American woman, an art restorer, who was working at Luang Prabang's Royal Palace Museum on a Rockefeller Foundation grant.
I found Bonnie Baskin in the basement of the museum, painstakingly cleaning the grit from an 18th-century Laotian sacred bronze drum with a Q-Tip. She was wearing a T-shirt and a long, gold-embroidered Lao silk sarong, called a sin. It was gorgeous. I asked her where she got it, and she smiled, put down her Q-Tip and said, "Let's go shopping."
Bonnie had been in Luang Prabang for five months with her husband, a doctoral candidate at Berkeley. The Royal Palace Museum, where she was cleaning drums and restoring wooden and gold-leafed Buddhas, is the most interesting place in Luang Prabang. The mansion, built in the 1920's, was the home of Laos's kings, and a repository for all their state treasures. For many years after the last Laotian king and his queen were whisked away by the Pathet Lao in 1975 (they died in a "re-education camp"), the palace remained empty, neglected and in disrepair. But the Laotian government is now promoting tourism, and trying to reconstruct a national identity disrupted over years of Communist rule. And so the palace and its treasures are being restored.
Bonnie accompanied me as I strolled, barefoot, around the palace, admiring the cases of bronze and crystal Buddhas, the imposing red-and-gold throne room, and the massive, Art Nouveau wooden bed of the king, with three royal elephants carved into the head. At the royal garage, we peered into a crack in the locked door and ogled the king's shiny white Edsel.
We walked to the marketplace, where Bonnie pointed out the different styles of sins, and how to spot one of good quality. I bought the fabric and hired a seamstress to sew the skirt to my dimensions (she did it overnight, and superbly, for $2). We ate laap, sauteed morning glory roots and sticky rice with our fingers at lunch for around $1.50, in her favorite stall. Together we climbed to the top of Phousi mountain to visit Luang Prabang's best-known shrine, Wat Phousi.
Sometimes you get lucky when traveling, and I felt doubly so: I'd found a guide and I'd made a friend. I was sure my good fortune had everything to do with the circumstances of my arrival. Breezing into town on a direct flight from Thailand, I could have gone for days speaking to no one but Australian backpackers.
I made a mental note: ride the bus more often when traveling, and always grab the seat next to the chicken.
 
The bottom line
I spent $33.02 a day on lodging, food, and museum and temple admissions during five days in Luang Prabang, Laos. Note that in Luang Prabang it is still uncommon for businesses, hotels and restaurants to accept credit cards.
 
Transportation
I took the public bus from Vientiane to Luang Prabang. It takes 11 hours and leaves on a very casual schedule in the early mornings from the night market in Luang Prabang. The one-way fare, bought at the depot, is $4. In its most recent Consular Information Sheet, the State Department says that people traveling on Route 13 north between Kasi and Luang Prabang "run the risk of ambush by insurgents or bandits."
To return from Luang Prabang I flew Lao Aviation; in Luang Prabang their number is (856-71) 212 172. A one-way ticket cost $55, and credit cards are not accepted. The State Department says the U.S. Embassy, citing concern about safety and maintenance, advises its personnel to "limit domestic travel on Lao Aviation to essential travel only." But I was told by an embassy spokeswoman that embassy officials do occasionally travel on the company's French-built A.T.R. plane. It is possible to request a booking on that specific aircraft.
Walking is the best way to get around Luang Prabang. Small motorcycle taxis can be hailed on the street -- rides are around 25 cents.
 
Lodging
I stayed in a pleasant, clean room with bath in the Xieng Mouane Guesthouse, 86 Ban Xieng Mouane, telephone and fax: (856-71) 252-152, a carefully restored French-Lao building dating from the 1920's. My single room cost $25 a night, cash.
The Duang Champa Auberge and Restaurant, Kingkitsarah Street, telephone and fax (856-71) 212 420, has large loftlike rooms, with balconies overlooking the river, at $25 to $35 a night.
 
Food
In the back area of the Dara market, vendors sell delicious lunches of sticky rice, stir-fried morning glory stems, and laap, ground beef or chicken marinated in lime juice and spices. I ate lunch there nearly every day for about $1.50.
At the Malee Lao, Phou Vao Road, (856-71) 252-013, and Pak Huoy Mixay (856-71) 212-260) restaurants, you can have a three-course feast for three people for around $6. At Pak Huoy Mixay my feast included purple sticky rice, a savory, not-too-hot chicken curry, and spring rolls filled with succulent peppery mushrooms.
 
Museums and Temples
Temples are the main attraction of Luang Prabang. The two best known, Wat Xieng Thong and Wat Phousi, charge a small admission fee of around 70 cents. The smaller temples are free.
The onetime home of the Laotian king Sisavangvong is being restored. Visitors should see the Royal Palace Museum, (856-71) 212-470), with its grand formal throne rooms and priceless Buddha figures. It is open from 8:30 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. daily, closed for lunch between 12 and 1. Admission is $1.33. DAISANN McLANE

HEADLINE: At Penn Station, Changes, and More Changes;
After Over $100 Million in Renovations, A $788 Million Terminal, but No Tunnel

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

 BODY:
IT is neither the suffocatingly low ceilings on the New Jersey Transit platforms nor the last-minute track information that bothers Kris Martin most about her daily commute.
"You know what the worst part of commuting is?" said the 39-year-old Ms. Martin of Matawan, who rides New Jersey Transit every day to Manhattan, where she works as a database manager. "The commuters. Everyone is so rude. Let's say you're standing and waiting for a train -- someone will come up and just push you out of the way. Everyone's jockeying for position." 
 Jeffrey N. Leibell, a lawyer and Long Island Rail Road commuter, agrees. "You become an automaton," said Mr. Leibell, 42, a family man and Little League coach in Great Neck who undergoes a Jekyll-to-Hyde transformation at Penn Station. "It's a rat race, one foot in front of the other. It turns us into unpleasant people."
But a lot of time and money is being spent to make things more pleasant for more than 300,000 commuters from New Jersey, Long Island, New York City, Washington, Boston and elsewhere who squeeze through Pennsylvania Station and the dizzying network of subways every day.
The commuters include about 200,000 rail passengers -- 44,000 on New Jersey Transit, 144,000 on the Long Island Rail Road and 8,200 on Amtrak, the railroads estimate. Another 100,000 people use the Seventh and Eighth Avenue subway stations, and 150,000 rail commuters scurry from their trains to the subways every day, according to the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, which was set up by New York State to guide a vast project to build a new station just to the west.
The grand expansion project will convert half of the James A. Farley General Post Office, across Eighth Avenue from Pennsylvania Station, into a new hub for Amtrak that will also serve New Jersey Transit and Long Island Rail Road commuters.
The 21 tracks, which are reached along 11 platforms, run east-west, passing below the post office before emerging into the Metropolitan Transit Authority rail yard west of Ninth Avenue. Even now, the post office ships some mail by rail, and in addition to creating new ticket booths and waiting areas, the Farley project will expand access to the tracks westward. The vaulted Postal Service lobby for the public along Eighth Avenue will remain.
For all of the hundreds of millions of dollars and years of effort, the project will not add any tracks or platforms. But Charles Gargano, chairman of the redevelopment corporation, said the easier access and fuller use of the existing platforms would increase the current station's capacity to handle the 30 percent increase in traffic that is projected by 2010.
Transportation experts generally welcome the Farley plan.
Lee Sander, director of the Center for Transportation Policy and Management at New York University who is also a member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, called the future station "a terrific project" that would improve conditions for everyone who uses Penn Station.
But Peter Haynes, a longtime commuter and a former L.I.R.R. employee who founded the Long Island Rail Road Commuter Campaign last August, is doubtful the project will have much effect, particularly since it will add neither tracks at the station nor much-needed train tunnels under the Hudson River or the East River.
"I'm all for new stations, but if they don't do anything underground, it's going to be very limited in effect," said Mr. Haynes, 42, a computer consultant. "My impression is, it's sort of like window dressing for people coming up from Washington or Philadelphia. It's a poor replacement for the old Penn Station."
Even before the the Farley project gets under way -- the target completion date is 2003 -- Amtrak is completing a $37.5 million renovation of the waiting area it shares with New Jersey Transit. Its modern design is intended in part to reflect Amtrak's sleek 150-mile-an-hour Acela train, which began local service between Boston and Washington this month. Yet that waiting area -- much of which is still not open to the public -- will be ripped up and turned into retail space when the Farley project is up and running.
"We anticipated being in that building with the Acela service for five years, and we had to bring it up to the same level as our trains," said Karen Dunn, a spokeswoman for Amtrak.
In another corner of the gloomy, windowless station, behind plywood construction barriers, New Jersey Transit is also ripping up huge concrete slabs and taking down heavy riveted I-beams to install new escalators, elevators and ramps to improve access to Tracks 1 through 12. This $105 million project -- "a station within a station," Saundra Lautenberg, New Jersey Transit's program manager for engineering and construction, calls it -- is scheduled for completion in mid-2001.
And on the East Side, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Long Island Rail Road, has approved $1.5 billion in its 2000-2004 capital plan to cover about half the estimated cost of linking L.I.R.R. tracks to Grand Central Terminal by 2010. Because 60 percent of Long Island riders head north and east from Penn Station, the Grand Central connection should sharply lower the number who use Penn Station, said Christopher P. Boylan, deputy executive director of the M.T.A.
Conversely, the link would be convenient for Westchester and Connecticut residents who now arrive at Grand Central but would rather arrive on the West Side.
Officials are careful to point out that the Farley project -- which will largely serve Amtrak passengers -- will by no means snub suburban commuters, who will be able to buy tickets and reach their trains from the new station.
"It's the busiest passenger transportation facility in the world, and growing," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat and the main proponent of the Farley project, said of Penn Station in a recent interview. "It's not just restoring grandeur. It's getting out of that hole in the ground."
For now, the renovation of the New Jersey Transit-Amtrak waiting area and tracks at the western end of Penn Station mimics the $90 million project that the L.I.R.R. completed in 1995. That modernization effort added a fourth concourse for access to Tracks 13 through 21, to say nothing of air-conditioning and better heating.
As a measure of the improved access that is envisioned, the total number of elevators, escalators and stairways will rise to 160 from the current 94 when the two projects are complete. The Farley project will add 46, while New Jersey Transit will add 20.
That said, the new areas in the Farley building will not have direct access to Tracks 1 through 4 -- frequently used by New Jersey Transit -- because they do not extend far enough west, said John Gerber, executive vice president of the development corporation. However, Farley will be connected to Tracks 5 to 21 by the Long Island Rail Road's west end concourse, which already runs from Track 21 south to Track 13, and will be extended to Track 5.
"That has always been a concern of ours," said John Gerber, the development corporation's deputy executive director.
Reminiscent of the original Penn Station's glass train house, the Farley project will incorporate the post office's vast skylight as the ceiling of what essentially will be a huge atrium.
"It's going to be a series of balconies that descend right down to the tracks," Mr. Gerber said. "So we're going to bring the natural light back down to the tracks."
Though the Farley project will further ease congestion, Mr. Boylan said, crowding is hardly the only problem as the station exists right now.
An Amtrak commuter, Christina Sterner, who commutes from Philadelphia twice a week, said that arriving at Penn Station was a numbing experience at best, especially compared with what she calls the spiritual uplift she gets from the 30th Street Station in Philadelphia or Union Station in Washington.
"I think that this is one of the ugliest train stations that exists," said Ms. Sterner, managing director of Baryshnikov Productions in New York, the ballet dancer's production company. "Philadelphia has a beautiful station, Washington has a beautiful station, and New York should. There's no sense of anything at Penn Station. It's nothing."
The Farley project, on the other hand, is something.
Highlighted by a 150-foot-high framework of steel and glass rising 75 feet above the roof of the Beaux-Arts post office, the new station is envisioned as a return to the grandeur that was lost when the old Penn Station -- a matched bookend to the Farley building when they were both completed in 1913 -- was demolished in 1963 to make way for Madison Square Garden and the undistinguished office towers above.
The new station will also be a major element of Amtrak's future, highlighting its new Acela service in an effort to woo airline shuttle passengers along the Northeast Corridor with the convenience of downtown-to-downtown high-speed trains.
Interestingly, plans for the new station include direct rail service to John F. Kennedy International and Newark International Airports -- though La Guardia, where the shuttle flights to Washington and Boston operated by Delta and Eastern arrive and depart, is left out of the loop.
Proponents of the new station are are optimistic about its outcome, particularly because it is being headed by Mr. Gargano, who can readily recite precise dollar contributions from nearly a dozen sources of funds at the federal, state and city level. Among his various job titles, Mr. Gargano is also commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development and vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the other agencies involved in the Farley project.
The price tag for the new station, put at $484 million when President Clinton presented the plan last May, is now estimated at $788 million, including $188 million in track work and improvements to the post office, said Tony Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff.
Groundbreaking is expected this fall, though the completion date varies, depending upon which agency is asked.
The redevelopment corporation says at least some operations will begin in 2003, and the new stations will be fully operational no later than early 2004. But Ms. Dunn of Amtrak puts the date at 2005.
"Putting it as politely as possible, Amtrak's feeling has, all along, been that the PSRC's date of completion on the Farley project has always been very ambitions and highly unlikely," Ms. Dunn said. "So we have always worked under the assumption that we would be in the building in 2005."
Mr. Gerber of the redevelopment corporation said bid specifications, to be advertised this summer, will include his agency's 2003 time frame.
"We'll show them," Mr. Gerber said, referring to skeptical Amtrak officials.
The sources of money, according to Mr. Gargano, include these:
*The Empire State Development Corporation, of which Mr. Gargano is also chairman, which will issue bonds to be repaid by the lease of retail space, $155 million.
*The federal Department of Transportation, $140 million.
*The United States Postal Service, $120 million.
*Amtrak, $68 million.
*New York State, $75 million.
*New York City, $25 million.
*The Federal Rail Road Administration, $56 million.
Additional funds will come from federal loans and lines of credit, and officials say neither the L.I.R.R. nor New Jersey Transit will have to contribute in the form of fare increases.
Just what to call the new station -- and the current Penn Station, for that matter -- has barely been broached. Senator Charles E. Schumer, New York's other senator and also a Democrat, has introduced a measure in Washington to name the new station after Mr. Moynihan, though the senior senator insists he is embarrassed by the prospect.
The annex and the main lobby of the Farley Building, named for a former United States postmaster general from New York, will continue to be used by the Postal Service, though some operations were shifted to a nearby complex several years ago. The Postal Service will continue to own the entire Farley complex, but will lease the station portion to the redevelopment corporation for 99 years.
The post office is actually two buildings, the original built in 1913 and an annex dating from 1934, though connecting walls make them appear as one. In the new design, by the architect David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the station's main concourse will occupy the space between the original building and the annex, which is now mainly truck bays. Plans also call for retail shopping and waiting areas on four levels stepping down to the train platforms, most of which already extend below the post office.
The main post office building was designed by McKim, Mead & White, who were also the architects for the old Pennsylvania Station, which was built in 1910. In what is universally reviled today as a crime against architecture, the old station was torn down in 1963.
The post office was designed to compliment the old station, in the same Beaux-Arts style, and Mr. Moynihan's hope is to recapture the grandeur of the original station.
Some of that grandeur can be glimpsed in photographs hanging in the Amtrak ticket area near Eighth Avenue and 33rd Street. And on the walls at the foot of the escalators on 34th Street, just west of Seventh Avenue, full-sized terra-cotta reliefs of toppled Corinthian columns by the sculptor Andrew Leicester commemorate the old station's bygone classicism. Another of Mr. Leicester's series, "Mercury Man," is in the main L.I.R.R. concourse, near a bakery named, perhaps suitably for the crowded station, Hot & Crusty.
Will the station succeed as a station and ease commuters' pain? More tracks are a frequent suggestion, but railroad officials have said the capacity of the tunnels has to be addressed first.
Mr. Haynes, the former L.I.R.R. employee, said an East Side connection to Grand Central would be a help for Long Islanders, but he doubted it would happen "in my lifetime."
Robert Yarrow, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a private organization, also said the lack of new tracks was a shortcoming.
Still, Mr. Yarrow said the new station's striking combination of classical and contemporary architecture, and on such a grand scale, would instill in New Jersey and Long Island commuters the same vaunted feelings that Grand Central did for Metro North riders like him.
"I do it every day," he said. "It's an ennobling experience. It makes you feel good about coming into the city."
But Ms. Martin, the New Jersey commuter, said what she looked for in a railroad was on-time performance, not nobility.
"To be honest, it really doesn't matter to me," she said. "If I had the choice between having a beautiful station and my trains running on time and being clean, I would much rather have my trains run on time."
But she did say her biggest problem with commuting was rude commuters, and proponents of the Farley project say one of its main effects will be to soothe those savage 9-to-5ers.
"People are rude, they're shoving and pushing because they're enduring an unacceptable level of discomfort," said Mr. Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff. "What the Farley project provides is a glorious new setting."
Mr. Leibell, the Long Island lawyer, said he was no student of behavior, but that seems to make sense to him: "If it were a larger space, if it weren't as crowded, if there were more options and easier access to the track level, and maybe just having it posted where your train is, it would make the commute easier, improve the experience, kind of take the edge off."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
How Waiting Can Pay Off In a Star Role

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
CLOTHES FOLDER. Dog walker. Morning bartender. Those are a few of the glamorous professions undertaken by Mark Setlock during his self-described "squalor days" a few years back, when he was living on a "syringe-lined" street in the East Village, learning about urban ecology. "I saw mice, I saw cockroaches," Mr. Setlock said cherrily. "I saw silverfish for the first time."
 
 That was then. Nowadays, his prospects are considerably brighter, starring as he does in the one-man show "Fully Committed," a satirical look at a day in the life of a rerservations clerk at a four-star restaurant besieged by high-powered customers demanding tables. The play, written by Becky Mode, a friend of Mr. Setlock's, and directed by Nicholas Martin, opened to raves in September at the Vineyard Theater and moved to a commercial run at the 180-seat Cherry Lane in December. A representative of the show said recently that "the box-office staff have had some astonishing encounters with people who are not accustomed to being told no." Sounds familiar.
 While a steady paychecks is always nice, Mr. Setlock, 31, said his success was particularly meaningful because much of the play's fictional action was born out of his own miserable experiences as an actor and day laborer. "Oh, the things I've seen," he said wryly over breakfast one morning in the East Village. "All grist for my mill."
 The chief grist: from 1994 to 1996, Mr. Setlock, an unemployed actor from the Midwest, was a reservations clerk in the basement of Bouley, the high-end, four-star New York restaurant founded by the chef David Bouley that closed in 1996. (Ms. Mode worked there briefly, checking coats.)
 And while Bouley is never mentioned, there is plenty of obvious biography at work in "Full Committed." In the play, after all, Mr. Setlock protrays Sam, an unemployed actor from the Midwest, struggling through his reservations shift in an unnamed, famously popular New York restaurant.
 Along the way, Sam deals with, as did Mr. Setlock, all manner of the petulant and the persnickity. There is Bunny Vandevere, a monied matron from the Upper East Side; Jean-Claude, the ur-French maitre d'; and Byrce, a manic, and imaginary, assistant to the model Naomi Campbell who requests a "no-fat, no-salt, no-dairy, no-sugar, no-chicken, no-meat, no-fish, no soy tasting menu."
 In all, Mr. Setlock plays 35 characters, switching from role to role wit deadly rapid-fire accuracy. Accents - Southern, German, Southern German - roll out of his mouth synchronized with their attendant facial acrobatics. By his own account, it is a skill he discovered while growing up in a middle-class Cleveland neighborhood, imitating Bugs Bunny on the Saturday morning cartoons. "I played a lot alone," he said. "Television was my friend."
Mr. Setlock went on to study acting at Kent State University, where he once fooled a radio disc jockey into believing he was Dr. Ruth Westheimer and took questions about sex from the public. (Dr. Westheimer's voice - channeled through Mr. Setlock - is heard in "Fully Committed.")
 He continued his training at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., where he met Ms. Mode, then he came to New York in 1992 to find work as an actor. Instead, he got a job at te Gap on West 34th Street, then the largest Gap in the world. "You would live in fear that the manager would say, 'Mark, go work on the pant wall,' " he said. "It was enormous."
 He settled into a small apartment in the East Village and worked with a variety of downtown companies, including Todo Con Nada and Target Margin. But getting paid for acting proved trickier. He quit the Gap, and after stints as a "dog exercise specialist" and a bartender - "people started tapping on the window at noon" - he landed the Bouley job, juggling six phone lines eight ours a day.
 He got a final callback for the one-man show "The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me" and, more agonizingly, was cast in the workshop but not the actual production of a little muscial called "Rent." "I thought I would go insane," he said. "I was tortured."
 After "Rent" moved to Broadway in 1996, Mr. Setlock landed a role as an understudy and quit Bouley. It would prove the starting point for "Fully Committed."
 For months, he had been entertaining friends, including Ms. Mode, with tales of obnoxious restaurant patrons. He kept a list over his phone with categories of callers - "hags," "depressed secretaries," "television anchormen" - that he would point to as the calls came in.
 Ms. Mode, who had long wanted to write a play set in a restaurant, thought his experiences might be a jumping-off place. The producer Daivd Stone agreed. "I thought it was a great idea for a play," Mr. Stone said, "because everyone I knew lived their lives trying to get into restaurants."
 Mr. Setlock and Ms. Mode developed the piece together, making lists of types of characters while Mr. Setlock improvised his calls. To find the voices, he relied on his past job experiences. "A lot of the voices are really similar," he said. "My brother is just my father faster."
 Mr. Setlock is scheduled to perform until September. There is some talk that "Fully Committed" may become a television show, though Mr. Setlock is uncertain how he would fit in. "I'm not that interested in restaurants," he said. "I'm interested in freaks, the odd people in the world. I like to take them all in and see if I can spit them back out."
