HEADLINE: All Aboard for a Big Rail Deal?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
It is just steel and stone, a rough line scratched across an immense and largely empty landscape. But for much of the last century, as the whistle of Canadian National freight trains pierced the northern night, the "government railroad," as CN was known, helped define Canada.
The grand old railroad ran from east to west, and so did Canadian commerce -- even with American markets lying seductively close to the border. So long as there was a separate Canadian market, and a separate Canadian railway, generations of politicians vowed, there would be a separate Canada. 
 Now, the current president of the Canadian National Railway Company, Paul M. Tellier, has a different vision of the railroad, of Canada and of the American continent -- a vision that some people on both sides of the border reject. Though his focus remains transcontinental, he is looking south, across the United States border and beyond that into Mexico.
Mr. Tellier wants to merge the Montreal-based CN with a giant American railroad, the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation, and create the most titanic railroad this continent has ever seen. The behemoth would have 50,000 miles of track, combined annual revenue of $12.5 billion, freight service to 32 states and 8 Canadian provinces, and cross-border access from Halifax, Nova Scotia, to Mexico City to Long Beach, Calif.
The proposed $6 billion rail pact is important for what it says about one of America's oldest industries as well as what it shows about how North America is changing. Perhaps more than any other symbol, the alliance would underscore how far the formation of a truly integrated continental economy has developed in the six years since the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect.
"There has been a change in the mind of the peoples of North America," said Halina Ostrovski, president of the Canadian Council for the Americas, an economics-oriented research organization in Toronto. "They now see the three countries as one big market."
Not everyone is willing to accept the vision of the new railroad or the changes it represents. In the United States, shippers and unions, burned by service disruptions after other big rail mergers, oppose the deal, a cashless transaction that would create a new holding company, North American Railways. Competing railroads have warned that another merger at this time would push the industry into a final round of consolidations that would end with just two enormous networks to serve the entire continent of North America.
In Canada, shippers and farmers are worried that the merger will reduce what little competition exists -- CN's only national rival is the Canadian Pacific Railway Company. And fervent nationalists see the proposed merger as the loss of a revered national symbol and the last spike in the dream of an independent, sovereign Canada.
"We would probably not have the western part of the country in Canada today if not for these railways," said David Orchard, a prairie farmer and chairman of a Canadian group called Citizens Concerned About Free Trade. "This merger would be a betrayal of everything that the founders of the country fought for."
Both freight lines are led by executives determined to drag American railroads into a new era. Robert D. Krebs of the Fort Worth-based Burlington Northern is a bred-in-the-bone railroad man, with 34 years' experience running American trains. Mr. Tellier, who joined CN eight years ago, is a former civil servant with a passion for Descartes.
The combined railroad, they say, makes perfect economic sense. North-South traffic across the borders is expanding at a rate of 10 percent to 15 percent a year, while east-west traffic is rising no more than 4 percent annually. United States trade with Canada and Mexico has continued to grow even when trade with many other countries flattened out.
"What we're seeing in North America is what you would expect from the development of a free trading zone, but in many ways it goes beyond that," said Jorge O. Mariscal, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs. "It's now engulfing banking, telecommunications and transportation in a quite remarkable way."
The railroads have taken pains to present the deal as a merger of equals. Burlington Northern and CN would keep their own offices, and their locomotives would continue to be painted with their separate corporate logos.
But the balance of power seems to tip toward the Canadians. The parent company, North American Railways, will be in Montreal, and, by Canadian law, the majority of board members must be Canadian. Mr. Krebs, 66, would become non-executive chairman and Mr. Tellier, 60, chief executive.
The $40 billion North American freight railroad industry has already slimmed down considerably in response to relentless competition from trucking, which began offering transcontinental service a decade ago.
"Truckers have been eating our lunch every day of the week," Mr. Tellier said.
Over the last two decades the number of large, independent -- so-called Class I -- freight lines has declined substantially. In 1980, 26 such freight railroads operated in the United States, according to the Association of American Railroads. Today, just seven are left. While that decline was due in part to changes in the way railroads are categorized, there is no doubt that national railroads have been forced to get bigger to survive.
The outcry over the Burlington Northern-CN alliance has reached the Surface Transportation Board, the United States regulatory agency with the power to review, and possibly block, rail mergers. The board has scheduled an unusual public hearing next month -- before the formal merger application is even filed -- to look at the rail industry's future.
If railroad consolidation "plays itself out to the endgame that some feel it will," Linda J. Morgan, chairwoman of the board, wrote in response to the merger announcement in December, "this is the final round."
The most recent consolidations -- CSX and Norfolk Southern's absorption of Conrail, and the Union Pacific's acquisition of the Southern Pacific -- have not gone smoothly. Disgruntled shippers who continue to suffer delays and interruptions caused by the last mergers are in no mood for yet more consolidation. Led by the Chemical Manufacturers Association, they have made their displeasure known to regulators and to important members of Congress.
"This just ensures that politics is going to be the operative word," said James M. Higgins, a railroad analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "It has become a political issue, and politics is more about perception than reality."
The regulatory environment in Canada is quite different. The only significant review will be undertaken by the federal Competition Bureau, which will assess the merger's impact on competition within Canada, where the two railroads' lines overlap just for short stretches in Manitoba and British Columbia.
But Canadian legislators, particularly in the grain-growing west, where farms, mines and manufacturing plants rely on efficient rail service, are concerned that the combined railroad will favor Burlington Northern's more heavily used and profitable western line in the northern United States over Canadian National's parallel route. "The big issue in western Canada is lack of competition," said Reg Alcock, a ruling-party member of Parliament from Winnipeg. "We don't have many options."
Even Mr. Tellier of Canadian National acknowledges that support is growing for Canada's House of Commons to use a coming revision of the Canadian Transportation Act to give federal officials new powers to review mergers.
"If I was back in my previous job would I argue that it makes sense for the Government of Canada to bring an amendment to Parliament?" asked Mr. Tellier, who was clerk of the Privy Council, which made him the top bureaucrat in Canada, before taking control of CN in 1992. "Sure it makes sense. Do I expect something like this to be passed overnight? The answer is no."
He accuses Canadian nationalists and the competing railroads of playing on emotions to fight the merger. "We're not going to get into any kind of emotional debate or confrontation," he told analysts at a meeting in New York. "We're going forward in a very rational, Cartesian fashion to make our case."
Still, the emotions are real. Perhaps more than any other nation, Canada used the building of the railroad to stitch disparate colonies into a nation. The fledgling federal government used the audacious promise of building a rail line across the empty western prairies to entice the faraway province of British Columbia to enter confederation in 1871.
The building of the Canadian Pacific and what later became the Canadian National were heroic undertakings, spurred more by national pride than economic sense. The cost was sizable, with billions of dollars in subsidies going toward keeping the railroads running.
By 1919, a group of money-losing lines was taken over by the government and combined to form Canadian National. In the early 1990's, CN was privatized. More than 60 percent of the shares are held by American investors.
Mr. Tellier said he had no patience for those who think the alliance represents the Americanization of Canada. Last year, he bought the Illinois Central and it was an open secret that he was shopping for another American line, the Kansas City Southern, which is part owner of the recently privatized line from Mexico City to the border that carries about 40 percent of Mexico's rail traffic.
CN already has a 15-year marketing agreement with the Kansas City Southern that gives it access to the Mexico City line.
"If you look at a map, it would be a logical extension at one point in time," Mr. Tellier said, suggesting that CN might go after the Kansas City Southern again. He also said that an alliance with a carrier in the Northeast was inevitable.
Mr. Tellier is sometimes criticized for thinking like a government official and not like the chief executive of a tradition-bound business that he has become. But Mr. Krebs of Burlington Northern who has spent his whole career in railroading, is also convinced that running the trains on a continental basis is not only logical but inevitable.
"Market forces are demanding a transcontinental system," he said. "It's just a matter of time."

HEADLINE: CHINA SAYS TAIWAN CANNOT CONTINUE DELAYING REUNION

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Less than one month before presidential elections in Taiwan, the Chinese government released the bluntest warning yet that it will not wait indefinitely for the island to reunite with the mainland. A prolonged lack of negotiations, in itself, China warned, could provoke a military attack.
The Chinese have long made it clear that any moves by Taiwan toward formal independence would lead to war. But today's government report on Taiwan adds -- for the first time in such a definitive policy statement -- that if Taiwan refuses indefinitely to pursue "the peaceful settlement of cross-straits reunification through negotiations, then the Chinese government will only be forced to adopt all drastic measures possible, including the use of force, to safeguard China's sovereignty and territorial integrity." 
 The report does not provide timetable or deadline for negotiating progress. Still, "This is a signal that Beijing is getting impatient with the delays in the process of reunification," said Andrew Yang, secretary general of the China Council of Advanced Policy Studies, a private group in Taipei. "This is a warning to the people of Taiwan."
Taiwan officials said they would not comment until they had studied the document. As of tonight, the candidates in the March 18 presidential elections had not responded. The top contenders have favored talks of some sort, but not Beijing's vision of reunification.
The 11,000-word report, entitled "The One-China Principle and the Taiwan Issue," was released by the Taiwan affairs office and the information office of the state council, China's cabinet.
It elaborates on China's longstanding proposal for a negotiated return of Taiwan under a version of the "one country, two systems" formula, with even greater autonomy than was given to Hong Kong, which reverted to Chinese rule in 1997. "Provided that it is within the framework of one China, any question can be discussed," the report says, including "Taiwan's international space for economic, cultural and social activities compatible with its status, the political status of the Taiwan authorities and other questions."
That formula has been rejected as too confining by Taiwan's leaders and the three leading presidential candidates.
The dire warnings in the document were a reminder of what an emotional issue the reunification of Taiwan with the "motherland" is for Beijing, especially now that Hong Kong and Macao have returned to the fold. While there was no ultimatum or threat of immediate attack, they also underscore how explosive the confrontation across the Taiwan Strait is, potentially drawing the United States into war with China.
Today's report lambastes the United States for providing advanced weapons to Taiwan, which China says violates promises, and for proposals in Congress for a closer military relationship with the island, which it calls a "gross interference in China's internal affairs and a grave threat to China's security."
The United States officially supports the concept of "one China," but is also committed to providing Taiwan with the means to defend itself against attack.
In Washington, the State Department said there would be no official response until the report was studied "very carefully." But the harder line on Taiwan was likely to cause political problems for the Clinton administration as it faces a battle for Congressional approval of to get China's membership in the World Trade Organization approved in Congress. And the report's denunciation of the Congressional bill to upgrade military ties with Taiwan, which passed the House this month, could enhance support for the bill in the Senate.
The new Chinese report bitterly condemns Taiwan's president, Lee Tung-hui, accusing him of destroying previous talks with his assertion last summer that Taiwan would negotiate with China only on a "state-to-state" basis and his refusal to repeat the traditional homage to the concept of "one China."
After Mr. Lee's statement last summer, China broke off planned high-level meetings, charging that Mr. Lee was secretly scheming for independence even though he professes to support reunion at some distant point -- after the mainland, too, has become a democracy.
The report condemns Mr. Lee's suggestion of waiting for democracy as "an excuse for postponing and resisting reunification," since China has offered to allow different political systems to coexist under the banner of one China.
It is too early to tell what effect China's sharp words might have on Taiwan's election campaign. In 1996, before Taiwan's first direct elections for president, China was angered by Mr. Lee's defiant statements and fired missiles near Taiwan as a warning. The United States sent two aircraft carriers to the region.
Mr. Lee won election handily and seemed to gain popular appeal though his brinkmanship, but since then many Taiwanese who had toyed with the idea of declaring independence have had second thoughts.
China lacks the military power to invade Taiwan, experts say, and is no match for American forces should they be drawn into a confrontation. But China is steadily improving its navy; it recently received the first of two Russian-built guided-missile destroyers designed to penetrate American carrier group defenses. And it is building up forces of ballistic and cruise missiles. Both could be used to cripple Taiwan's economy by disrupting sea lanes.
So far, this year's election campaign has involved fewer military tensions, and in Taiwan the candidates have gone out of their way to avoid sounding provocative. Surveys show that a large majority of the Taiwan public, after enjoying years of prosperity and democracy, does not want a military confrontation with China.
All three major candidates, -- Vice President Lien Chan of the governing Nationalist Party; James Soong, a former Nationalist leader who is running as an independent, and Chen Shui-bian, of the Democratic Progressive Party -- have made vague pledges to resume negotiations of some sort with China and to encourage more trade and business links. But none endorses China's formula for reunification, and it is unclear what the two sides might say in future to talks to give China a sense of progress toward unity.
Some political experts think that today's Chinese warning may be intended, in part, to scare voters away from Mr. Chen, whose party has long been associated with Taiwan independence. The founding charter of his party calls for a referendum on whether the island, still formally called the Republic of China, should be renamed the Republic of Taiwan.
Mr. Chen, seeking to broaden his electoral appeal, has declared that since Taiwan is already independent in practice, it does not need a formal declaration and that if elected, he would not pursue a referendum on the issue unless Taiwan came under attack. He has offered to discuss improving communications and economic ties, something the mainland badly wants.
The report released today unequivocally rejects the legitimacy of any referendum in Taiwan on independence, warning, "Any attempt to separate Taiwan from China through so-called referendum would only lead the Taiwan people to disaster."
In effect, today's warning puts the Taiwan candidates on notice that China does not intend to allow a repeat of Mr. Lee's performance, which it believes brought a halt to even the pretense of negotiations toward symbolic unification.

HEADLINE: Pardon Lets Black Exile Come Home

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton granted a pardon today to a 63-year-old political scientist who went into self-imposed exile almost four decades ago after his draft board in Georgia, learning that he was black, refused to address him as "mister."
The pardon for the man, Preston King, a professor at the University of Lancaster in Britain, overturns Mr. King's 1961 conviction for draft evasion and allows him to return to the United States for the funeral of his oldest brother later this week. 
 Mr. King had said at the time of his conviction that he was willing to report for an Army physical and serve in the military so long as the draft board in Albany, Ga., referred to him as "Mr. King" instead of "Preston."
The board, which had used "mister" in earlier correspondence to Mr. King but stopped after its members learned of his skin color, refused. Mr. King was convicted of draft evasion by an all-white jury and sentenced to 18 months in prison. He fled the country while out on bail.
Among those who had recently called for a pardon was the trial judge in the case, William A. Bootle of Federal District Court in Macon, Ga. In a letter to President Clinton last year, Judge Bottle, who is now in his 90's, said Mr. King had "followed his conscience just as Rosa Parks had followed hers."
A White House spokesman, Jim Kennedy, said President Clinton had "considered the facts, the law and all the circumstances involved here and decided that clemency was appropriate."
He said that the White House had a policy of not discussing the details of the president's reasoning in clemency cases but that the decision-making process was speeded up for Mr. King "because of humanitarian concern," given his brother's death.
"Preston King was one of the first people who stood up against government discrimination," said one of his lawyers, Elizabeth Holtzman, the former Democratic congresswoman and Brooklyn district attorney.
"He was denied an extension of his draft deferment because of his race," Ms. Holtzman said in an interview. "He was addressed in a demeaning fashion because of his race. He was convicted by a totally segregated jury. In a way, this case reflects not just Preston King coming home, but this country coming home."
She said Mr. King, who was traveling tonight to London from his home in Lancaster and was not available for an interview, would return to the United States on Wednesday, for the first time in 39 years.
Clennon L. King, a television journalist in Jacksonville, Fla. who is a nephew of Mr. King, said that the family was "thrilled" by news of the pardon "although these are very sober circumstances because of the death of his brother."
Mr. King's oldest brother, also named Clennon, a civil rights leader who was committed to an insane asylum for a time because he had the temerity to try to enroll at the all-white University of Mississippi in the 1950's, died last week at the age of 79. He is scheduled to be buried on Thursday.
Mr. King graduated magna cum laude from all-black Fisk University in Nashville in 1956 and received a deferment from military service that allowed him to study for a master's degree at the London School of Economics.
He has said the draft board refused additional deferments and began to refer to him simply as "Preston" in letters, dropping the "mister" that was routine for white students when he appeared in person at their offices in 1958 and the board's members realized for the first time that he was black.
In his letter to the White House, Judge Bootle said that Mr. King "has paid a big price" and that "to lock him up today would amount to overkill."
While he insisted that the trial had been "error free," the judge suggested that Mr. King was right, in fact, heroic, to stand up to the draft board and insist that he be addressed as "mister." "Mr. King was deeply sensitive to what he recognized as this long-lasting, deeply rooted method of racial discrimination," the judge said.
He noted that a new federal courthouse in Albany was being named for another of Mr. King's brothers, C. B. King, a prominent civil rights lawyer. "If Mr. King can be allowed to attend the dedication of this building," the letter said, "many of us who are familiar with the facts will be comfortable and happy that this little tragedy has ended."

HEADLINE: Safety a Worry as Companies Shop for Nuclear Reactors

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
As nuclear families go, the Indian Point 2 reactor's is about as small as they get. It has suffered its teething problems, growing pains, setbacks and crises pretty much as an only child, under the tutelage of a corporate parent, Consolidated Edison, that has little experience in the care and feeding of a nuclear reactor.
The adjacent Indian Point 3, with its checkered operational history, is also pretty lonely, in the corporate sense. It is run by the New York Power Authority, which has only one other reactor, of a different design, on the shores of Lake Ontario. 
 But both may be sold soon. Would the plants operate better, or more safely, if adopted into a company with a bigger brood?
"There's benefit to aggregating expertise," said Stephen E. Quinn, a vice president of Con Edison. "There's a lot of professional things you gain there." His company once set out to have three reactors, but Indian Point 1, which resembles a modern reactor the way a Commodore 64 resembles an iMac, was shut down before Indian Point 2 opened in 1974. Con Ed built Indian Point 3 but sold it to the Power Authority before opening it.
Both Con Ed and the Power Authority run what experts sometimes refer to as mom and pop reactors. Like many other utilities, Con Ed is seeking to sell Indian Point 2 mostly because of utility deregulation, which has sent a handful of other groups shopping for reactors.
Experts, including advocates and critics of nuclear power, are ambivalent about what the effect could be. It could be management with more experience, or it could be management with a stronger drive to make money, which some people think may not be consistent with safety.
Circumstances seem likely to provide a test. Power Authority directors are scheduled to meet this month to vote on the sale of Indian Point 3 and the James A. FitzPatrick reactor, in Oswego, N.Y., to Entergy Nuclear, a company based in Jackson, Miss. The company has negotiated a deal to operate Nine Mile Point 1 and 2, in Scriba, N.Y., for Rochester Gas and Electric, although ownership of those reactors is confused. Nine Mile Point 1 and 2 could go to another entity that is trying to buy reactors: Amergen, a partnership of British Energy and the parent company of Philadelphia Electric.
Entergy officials would not say if they were negotiating for Indian Point 2, but Carl Crawford, a spokesman, said: "We are interested in any plant that's available in the U.S. We're building a new fleet of reactors in the northeast."
The Amergen partnership, which is interested in Indian Point 2, would like to buy as many as 20 reactors, a spokesman, J. William Jones, said. The group has already bought Three Mile Island 1, near Harrisburg, Pa., and Clinton, near the southern Illinois city of the same name, and has struck a deal to buy Oyster Creek, in Toms River, N.J., and Vermont Yankee, near Brattleboro, Vt.
There are factors that make it positive for safety, said David Lochbaum, a nuclear engineer based here at the Union of Concerned Scientists, which is generally critical of the utilities and of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. "The new owner of a nuclear power plant clearly has a commitment to a nuclear future," said Mr. Lochbaum, who worked as a consultant for both Philadelphia Electric and Entergy before moving to the Union of Concerned Scientists. "They've made a business decision they can make money at nuclear power. They will do whatever it takes to make that investment work."
The sellers, on the other hand, "may not have made the choice to go nuclear," Mr. Lochbaum said. "It may just be the legacy they've inherited." Of course, he added, "you can also make the counterargument that the new owner is only trying to make a quick buck, to recoup their investment and make some money."
Shirley Anne Jackson, a physicist who retired last year as chairwoman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to become president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in Troy, N.Y., also expressed ambivalence.
"If you have a strong company taking over a number of plants, then you'd have the potential for quite a salutary effect in how those plants are operated, in overall safety performance as well as economic performance," she said. "It's more difficult for a single-plant utility to amass the kind of critical mass to be able to have the kind of expertise and resources to bring to bear."
But she added, "you can't argue that size in and of itself gives you good performance." Two of the biggest operators, she said, the Tennessee Valley Authority and Commonwealth Edison, also had some of the worst operating experiences.
Some people concerned about nuclear safety say that a buyer is under more pressure to keep a plant running, even if it needs maintenance, than an old-style monopoly utility with a captive customer population. But other experts say that high reliability and safety are likely to come hand in hand.
At Entergy Nuclear, Jerry W. Yelverton, the president and chief executive, said that the old theory was that plants that shut down only briefly for refueling must be skipping something important and reducing safety. But he said that capacity factor -- the amount of electricity produced, compared with what would have occurred if the plant ran at full power 365 days a year -- tended to be highest when other statistics were also favorable, like low radiation exposure to workers, low number of hours when crucial systems were not working, and small number of problems that had to be reported to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.
Entergy, he said, had changed its strategy, undertaking aggressive maintenance on various systems while the plant was running to keep them in top shape. One example is emergency diesel generators, needed in case of a blackout in the region. Entergy used to take the generators, which are trouble-prone, off-line for service while the plant was shut, which lengthened refueling shut-downs and also made them unavailable at a time when, analysis shows, they were more likely to be needed. Now it takes them off-line in rotation while the plant is running, keeping them in top shape and raising their availability at important times.
Others see a less glowing picture. The Nuclear Information and Resource Service, a nonprofit group here that favors shutting down reactors, is trying to block Amergen's purchase of Oyster Creek. The partnership is expanding into too many plants, according to Michael Mariotte, the executive director, and may be stretched too thin.
In addition, he said, operators are supposed to have enough cash on hand to weather a six-month shutdown, which can amount to $75 million or more, and to help pay for a nuclear accident anywhere in the country, which can come to $10 million a year for 7 years. It is not clear if Amergen can do that for more than one reactor, Mr. Mariotte said.
"It's a company with essentially no assets," he said. "It didn't exist two years ago."
Mr. Jones, the Amergen spokesman, said he could not say if such liabilities would rest with the partnership or the parent companies.
At the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Robert S. Wood, the senior financial policy adviser, said that Amergen was financially qualified to handle its completed purchases.
When companies make an agreement to buy a plant and apply to have the operating license transferred to them, they tend to have far more experience than the original licensee had. Between acquisitions and mergers, another trend in the utility industry, the agency foresees getting about 20 applications in the next few months, representing one-fifth of the operating reactors.
But Mr. Mariotte of the Nuclear Information and Resource Service said it was a case-by-case problem. Recalling Northeast Utilities, among others, he said, "the largest utilities have often gotten into the most trouble."

HEADLINE: Hasty Call for Amnesty

 BODY:
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s call for the government to grant amnesty to an estimated six million illegal immigrants currently living in the United States and to eliminate most sanctions on employers who hire them in the future was a surprising turnabout. Until now, organized labor has fought hard to keep illegal workers from taking jobs from higher-paid union workers.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s proposal is attractive to many groups. Unions welcome the chance to go after a huge new pool of unorganized workers. Employers welcome the chance to hire cheap labor without fear of criminal liability. And illegal immigrants who have worked hard for years and raised families under harrowing circumstances would welcome access to medical care and other services denied to illegal aliens. 
 But the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s proposal should be rejected. Amnesty would undermine the integrity of the country's immigration laws and would depress the wages of its lowest-paid native-born workers.
Back in 1986, Congress granted amnesty to an estimated three million illegal immigrants as part of a law that also promised to crack down on further illegal immigration by imposing sanctions on employers who knowingly violated the law. At that time, this page endorsed amnesty because it was tied to measures that promised to keep further rounds of illegal immigration in check. But 14 years later there are twice as many illegal workers, and employer sanctions are widely deemed a joke. Workers pretend to show employers proof of citizenship or work visas and employers pretend they do not know the proof is fake.
The primary problem with amnesties is that they beget more illegal immigration. Demographers trace the doubling of the number of Mexican immigrants since 1990 in part to the amnesty of the 1980's. Amnesties signal foreign workers that American citizenship can be had by sneaking across the border, or staying beyond the term of one's visa, and hiding out until Congress passes the next amnesty. The 1980's amnesty also attracted a large flow of illegal relatives of those workers who became newly legal. All that is unfair to those who play by the immigration rules and wait years to gain legal admission.
It is also unfair to unskilled workers already in the United States. Between about 1980 and 1995, the gap between the wages of high school dropouts and all other workers widened substantially. Prof. George Borjas of Harvard estimates that almost half of this trend can be traced to immigration of unskilled workers. Illegal immigration of unskilled workers induced by another amnesty would make matters worse. The better course of action is to honor America's proud tradition by continuing to welcome legal immigrants and find ways to punish employers who refuse to obey the law.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC INTERESTS;
Remembering a George for All Seasons

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Happy Washington's Birthday! Today we celebrate the career of a George who became first in the hearts of his countrymen without conducting a single town meeting.
Washington, by the way, was actually born on Feb. 11, not 22. In 1752 Britain and its colonies jumped ahead 11 days in order to get their calendar in sync with the rest of Europe. After that, he was never entirely certain about his birthdate, or even birth year, since the Americans also shifted New Year's Day from March 25 to Jan. 1. 
 Q. Excuse me, but why in the world are you telling me all this?
A. I just thought it would be a nice millennial touch.
Q. Uh-huh. Actually, I was hoping you'd explain how the Bush campaign managed to spend $50 million so fast.
A. George W. Bush was asked that very question last week. He told reporters that "We have a plan in place," and also that "We're on the plan." He went on to say that his campaign had "got a plan," which was "a broad plan" and "a plan that's working."
Q. So in other words, it's a plan.
A. The official theory is that the Bush campaign cannily and deliberately threw all its resources into smashing John McCain in South Carolina, confident that it would still be able to raise heaps more money later on.
Q. What's the unofficial theory?
A. Contrarians believe that Mr. Bush, like Al Gore before him, fell victim to the Law of Financial Leakage, which dictates that a candidate's assets will quickly come into equilibrium with supporters' desire to spend them. Cynics refer to this as the District Chairmen With Unemployed Relatives Rule, and it is far more effective than the Federal Election Commission in leveling the presidential playing field.
Q. Have you tried that out on the Bush campaign people?
A. They prefer it to the Gramm-Connally Law, which states that presidential candidates who emerge from Texas bearing pots and pots of money inevitably come to disaster.
Q. Is George Bush really a completely different candidate now? How do you get a middle-aged man to change himself so fast?
A. Stylistically, Mr. Bush has simply adopted the Al Gore tactic of demonstrating his sincerity by raising his voice. But while Mr. Gore likes to yell out entire sentences, Mr. Bush simply goes for every other noun. ("The people of THIS STATE can start the end of the CLINTON ERA in Washington D.C.")
Q. Would you remind me again what compassionate conservatism is?
A. To quote Mr. Bush: "It is conservative to lower taxes. It is compassionate to give the money back to the people."
Q. If you lowered taxes, who else would you give the money back to?
A. Hey, you can't claim the low road from a high horse. We're talking about reducing the toll booth to the middle class and demolishing the tolls.
Q. How come when the other candidates are fuzzy on an issue, reporters say they're "ducking," but when John McCain does it they say he's "evolving"?
A. When reporters point out contradictions in his positions, Senator McCain often says, "That's a good point, I'll have to think about that." This is what we call evolving.
Q. How come he got whomped in South Carolina?
A. Look, it's an unusual place. Half of American history involves efforts to get South Carolina to stop acting out.
Q. I saw the Democrats had a debate last night. Whatever happened to that primary?
A. Some say John McCain sucked the air out of Bill Bradley's campaign. My own theory is that Mr. Bradley's troubles began when women realized that he sounds a lot like an extremely pompous husband pretending to be patient.
Q. Does he still have a chance?
A. Mr. Bradley is trying to re-start his campaign even as we speak. He says the state of Washington could be the firewall that stops Al Gore in his tracks.
Q. Say what?
A. That's the plan, and if it keeps the race alive until my state gets a chance to vote, let there be firewalls. The Washington primary, by the way, is on Feb. 29. Have I mentioned that, because of calendric reforms initiated by Pope Gregory XIII, this is the first '00 leap year since 1600?

Debate Over Who Must Pay For Calls to Cellular Phones
A debate is raging at the Federal Communications Commission about whether cellular telephone customers must continue to pay to receive calls as well as to make them.
Cellular companies, hoping to make wireless phones a viable alternative to the desk phone, have pressed for a rule change that would allow them to bring wireless calls under the same "calling party pays" system used with the traditional telephone network. Some traditional phone companies and consumer groups oppose such a change. Page A1. 

MCI-Sprint Merger Investigation
The European Commission's antitrust regulators said that they had "serious concerns" about the plans of MCI Worldcom to acquire the Sprint Corporation for $130 billion and that they would conduct an intensive four-month investigation into the deal. C4.
 
German Concern Buys the Muppets
EM.TV & Merchandising, a German television program distributor, agreed to buy the Jim Henson Company, creator of the Muppets, for $680 million. C4.
 
Czech Promoter Sued by Investor
A second American investor has sued a Czech promoter who sold investments in Azerbaijan, primarily the state oil company, which was being privatized. The suit seeks $126 million in damages. C4.
 
British Insurance Companies Merge
Two of Britain's best-known insurance companies, CGU P.L.C. and Norwich Union P.L.C., announced today that they would merge in a $12 billion stock swap that analysts depicted as a shield against Continental European predators. The deal would create Europe's fifth-largest insurer. C4.
 
British Remain Opposed to Euro
Contrary to a tenuous schedule offered a year ago by Prime Minister Tony Blair, British sentiment is growing stronger against joining Continental Europe in adopting the euro as its currency. C4
 
Stocks Fall in Europe and Asia
Most European and Asian stocks fell amid concerns that higher interest rates in the United States would hurt corporate profits. Much of the fear stemmed from comments made last week by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, indicating that more rate increases were likely if the United States economy did not cool down. HEADLINE: F.C.C. Splits on Issue Of Cellular Charges For Incoming Calls

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
A debate is raging at the Federal Communications Commission about whether cellular telephone customers must continue to pay to receive calls as well as to make them.
Cellular companies, hoping to make wireless phones a viable, everyday alternative to the desk phone, have pressed for new rules that would allow them to bring wireless calls under the same "calling party pays" system used with the traditional telephone network. 
 But traditional local phone companies, which benefit from the current system, see far less need to change the rules. And some consumer groups argue that a change would mean higher rates for regular phone customers.
The F.C.C. had been scheduled to vote on final rules for such a system last Thursday, giving cellular companies the option of adopting caller-pays billing systems. But the vote was canceled amid continued wrangling among commissioners, staff members and lobbyists. The commission could still reach a decision over the next few weeks, but with heavy lobbying from all sides, the process could well stretch into the spring.
More than 80 million American consumers now use wireless phones. But for only very few of them has the wireless phone become a true replacement for the standard home telephone, because the current payment system gives standard, wired telephones a distinct cost advantage.
When the wired telephone rings at home, people generally answer without worrying about whether it is a local or long distance call. Unless the call is made collect, any charges will be the responsibility of the person who placed the call.
But as anyone with a cellular phone knows, wireless subscribers almost invariably pay for incoming as well as outgoing calls. People who use a traditional telephone to place a long-distance call to a wireless subscriber incur long-distance fees just as if they were calling a desk phone. Still, wireless charges can quickly mount, especially if the incoming call incurs roaming fees. That is a big reason many users do not give their numbers to others and generally leave their cell phones turned off.
Even with the rise of so-called one rate plans, pioneered by AT&T, which eliminate roaming fees and long-distance charges for wireless users, subscribers still pay for incoming calls.
The current payment system for cellular calls is a legacy of the industry's founding in the early 1980's, when cellular phones were conceived as a business-class luxury. The entrepreneurs who built many of the early networks sought to recoup their investments by charging premium rates to the people affluent enough to use the phones -- and charging them whether they were using the network to make or to receive calls.
But as competition within the cellular industry has led to more affordable rates, and more Americans have become cell phone subscribers, cellular companies are seeking an overhaul of their industry's basic economics. The cellular companies are eager to compete on a more equal footing with conventional phone companies for the nation's $100-billion-a-year local communications business.
So far, residential local phone markets have generally remained de facto monopolies, dominated by the regional Bell companies and a handful of independent operators including the GTE Corporation, which has agreed to merge with Bell Atlantic. Although many of the local telephone companies, including Bell Atlantic, are also active in the wireless business, they tend to run their cellular companies as separate units.
Many analysts and wireless executives believe that eliminating wireless fees for incoming calls -- as most other countries have done -- could go a long way toward making wireless carriers viable long-term competitors to local phone monopolies.
"We're trying to get a level playing field with the local phone companies," Andrew Sukawaty, chief executive of the Sprint Corporation's wireless unit, Sprint PCS, said in an interview last week. "If you look at almost every other country in the world, they all have calling-party- pays as a standard. In those countries where you have calling-party- pays, you have a much higher percentage of people giving out their number and using it for inbound calls. In this country there is a lot more hesitancy to give out the number."
In other parts of the world, particularly in Europe, the cellular industry developed more recently than in the United States. And rather than being conceived as a luxury item, the cell phone overseas has been seen as an extension of -- or even an improvement upon -- the wired telephone network.
Wireless carriers in the United States are not prohibited from offering calling-party-pays. But with the F.C.C. having spent the last few years studying the issue, few carriers have been willing to bring such plans broadly into the market until they know just what the commission's national rules will be. Bell Atlantic's wireless unit, for instance, began a trial program in Delaware last November called Call Me, but has not expanded the plan past a "couple of thousand" subscribers, according to a Bell Atlantic spokeswoman.
As a general proposition, many of the F.C.C. commissioners appear to agree that fostering calling-party-pays could increase overall competition among wired and wireless phone operators, according to people close to the agency.
But there are big hurdles concerning consumer protection and the internal financial structure of a caller-pays system that must be cleared before any consensus can be achieved.
Regarding consumers, the most important issue is to make sure that people who dial a wireless subscriber who uses a caller-pays plan are made aware that they will be charged, and how much.
Someone who makes a conventional telephone call from the United States to, say, Kazakhstan, is not told the charges. But the caller presumably has a reasonable expectation that the fee will be substantial, if only because they are making an international call to a place so far away.
The complication posed by a caller-pays system in the wireless sector is that a call to what appears to be a local number could in fact incur big per-minute "roaming" fees because the user is traveling on the other side of the continent. Without some sort of notification, the caller would have no way of knowing about those fees until a bill arrived.
The wireless carriers appear to be in favor of less notification rather than more. For example, Mr. Sukawaty said consumers could eventually be informed by a simple tone that the call they were placing was to a wireless number that would incur a charge.
In Europe, where the caller-pays system is generally the rule, wireless phone numbers often include one or two digits more than do traditional lines. So while European callers do not generally hear a notification message, the additional digit indicates that additional fees may apply. In the United States, many communications experts say it would not be feasible to add an additional digit to wireless numbers, if only because the cost of modifying communications switches across the nation could be prohibitive.
It is also somewhat simpler for European carriers to establish caller-pays systems because most wireless companies in Europe own nationwide licenses, reducing the prevalence of roaming fees. In the United States, few wireless carriers own licenses for the entire nation.
The F.C.C. is thought to be leaning toward a substantial notification system -- one that would require that a caller hear a message indicating what the charge will be and that would give the caller an opportunity to disconnect before incurring any fees at all.
Some of the conventional local phone companies appear to hope that extensive notification messages would discourage people from calling wireless subscribers who use a caller-pays plan.
The other major issue that stands in the way of consensus on a caller-pays system is one that would not be obvious to most consumers but which is vitally important for the carriers: billing.
Generally, local phone companies are no longer obliged to include the services of other companies on their bills. That is why some consumers now receive separate bills from their local and long-distance carriers.
Extending that logic, some local phone giants are arguing before the commission that they should not be obliged to include charges on their bills for calls their customers make to wireless phones under a caller-pays system.
If that argument succeeded, it could mean that consumers might receive separate bills from various wireless carriers. Or, alternately, they could be forced to use a credit card to call a wireless number.
All of the complications strike some consumer advocates as ridiculous. They argue that people who choose wireless phones should pay for their use.
"We think this is one of the silliest ideas to hit the policy arena," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union, an advocacy group. "The notion that people who don't use wireless phones should pay extra to reach people who are using the new technology is just absurd."

HEADLINE: How to Make Globalization Work

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman ("An American Pie," column, Feb. 16) delights in the irony of affluent Americans trying to hold back the economic growth of impoverished third world countries. Opponents of globalization do not, by and large, oppose modernization per se; rather, they oppose development dictated by the rich industrialized countries at the expense of the vast majority in the developing world. 
 Furthermore, the protesters in Seattle included the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the United Steel Workers as well as activists from around the world. Some delegates from developing countries even credited the demonstrators for giving them increased leverage with the wealthier countries in negotiating trade rules.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE BATTLEGROUND;
Evangelist Goes On the Attack To Help Bush

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 21

 BODY:
While George W. Bush tried today to rally Michigan voters for Tuesday's primary here with a sunny message of tax cutting and political reform, a second, shadow campaign by his allies sought to sow suspicions of Senator John McCain.
Supporters of Mr. McCain reported receiving automated telephone calls in which the recorded voice of the evangelist Pat Robertson urged them to "protect unborn babies and restore religious freedom" by opposing Mr. McCain. As he has on his cable television program, Mr. Robertson, a supporter of Mr. Bush, accuses Mr. McCain of having chosen as his national chairman "a vicious bigot who wrote that conservative Christians in politics are anti-abortion zealots, homophobes and would-be censors." 
 The reference is to former Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who used those phrases in his autobiography to describe some in the Christian right, although he also said there were "some fine, sincere people in its ranks."
Mr. McCain, as he crossed the state on the final day of campaigning before the primary, continued to attack Mr. Bush as a character assassin and a pretender to the mantle of Republican reformer. And the Bush campaign accused Mr.McCain's operatives of making attack calls of their own.
A spokesman for Mr. Robertson said tonight that he had recorded his message without the knowledge of the Bush campaign. Bush aides said that they knew nothing of the calls and that the direct calls they were making to voters were all positive.
"All of our scripts are positive get-out-the-vote scripts," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Mr. Bush.
The parallel campaigns here against Mr. McCain, one above the fray and the other slashing, recalled the pattern in South Carolina, where third parties spread damaging and sometimes false information about Mr. McCain. The votes of conservative Christians, who were and are the focus of those messages, were crucial to Mr. Bush's victory.
In Michigan, other groups are also coming to Mr. Bush's aid with radio commercials intended to inflame doubts about Mr. McCain's commitment to ending abortion.
As the McCain campaign disclosed Mr. Robertson's calls, the Bush campaign late today released transcripts of two automated calls supporting the senator. In them, a recorded voice repeated many of the same criticisms that Mr. McCain has made publicly. One call accused Mr. Bush of increasing public spending by a greater percentage in Texas than Bill Clinton has in Washington.
"Both McCain and Bush are good men," the caller continued, "but John McCain has a much more conservative record on fighting spending."
The second call accused Mr. Bush of a "negative smear campaign" and urged a vote against "negative smear politics."
Michael Hudome, Mr. McCain's top aide in the state, said that the two calls transcribed by the Bush campaign were consistent with calls the McCain forces were making.
"We have a transcript that says they are both good men, and they call that negative," Mr. Hudome said. "What do they want us to say?"
Mr. McCain's message today was largely consistent with the two automated calls.
"I'm just like Luke Skywalker trying to get out of the Death Star," the senator declared, delighting in his new Star Wars imagery before a rowdy crowd at Heritage High School in Saginaw, north of here.
In an appeal to Michigan's independent-minded voters, he held Mr. Bush's establishment support, including that of Gov. John Engler, against him.
"I'm telling you, they're shooting at me from everywhere," Mr. McCain said. "Everybody's against me. Governor Engler, Governor Bush, all the governors, all the senators. And we're going to kill them, right?"
As some in the crowd chanted, "No more Bush!" Mr. McCain replied, "I thank you. There's our secret weapons."
Mr. Bush tried to ignore his Republican rival today, explaining to reporters that "this is the time to rally the vote." He preferred to direct his barbs at Vice President Al Gore, whom he accused of "politics that's so stale and so negative." But when pressed, Mr. Bush again questioned Mr. McCain's commitment to cleaning up the political system.
"He talks about the iron triangle in Washington, D.C.," Mr. Bush said, referring to the senator's complaints about the links between lobbyists, campaign donations and legislation. "He's been ringing that iron triangle like a dinner bell."
Told of Mr. Bush's simile, Mr. McCain responded, "He's the one taking all the money from them. Seems to me he's had a Pavlovian reaction."
With a laugh, he essayed a metaphor, accusing Mr. Bush of having "both feet in the trough."
After weeks of boutique politicking in New Hampshire and South Carolina, the candidates, short of time to impress voters and short of patience with each other, were counting on their national images and a burst of appearances to make and correct impressions in what Mr. Bush today called an abbreviated "two-day primary."
In his speeches, Mr. Bush was buoyant as he moved east to west, from the company of workers at a Detroit factory to a rally among Grand Rapids's more conservative voters this evening. Mr. McCain traveled north to south before flying home this evening to Arizona, which also votes on Tuesday.
Late into the evening, the Bush and McCain campaigns traded accusations of sinister telephone calls. Bush aides supplied the telephone numbers of women who said they had received calls accusing Mr. Bush of being anti-Catholic.
Adrienne Karns, who lives in the Detroit suburb of Birmingham, said she received a call at 5:30 this afternoon that issued a "Catholic voters alert." Then, she said, the anonymous voice told her "that George Bush had gone to Bob Jones University, and Bob Jones University was anti-Catholic, and George Bush was anti-Catholic." Then, she continued, "It said John McCain was pro-Catholic and I should vote for John McCain."
The McCain campaign denied any knowledge of the calls. And it supplied the telephone number of Sue Eaton, a homemaker in Ypsilanti who said she had received an automated telephone call today attacking Mr. McCain and "more or less insinuating to the fact of being a P.O.W. made him have a bad temper."
Ms. Eaton said the call suggested that Mr. McCain would have a hair-trigger in dealing with an obstreperous foreign power like Iraq, and urged her to make a "wise choice." She said she did not know the origin of the call, and the Bush campaign denied any knowledge of it.
Any of Michigan's 6.7 million registered voters is free to cast a ballot Tuesday, regardless of party affiliation. Pollsters have pronounced the race too close and too volatile to call.
Candice Miller, Michigan's secretary of state and state elections officer, has been predicting that 950,000 voters will turn out on Tuesday, when the weather is expected to be unseasonably mild but seasonably cloudy. Just over half a million voted in the primary of March 1996.
In addition to the bigger voice that the primary's earlier date has given them in selecting the nominee, Michigan voters are likely to be drawn to the polls by several local ballot issues, like whether to to raise $12 million to overhaul Birmingham's sewers.
As much as 20 percent of the potential vote may already have been cast by absentee ballot. Michigan automatically mails such ballots to its elderly residents.
John Schwarz, the only Republican state senator to endorse Mr. McCain, said he was hoping for 1.1 million voters to turn out, because he felt that would benefit the senator.
"Your rejoinder could be, 'Well it didn't in South Carolina,' " Mr. Schwarz said, referring to the record turnout that carried Mr. Bush to a big victory on Saturday. "My answer to that is South Carolina is not Michigan. I can't think of two states that are more different in their geography, their demography."
Higher turnout, he said, "indicates more independents are voting, and as you know, Michigan is independent heaven." In 1996, 10 percent of the voters in the Republican primary were Democrats, and 28 percent were independents.
Polls indicate that Mr. Bush has strong support among Republicans here. Given Mr. McCain's hopes of rallying independents, the senator's itinerary today seemed odd, since he did not campaign in suburban Detroit, where they are concentrated.
"Would I have gone to Oakland County?" asked Mr. Schwarz, speaking by telephone before climbing back on the candidate's bus in Saginaw. "Yeah, I would have. But I'm not making those decisions." He noted that in two days Mr. McCain had hit "probably six of the nine media markets in the state."
 Mr. McCain ended up in Arizona Mondy night, where he held one last rally at the University of Arizona in Tucson. Greeted by a crowd of more than one thousand, he said, "I can't tell you how greatful I am for the large turnout." He also took a jab at Mr. Bush saying, "Friends, we want to thank the Bush campaign -- we want to thank them for contributing about three million dollars to our economy," a reference to the campaign advertisements Mr. Bush has run in Mr. Mcain's home state.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
A New High-Tech Boom

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Along the Merritt and Wilbur Cross parkways in Connecticut, business analysts say, there is a new superhighway springing up -- a technology corridor formed by scores of high-tech and Internet businesses.
Some, like Stamford's Priceline
.com and the Gartner Group, are internationally recognized. Others, like Norwalk's iBirthday.com, are just getting started. 
 But taken together, they hold the potential to achieve national prominence.
"There definitely is a boom in the Internet companies and the companies that serve them," said Victor Budnick, executive director of Connecticut Innovations Inc., which invests in technology start-ups.
Should the area gain a national reputation as a vibrant technology corridor, it could result in dozens of new businesses and their employees coming to the state.
A survey last year counted more than 600 technology-oriented businesses in communities along the parkways. In the months since then, many more have been founded. A poll of venture capital firms found investment in Connecticut companies -- many involved in high-tech and software enterprises -- doubled in 1999 to a record $521 million.

HEADLINE: FOOD CHAIN

BYLINE: By MELISSA CLARK

 BODY:

Of Oats and the Meal
Q. I have just returned from London, Paris and Milan, where I often found porridge on breakfast menus. While similar to oatmeal in texture, it had a taste of its own, and I was told it is low fat and nutritious. Is porridge available in the New York City area?
A. Although porridge, essentially boiled cereal, can be made from any type of grain, the type you were served was probably made from oats. It tasted so different from the oatmeal you're used to in the United States because of the way the grains are processed. 
 Steel-cut oats, also known as Irish or Scotch oats, are much more popular for porridge in Europe than the rolled oats preferred here. Steel-cut oats are unrefined; they have simply been dried and roughly cut. Since hardly any heat is applied during processing, they retain a good portion of their nutrients, and are an excellent source of B vitamins.
Rolled oats, on the other hand, have been sliced, steamed, rolled into little flakes and dried, losing a bit of their nutritional value along the way. Both types of oats are low in fat.
With their denser shape, steel-cut oats take much longer to cook than rolled oats (45 minutes as compared to 5). But the resulting porridge has a creamier texture and nuttier flavor.
Although most New York City area restaurants serve rolled oats, you can find some that serve steel-cut oats, especially those that serve Irish or English breakfasts. You can buy steel-cut oats in most health food stores, or in specialty shops, where they are labeled Irish oatmeal.
 
Substituting Gelatins
 
Q. I have a recipe calling for sheet gelatin. I'm used to using powdered gelatin and wonder if I can substitute that for sheet gelatin.
A. Powdered gelatin, carried in most supermarkets, can be substituted for sheet gelatin (also known as leaf gelatin), which can be hard to find in stores. Generally, one quarter-ounce package (two and a quarter teaspoons) of powdered gelatin has the equivalent gelling power of five sheets of gelatin. That means you should use a scant half-teaspoon of powdered gelatin for every sheet of gelatin called for. It's not an exact science, though, and I've found that it takes some experimenting to get the texture just right. You might want to practice the recipe once if you are making it for a special event.
Once you have figured out how much powdered gelatin you'll need, place it in a heatproof cup and dampen it with a tablespoon or so of cold water. Let the gelatin sit for five minutes, then place the cup in a pan of simmering water. Stir the gelatin mixture until it is smooth and dissolved, then add it to the liquid to be gelled and proceed with the recipe.
If you would like to try using sheet gelatin, which many chefs find easier to work with than powdered gelatin, it can be ordered from the Baker's Catalog (800-827-6836), which sells packets of six sheets for $1.95 each.
 
Homemade Baking Powder
 
Q. I recently ran out of baking powder. I read the contents of the empty can, which listed essentially cornstarch and baking soda. As these two items are always in the house, could you please tell me the proportions necessary to make my own baking powder at a fraction of the cost?
A. Baking powder contains both a mild alkali component (baking soda) and a combination of mild acids, which react when moistened and then baked. Cream of tartar is one of the acids used, but since it reacts quickly, the batter must be mixed and immediately placed in the oven before the reaction is over.
Most baking powders have a slower-acting acid in them as well, commonly sodium pyrophosphate. This will cause another reaction when the batter is in the oven. This is why baking powders are labeled "double-acting." A small amount of cornstarch is then added to help keep the mixture dry.
To make your own fast, single-acting baking powder, Shirley Corriher, in her book "Cookwise" (William Morrow, 1997), suggests mixing one tablespoon baking soda with two tablespoons cream of tartar and one and a half tablespoons cornstarch. But given the cost of cream of tartar, your homemade baking powder probably won't be any more economical than store-bought. MELISSA CLARK

HEADLINE: New Tools for Employee Maintenance

BYLINE: By JOANNA L. KROTZ 

 BODY:
Wage inflation may have all but disappeared from the economic map, but for companies looking to grow, there is anotherside to that good news. Just about any worker with a marketable skill has by now caught on to corporate America's worst-kept secret: managers are desperate to attract talent and even more desperate to hold onto it.
Mambo.com, a start-up events-planning Web service in Menlo Park, Calif., for example, hired a longtime Internet recruiter last spring before it even thought about hiring a vice president for business development, according to Madeline Schroeder, Mambo's chief executive. "It was a strategic move," Ms. Schroeder said. "Competition for good candidates is fierce in Silicon Valley." 
 And when the computer networking company Cisco Systems moves into a market and needs staff, it often hires trucks to be driven around town with billboards that flash the company's Web site and plead: "Talk to us at Cisco."
"We like people to know we're there," said Randall Birkwood, Cisco's senior employment manager.
The latest method to persuade midlevel and senior managers to turn down rival offers is one borrowed from addiction treatment: an intervention by those in the workplace who are nearest and dearest. James Boone, president of the recruiter Korn/Ferry International, says that besides "hard offers of compensation, position and title immediately, you have to hit at the heart."
"As soon as a manager announces he's leaving," Mr. Boone added, "you get his team in a room to say things like, 'We need you to succeed' or 'What can we do to make you stay?' People don't usually leave just for money. It can be just as effective to tug at the emotions to get them to stay."
That sort of pleading puts employees in a strong position. Colleen McGrath, 26, had been at Monster.com, an Internet career and recruitment site, for almost four years last September. Though she had worked her way up to the position of project manager, she said, "I felt stale; the job wasn't much of a challenge."
Ms. McGrath went job hunting, and soon got an offer from another Internet company with comparable benefits and a $5,000 raise. She accepted and gave notice.
Two days later, Jeff Taylor, Monster .com's founder and chief executive, asked why she was leaving. Then he made a counteroffer: he would promote her to manager of special projects and give her an immediate $4,000 raise, with the likelihood of more to come.
She accepted because she was shedding the old routine job and preferred Monster .com to the new company, anyway.
"I wasn't leaving because I hated the job so much," Ms. McGrath said, "but because the company had turned formal and corporate in the past three years -- titles and what size cube you have. So I wanted more money. Jeff got me to stay by making me feel like a change agent again." Two months later, she snared an additional $2,000 raise.
For Mr. Taylor, grabbing people on their way out the door has become a way of life. Monster.com began with a staff of 70 in 1997, grew to 500 by the end of 1998 and doubled again last year. Competition for skilled workers from other dot.com start-ups is fierce, so he pays close attention to his employees' needs and makes sure the workplace reflects Net speed and culture.
"My employees get shot at regularly by recruiters," Mr. Taylor said. "And money rocks people's worlds, so almost always, I'll make a counteroffer. They wouldn't be here if they weren't great at their job. But I like to counter opportunity, not offers."
Companies are becoming increasingly inventive when it comes to incentives, either by dangling special premiums over compensation or by bumping up the role and autonomy of the job. Counteroffers now often include letting managers exercise stock options at earlier dates or at lower prices than the contracts call for and guaranteeing juicy bonuses for employees who stay a specified number of years, even if their performance fizzles along the way. Recruiters and human resources professionals have even coined a term for these gun-to-the-head elevations: battlefield promotions.
Managers are also more willing than ever to cut special deals. Daphne Matalene, 26, an advertising account manager at a travel magazine in New York, turned down an unexciting offer from a rival company last June. But when she mentioned it to her boss, he immediately withdrew an earlier suggestion that he might have to reduce her commission from 10 percent of sales to a rate more in line with the industry average of about 2 percent. Then, a few months later, an attractive job offer came her way from a prestigious business publication, and she was leaning toward accepting it.
But when she informed her boss, he countered by raising her base salary by $17,000, a 75 percent increase. To do that, he said, he would have to lower her commission rate, but he awarded Ms. Matalene some plummy extra accounts and some added responsibilities to compensate for that.
"I decided to stick around," shesaid.
According to a recent survey by Development Dimensions International, a consulting firm, most companies will be enhancing stock options, benefits packages and salaries this year to attract qualified applicants.
But according to the survey, workers want more than just money. Organizations with the most effective recruiting strategies, according to the survey, were more likely to offer potential for advancement, a solid reputation, learning opportunities and a positive corporate culture as well as stock options and competitive salaries.
That means employees across the board can expect more and better job offers and increased leverage with their current employers, said Jeffrey Christian of Christian & Timbers, an executive search firm. "Today, the best talent wins," Mr. Christian said. "So if you haven't had a counteroffer, you're probably not working."
