LENGTH: 2473 words

HEADLINE: NATIONAL ORIGINS: Central Florida;
Squeezing Gold From the Groves

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

DATELINE: AUBURNDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
"YOU want to look at oranges?" Jim Walker asked. "Well, let's go look at oranges." Mr. Walker, lean and fit at 70, jumped into his red minivan. I joined him, and minutes later we were deep into Walker Groves, a 70-acre spread of citrus trees midway between Tampa and Orlando that his family has cultivated for more than a century.
Here in central Florida, the citrus groves form a sea of dark green foliage stretching to the horizon. Unfortunately, the horizon is limited; the land is so flat that there are hardly any places high enough to see more than a mile or two. The growers and the bureaucrats who watch over them use helicopters to keep an eye on the groves and, in fact, to count the oranges. Not one by one, of course, but by using educated guesses about how much fruit a tree will produce. The crop for the growing season from fall 1997 through late spring 1998, the most recent count available, came to about 48 billion oranges, according to the Florida Citrus Department. 
 For a time, we bumped along past rows of 12-to-15-foot-high trees thick with glossy, dark green leaves but bereft of fruit. "Early varieties," Mr. Walker said, "all picked." Abruptly, we came upon row after row of trees laden with fat orange fruit. "Valencias," my host remarked, "not quite ready yet."
Actually, I had recognized them. In fact, it was their imminent arrival in my local supermarket that lured me down here last week in the first place. I am, I must confess, an orange-juice addict. Only two or three fresh-squeezed oranges a day will do it for me, and Valencias are my orange of choice. I await their annual debut the way some people yearn for the start of spring training. In fact, the ballplayers and the Valencias turn up around here every year at about this time.
"Best juice oranges in the world," Mr. Walker agreed.
You might not know it by looking at them. These happen to be pretty good looking oranges, but not all Valencias are. Valencias are thin skinned, making them susceptible to nicks and bruises. When they are ripe, they may be a brilliant orange or tinged with yellow or even green.
"Color has nothing to do with ripeness," Mr. Walker said. "A green orange can be fully ripe and an orange one far from ready to be picked. What makes an orange orange is cold weather. When it gets a little warmer around here in a few weeks, these Valencias could turn green again. But they'll be ripe."
But they are heavy with juice. They have been bred that way, although the Florida weather helps. California oranges, navels mostly, develop thick skins because they are grown in a dry climate. They are light in weight and drier in texture. Florida oranges are juicier because Florida is wetter. The water table is high, and the rainfall is one of the heaviest in the United States. In Florida, water is everywhere, even in the oranges.
Even so, it's the navel that is considered the eating orange, by growers and consumers alike, because it peels so easily and looks so much more attractive in the produce bin. It's too bad; a Valencia sliced into wedges or circles is a fine thing.
The Valencia was once known as the Rivers Late, after the Englishman who first shipped the seeds here in the 19th century. It came to be known as the Valencia when, it is said, a Spanish grower saw some Rivers Late trees in this country and claimed them to be his country's Valencias. (The navel orange has a less romantic history: it is known formally as the Washington Navel, not for the state but for Washington D.C., where it was propagated by the Agriculture Department after arriving from Brazil in the 1870's.)
Today, Valencias are the world's most popular orange, and they grow in every part of the world where oranges thrive.
Orange trees have a lot in common with grapevines. With wine grapes, the noble European vinifera vines -- cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay and others -- are grafted onto disease-resistant American roots that, left on their own, would produce relatively useless grapes. Similarly, fruit-bearing citrus branches are grafted onto rootstock derived from, among others, the Rough Lemon tree. On its own, the Rough Lemon will produce unusable fruit. Paired with good plant material, it produces high-quality fruit: oranges, lemons, grapefruit or limes.
A grafted orange tree comes into maturity in five years; a tree grown from seeds takes at least 15 years. Seedling trees are rare in Florida these days. Growing lemon tree rootstock is itself a major business. Much of Florida's citrus is grown in sand, which contributes little or nothing to the tree's well-being. Most of its nutrition, aside from what it gets from sun and water, comes from hefty doses of manufactured nutritives.
A healthy tree can be economically viable for 50 years, a Citrus Department spokesman said.
In Florida a century ago, the groves began much farther north, not all that far from the Georgia border. Frequent devastating frosts prompted the industry to move farther and farther south.
"There are fewer frost problems," the spokesman told me. "But lots of the groves are in hurricane territory now, and a hurricane can be just as deadly as a bad frost."
But even in an ideal season, there is a long period, from late summer through winter, when there are no Valencias to be found. Since oranges, including Valencias, are grown all over the world, they are always in season somewhere.
In northern European cities, it's not uncommon to find oranges from all over the world in the markets. Why don't we see oranges from Morocco or Uruguay or South Africa or Brazil in this country? Spanish clementines do show up, but other foreign oranges are scarce because they compete with the domestic product. French supermarkets may put on a dazzling display of imported oranges, but there are no domestic growers to complain.
In the United States, tariffs protect Florida Valencias; California navels, which ripen in the early fall; and other varieties that ripen between those two main seasons. The only times we are short of oranges in this country is when Florida is hit by a bad freeze, as happened in 1990, when more than a third of the crop was destroyed.
The juice business also has had a profound effect. The year-round availability of good -- and infinitely cheaper -- frozen and bottled juice has all but squeezed out the fresh-orange business. Sales of fresh citrus fruit are almost an afterthought in the orange-juice business, a $3 billion-a-year industry. Oranges are counted in 90-pound boxes, the way they are picked in the groves. In 1997-98, more than 230 million boxes of Florida oranges went into pasteurized, chilled juice, most of it from reconstituted frozen concentrate, according to the Citrus Department. Fewer than nine million boxes were sold as fresh fruit.
Fresh grapefruit fared better. From the same harvest, some 28 million 85-pound boxes went into chilled juice, and 20 million were shipped as fresh fruit, the department says.
In 1966, when John McPhee wrote a monumental two-part essay on oranges for The New Yorker magazine, he was surprised to discover how difficult it was to get fresh orange juice in Florida. State-run tourist offices offered every sun-starved visitor a cup of juice, Mr. McPhee reported, but it was all made from concentrate.
Nothing has changed. Tourists arriving at the portals of the Sunshine State are still offered free orange juice, and it still isn't fresh squeezed, even though an orange, presumably a fresh one, is featured prominently on the state license plate. Some Florida hotels offer fresh juice, at a price, but rarely does anyplace else. At both the Florida Citrus Department in Lakeland and at Tropicana Products' vast headquarters and bottling plant in Bradenton, cordial receptionists offered me orange juice, but none of it fresh squeezed.
"Unbelievable," Mr. Walker said, shaking his head.
Oranges have been grown in Florida since the 16th century. Columbus took citrus seeds on his first voyage and spread them around the Caribbean. Ponce de Leon is supposed to have taken them from Spain to Florida. "He came looking for the Fountain of Youth," the juice people like to say, "but in fact he brought it with him."
Four hundred years later, some Florida scientists invented frozen concentrate. By the time Mr. McPhee wrote his essay, the changeover from fresh fruit to frozen concentrate was almost complete. The 6- and 12-ounce cans whose contents were diluted with three equal amounts of water were in millions of home freezers. Minute Maid, a pioneer in the concentrate business, became the country's largest producer of processed orange juice.
In the early 1970's, however, consumers began to move away from frozen concentrate toward chilled juice, both pasteurized not-from-concentrate and reconstituted concentrate. Chilled-juice sales passed frozen concentrate in 1986, and the gap has continued to widen. Chilled juice now accounts for more than 60 percent of all orange-juice sales, the department says.
Tropicana, which produces only chilled juice, both from fresh fruit and from concentrate, is now first in the industry, with between 37 percent and 38 percent of the market, said Jim Dwyer, Tropicana's senior vice president for North American operations. Florida is the nation's largest producer of oranges, and each year Tropicana buys about 25 percent of the state's orange crop. In the 1998-99 season, the company produced some 320 million gallons of orange juice.
The Northeast is the United States's biggest orange-juice market, consuming some 40 percent of all the orange juice the country makes. The New York metropolitan area alone consumes about 17 percent of the national output. Just to serve the metropolitan market, Tropicana dispatches five full trainloads of orange juice each week to its bottling plant in Jersey City. Each train carries more than 5.2 million gallons of juice. Tropicana also has production plants in France, Britain and China.
The Tropicana plant in Bradenton is a technological marvel. Twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, millions of oranges are squeezed, turned into rivers of juice and bottled, some with no pulp, some with a bit of pulp and some with a lot of pulp. "Kids hate pulp," said Steven Lezman, a Tropicana executive, who showed me around.
Actually, he didn't just say it; he shouted it, the only way to be heard over the ceaseless, ear-splitting roar of the plant machinery. Like all dedicated Tropicana people, Mr. Lezman is immune to the lure of fresh juice, even though he has his own private orange tree in his backyard.
"We keep two kinds of Tropicana juice in the refrigerator at home," Mr. Lezman said. "No pulp for the kids and pulp for the adults."
Back in Auburndale, where the only noise is an occasional blackbird and where hawks wheel lazily in the warm, late winter air, Mr. Walker squeezes his juice in a stainless-steel machine about half the size of a player piano. It's in a back room of the little shop on Route 599, where he welcomes tourists who are loyal fans, newcomers lured by his billboards out on the Interstate and a surprising number of Floridians who refused to take the dearth of fresh juice in their state lying down.
"I've got people coming all the way up from Hollywood," he said, chuckling. "They want a few gallons of the real stuff."
Still, Mr. Walker is no stranger to the more commercial side of the business. What he doesn't sell at his shop, or ship around the country in gift packages, he sells to local processors to be turned into pasteurized juice or concentrate.
"Just so I can keep this way of life going for a while," he said, as we walked among his fruit-laden trees. "My grandfather came down here from Tennessee in 1884. He was 30 years old and suffering from what they used to call consumption. They'd told him he wasn't going to live long in any case but that he might live a little longer in Florida. Well, this life must have agreed with him; he lived to be 87."
I returned to my car and headed for Tampa, pulling on a quart bottle of Walker juice and thinking about that old man. Could it have been the orange juice? It seemed distinctly possible.
 
ORANGE VINAIGRETTE
Adapted from Palladin
Time: 20 minutes
 
1 cup freshly squeezed orange juice (from about 4 oranges)
1 shallot, peeled and chopped
2 cloves garlic, peeled and chopped
 1/2 cup honey
1 cup red wine vinegar
2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar
 1/2 cup lemon-flavored olive oil
 1/2 cup grape seed oil
Salt and freshly ground black pepper.
1. In small saucepan over high heat, bring orange juice to boil. Reduce to about 1/4 cup; juice should be thick and syrupy.
2. Transfer juice to blender. Add shallot, garlic, honey, red wine vinegar and balsamic vinegar. Blend at high speed until shallot and garlic are pureed. Reduce speed to medium, and slowly add lemon-flavored olive oil and grape seed oil through the feed tube. Cover feed tube, increase speed to high, and blend until vinaigrette is emulsified. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Yield: 3 cups.
 
TAJINE OF VEAL SHANK BRAISED WITH ORANGE
Adapted from L'Actuel
Time: 2 hours
 
 1/4 of an orange skin, finely diced
 1/2 pound fresh tomatoes
 1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil
1 onion, peeled and finely diced
1 carrot, peeled and finely diced
1 leek, white part only, rinsed and finely diced
1 garlic clove, peeled and minced
4 veal shanks, 3 inches thick
2 cups freshly squeezed orange juice
1 bay leaf
4 cups veal stock or low-sodium canned chicken broth
Salt and freshly ground black pepper.
1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Bring large pot of water to boil. Place orange skin in a strainer, and dip it into boiling water for 10 seconds. Drain, and set aside. Add tomatoes to boiling water for 6 to 8 seconds. Rinse with cold water. Peel, chop, and set aside.
2. In large saute pan over medium heat, heat 1/4 cup olive oil. Add onion, carrot, leek and garlic, and saute until vegetables are softened and lightly colored, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat, and reserve.
3. In large skillet over high heat, heat remaining tablespoon olive oil. Add veal shanks, and sear until well browned on all sides. Transfer shanks to a large casserole. Add reserved vegetables, along with orange juice, and place casserole over high heat to bring to boil. Reduce juice to about half its volume, and then add reserved tomatoes, along with bay leaf and stock or broth. Season with salt and pepper to taste.
4. Cover casserole, and transfer to oven. Bake until shanks are tender, about 1 1/4 hours. Then transfer shanks to a plate. Place casserole over high heat to reduce broth to about 2 cups. Adjust seasoning, if necessary. Return shanks to sauce; reheat as needed. Serve with orange zest garnish.
Yield: 4 servings.

HEADLINE: Economy's Next Leader

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Krugman (column, Feb. 20) finds it a "reassuring thought" that the next president need only be someone "who won't do too much damage" to our booming economy. 
 For the millions of Americans not sharing in the wealth, the next president's positions on the minimum wage, the growing gap between rich and poor, the right to join a union, and a host of other issues will matter very much.
This country's poor and working class could use a friend in the White House. Mr. Krugman seems to view the global economy, in and of itself, as more important to defend than the welfare of those who are not among its winners.
 
NEIL AQUINO

HEADLINE: Social Security Risks

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While a Feb. 17 editorial acknowledges that "piecemeal changes to the Social Security system are rarely a good idea," its praise for a $22.7 billion measure to end the earnings test in effect encourages Congress to support measures that increase Social Security benefits before enacting the more difficult comprehensive reforms. This invites elected representatives to pander to the largest voting bloc -- those over 65 -- without regard for the program's generational inequity. 
 While only 30 or so members have co-sponsored reform bills, there is a waiting list to co-sponsor bills that increase benefits for retirees (for example, prescription drug benefits and bonus benefits for "notch babies"). By failing to contain Social Security's costs, we run the risk that the national debt will rise above 125 percent of gross domestic product or that future Americans will face a 50 percent payroll tax increase or a 25 percent to 33 percent cut in Social Security benefits.
BOB KERREY
U.S. Senator from Nebraska
Washington, Feb. 22, 2000

HEADLINE: Murray Bernstein, West Side Sturgeon King, Dies at 87

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Murray Bernstein, who took a narrow store on Broadway and turned it into Murray's Sturgeon Shop, a legendary Upper West Side purveyor of salmon and sable, caviar and camaraderie, died Monday at a nursing home in Lauderhill, Fla. He was 87.
Limousines would line up in front of the store, and it regularly shipped sturgeon and other delicacies overseas. But its heart and soul were in the ready smile and deft cutting stroke of Mr. Bernstein. His own life epitomized a neighborhood of immigrants, many of them Jewish, who had known and expected struggle. He remained active in the grocery workers' union even after he became a store owner, worked six days a week and never took a single vacation. 
 His ambitions were sturgeon-size (a beluga sturgeon can weigh half a ton). "He had grandiose plans for making the best smoked fish in the world," said his daughter, Cecile Rivel. "He was a perfectionist."
Jack Rudin, a member of the New York real estate family, began coming by in 1950, and remembers the sturgeon shop as a sort of lodge where the regulars would nosh on pieces of salmon and bagels between shots of ice-cold vodka. Mr. Rudin's wife Rebecca asked Mr. Bernstein to bless the couple's marriage, which lasted until her death 35 years later.
Murray's Sturgeon Shop, which looked like a jewel box with its large mirrors and stainless steel, became a place where real estate magnates and politicians would bump into policemen and shopkeepers. Show business personalities like Zero Mostel and Sammy Cahn were regulars.
"He may have been a fish slicer, but he was a very sage fellow," Mr. Rudin said of Mr. Bernstein. "He knew his product. He knew his customers. He ran a clubhouse there."
Mr. Bernstein was born on Feb. 14, 1913, in Poland, and came to New York as a teenager to escape anti-Semitic violence. In 1932, he met the woman who would become his wife, Nettie Katz, through a friend, Albert Newman. He and Mr. Newman went to Montreal, where the prospective bride was living, for the introduction. They married three days later, and returned to New York.
Mr. Bernstein worked mainly in grocery stores, but as the Depression deepened in the early 1930's, he lost job after job and was unemployed for an entire year. But in 1945, Mr. Bernstein was able to buy his first store, at Broadway and 89th Street, from the same Mr. Newman who had helped arrange his marriage.
Several years later, his brother Sam became a co-owner. Sam died in 1977. In the late 1940's the store moved to its current location, 2429 Broadway, at 90th Street.
When Mr. Bernstein took over, the store sold some fish but specialized in candy and nuts. The Bernsteins concentrated on fish, and set out to popularize smoked fish in the European tradition at a time when many Americans who lived beyond New York didn't know nova from lox. It was hard work.
Sturgeon, the specialty of the house, may produce caviar, but its pearly saline flesh is loved for itself by connoisseurs of smoked fish. Murray's had some of the finest, each customer's order immaculately sliced with surgical skill. The slicing board was hospital clean, and the store held no odor of fish. Murray's sable, the silky smoked codfish known as the poor man's sturgeon, was legendary, too.
Early each Tuesday and Thursday morning, Mr. Bernstein could be heard negotiating with his smoked-fish suppliers in a loud voice. "This is not acceptable," his daughter remembers him saying, again and again. "This has to go back."
She said he would regularly return a third of the fish, and then demand that it be replaced the same day. He believed that the customer was always right, and that included himself.
The diligence paid off. The food critic Craig Claiborne said the store was "perhaps the finest in the city." New York magazine, calling it the "Tiffany of smoked-fish stores," likened Murray and Sam Bernstein's carving skills to that of the heart surgeon Christian Barnaard.
In 1974, the Bernsteins sold the store to Artie Cutler, a restaurateur. As Mr. Cutler's empire of Manhattan restaurants like Ollie's and Carmine's expanded, he sold the sturgeon shop to Ira Goller in the early 1990's.
One day, a year after Mr. Bernstein's wife Nettie died in 1990, he was talking to Florence, the widow of his nephew. She had been a widow for 18 years, and the two, who had known each other for 43 years, were discussing how lonely they felt. He immediately proposed.
"My father doesn't take long," Ms. Rivel said.
In addition to his wife and daughter, who lives in Weston, Conn., he is survived by a sister, Ann Fortune of Clifton, N.J.; a son, William Bernstein of Westminster, Colo.; five grandchildren; and four great-grandchildren.
Mr. Bernstein remained active in the grocery store union even during his Florida retirement. He always refused to open an Upper East Side branch, though many of his customers had moved across town.
"He felt it wouldn't be the same," Ms. Rivel said. "It wouldn't have had his personal touch."

(Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Rosenbluth, a trend spotter among travel agents, believes it has found a new one. Think Internet.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AMONG travel agents, Rosenbluth International gets credit, though sometimes very grudgingly, for having anticipated several of the economic trends that have shaken that industry recently. In the early 1990's -- years before the airlines enraged travel agents and even drove some out of business by slashing commissions on tickets sold -- Rosenbluth began sharply reducing its dependence on commissions and instead started charging corporate clients fees for providing travel-management services.
So it is probably worth briefly examining the latest business idea by Rosenbluth, a Philadelphia-based travel agency with 1,300 offices worldwide. Last month, its Rosenbluth Interactive subsidiary rolled out a business-to-business travel-booking service that sets up custom online travel-booking sites, with off-line travel-agent telephone assistance, "tailored specifically for small, midsized and emerging-growth companies," said Justin Shaw, the vice president and general manager of Biztravel.com, a division of Rosenbluth Interactive. 
 Anyone can book a trip online on dozens of different sites, including Biztravel.com, which Rosenbluth bought last year. What's different here is that Rosenbluth will design a site -- the company refers to it generically as biztravel@mycompany
 -- individually for a company. The site will accommodate a company's employees' travel profiles and allow travelers wide flexibility not only in making airline, hotel and other bookings, but in making last-minute changes by speaking with someone on the telephone.
"Say you're en route and something changes -- the weather, a meeting is rescheduled, the boss calls and says they want you in North Dakota tomorrow," Mr. Shaw said. "These are times when it's not easy to access the Internet and making a phone call is the way to get it done."
About 35 companies are now clients of the service. They pay nothing for the custom site, and pay fees, which Mr. Shaw says are lower than typical travel agencies charge, for having Rosenbluth's agents provide telephone assistance in changing tickets, available around the clock.
How does Rosenbluth make money at this? Well, besides the telephone-service fees, much of the revenue comes from "certain payments from the suppliers whose products we sell, such as an airline," Mr. Shaw said.
Ah, yes, that would be commissions. Oddly enough, as many struggling small travel agencies were forced to impose fees for face-to-face transactions to make up for the reduced commissions, big-brand agencies with huge volumes were negotiating bulk commissions for bookings from airlines and others.
"We found that with some of the commission cuts, a lot of local and regional agencies were getting to the point where they had no choice but to charge all of their customers a transaction fee, maybe as much as $20, for booking a ticket," Mr. Shaw said.
"Now obviously with the economics of an Internet business, we can do the booking online and not charge anything" for selling the ticket, he said.
Go figure.
Speaking of travel agents and online competition, last week the American Society of Travel Agents petitioned the Justice Department to look into possible antitrust violations by major airlines who announced last month that they would participate jointly in a new Web site that would offer low-cost tickets.
The travel agents' trade group called the site, scheduled to start this spring, an anticompetitive ploy to "lure consumers onto the Web with lower prices."
A spokesman for the Web site said there was no merit to the complaint.
The travel agent group, which has been dismissive of online booking sites until the airlines started getting into the act, says that travel agents still book 80 percent of airline tickets, 95 percent of cruises and 90 percent of package tours, and most continue to prosper as overall travel spending increases in a booming economy.
Now that oil prices are wedged in the $30 a barrel range, airlines are scrambling -- a bit frantically at times -- to keep profits up as fuel costs soar. Last Friday, Continental Airlines increased domestic fares by as much as $15. The next day, Delta Air Lines and AMR's American Airlines also raised fares, followed on Sunday by US Airways, UAL's United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines. But Northwest Airlines stubbornly refused to get on board.
"Never mind!" yelped the others, fully aware that mischievous Northwest would undoubtedly get a lot of mileage out of ads trumpeting that it alone had refused to jack up fares. One by one on Monday, the others dropped their price increases.
Let's see what happens next week.
The troubled British Airways, meanwhile, raised trans-Atlantic fares by 3 percent earlier this month, after earlier increases on those routes by American competitors. And since January, major American carriers have been adding a $20 fuel surcharge to most domestic tickets.
Because of the cost of oil, American Express says, "typical" business air fares will rise this year by 3 to 4 percent, to an average of more than $1,000 round trip -- a higher rate than it forecast last fall.
"Flying for business will get more expensive than many expected this year," said Rusty Carpenter, vice president of American Express Consulting Services. He said the predictions on air fare costs might have to be revised upward later in the year if the airlines maintained their fuel surcharges.

HEADLINE: Home Depot's Quarterly Profits Rise 38%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Home Depot Inc., the nation's largest chain of home-improvement stores, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 38 percent as it sold more water heaters, appliances and other big-ticket items.
Net income rose to $578 million, or 25 cents a share, from $418 million, or 18 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 26 percent, to $9.17 billion in the quarter ended Jan. 30, from $7.26 billion. 
 Home Depot has expanded its selection of higher-priced and higher-profit goods. It has also added services and products to attract plumbers and other contractors, who typically buy more expensive items than homeowners, the stores' main customers. The average purchase increased 4.8 percent, to $46.61, from a year earlier.
"They're demonstrating to the customer the benefits of products that are one step up in price," said Doug Gordon, a Banc of America Securities analyst, who rates the stock "strong buy."
Shares of Home Depot fell 12.5 cents, to $53.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading today. The stock has fallen 20 percent this year on concern that higher interest rates could curb consumer spending and hurt profit growth.
"With rates rising at least two more times this year, Home Depot is going to have a hard time moving back up into the low 60's," said Phil Larkins, a market strategist at Legacy South Inc. in Atlanta, which owns about 220,000 shares.
Even with higher rates, housing trends for the year "look strong" as more Americans buy homes and housing construction increases, said Home Depot's chief executive, Arthur Blank, in a conference call. "We're very optimistic," he said.
Sales at stores open at least a year rose 9 percent in the quarter, topping forecasts for a gain of 6 to 8 percent.
The 930-store chain expects same-store sales to rise by a high single-digit percentage rate this quarter, executives said. The figure is a principal indicator of a retailer's business because it excludes sales from new and closed stores.
Home Depot was expected to earn 24 cents, the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. The chain, based in Atlanta, has beaten forecasts for eight consecutive quarters.

HEADLINE: Many Iranian Conservatives Lose Seats

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

DATELINE: TEHRAN, Iran, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Many of the conservative parliamentarians who led the opposition to President Mohammad Khatami's reform program were apparently soundly defeated in their re-election bids in the election last Friday, according to independent analysts who tallied the hard-liners' losses today.
Vote counting was nearly completed in the major cities, including the capital, Tehran, although no official results will be announced until the end of the week, officials said. 
 But preliminary results in Tehran, plus decided races in provincial areas, indicate that the conservatives lost most of their senior representatives in the Parliament, analysts for several foreign embassies and Iranian political parties said.
A runoff election will be needed to decide the winner of about 60 to 65 seats in the 290-member Parliament, they added. The runoff has tentatively been set for sometime in April.
In one of the most closely watched races, the former President of Iran, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, was barely holding on to 30th place in voting in Tehran for 30 seats in the Parliament. It was unclear whether he would even get the minimum number of votes -- 25 percent of those cast in the capital -- to claim a seat in the first round, or be forced into a runoff.
The first 29 biggest vote-getters in the capital appear to be from the reform camp, which supports Mr. Khatami and advocates liberating Iran's press from clerical censorship and other cultural freedoms.
Mr. Khatami's brother, Mohammad Reza Khatami, has held onto his lead as the top vote-getter in the capital since the counting started. Most analysts, including those for the reformers, give the pro-Khatami forces about 70 percent of the seats in the first round and the conservatives about 30 percent. Tallies differ because some independent candidates are claimed by both sides.
For the first time since the elections, a spokesman for the defeated conservatives admitted publicly today that they have suffered a damaging blow. The spokesman, Mohammad Reza Bahonar, one of the most prominent conservative ideologues, suggested in an interview with a Tehran newspaper that hard-liners have some soul-searching to do.
"We will not change our principles and positions, but it is natural that we should reconsider our policies and methods," he was quoted as saying in the newspaper Iran Vig. Mr. Bahonar also lost his seat, according to unofficial Tehran results.
In a news conference today to proclaim victory in the parliamentary poll, the reformers pledged to push for legalizing satellite dishes and allowing a free public debate of religious and social issues that hard-liners had tried to suppress.
But President Khatami's younger brother warned that normalizing relations with the United States -- an issue that some of his allies have suggested should be put to a public vote -- would depend on action by Washington.
"The United States supported the totalitarian regime of the shah," he said. "And now that Iran has become one of the most free nations, it continues its policy of sanctions and continues its baseless claims against Iran."
The United States cut relations with Iran during the 1979 revolution, after students seized its embassy in Tehran and held 52 diplomats captive. It also has classified Iran as a state that sponsors terrorism.
In one of the paradoxes of Iran's budding reform movement, some of its most prominent advocates for opening the country to the outside world and institutionalizing democratic values were either hostage-takers or supporters of the seizure.
The poor showing by Mr. Rafsanjani, a veteran politician who has held high government positions since the Islamic revolution 21 years ago, surprised even his reformist critics.
He was described as a man who could provide balance in the Parliament between up-and-coming leftists and their foes on the right. Many analysts had assumed that most Tehran voters, who could choose 30 candidates, would include Mr. Rafsanjani as a stabilizing factor.
Outside Iran, Mr. Rafsanjani had long been considered a moderate who allowed independent newspapers and took steps to liberalize the economy. But in recent weeks, some pro-Khatami activists have accused him of steering government contracts to family members during his presidency and failing to support the cause of reformers jailed during the last two years for expressing political views.
One Tehran-based diplomat said his analysis showed that between 140 and 150 incumbent parliamentarians failed to gain the minimum number of votes on Friday to keep their seats.
Among them is a core group of senior right-wing lawmakers who formed a powerful directorate of deputies under the Parliament Speaker, Ali Akbar Nateq Nouri. Mr. Nouri did not run for re-election. He lost in the presidential race two and a half years ago to Mr. Khatami.
Veteran incumbents who lost their seats included Jabat Larijani, the brother of the head of state television, and Hassan Rohani, the first deputy speaker. A former intelligence chief, Ali Fallahian, was also not re-elected. Some reformers have called for Mr. Fallahian to be questioned by the police about what he may know about the murders of prominent liberals in Tehran that took place during his tenure. President Khatami has said the murders were carried out by "rogue" intelligence agents.
Another outspoken hard-liner, Ali Zadsar, lost his re-election bid. Mr. Zadsar was one of the parliamentarians who tried last year to impeach the liberal culture minister, Ataollah Mohajerani. Ahmed Rasouli-Nejad, another incumbent involved in the impeachment attempt, also lost.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
The Euro Rebounds Above $1 On Weakness in Yen and Stocks

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The euro rose sharply yesterday, settling above parity with the dollar for the first time in a month, as United States stock markets wobbled.
After ending Friday's trading at a rate of 98.49 cents to the dollar, the single currency sold above $1.00 overnight after steep declines Friday by United States equities. It drew additional support from speculation about a euro-zone interest rate increase and also made sizable gains against the Japanese yen. 
 Markets were closed in the United States on Monday for the observance of Washington's Birthday. Early yesterday, declines on major stock indexes accelerated waves of short-covering -- buying to repay currency borrowed in anticipation of a price drop. This helped send the euro to a one-month high of $1.0078 before it settled in New York at $1.0036, or nearly 2 percent higher, for the session.
Traders said the euro's moves had been set off in part by heavy selling of yen for euros; the euro rose 1.25 percent at one point in midsession, touching a four-month peak of 111.73 yen.
"The euro-yen cross is clearly the hot currency pair that everyone in the market is trading," said Greg Anderson, currency strategist at FleetBoston. "The flurry of activity overnight sent the whole speculative community even further long of euros relative to the yen, and the dollar as well."
Mr. Anderson said he expected the euro to maintain its gains against the yen, which has declined against major currencies in recent weeks as doubts circulated on Japan's economic outlook. But he said that fears of a correction on Wall Street were overblown and that the dollar's downside value was limited, with the euro's trading band between 96 cents and $1.01.
"In my opinion, the euro is at an attractive level to sell," Mr. Anderson said.
The dollar's declines against the euro spilled over into losses against the yen; the dollar slipped to 110.70 yen from 110.96 late Friday.
The euro's move back above parity with the dollar was seen as breaking through an important psychological level. The single currency has been under pressure from the belief the United States economy would continue to outperform that of European countries.
But many traders are looking for the tide to eventually turn, as the price action for the euro begins to reflect signs of improvement in European economies.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Trinidad Takes Role Of Attention Grabber

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

 BODY:
Felix Trinidad and Oscar De La Hoya were in Manhattan yesterday, each doing his own thing. The proximity was not by accident.
Trinidad was working out at the Church Street Gym trying to drum up attention for his bout in Las Vegas on March 3 against David Reid, the World Boxing Association superwelterweight champion. Trinidad was hoping his presence would take a little attention away from De La Hoya, who fights Derrell Coley on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. 
 Trinidad's presence only begged the question of why he was fighting Reid instead of a rematch against De La Hoya, whom he defeated in a controversial decision Sept. 18 in Las Vegas to win the World Boxing Council welterweight title.
The answer was simple and readily available from the two people who should know: Trinidad's promoter, Don King, and De La Hoya's promoter, Bob Arum. King was with his man at the Church Street Gym, while Arum was holding court with reporters at The Friars Club for lunch.
King and Arum, rivals who have feuded for years, took turns trying to kill each other's coming fight.
"His fight is a nothing fight," King said of the De La Hoya-Coley match. "It doesn't segue into anything. He has nothing after this. The fight Tito is fighting is a something fight. He's fighting a world champion with a gold medal. There's no upside for De La Hoya. The guy he's fighting is a bum."
Arum threw cold water on Trinidad-Reid.
"I'm not chortling," Arum said. "It's a lot like a guy who breaks up with a woman and rushes into another affair without thinking. It generally ends up a big disaster. King's losses in this fight will be the biggest losses in the history of boxing. He's going to lose between $6 million to $7 million."
King said if he loses money, he loses money. He said he would need about 400,000 pay-per-view buys on Showtime Event Television to break even.
"I made the fight and I'm going on with it," King said. "Money is incidental to me in this. When we knock out Oscar, I'll make up for it."
King has presented a rematch deal to Arum that he thinks will work. King's proposal has De La Hoya and Trinidad each making $20 million and fighting at a catch weight, possibly 150 pounds (3 pounds over the welterweight limit). King said that under his plan, De La Hoya could keep the W.B.C. welterweight championship belt win or lose. Trinidad doesn't want to have to fight at welterweight again, because he is having trouble making the weight.
Arum said they talked about the deal two weeks ago and it seems workable. He said if they could reach an agreement, the fighters could be in the ring for a rematch on June 17. That is the date that De La Hoya had reserved for Sugar Shane Mosley, but Arum hasn't been able to reach an agreement with Jack Mosley, the fighter's father, manager and trainer.
Arum said he has not discussed King's proposal with De La Hoya, who has been concentrating on the Coley fight. He said he would talk to him about it once De La Hoya gets past Coley.
"It seems to me that the only issue is the weight and I can't speak to that," Arum said.
He added: "The economic issues have all been addressed. I said we wanted the fight at Mandalay Bay, because we're loyal to them. King wanted the fight at Caesars. Dr. Ghanem said the fight would be at Caesars and a third fight would be at Mandalay Bay."
Dr. Elias Ghanem is the chairman of the Nevada State Athletic Commission.
The one thing both King and Arum readily agreed on is that Trinidad and De La Hoya have to win their respective coming bouts to keep this shaky rematch deal from falling apart.
"After that if this guy doesn't fight Trinidad, then he is truly Chicken De La Hoya and no one should support him," King said.
 
King Clears the Air
Don King said he doesn't understand how the F.B.I. can be chasing him for making payoffs to the International Boxing Federation while other promoters and managers have admitted to federal authorities that they made bribes to advance their fighters in the rankings.
"They got about five or six confessors," King said. "How do they look past the confessors and look for the ghost?"
When asked if he had ever paid a bribe to the I.B.F. to have one of his fighters ranked, King said: "No. No. No. No. No. No."
In terms of making financial contributions to the various boxing sanctioning organizations, King said he treats them as he treats the government.
"You can't get goods and services without paying your taxes," King said. "I don't look for tax loopholes. I pay what I owe. I paid $34 million in taxes and I sent out a release to tell everyone that I had paid my taxes.
Bob Arum was one of the people who gave affidavits to the F.B.I. detailing what he knew about bribes to the I.B.F. for rankings. Arum said he has never made a payoff to any sanctioning organization for a ranking.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1633 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: Joy for Second-String M.B.A.'s;
Elites and Internet Change Face of Campus Recruiting

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
For years, America's big-name investment banks and consulting firms considered it a waste of time to send recruiters to second-tier business schools. Harvard, Stanford, the Wharton School at Penn and a handful of others supplied the talent they needed.
M.B.A. candidates at large state schools or lesser-known private schools could not expect to see many blue-chip recruiters on their campuses. They had to send in their resumes and hope for the best. 
 Now, however, that elitist approach is fading, another consequence of the Internet economy.
Even as the long economic boom has increased demand at banks and consulting firms for new hires, many of the brightest students at the top business schools are joining Internet start-ups instead. As a result, prestigious firms are descending on many schools that make the top-50 lists compiled by Business Week and U.S. News & World Report but are nowhere near the top.
Not surprisingly, students and administrators at the newly initiated members of the club are ecstatic. "The top firms are coming up empty more often at the top schools," said Stuart I. Greenbaum, dean of the Olin School at Washington University in St. Louis. "It's opened a whole new tier of opportunities for our students."
In the last year alone, 17 companies, including CIBC Oppenheimer, have started recruiting at the Kelley School of Business at Indiana University, increasing the number of on-campus recruiters there by about 15 percent. A. T. Kearney has gone to the Cox School of Business at Southern Methodist University for the first time. Chase Manhattan is recruiting at Boston University.
PricewaterhouseCoopers went to the University of Georgia. And Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette made a visit to St. Louis to talk to Professor Greenbaum's students. Andersen Consulting, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter are also among the firms expanding their pools. And recruiters say they are having little trouble finding qualified candidates, so long as they focus on the best students at the second-tier schools. "The notion that all the world's talent comes out of three business schools I find hilarious," said Lenny T. Mendonca, a director in the San Francisco office of McKinsey & Company. Three years ago, McKinsey began using the Internet to reach campuses where it does not send recruiters, he said.
The shift could not have come at a more opportune time for second-tier schools. At some of them, applications have leveled off in the last year as the booming economy has kept in the work force people who might otherwise have taken time off to give their careers an M.B.A. boost. Many deans also fret about the long-term threat of the top schools' cutting into the second-tier schools' revenue by offering programs over the Internet. The prestigious additions to their recruiting lists, the deans said, will help their marketing efforts.
Life just got easier for the recruiters, too. Accustomed to wooing freshly minted Harvard and Stanford M.B.A.'s caught up in dreams of Internet riches, they are suddenly encountering students who are generally thrilled to see them and eager to sign up at their firms.
"I'm tremendously excited," said Vivian Chen, 29, a second-year student at Washington University who recently accepted a job at Salomon Smith Barney. When recruiters for the firm came to her school in St. Louis for the first time this year, but did not interview for the kind of job Ms. Chen wanted, she used connections through an alumnus and her internship at another firm last summer to land an interview at a Salomon office. "It was a joint effort," Ms. Chen said, a combination of "a firm willing to expand its horizons" and "my tenacity."
When recruiters do find what they are looking for, a bonus often comes attached: cheaper labor. Students at lower-ranked schools -- whose average starting pay packages are about $80,000, some $30,000 less than the typical student at the top schools would draw -- are less likely to have lucrative competing offers that would force a firm to bid up their salaries.
The big uncertainty now is whether the trend will reverse when the economy slows or Internet businesses go through a retrenchment. Deans at the second-tier schools say that the students of today are the recruiters of tomorrow and that the current wave of hiring will allow the schools to establish a long-term presence at the firms.
"Once I have my people on the inside," Professor Greenbaum said, "I don't expect to get pushed out." If that is the case, middling students at the top schools could eventually lose out to star performers at lesser-ranked institutions.
Others looking at the trend are not so sure, though. "I'm hoping they'll come back to us" and try to hire as many graduates in future years as they now are, said Roxanne Hori, the director of career management at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern, a top-ranked school. "But I don't know. That's sort of the million-dollar question."
The elite firms' deployment of recruiters to second-tier schools began in earnest a couple of years ago to fill double-digit increases in their staff openings. Bain & Company, for example, says it will hire about 250 M.B.A.'s this year, up from 180 two years ago. "The top seven or eight schools," said Stan Miranda, a director in charge of the firm's recruiting, "just cannot satisfy our needs. We're growing very, very fast and cannot find enough people to support the growth."
The supply squeeze has worsened in the last year, as dot-com frenzy has gripped many business school campuses. "Historically, when you got an offer from Morgan Stanley or J. P. Morgan, you just took it. End of story," said Meyer Feldberg, dean of the Columbia Business School, another traditional recruiting ground of the top firms. But now, "in some circles, there is a panic over not being able to hire a sufficient number of talented people," Professor Feldberg added, as many of the most promising students rush to join Internet start-ups or venture capital firms.
As one stark example, the proportion of Stanford M.B.A.'s taking jobs with either consulting firms or investment banks dropped to 33 percent last year from 43 percent in 1998. For the first time in memory, people in business school placement offices say, some firms are having trouble filling out their on-campus interview schedules. "People who typically had long waiting lists now have shorter lists," Ms. Hori said. "People who had full schedules now have holes."
The response of Andersen Consulting, the world's biggest consulting firm, illustrates the urgency recruiters feel. Andersen has expanded the list of schools where its "strategy group" recruits to 15 from 12, said Bill Copacino, a managing partner. And at the original 12, it is giving more presentations to students this year, taking them out to more dinners and trying to make stronger connections with student clubs. "We had to work harder on the campuses because there are more options" for students, Mr. Copacino said.
Sensing a golden opportunity, second-tier schools and their students are becoming more aggressive about selling themselves. After attending a recruiting conference and hearing a manager from Salomon Smith Barney describe the banking industry's hiring woes, Kim Gattiker, the assistant director of the University of Georgia's M.B.A. career services office, organized a promotional campaign. She and her colleagues pitched Georgia's students and the school's highly regarded information systems to the big investment banks and consulting firms, called Georgia alumni already working at some of those companies and sought out recruiters at other conferences.
Ms. Gattiker thought that adding just one or two corporate blue-bloods to the list of Atlanta companies like Delta Air Lines and United Parcel Service that traditionally scour the University of Georgia's graduating class would give her big marketing leverage. Signing up just a few new firms allows her to mention their names to other recruiters, who then will be more likely to come to Georgia as well, she said.
For the first time this year, for example, McKinsey invited Georgia's M.B.A.'s to send in their resumes. "McKinsey, up until this year, had not had anything to do with us," Ms. Gattiker said. One student received an invitation to travel to Florida for an interview. She did not get the job, but Pricewaterhouse, which had not shown interest in her before, also decided to talk to her after she told the firm about the interview with McKinsey.
To students and administrators at places like Georgia, the new-found interest is overdue recognition for a level of excellence that they believe is a near match for Columbia or Wharton. "I have these incredible students," said Jennifer Lawrence, an assistant dean at Boston University, "who have been severely undervalued by the marketplace."
Recruiters, however, are not so easy to convince. "You can't go any deeper" than the very top students at second-tier schools, said Mr. Miranda at Bain & Company. "We're already pushing the boundaries at those schools."
Pushing the boundaries or not, they still sometimes have to do battle with the lure of technology. Students at Boston University, for example, are delighted that Boston Consulting Group, Chase Manhattan and McKinsey are all doing more to recruit them than they did in the past. "There's definitely a happiness about their coming to campus," said Moshiko Levhar, a second-year student who survived the interviews and got a job offer from McKinsey, which is, he declares, "as good as it gets."
Still, Mr. Levhar says he may not accept the offer. After all, he said, the telecommunications industry, where he worked before entering graduate school, looks very exciting right now.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
The Dishonest Truth

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
You don't have to be a brilliant political analyst to realize that the Republican nominee for president (whose identity is still, amazingly, in doubt) is going to have trouble making an economic case for his candidacy. As Bill Clinton put it, declaring that he had a "lot of sympathy" for the Republicans: "I mean, it's hard for them to figure out what to run on. They can't run against the longest economic expansion in history."
No, but they can try to claim credit for it. In the months ahead, there will be a deafening chorus of pundits insisting that it was Ronald Reagan who laid the foundations for our extraordinary prosperity -- indeed that today's prosperity is the ultimate vindication of Reaganomics. 
 The other day I happened to read a fairly typical example of the genre, an article titled "It's the Reagan Economy, Stupid." The piece, circulated by a neo-Reaganite pressure group called The Club for Growth, was written by Lawrence Kudlow, who was an adviser to Steve Forbes's campaign, and the club's president, Stephen Moore. (Mr. Moore is also director of fiscal policy studies at the Cato Institute.) The title says it all: Rapid growth in the late 90's is the continuing legacy of Mr. Reagan's tax cuts, way back in 1981. And reading the piece, an idea occurred to me.
You see, the usual riposte to this sort of thing involves a weary reiteration of the basic economics involved. One tries, for the umpteenth time, to explain that nothing extraordinary happened to the U.S. economy during the Reagan years. Well before the events of the 80's, scenarios of disinflation had become standard exercises in the macroeconomics textbooks. In these scenarios, an initial period of rising unemployment and slow or negative growth would be followed by a period of rapid, non-inflationary growth and falling unemployment, with the unemployment rate ending up about where it started. And that's just what happened. But though it's the simple truth, this explanation is too complicated to be heard over the shouting.
So what do you say we focus on the character issue instead? Are the commentators who say that our current prosperity vindicates Reaganomics being honest? If they are, then if things had gone differently -- if the economy had done badly under Bill Clinton -- logic implies that they would have reached a different conclusion. If good news vindicates the Reagan legacy, bad news would have called it into question, right?
I suppose I could stop right there. You know and I know that if the economy were slumping instead of booming, the same people would triumphantly contrast the Clinton record with Mr. Reagan's and declare the contrast -- surprise! -- a vindication of Reaganomics.
But we don't have to leave this as a mere conjecture. Instead we can be scholarly, and look at the literature -- that is, earlier writings by some of the Reaganite faithful, from the years before it became clear that their problem would be how to explain away the economy's continuing success.
For example, it so happens that in October 1996, little more than three years ago, Mr. Moore and William Niskanen, Cato's chairman, put out a report titled "Supply-side tax cuts and the truth about the Reagan economic record." This report was vehement in insisting that in assessing Mr. Reagan's achievement one must not include any data after 1989, which marks the end of the Reagan era; the years from 1981 to 1989 "provide a convenient and unique laboratory-like testing ground for assessing the success or failure of Reaganomics." And the report went on to argue that the slower growth from 1989 to 1995 demonstrated the superiority of Reaganite policies.
It doesn't get much better than this. If the post-Reagan economy stumbles, the great man's responsibility ends on the day he left office. But if the good times keep rolling, so does Mr. Reagan's legacy. As they say in the scholarly journals: Gotcha!
Of course, none of this will make any difference either to the views or the behavior of the faithful. Commentators will commentate, fulminators will fulminate, and everyone will pretend to base his arguments on the evidence. But now that you know the truth, here's a suggestion: Next time you hear a talking head start to explain how Ronald Reagan deserves the credit for Bill Clinton's economy, switch to the Discovery Channel -- where you might actually learn something.

HEADLINE: Another Big Paper Company Acquisition

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
In a move that brings the fourth major paper-industry merger or acquisition in less than two weeks, the big Finnish paper company Stora Enso said yesterday that it would acquire Consolidated Papers Inc., based in Wisconsin Rapids, Wis. The deal is valued at $3.9 billion, plus the assumption of $900 million in debt.
The merged company's combined sales of $13.2 billion in 1999 place it a distant second in revenue to the International Paper Company, which sells a bigger proportion of high-priced stock, and had $25 billion in sales. The new company, though, will probably be the world's largest producer in terms of paper tonnage. 
 Stora Enso is paying $44 a share for Consolidated, a rich premium over the company's preannouncement closing price of $26. Investors clearly felt that Consolidated got the better deal: its stock jumped $10.50 on Tuesday, to $36.50, while Stora Enso's shares lost 2 euros in Helsinki, closing at 11.10 euros.
Still, analysts hailed the merger as another sign that the fragmented paper industry was building a global business. "This sea change that we've been expecting is finally happening," said Kathryn F. McAuley, a Brown Brothers Harriman analyst, "and we're seeing real globalization of the industry."
In the last two weeks, UPM-Kymmene, also of Finland, bought Champion International, creating a behemoth in coated papers; Abitibi-Consolidated bought Donohue Inc., creating a leader in newsprint, and International Paper, which bought Union Camp last year, said it would acquire Shorewood Packaging, which had been embroiled in a takeover battle with the Chesapeake Corporation when International Paper made its offer.
More deals are in the works. The New Zealand conglomerate Fletcher Challenge has said it wants to sell its newsprint operations. Norske Skog is said to be looking for a North American acquisition. And on Friday, St. Laurent Paperboard of Canada said it was in merger talks. It did not specify with whom, but the name swirling around Wall Street was that of Smurfit-Stone Container, the world's biggest corrugated-box maker -- itself formed when Jefferson Smurfit gobbled up the Stone Container Corporation in 1998.
Despite all the mergers, paper remains a highly fragmented industry. "You can still find 30 or 40 publicly traded paper companies in the U.S., and probably another 15 in Canada," said Mark Wilde of Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, noting that even International Paper, the industry leader, accounts for only about 5 percent of the 300 million tons of paper produced worldwide each year.
The lack of cohesion has cost the industry dearly. Most companies expanded wildly when paper prices started to soar in the mid-90's. When economic troubles overseas put the brakes on demand, the industry found itself drowning in capacity. The long lead time required to plan and build paper mills meant that construction proceeded even as prices and profit plummeted, starting in late 1995. They did not recover until last year.
Industries like publishing and manufacturing, which are prime customers for paper, have been consolidating into global powerhouses that want global suppliers.
"They want to deal with the same supplier all over the world," Ms. McAuley said, "but they don't want their paper shipped to Chicago from Finland."
In such an environment, consolidation may have been inevitable. The European paper companies began merging several years ago and the resulting big producers, like Stora Enso, are now looking to North America for merger partners. North American companies, though, are still joining mainly with each other.
"The American companies may be missing chances to expand into higher-growth markets," Mr. Wilde warned.
And the industry has returned to good times. After a dismal 1997 and 1998, most companies were profitable last year, and Ms. McAuley, for one, predicts that profits will remain robust through 2002. Consolidation can only improve the profit picture, as merged companies close older plants and eliminate administrators.
This has not yet translated into higher prices. "We may see more pricing power but we're far from being an oligopoly yet," Ms. McAuley said.
The deals may help smooth out some of the wild swings that have characterized paper pricing. And they are likely to buoy profit. "It doesn't mean anything for prices," said John V. Faraci, International Paper's chief financial officer, "but it's enabling all of us to get costs out and to put more money into product development."
Analysts say stockholders will settle for nothing less. "Shareholders have made it clear they want financial returns improved," Mr. Wilde said, "that they want C.E.O.'s to stop building plants and start rationalizing their businesses."

LENGTH: 492 words

HEADLINE: New Tension Over Taiwan

 BODY:
A dangerous pattern is emerging in the troubled relations across the Taiwan Strait. During Taiwan's last presidential campaign, in 1996, China test-fired missiles over waters close to the island's major cities to protest what it saw as a drift toward independence. Now, with a new campaign under way, Beijing is again trying to intimidate Taiwanese voters and push the island's next leaders into early reunification talks on the mainland's terms.
China was wrong this week to threaten to use force against Taiwan if the island's leaders take too long to agree to reunite with the mainland. By coupling that threat with an attempt to deflect the blame to Washington for increasing military tensions over Taiwan, Beijing may have damaged its chances of winning Congressional backing for China's entry into the World Trade Organization. 
 Unlike some of the past crises stirred up by the provocative actions of Taiwan's departing president, Lee Teng-hui, the blame for this flare-up lies squarely with Beijing. Taiwan's three leading presidential candidates have tried to mute the independence issue, and all three favor early talks with the mainland. Most of the world, and most Taiwanese, acknowledge the principle that Taiwan and the mainland are part of a single China that should ultimately be reunited.
But there are vital differences on how and when reunification should take place. The United States, which recognizes the Communist government in Beijing as the sole government of China, rightly insists that reunification be achieved by peaceful means. Beijing, however, has consistently asserted its right to settle the question by force. When China underscored that threat with missile tests in 1996, it created an anti-mainland backlash among Taiwanese voters and damaged Beijing's relations with the United States. The mainland could again hurt its own interests if it fails to show greater restraint.
Taiwan's presidential race is a tight three-way affair between the candidate of the ruling Nationalist Party, Lien Chan; a dissident nationalist, James Soong; and the candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Chen Shui-bian. Although Mr. Chen's party has traditionally called for an independent Taiwan, he has deliberately stepped back from that position, promising that if elected, he would not seek formal independence. This caution reflects the general sense on Taiwan that President Lee needlessly provoked the mainland with his politicized 1995 visit to the United States and his 1999 declaration that Taiwan would henceforth negotiate with China only if Beijing acknowledged it as an equal state.
Over five decades, a relatively stable arrangement has evolved that allows Taiwan and the mainland to maintain separate political and economic systems as part of a larger, single China. That understanding has served both sides well and preserved peace. This is no time for Beijing to threaten to overturn it. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Police Union Seeks Inquiry

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22

 BODY:
In an extraordinary step that reflected the plummeting public confidence in the Los Angeles Police Department over a growing corruption scandal, the union representing police officers undercut the department's chief today and demanded an independent investigation of the growing evidence of police brutality.
The union noted that since its creation in 1925 it had never advocated an outside investigation of the department. But it said such a step was needed now because the scandal had so tainted the department, as reports emerged that corrupt officers framed perhaps several hundred people and in at least two instances shot unarmed suspects and then planted guns on them. 
 The announcement was also a political shot at the chief of police, Bernard C. Parks, who has fought any outside interference but is now clearly losing the confidence of his uniformed officers, some of whom have said they fear the chief may make some of the wrongdoers scapegoats and not thoroughly investigate the department's senior officers.
The Police Department has established an internal Board of Inquiry, composed of top officers, that has been investigating the scandal for several months separately from the criminal investigation at the district attorney's office. The Board of Inquiry is expected to deliver its report to the police commission, a civilian oversight body, on March 1.
Mr. Parks did not comment on the announcement, and Cmdr. David Kalish, the department spokesman, did not return calls seeking comment.
"This represents a great leap forward for the police union and it's also the first step in reinforcing to the public that restoring the credibility of the Police Department is our single biggest priority," said Ted Hunt, the president of the Los Angeles Police Protective League, which represents about 9,500 officers.
In addition, the City Council considered a motion today to create an outside entity to investigate the scandal. Joel Wachs, a councilman who is running for mayor, proposed that the city consider such a body to ensure that the police brutality was being thoroughly investigated, particularly the accusations of culpability by the department's top officers.
His motion was voted down, 8 to 6, but several other members of the Council said that over the past week a more militant mood had developed as confidence in the police chief tumbled and concern grew over the extent of the brutality.
"How could this go on so long and be so bad and nobody at the top knew about it?" Mr. Wachs asked in an interview. "It just doesn't pass the smell test to do something from within."
He called the scandal "a moral and a financial crisis," and said that politicians and the public were sobered by reports that the civil suits by those unjustly imprisoned could cost the city $200 million or more.
The new mood marks a major shift, since politicians, especially the mayor, had generally watched quietly since the first reports of corruption emerged last September.
"I'm one of those whose views are evolving, particularly in the last week or so," said Councilwoman Laura Chick, who voted for Mr. Wachs's motion.
Ms. Chick said she now believed that restoring public confidence in the Police Department could not be achieved by the police commission alone.
The scandal began last September when a former officer, Rafael Perez, agreed to disclose evidence of the corruption in return for a lighter sentence in a case in which he admitted stealing about eight pounds of cocaine from the department. He told how the police had framed scores of innocent people, many of them gang members, and lied in court. In at least two instances, Mr. Perez said, officers shot unarmed gang members, one while he was handcuffed, and had then framed them on trumped-up charges.
Initially, the scandal was focused on Mr. Perez's old inner city station, the Rampart Division, but evidence is emerging that the brutality may have been more widespread.
More than 40 criminal cases have been overturned so far, with the police saying that at least 99 have been tainted.

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Knicks Won't Train in South Carolina

BYLINE: By STEVE POPPER 

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y., Feb. 22

 BODY:
The Knicks have trained in Charleston, S.C., for the past eight years, spending a week of preseason training camp at the College of Charleston and then returning there for the period between the end of the regular season and the beginning of the playoffs. But the Knicks won't be there this spring, as they get ready for the postseason.
The Knicks announced today that they are pulling out of South Carolina because of the state's continued policy of flying the Confederate flag over the state Capitol building in Columbia, a policy that has created an intense, nationwide debate. In doing so, the Knicks apparently became the first professional sports team to take such an action. 
 "We're making a decision that we think is in the best interests of our team," said Steve Mills, the Knicks' executive vice president for franchise operations. "That's what this decision is really all about. We obviously don't want to put our players in a situation that they're uncomfortable with. We felt this was the right and best decision to make."
Last July, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called for an economic boycott of South Carolina because of the flag issue. Last week, USA Track and Field, mindful that the United States women's marathon's trials are to take place in Columbia this Saturday, issued a statement in support of removal of the flag. At the same time, some track and field athletes have contemplated a protest during Saturday's trials and some college sports teams have already begun canceling trips to South Carolina.
According to Mills, it was the USA Track and Field statement that pushed the team to consider taking action, and Coach Jeff Van Gundy broached the issue with the Knicks players in a meeting last Friday. "Based on what we saw with the USA Track and Field issue, and how the athletes were reacting to the situation, that's when we started looking at it," said Mills, the highest-ranking African-American on the Knicks. "We realized this is something we needed to address. We spoke to Jeff and through our conversations with him, decided that he was going to raise the issue with the players.
"We, as an organization, identified it as an issue and knew it was something the players were going to have a strong view on. We thought we ought to have Jeff speak to them."
While the Statehouse is nowhere near the College of Charleston or the Charleston Place hotel where the team stays, Mills said the team still felt it would be wrong to be in South Carolina. The Charleston site has been an easy fit for the team, offering a facility where the team could focus in relative anonymity, far from the masses of cameras and tape recorders that they are subjected to when they work out at home.
"We all enjoy going there," said center Chris Dudley, the lone white player on the Knicks. "But we feel this is only right. Once everything is worked out, we'd like to go back."
Mills said the decision to relocate was reached today after a number of players had voiced their objections to a Charleston trip to Van Gundy. Several had spoke publicly, too, with Larry Johnson, Charlie Ward and Chris Childs all making it clear they did not want to go. For now, the decision only affects this spring's pre-playoff camp, with Mills saying that the decision whether to return in the fall for training camp depended on whether the state could come up with a compromise that would remove the flag from the Statehouse.
But even if a compromise were reached soon, Mills indicated that the team would stay away from Charleston this spring.
"We feel that now that we've gone this far, we've made a decision as it relates to the playoffs," Mills said.
The team had contact with representatives of the College of Charleston to tell them of the team's plans, but there was no interaction with representatives of the state. Mills said the Knicks would now look at a variety of options to replace Charleston. In the abbreviated preseason of last season's lockout-shortened season, the Knicks worked out locally.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
Bradley Nod To Clinton On Universal Health Care

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 22

 BODY:
In a nod to President Clinton's continuing popularity among Democratic voters, former Senator Bill Bradley asserted today that Vice President Al Gore had adopted many core Democratic principles only after becoming Mr. Clinton's "No. 2," and he suggested that the vice president could not be counted on to defend those principles on his own.
Though he has criticized Mr. Clinton's ethics in the past, the former senator from New Jersey twice wrapped himself in the president's mantle today, saying he and Mr. Clinton shared views on universal health care, and contending that Mr. Gore had forsaken that goal. 
 "When he was running for vice president in 1992, he took Bill Clinton's views on health care and said we needed health insurance for everyone," Mr. Bradley told more than 250 people here at Adelphi University. "Now that he's on his own running for president, he says health insurance for all Americans is too expensive and we can't do it, even though we have a giant budget surplus and eight million more uninsured than seven years ago."
Mr. Bradley went on to argue that in 1993 Mr. Clinton supported replacing Medicaid with a new program that was similar to what Mr. Bradley has called for in this campaign.
"When Bill Clinton wanted to reform Medicaid to end the two-tiered system in our country, Al Gore supported it," Mr. Bradley said. "Now that he's running for president, he attacks me for wanting to do the same thing that Bill Clinton wanted to do, and that he used to support."
In evoking Mr. Clinton today, Mr. Bradley -- who is trailing Mr. Gore by double digits in public opinion polls in most states -- was trying to show that Mr. Gore was a follower in the Clinton administration, not a leader, his aides said. Mr. Bradley sought to underscore that theme by calling Mr. Gore "a loyal No. 2."
But Mr. Bradley also seemed intent on trying to separate Mr. Gore somewhat from Mr. Clinton, who remains popular among voters in Democratic primaries. A CBS-New York Times poll conducted last week, for example, found that 70 percent of Democratic voters viewed Mr. Clinton favorably.
And by mentioning the president twice -- he usually does not mention Mr. Clinton at all in his speeches -- Mr. Bradley wanted to show that he strongly supported some of the president's major initiatives, Mr. Bradley's aides said.
That acknowledgment represents a subtle shift for Mr. Bradley, whose campaign was once strongly premised on the idea that Democrats would be ready to throw Mr. Gore out of office because of weariness with the Democrats' fund-raising abuses in 1996 and questions about Mr. Clinton's ethics.
"He's trying desperately to create phony distinctions, because he loses when voters focus on the real differences in this campaign," said Douglas Hattaway, a Gore spokesman.
Coming just two weeks before the Super Tuesday primaries on March 7, Mr. Bradley's 20-minute prepared speech today was one of his most forceful and clearly articulated explanations yet for why Democrats should choose him over a sitting vice president when the nation, by many measures, is in very good health.
It also picked up on a theme he began sounding during the Democrats' debate in Harlem on Monday night, when Mr. Bradley asserted that Mr. Gore was a conservative member of Congress whose views turned left when he joined the administration in 1993.
By having shifted ground on abortion, gun control, tobacco regulations and health care, Mr. Gore had showed himself to have no clear ideological core, Mr. Bradley said.
But Mr. Hattaway said, "Senator Bradley knows very well that Al Gore is pro-choice and supports gun control."
Mr. Bradley, who has been criticized by some Democrats for having a low-key stump style, also urged voters not to be taken in by Mr. Gore's more forceful manner.
"Strength is not about shouting or pounding a table, it's about knowing what you believe and acting on those beliefs no matter what those around you are doing," Mr. Bradley said.
"I'm not flashy," he added. "Never have been, either on the floor of Madison Square Garden or in the United States Senate.
"My passion for these things is deep in my heart, and it's deep in my soul," Mr. Bradley continued. "I show them not by shouting or making a fist, but by the consistency of my beliefs."
Before his speech today, the candidate stopped in Astoria, Queens, where he shook hands with voters and dropped by a Greek delicatessen where he ate feta cheese and baklava, bought a spinach-and-cheese pie and did his version of a Greek folk dance for the amused clientele.
On Wednesday, Mr. Bradley will give a speech on economics at Columbia University before flying to Washington State, where he intends to spend almost all of the week campaigning in preparation for its Feb. 29 nonbinding primary.
Mr. Bradley is staking much time and money on that state, hoping to jump-start his struggling campaign for the stretch run to March 7, when 16 states will hold primaries or caucuses that will select nearly a third of the Democratic delegates.
