HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: NEWS ANALYSIS;
On a Rocky Road, the Race Tightens

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 22

 BODY:
This road is nothing but bumps.
New Hampshire knocked Gov. George W. Bush's bandwagon off the highway. Then, last Saturday, South Carolina derailed Senator John McCain's Straight Talk Express. Today, after a meager two-day campaign, Mr. Bush hit a sizable pothole in Michigan, right in the middle of his turnpike to victory. 
 Mr. McCain's electrifying andoh-so-vitalvictoryhere was reinforced by an overwhelming victory in his home state of Arizona, where Mr. Bush had once hoped to make inroads.
So Senator McCain lives to fight another day, and Governor Bush, with his cloak of inevitability further frayed, must find somewhere else to drive the Arizonan from the contest. Mr. Bush tried to look past Mr. McCain in his speeches here, concentrating his fire on President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, the most likely Democratic nominee. That proved premature.
Although it sounded at the time like wishful thinking, Mr. McCain prophesied on Sunday that Michigan would differ from South Carolina. In South Carolina, he said, "it was very clear that we were wiped out by the so-called Christian right, and that's where a lot of this hate stuff was directed" -- implying that Republican conservatives would count for less today.
Because he has more money, more prominent backers and two powerful geographic bases -- Florida, where his brother Jeb is governor, and his own state of Texas -- Mr. Bush must still be counted the man to beat. He also demonstrated again today his ability to beat Mr. McCain handily among Republicans, and in many of the primaries ahead they are the only ones who get to vote.
On the other hand, Mr. McCain can now entertain legitimate hopes of rekindling the widespread enthusiasm he generated in the campaign's early weeks.
The results in Michigan, much the most representative state to vote so far this year, also contained dire warnings for both of the candidates. This is the eighth-most-populous state, with a highly competitive two-party system, a downsizing government, prosperous farms and a growing, highly innovative economy: the kind of state all presidential candidates shoot for.
Mr. Bush was outpolled 60 to 40 by Mr. McCain among moderate voters here. Such voters usually hold the key to presidential elections. Having allied himself firmly with the far right in South Carolina, he apparently suffered for that in Michigan.
Although the poll of voters conducted by the television networks and The Associated Press contained no denominational questions, many politicians suggested that the governor's visit two weeks ago to Bob Jones University, which is often accused of anti-Catholicism, had hurt him among Roman Catholic voters in the blue-collar suburbs of Detroit and other big cities.
Mr. Bush's father, George Bush, lost centrist voters to Bill Clinton, and with them the election of 1992, and then Bob Dole did the same thing in 1996. This year, the Republican leaders who flocked to the Texas governor did so in large part because they thought he would have broader appeal.
Delighted though he was to do so well here, Mr. McCain must worry about the uncomfortable degree to which his advantage depended upon Democrats and independents. Mr. Bush took two-thirds of the Republican vote, and only the astounding fact that Democrats and independents accounted for more than 50 percent of today's electorate pulled the Arizona senator through.
It appeared that the non-Republican turnout reached record proportions for a Republican primary, partly because of local ballot issues in some places. There were hints that at least a few Democrats deliberately voted in the Republican primary to foul up the other party's process.
Michael Flashner, 31, a Democratic sales representative in the Detroit suburbs, backed Mr. McCain. Asked why, he replied: "To tell the truth, I'd like to see the process go on as long as it can, because the more they beat each other up, the better."
Gov. John M. Engler, who had put his political prestige on the line for Mr. Bush, confessed tonight that he may have miscalculated.
"I thought if we could just get the Republican vote out," he said, "we could withstand whatever Democrats and independents came out for McCain. I didn't see any need to go up on television and warn about this wave of Democratic and independent voters. Maybe that was a mistake."
The ability to attract voters across party lines augurs well for Mr. McCain's chances this fall, should he be nominated, but it will not help him in many of the primaries that take place later this month. Virginia's voting next Tuesday and Georgia's and Ohio's on March 7 are open to all registered voters, but only registered Republicans can vote in primaries in Washington State next Tuesday and in New York on March 7. In California, also on March 7, non-Republicans can cast ballots, but their votes will not count in awarding delegates.
In Michigan, the electorate was much more balanced than in South Carolina, from a number of points of view. Half the voters here described themselves as conservatives; 60 percent did so in South Carolina.
In South Carolina, 34 percent called themselves Christian conservatives. Fewer than 3 voters in 10 here said they identified with the religious right, a decline from 1988, when Pat Robertson ran strongly here, and 1996, when Patrick J. Buchanan took 34 percent of the total in giving Mr. Dole a tough fight.
Mr. Robertson recorded telephone messages to Michigan voters this year urging them to turn out in support of Mr. Bush, accusing Mr. McCain of having chosen, in former Senator Warren E. Rudman of New Hampshire, a "vicious bigot" as national chairman.
Because the voting here followed almost immediately on the heels of that in South Carolina, the results there may not have had time to sink in and generate a surge for Mr. Bush. Not until election day itself, the exit poll indicated, did a small swing to the Texas governor get under way.
Michiganders, subjected for a much shorter period to bombardment by the artillery of radio and television advertisements, took a different view of the candidates on important points. There, Mr. McCain was seen as the less fair of the two contenders; here, Mr. Bush was, although Mr. McCain took a more caustic tone in his personal appearances. There, Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain were seen as equally likely to say what they believed rather than what people wanted to hear; here, Mr. McCain had an advantage on that score.
Todd Breadon, a United Auto Workers member who works on a Chrysler production line, said in explaining his vote for Mr. McCain: "I really don't care for George Bush. He seems like a daddy's boy. He seems like a weasel." An independent, Mr. Breadon voted in Royal Oak, north of Detroit.
A third of the voters said they belonged to a union, and Mr. McCain took 6 of every 10 votes in that group. But that margin lent little credibility to the argument, voiced by some Bush backers, that the state's big trade unions had set out to disrupt Mr. Engler's pro-Bush efforts.
In addition, Mr. McCain seemed to have gone some way towards reclaiming his identity as a reformer, for which Governor Bush successfully challenged by proclaiming himself a "reformer with results."
Once again, Mr. McCain did less well than he had hoped among two groups he has targeted. A Vietnam veteran who spent years as a prisoner of war, he got the votes of only slightly more veterans than Mr. Bush. And he did less well than his rival among young voters, especially under 30.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE SENATOR;
McCain Makes Appeal to G.O.P. Loyalists

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Feb. 22

 BODY:
With his insurgent campaign brought back to life tonight by victories in the Michigan and Arizona primaries, Senator John McCain reached out to loyalists in his party, imploring, "Don't fear this campaign, my fellow Republicans -- join it."
Just three days after a drubbing in South Carolina looked like it could be the death knell for his campaign, Mr. McCain was exuberant, grinning and saying, "What a difference a couple of days make." 
 Recognizing that his victory in Michigan relied on his crossover appeal to Democrats and independents, he immediately began trying to shore up support from Republicans in preparation for the round of primaries ahead.
"I want to make a special plea tonight to my fellow Republicans," he said in a hotel ballroom here. "There are those who rule the establishment who want more than anything to defend Washington's big money, big spending status quo. They want to fool you about me. Well here is some more straight talk: I am a proud Reagan conservative. I love the Republican Party. It is my home."
The night's victories, particularly in Michigan, made Mr. McCain viable again and propelled him and Gov. George W. Bush into a fierce cross-country struggle for the Republican presidential nomination.
The schedule ahead still presents a formidable challenge to Mr. McCain's underdog campaign, which largely lacks institutional support while Mr. Bush has piled up the endorsements of governors and has a national apparatus in place.
Showdowns loom next week in Washington, Virginia and North Dakota. And on March 7 comes the first super Tuesday when the delegate-rich powerhouses of California and New York, a host of New England states and Ohio and Georgia vote. Asked as he voted this morning whether the Michigan primary was "do or die" for him, Mr. McCain said: "Every day is do or die. We're a high-wire act and an insurgency campaign."
In Michigan today, Mr. Bush once again won handily among Republicans while Mr. McCain drew independents and Democrats into voting in the Republican primary. While that shows Mr. McCain's potential general election appeal, it also represents a challenge for him. (In his home state, the results were somewhat different, with Mr. Bush winning his support only from the most conservative Republicans.)
While some of the states ahead have open primaries, like Michigan's, others allow only party members to vote. And while California has an open primary, its 162 delegates are allotted based only on how Republicans vote.
In order to shore up his support among Republicans, Mr. McCain began trying to hammer home the themes that he is the one who can best propel his party to victory in November. "We are creating a new majority, my friends, a McCain majority," he said, "and we are Al Gore's worst nightmare."
Mr. McCain was also preparing to begin airing a new commercial in California, Washington and Virginia perhaps as early as Thursday to try to make up ground with Republicans, his aides said. Striking similar tones to his victory speech, the advertisement will likely feature Mr. McCain looking into the camera and saying that the establishment is running ads to fool voters about him.
The advertisement will then stress his economic message of fighting against pork-barrel spending, and his plan for tax cuts for the middle class while devoting much of the surplus to Social Security.
"I want to end Washington's outrageous pork barrel spending," Mr. McCain said tonight, striking some of the same themes. "I want to rebuild our military, strengthen our families, protect the unborn, and cut your taxes. I want to use the surplus the right way, by keeping our obligation to shore up Social Security, fix Medicare and pay down our debt."
Mr. McCain's aides argue that Washington, California, New York and New England now represent fertile ground for Mr. McCain's message of reform Republicanism and that Mr. Bush will be haunted by the tenor of his South Carolina campaign and his close alliance with the Christian right. "South Carolina did not define this campaign," said Rick Davis, the McCain campaign manager. "Unfortunately for Bush he got defined in South Carolina."
Dan Evans, the former governor of Washington, recently switched from Mr. Bush to endorse Mr. McCain. In New York, Representative Peter T. King also switched to the McCain camp, criticizing Mr. Bush's appearance at Bob Jones University.
And though the pace now becomes punishing and the campaign has to be waged coast to coast, Mr. McCain's aides said that Mr. Bush's vast spending in South Carolina, Michigan and Arizona has virtually eliminated his fund-raising advantage and that they could now come closer to matching his television advertising.
To ensure that, Carla Eudy, Mr. McCain's finance chairwoman, said the campaign was sending out new mail, telephone and Internet appeals for cash and that fund-raisers were planned for Thursday in San Francisco and Friday in Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: MICROSOFT CHIDED AS ANTITRUST TRIAL DRAWS TO A CLOSE

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY and STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Microsoft had its last chance in federal court today to persuade the trial judge not to issue a stinging antitrust verdict against the company.
But the judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, gave Microsoft little comfort. At one point in today's final arguments, he dismissed a crucial Microsoft defense by comparing the company to John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil monopoly, the subject of the first major antitrust case, in 1906. That case resulted in a breakup of the company. 
 "I don't really see a distinction," Judge Jackson said.
The government, in its final argument, said it was "simply impossible to imagine" that the company would not be found to have violated the nation's antitrust laws.
The Microsoft Corporation, for its part, argued that it was impossible to see how the company could be found guilty. "A lot of nothing doesn't add up to something," said John Warden, the company's lead lawyer.
And so the trial drew to a close on exactly the same notes that carried it through 16 months of testimony and argument. The government pressed hard on its broad points, while Microsoft refused to concede even a nit. Today's arguments on the relevant points of law bearing on the case were the last act before a verdict, which will probably be issued in the next few weeks.
The court is likely to hold separate hearings on remedies if, as expected, Judge Jackson rules that Microsoft violated antitrust laws.
A strong verdict against Microsoft could well lead to harsh sanctions against the company, including breaking it up. If, however, Judge Jackson agrees with some of the government's legal contentions but rejects others, the sanctions against Microsoft could be less severe, prohibiting it from some practices but leaving the company intact.
Still, the Justice Department and state attorneys general pressing the case insist that they will not settle for mild sanctions.
"The remedies have to be drastic and far reaching," Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut and one of the plaintiffs, said this evening.
But even as Microsoft and the government concluded this phase of the trial, their representatives were continuing to meet in Chicago in search of a settlement in mediation talks overseen by Richard A. Posner, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The sides reportedly remained far apart, but government officials noted that the fact they were still meeting at this late date suggested willingness on both sides to reach a settlement.
"We're continuing to work hard with Judge Posner," said William H. Neukom, Microsoft's general counsel.
The debate in court today was over how legal precedents from industries ranging from ski slopes in Colorado to newspapers in Ohio apply to the facts in the Microsoft case. The government said Microsoft was an old-fashioned monopolist in high-technology clothes. Microsoft responded that computer software -- a fast-changing, dynamic, fiercely competitive industry -- did indeed have distinctive characteristics, and the courts should tread carefully.
The Standard Oil analogy was just one of several skeptical questions and remarks Judge Jackson aimed at Microsoft's lawyer in court today. Mr. Warden was making the argument that the Windows operating system was protected by a copyright and, therefore, was protected against some of the government's accusations, when Judge Jackson spoke up to say he had a problem with that defense.
"What exactly is covered by copyright?" the judge asked. He then asked whether it was "fee simple" -- or absolute -- control over code.
"Mr. Rockefeller," the judge said, "had fee-simple control over his oil. I don't really see a distinction."
 Mr. Warden responded that the laws were different then, adding that he did not think copyright law was more powerful than antitrust law.
Today's presentations were the final attempts by both sides to try to influence Judge Jackson's thinking. At one point, David Boies, the Justice Department's lead trial lawyer, said Microsoft's business strategy was based on trying to "bribe and coerce" other companies in the computer industry. Mr. Warden dismissed one of Mr. Boies's arguments as "entirely wrong."
The government, according to most antitrust experts, is sitting on a big lead, while Microsoft is trying to limit its losses in Judge Jackson's court while hoping to fare better on appeal. But at one point, Mr. Boies appeared to be trying to embolden Judge Jackson not to worry about appeals by saying: "Try to imagine the Supreme Court ruling that these acts do not violate the antitrust laws. It is simply impossible to imagine that."
Microsoft, on the other hand, seemed to be employing elements of a loss-limitation strategy. Mr. Warden began by saying that Microsoft "respectfully disagreed" with much of Judge Jackson's findings of fact last November, which strongly favored the government's case.
Mr. Warden then went on to tell the judge that his ruling might well shape the ground rules for competition in the entire high-technology economy. And he lambasted the government for its "assault on Windows, which promotes and creates commerce."
The Microsoft case, Mr. Warden noted, focuses on the company's "fights with competitors in a highly competitive, fast-moving industry." And antitrust law, he observed, encourages competition even when that rough-and-tumble competition hurts a company's rivals.
"The law should not be rewritten to prevent Microsoft, or any other company, from competing aggressively," Mr. Warden said.
In the government's view, Microsoft is trying to change the subject with arguments like these. "We don't say competition is a violation of the antitrust laws," Mr. Boies said. "Our allegations here deal with the means by which they compete. They are seriously anticompetitive."
He added that the voluminous court record, including thousands of e-mails, internal Microsoft documents and months of witness testimony, had shown that Microsoft was an arm-twisting monopolist, whose corporate behavior stifled competition and harmed consumers. Judge Jackson's factual findings agreed.
Mr. Boies opened his remarks by emphasizing that the Supreme Court had long recognized that antitrust cases were "especially fact-based cases." And throughout his presentation, he repeatedly made reference to the judge's findings of fact.
But at one point, Judge Jackson asked hard questions of Mr. Boies, too. Antitrust experts say that the government accusation that is most vulnerable is the contention that Microsoft illegally tied its Internet browser to a separate product, its industry-standard Windows operating system.
Judge Jackson questioned Mr. Boies closely on the tying issue. Mr. Boies argued that Microsoft's decision was not really a product design decision but more a mere "bolting" together of the browser and Windows.
In short, Mr. Boies was trying to recast the tying charge as a contract restriction -- that is, PC makers who wanted Windows had to take its Internet Explorer browsing software whether they wanted it or not.
Judge Jackson appeared to be skeptical. What about the benefit, he asked Mr. Boies, of the increased distribution of browser technology resulting from Microsoft's decision to fold its browser into Windows? "I can't offset that -- one plausible benefit," Judge Jackson said.
Still, Kevin O'Conner, an assistant attorney general for Wisconsin, who represented the states, declared that "Microsoft has used virtually every tool of the monopolist's trade -- attempted collusion, exclusionary contracts, tying, predation -- in a coordinated scheme to eliminate threats to its monopoly."

HEADLINE: As Workers Go Off Duty, So Do Cabbies. How Odd.

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It is as inexorable as the tides, as reliable as the setting sun. And it happens every weekday afternoon around 5, just as office buildings are beginning to empty out, just as hundreds of hands are being raised into the air on hundreds of crowded Manhattan street corners: the Great Taxi Drought begins.
"Hey, guy!" yelled Don Ciliotta, waving, leaning into traffic, trying to catch the eyes of a cabbie tearing down Ninth Avenue. "Guy! Hey, guy!" 
 The driver waved back, which was nice of him, considering that more than a dozen taxis had simply roared past Mr. Ciliotta, a tile importer from Long Island, suffering for more than 20 minutes in a subfreezing wind with his brother and their wives.
Atop each passing cab glared the familiar amber off-duty light, as forlorn as a no-vacancy sign buzzing in the dead of night.
The Ciliottas, far from alone, were caught in the gears of the dreaded taxi shift change. It happens when daytime drivers end their 12-hour work day and hit their off-duty lights to give themselves time to gas up and return to their garages to hand the cab to the night drivers, who are eager to start their own 12-hour shifts to catch as much of the evening rush as possible.
As New York phenomena go, the changeover approaches a kind of natural law, and one that seems to have been handed down from God, like alternate-side-of-the street parking rules and 20 percent tips.
In fact, it has been around so long and has become so ingrained in most taxi drivers' lives that explaining it seems, to them, as unnecessary as explaining why their cars have tires. "It's been around, like, forever, for eons," said Mike Higgins, a longtime cabbie who publishes the trade newspaper Taxi Talk. "It's just a traditional thing."
But to the cab-hailing public, it is a natural law that makes about as much sense as the one that compels salmon to swim upstream.
"It doesn't follow any kind of supply and demand laws," said Nathana Josephs, a public relations consultant who practically lives in taxis and has, in desperation, talked police officers and once even firefighters into giving her rides when she could not find a cab during a shift change.
"From 53rd and Fifth Avenue to 57th and Fifth, you could die before you get a cab at 5 o'clock," Ms. Josephs said. "Or you could get killed because of the competition to get the ones out there that are on duty."
Taxi industry historians say that the weekday late-afternoon shift change -- or at least the version that has become so noticeable and roundly reviled -- started happening in the early 1980's, when the large taxi fleets began leasing cabs to drivers instead of hiring the drivers as employees and paying them on commission.
The change, the result of a taxi industry policy adopted in 1979, made drivers into independent contractors who generally worked longer hours -- 12-hour shifts instead of 9-hour shifts, to make more money -- but who had more control over when they worked.
To keep the cabs occupied with drivers, fleets and other companies that leased taxis needed to divide the two 12-hour shifts so that there would always be a roughly equal number of drivers wanting to fill day and night shifts.
The problem was that if the day drivers started their shifts when they really wanted to -- at around 7 a.m. or even 8, when the streets begin to fill with people -- they would hand off to the night drivers too late for those drivers to reap the busiest time of their shift, when people left work. This would mean fewer drivers willing to take on night shifts.
So widespread shift changing around 4:30 or 5 o'clock began to evolve, giving both groups of drivers the benefit of a rush hour. And to make sure that the system was fair to night drivers, fleets also began to assess late fees from day drivers who stayed out too long and cut into night drivers' business.
But, in truth, night drivers are always complaining that day drivers should start earlier and hand off earlier because so many of their precious evening fares are simply evaporating, into the subways or into private car services, while the hand off takes place.
Day drivers, who hate starting as early as they do, are not budging.
Ron Sherman, president of the Midtown Operating Corporation, one of the city's largest fleets, with about 200 cars, recalled a heroic effort a few years back to move the shifts so that more of his drivers would change over earlier in the day.
"I thought it made sense and we'd give it a try," he said. The result? "We completely lost our whole day line." He said that about 70 percent of his drivers now change at 4:30 p.m. and others work out changes among themselves that are earlier or later.
There is not much he can do, he added, because the healthy economy has prompted many taxi drivers to leave for more lucrative work at private livery companies and has increased competition among taxi fleets for drivers. So the drivers who lease his cabs, Mr. Sherman said, pretty much "do what they want to do."
"We're really no different from Hertz or Avis," he said. "I can't tell you when to come in and rent a car from me."
Mr. Sherman's drivers insist that, sure, they feel for the stranded pedestrian with a late afternoon meeting or a plane to catch or a child waiting at day care. But there is really not much they can do.
"Of course it's rough out there, and of course everybody wants to go home, but I want to go home, too," said Anthony Tilelli, 58, who stood in Mr. Sherman's Long Island City garage last week after his day shift, while restless night drivers played "Ms. Pac-Man" in the waiting room behind him.
Mr. Tilelli, a 20-year taxi veteran, says that when he is off duty and angry pedestrians begin knocking on his window at a stop light, threatening to report him to the Taxi and Limousine Commission for refusing service, he generally rolls down his window and spells his name.
"I tell them to make sure and get it right," he said. "I don't care."
While the commission has no exact figures to show how many cabs are changing shifts around 5 P.M., the indications are that more are doing so than several years ago.
This is because the number of taxis being driven by individual owner-drivers -- those who work for themselves and tend to drive from the morning rush through the evening rush, filling in the gap -- is dropping, said Bruce Schaller, a transportation consultant who studies the taxi industry. From 1994 to 1998, the proportion of all taxis driven by owner-drivers fell from about 28 percent to 18 percent, and the percentage is believed to be lower now.
That, combined with the fact that more discretionary income means more people competing for the fraction of the 12,187 cabs remaining on duty, means one thing: some very mean streets.
"There isn't really a lot we can do about it," said Diane McGrath-McKechnie, the chairwoman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission. "Except make it very hurtful for the drivers, and we're not going to do that."
Perhaps the ugliest manifestation of the increase, said Mr. Higgins, the Taxi Talk publisher, is the rising occurrence of what he calls "the big double cross," when an off-duty driver, motivated by both commercial and humanitarian impulses, decides to pick up a passenger who swears his destination is in the direction of the driver's garage.
"They say, 'Yeah, I'm going to 49th Street. This works out great!' And then they get in and say, 'O.K. buddy, take me to Brooklyn Heights,' and what are you going to do because they're already in the cab?"
More often than not, Mr. Higgins says, he does not take the risk anymore. He does exactly what all those cab drivers who whooshed past the poor Ciliottas on Ninth Avenue did.
"I don't care if it's Jesus Christ or a little old lady," Mr. Higgins said. "I've got to get to the garage on time."
And what about the Ciliottas, who had a dinner reservation in the West Village? When a reporter left them, they were still waiting, and beginning to shiver.
"What are we going to do?" Mr. Ciliotta said. "We're not going to walk 40 blocks."

HEADLINE: Pain Relief Underused For Poor, Study Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 22

 BODY:
An international narcotics control agency that is better known for raising alarms about the narcotics trade and drug abuse has turned its attention this year to a severe shortage of morphine and other painkillers in poor countries, where many are left to die in agony from cancer and other diseases.
The International Narcotics Control Board, a United Nations agency based in Vienna, says in a report to be published on Wednesday that it has been tracking the rising but uneven use of morphine and other natural or synthetic drugs with similar structures and effects for several years. 
 The board and the World Health Organization encourage the use of morphine, which is derived from opium, or similar drugs to relieve cancer-related pain. The board says that there is no evidence that those drugs are widely diverted for illicit use, and therefore no reason to caution against increased production.
In its report, the 26-member board made up of experts and diplomats found great disparities in access to strong painkillers among countries and also within them -- usually for economic reasons, but not always. Cultural or social attitudes and medical philosophies also play a part. Treating pain has gained more attention in the United States and Europe in recent years, but for other countries morphine may still be an unaffordable luxury, experts say.
"The ten largest consumer countries accounted for as much as 80 percent of analgesic morphine consumption," the report found. In those countries, all richer nations, the annual average consumption of such drugs was 31 grams for each 1,000 people. At the other end of the scale, in 120 mostly poor countries, there was little or no consumption of those painkillers, called opiods. Eighty other countries fell somewhere between those extremes.
"In a large proportion of the countries and territories of the world," the report says, "insignificant amounts of these medicines are available for medical purposes and it is generally agreed that the treatment of chronic or acute pain caused by cancer is still inadequate. Only about 10 to 30 percent of patients suffering from severe cancer-related pain may be receiving adequate treatment, even in many technologically advanced countries."
But the situation is often starkest in the poorest countries, the report found. "In developing countries, the relief of pain and suffering is given much lower priority than other, more urgent, health and social problems," it says.
The World Health Organization, which is represented on the narcotics board, predicts that by 2015, two-thirds of an estimated 15 million new cancer cases each year will be in developing countries.
Like calls made by others for cheaper and more readily available drugs for H.I.V.-AIDS in the third world, the narcotics board report recommends making more painkillers accessible.
The use of morphine for medical purposes was relatively low and stable until 1984, the report says. In the last 15 years it has risen tenfold.
The country with the highest consumption of morphine for medical use in 1998 was Denmark.
In its report, the narcotics control board also surveyed the use of legal mind-altering drugs and found that Europe far outstripped America and all other regions in the medical use of hypnotics and sedatives. Americans, on the other hand, continued to lead the world in the use of amphetamines, which act as stimulants, and, in fact, increased their intake.
"Over the last few decades, accepted therapeutic uses of amphetamines have become rare and as a result almost all countries in the world report declining medical use of such substances," the report found. "Not so the United States." American consumption of amphetamines for medical use is 10 times higher than in any European country, the narcotics board said.
The board said the issue of possible oversupply and overmedication with those drugs will be the focus of next year's annual report.

HEADLINE: Tickets: In Line or Online?

BYLINE: By CAROL FLAKE CHAPMAN 

 BODY:
LAST year, if you had set out to buy tickets to a hot event like a World Series game, a Backstreet Boys concert or the local premiere of "Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace," chances are you would have joined in the traditional rituals of ticket buying: the around-the-block line, the stampede or the keypad race to get through on the telephone.
Even though the lottery system now commonly used for selling tickets has helped reduce the number of all-night camp-outs at ticket windows, getting tickets to the most popular concerts, shows and sporting events remains a test of the will or the wallet. 
 Thanks to the Internet, however, any pain associated with buying entertainment tickets can be mostly a matter of the wallet. There are ticket vendors, auction markets and scalpers galore on the Web. And you can purchase tickets online for an amazing range of events and venues, from World Wrestling Federation matches and Nascar races to the Louvre, "The Lion King" and the San Diego Zoo.
Bypassing the box office to buy entertainment tickets online makes a lot of sense. It's not like buying books or clothing -- you don't need to glance at a book's cover and a few pages or finger the goods for texture, peruse them for style and find a certain color. You just need to know where you will be sitting and how much you will pay for the privilege. (If you're buying from an unlicensed broker, you also need to know that the tickets are legitimate. One way is to see if the seller is listed on the www.natb.org site of the National Association of Ticket Brokers.) Many sites now offer not only seating charts but also photos that show your actual vantage point. And of course, there's the convenience factor, which is particularly important when the event you will be attending is out of town.
Not surprisingly, the sale of entertainment tickets has become one of the fastest-growing segments of electronic commerce. In 1999, online brokers sold some $300 million worth of tickets. According to Forrester Research, the market is expected to grow to nearly $4 billion by 2004.
The Internet has been a boon to traditional vendors like Ticketmaster, the giant of the ticketing business, which sells online through a separate company called Ticketmaster Online-City Search. The percentage of the company's total sales attributed to online transactions has been growing steadily, from 12 percent in the second quarter of 1999 to 18 percent in the last quarter.
Some places and artists sell tickets through their own Web sites, allowing fans to avoid extra fees. Last year, for example, the Cranberries sold tickets to some of their shows exclusively on their Web site. A growing number of classical music and dance companies, like the New York City Ballet, the Houston Opera and the San Francisco Symphony, are also selling tickets through their own sites.
For smaller performing groups, though, the high cost of software or technical support can be prohibitive. (Selling tickets online usually requires an electronic sales-tracking system.) Nor can smaller groups afford the kinds of links and advertising they need on the Web to reach a wide audience. As a result, most entertainment tickets are sold online through sites operated by large vendors like Ticketmaster Online. The brokers connect the organizations or venues selling the tickets to the brokers' systems through either equipment established on site at each vendor's place of business or through Web-based systems that allow access by vendors using Web browsers.
Although the Web would seem to offer opportunities for cutting costs, online brokers' fees are seldom cheaper than those than tacked on at regular outlets.
Ticketmaster Online has said that ticket buyers will soon be able to print their tickets at home after buying them online. These tickets, which will be letter-size sheets of paper imprinted with bar codes, will be accepted in place of traditional tickets.
Just about any printer will be adequate, said Tom Stockham, a spokesman for Ticketmaster.com, and if the paper jams, the ticket can be printed out again. You won't be able to use the same ticket more than once, however, because the system allows only the first person who shows up with the encoded ticket to get in.
The system may deter scalpers from using it to buy tickets, Mr. Stockham said, because it will be harder to convince buyers that a sheet of paper with a few lines on it is a real ticket.
While Ticketmaster Online continues to dominate the Web-ticketing business for live events, a number of competitors have cropped up, including fast-growing Tickets.com, which recently announced that it would be the online broker for tickets to the 2002 Olympics in Salt Lake City. Tickets.com offers tickets from some 4,000 venues worldwide. It also offers links to events and venues for which it does not act as broker.
"We'll connect any consumer to any event," said Tim Kelly, the company's president.
The company, which came under fire from competitors for offering tickets to some high-demand events at high resale prices , is phasing out its site's links to so-called secondary-market sellers, Mr. Kelly said.
The online movie-ticket business is also about to experience some competitive jostling. A new company called MovieTickets.com is set to challenge Moviefone, which has been the dominant online seller for film tickets. MovieTickets, a joint venture between AMC Entertainment and Hollywood.com, has announced that it will begin selling tickets online during the Memorial Day weekend.
There is also room in the Web ticket market, it seems, for the niche seller -- the gatherer of "low-hanging fruit," as Andrew Dreskin, president of TicketWeb, put it. TicketWeb, which began in 1995, established itself as an alternative broker with tickets to trendy nightclubs, festivals and such oddball events as the Burning Man Festival, which centers on a wooden statue of a man that is set on fire on the last day. Its fees are considerably lower than Ticketmaster's, partly because its ticket-selling clients tap into the system online and do not need any special software to use TicketWeb's servers and database. The company has been growing at a rate of 400 percent a year, Mr. Dreskin said, and it has gathered a number of prestigious clients, like the Louvre.
Another company called CultureFinder, which went online mainly as a search engine for cultural events, has grown into a major source for buying tickets to museums, concerts and shows. CultureFinder.com is particularly useful for travelers. The site offers comprehensive listings of events, including free events, as well as nutshell descriptions of the offerings. Users of CultureFinder purchase tickets online and pick them up at the box office.
Anyone searching for tickets to a hot attraction will probably be out of luck using a regular online broker. "One of the things that doesn't work well online is selling tickets for big events," like Super Bowl games or Backstreet Boys concerts, said Seema Williams of Forrester Research. "They sell out in minutes, and the volume is so high their systems can't handle it." And that is where the resale, or secondary, online market comes in. Such sites have proliferated, although some states, including New York, have strict regulations regarding scalping.
While the authorities in New York and elsewhere have recently cracked down on ticket brokers who skim tickets to sell on the secondary market, Web scalping has remained something of a gray area. The eBay auction site recently incorporated state laws into its requirements for selling entertainment tickets. For example, eBay forbids resales of tickets at prices more than $2 above their face value for any entertainment event held in New York. For events held in Louisiana, in case you are looking for something to do at Mardi Gras, the allowed markup above face value is zero.
Such restrictions do not seem to faze online resellers like Frontrow.com, Tixx.com or Ticket Dog. For them, the sky seems to be the limit on prices (for sky box tickets, you might as well be buying tickets to the moon). People who wanted tickets to this year's Kentucky Derby could have joined Millionaire's Row, courtesy of the online scalpers, for a minimum of $4,000 -- or waited until the day of the Derby, when they could buy tickets to the infield at the gate for $35 apiece.
 
Strategies
Looking for Deals While Looking Out
 Here are tips for online tickets.
Try searching for tickets on your favorite search engine by typing in "tickets" and adding the name of the show, artist or sports team you're looking for. (Example: "tickets Spurs" or "tickets Springsteen.") You'll get a range of sellers, some legitimate and some scalpers.
Check out the Web sites devoted to your team, musician or group. A number of sites devoted to rock groups have areas for ticket trading, and you might get lucky. But be aware that those sites are often invaded by scalpers.
To save money on shipping and extra fees, buy from a broker working directly with the venue, so you can pick up your tickets there. You'll usually need to present the credit card you used to purchase the tickets.
If you're not sure about a broker's reliability, check with the National Association of Ticket Brokers (www.natb.org) to see if the broker is listed and if the broker is bonded. If you're buying tickets on eBay, you can check the seller's customer feedback rating. Check eBay's rules on selling tickets; scalping may be regulated in your area.
Check the location of the tickets offered for sale against a seating chart (usually available on the venue's or broker's site).
If you're buying high-demand tickets online, find out when the tickets go on sale (often it's Saturday morning). Go to the broker's Web site ahead of time and fill out the order form. Be ready to hit the button again and again until you get through. Be prepared to be disappointed.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Kuwait Is Said to Be Opposed To U.S. Effort to Cut Oil Prices

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Feb. 23

 BODY:
A consensus on the need for lower or stable oil prices is slowly building among some leading producers, but resistance to the Clinton administration's campaign for increased oil supplies and lower prices is coming not only from Algeria and Iran, but from a traditional Middle East ally, Kuwait.
According to American and Arab oil officials, Kuwait, which controls 9 percent of the world's reserves and has considerable ability to produce more oil, apparently remains opposed to the administration's view that the recent run-up in prices to the highest in nearly a decade will cause inflationary pressures that threaten global economic growth. 
 The Secretary of Energy, Bill Richardson, in the sixth day of his 10-day tour of some of the largest oil producers, picked up strong support here from Egypt. After Mr. Richardson met today in the Egyptian capital with President Hosni Mubarak and Sameh Fahmy, Egypt's minister of petroleum, Mr. Fahmy said current prices were too high and had to come down.
"If we don't take the price down, everything will go up," said Mr. Fahmy, speaking in English to Egyptian and American businessmen. An inflationary spiral now, Mr. Fahmy said, would jeopardize Egypt's development plans as well as its economic overhaul and privatization. What the United States is promoting, Mr. Fahmy said, would result in "a balanced situation for everybody."
In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, oil ministers from the four-member Gulf Cooperation Council pledged today to work with other producers to create a predictable oil market to avoid "harming the world economy."
But the ministers from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar, which together produce about half the daily output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, did not say they would do this by releasing more oil.
The absence of such a statement, coupled with the refusal of the Saudi oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, to answer reporters' questions about whether production would be raised, led to speculation on the oil markets that the group could not reach a consensus on strategy.
This in turn, helped pushed up oil prices today. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, prices rose 47 cents, to $29.39 a barrel. Prices reached a nine-year high of $30.45 last week.
Kuwait's reported resistance to what is said to be an emerging majority view among its fellow OPEC members also annoyed Clinton administration officials in Washington, as well as Mr. Richardson's energy team, which is expected to arrive in Kuwait on Thursday.
In an interview today, Mr. Richardson said he was extremely pleased with Egypt's support. Asked about the the Gulf Cooperation Council's ambiguous statement, he called it "responsible," adding that it was "heading in the right direction." He declined to elaborate.
Other administration officials who had hoped that the cooperation council would be more decisive about increasing production to lower prices were clearly irritated by what they described as Kuwait's continuing hard-line stance, particularly in view of the American-led military effort nine years ago to liberate Kuwait from Iraq's occupation.
"That's gratitude for you," said one American oil expert, who insisted on not being identified.
A hard-line stance on prices by Kuwait is also likely to infuriate Capitol Hill. At a hearing last week, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, the Republican chairman of the House International Relations Committee, urged the Clinton administration to cut off military assistance to OPEC nations that refused to help reduce oil prices. "The people in the Northeast are facing a major crisis in the cost of home heating oil," Mr. Gilman said.
Pressed today to say what oil price he was seeking from the countries he called "good friends of the United States" -- Kuwait and Saudi Arabia -- Mr. Richardson demurred. "Thirty dollars a barrel is too high," he said. "And $10 is too low."
"We're not trying to be greedy," he added, saying that it should be market forces that determine price. "We're trying to do what is in everyone's best interest," he said.

HEADLINE: Threat Seen To Trade Deal To Let China Join W.T.O.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Two supporters of China's entry into the World Trade Organization warned the White House today that the administration is in imminent danger of seeing its huge trade initiative die, partly because of Beijing's threats to Taiwan and because Vice President Al Gore appears to have cold feet about the deal.
In a heated exchange before the Senate Finance Committee, the chairman of the panel, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, said today that recent comments by Mr. Gore "raise serious questions about the administration's commitment to getting this deal done and the legislation passed." Speaking at a meeting of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last week, Mr. Gore promised to negotiate stronger protections for workers' rights and the environment if elected president. 
 The ranking minority member of the committee, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, was even harsher in his assessment of how the administration has handled an agreement on which much of the United States-China relationship now hinges.
The administration, he said, has not yet sent a bill to Congress to grant China permanent "normal" trade status -- the one American concession in an accord that opens China's markets.
"The administration has to know that they have to get this thing done in two to four weeks," Senator Moynihan said in an interview this afternoon, describing a timetable for a vote far speedier than what the White House is considering. "After that this whole thing is in jeopardy."
White House officials say they disagree and want a vote before the summer. But the timetable is partly up to the Republicans, and administration officials met today with Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader.
President Clinton has begun a lobbying campaign on the China deal, meeting members of Congress in small groups in the yellow Oval Room in the White House residence, and will speak on the issue on Thursday morning in front of the Business Council, a group of 75 business leaders.
The White House insists that it can win passage of the deal by relying on the support of Republicans, and by winning over 70 to 90 Democrats. But it is far from clear they will get that support.
Democrats, pressured by labor's opposition to the trade deal, are far more leery. Mr. Gore promised last week to get labor and environmental protections into a subsequent agreement with China, but Senator Moynihan said today "the Chinese won't sign that deal, so we won't have any future trade agreements."
Mr. Gore's comments put the White House in what one administration official said this week was "an intellectually indefensible position." By suggesting that he would press for a better deal later, Mr. Gore gave political cover to those Democrats who want to skip the vote this year. And plenty want to do exactly that, after the unions have made clear that they will work to defeat, district by district, members of Congress who vote for the China agreement.
This week China also made passage more complex. Its 11,000 word report on Taiwan, released on Monday, suggested that Beijing would feel free to use military force to reunify the mainland with the Republic of China if negotiations with Taiwan drag on for too long. That drew a sharp response from the Pentagon and from conservative Republicans who see China as an emerging security threat to the United States.
The result is a bizarre political alliance between conservatives in Congress and labor and environmental groups opposed to the China deal.
In testimony before the Finance Committee today, Charlene Barshefsky, the American trade representative, made no direct references to either Mr. Gore or the threats against Taiwan. She told Mr. Roth and Mr. Moynihan that she was testifying "with the full support of the administration."
But she also argued that while Congress could debate the issue endlessly, it really had no choice other than to sign on to the deal -- or risk putting American firms at a huge competitive disadvantage in the world's largest and fastest-growing market.
Clearly, though, the administration is going to have to give ground to its critics. Some supporters of the trade organization deal say that may mean approving more arms for Taiwan -- which enrages Beijing -- or may mean finding a way to enforce Chinese compliance with the deal that would appease the critics.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Warns of Big Shortfalls and Cutbacks in Mayor's 4-Year Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's four-year spending plan leaves New York City with dangerously large budget gaps that could force layoffs and cuts in city services after the mayor leaves office, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday.
The comptroller's sharply worded warning and the mayor's quick dismissal of it yesterday afternoon as groundless and politically motivated represent the latest in a series of skirmishes between Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Hevesi, who is considering running for mayor. 
 The problem with the mayoral spending plan, the comptroller said, is that it relies far too heavily on one-time revenue sources that will disappear if the economy falters. The mayor, for example, wants to use Wall Street-fueled surpluses accumulated over the last four years in the city's pension funds to help balance budgets in the next two years.
"It is a mistake," Mr. Hevesi said. "This boom isn't going to last."
The comptroller, a Democrat, did offer the Republican mayor some good news. With the city's economy still charging ahead, at least for now, the surplus will probably be even larger than the mayor expects by the time the current fiscal year ends on June 30: it will total $2.46 billion, or nearly 7 percent of the $37.4 billion budget, the comptroller predicted.
But by the 2002 fiscal year, the city may face a $2.5 billion deficit, Mr. Hevesi said, in large part because of tax cuts the mayor has proposed. The comptroller said the cuts were more generous than the city could afford.
That shortfall could reach as much as $4.1 billion by 2004, a total that is 63 percent higher than the amount Mr. Giuliani has predicted, Mr. Hevesi said. Even when using the mayor's projection, the deficit would exceed deficit predictions issued at comparable times during the Dinkins and Koch administrations, the comptroller said. These budget gaps are so large, Mr. Hevesi said, that the next mayor may be forced to lay off teachers or cut city services to balance the budget.
"What is lacking here is long-term planning," Mr. Hevesi said. "It is a very, very serious problem."
Mr. Giuliani ridiculed the comptroller's remarks, suggesting at his own afternoon news conference that Mr. Hevesi had proved over the last six years that he was incapable of issuing an accurate budget analysis. Prudent fiscal management, the mayor said, has allowed his administration to cut taxes while still generating record surpluses. "We've accomplished a turnaround in the economy of the city, and I would suspect that the comptroller, not having been part of that, is probably a little jealous of that," Mr. Giuliani said.
As the comptroller and the mayor disagreed over New York's finances, the city's Independent Budget Office issued a report yesterday showing that New York City's tax burden, as of 1997, was 79 percent higher than the average burden of the nine next largest cities in the nation. The study found that $7.99 worth of every $100 in household income or business profits in New York City goes to the local government as taxes, compared with an average of $4.47 for the nine other cities.
Part of the reason for the higher New York City tax burden is that New York pays a much larger share of Medicaid and welfare costs than the other cities. City tax cuts adopted in the last two years also are not reflected in the study. Even when these factors are taken into account, New York City's tax burden remains higher than the tax burden for the other nine cities, said Andrew S. Rein, associate director of the Independent Budget Office.
Mr. Hevesi said that he had supported tax cuts adopted by the mayor and the City Council over the last several years and that he supports a number of the new tax-cut measures the mayor is advocating. The question, Mr. Hevesi said, is whether the city can afford them all at once.
"You have got to be judicious," Mr. Hevesi said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq in Record Gain to New High, but Blue Chips Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The technology-laden Nasdaq stock index soared 168.21 points yesterday -- its biggest point gain ever -- more than offsetting the losses it incurred in the two preceding sessions and surpassing the high it had set just last week.
But in another sharp divergence between the performance of the high-technology sector and most other stocks, 20 of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average fell -- 10 of them by more than a dollar -- to push the blue-chip gauge down 79.11 points, to 10,225.73, its fourth loss in five sessions. 
 The bullish technology tone was set early, analysts said, when Merrill Lynch strongly recommended eBay, the Internet auction house, and America Online, whose deal to acquire Time Warner has met skepticism in various quarters.
Then, in an appearance before Congress, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, seemed to dispel some fears he aroused last week that he was focusing on stock prices in an effort to cool an overheated economy that might cause inflation to pick up.
"I think it was a big relief rally" for buyers of growth stocks, said Matthew W. Johnson, head of Nasdaq trading at Lehman Brothers. "He didn't drop another shoe."
Mr. Johnson also pointed to heavy buying of Cisco Systems and Qualcomm stocks by index funds needing to add shares to conform with rebalanced index weightings.
Ebay surged 20 7/16 a share, to 154 15/16; America Online 7 7/16, to 57 3/16; Cisco 14 11/16, to 138 5/8; and Qualcomm 16 5/16, to 146 7/8.
"There's only one game for the portfolio manager" these days, said Richard E. Cripps, chief equity strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore. "He can't afford to be in anything that's not showing great relative strength."
And when technology stocks took off, many traders who had bet that the declines of Friday and Tuesday would continue were driven to cover their short positions, buying back shares they had borrowed and sold.
The Nasdaq composite index finished at 4,550.33, up 3.84 percent, with the 168.21-point gain slightly greater than the previous one-day record of 167.05 points on Jan. 10.
Technology also lifted the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which climbed 8.52 points, to 1,360.69, even though 350 of its component issues fell while only 140 rose.
As for the Dow, Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson, I.B.M., Merck and Honeywell all lost more than 2 points a share to lead its retreat. The only issues to gain more than a point were Intel, up 2 5/16 a share, to 109 1/16; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up 2 3/16, to 92 5/16; and Hewlett-Packard, up 2 1/4, to 130 3/4.
Henry Blodget, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, initiated coverage of eBay with a buy rating, saying that the stock could reach 175 a share within 12 to 18 months; it wound up moving about halfway there yesterday. Mr. Blodget and another Merrill analyst said America Online "seems undervalued by almost any measure."
Concerning Mr. Greenspan's testimony before the Senate Banking Committee the Fed chief said that among other things, he agreed with those analysts who see no evidence of revived inflation. "I cannot find it, no matter where I look," he declared.
He also said, "the basic purpose of what we are trying to do is to sustain this extraordinary recovery, this extraordinary acceleration in growth and a vibrant labor market."
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered advancing ones 1,764 to 1,258, with 219 stocks setting new 52-week lows and only 47 reaching new highs. Volume remained heavy, with 994 million shares traded.

Treasury Prices Drop
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday, as investors took profits to make room for new supply and technology shares surged after several jittery sessions in the stock market.
Dealers said Treasuries were taking their cue from equity markets, which were recovering after last week's declines on rate worries.
"It's a little bit of an unwind" from earlier run-ups in bond prices, said Richard Gilhooly, fixed-income strategist at the Paribas Corporation. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 18/32, to 101 24/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.12 percent from 6.08 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: It Blocks Cat Odors, And Maybe Radiation;
Material Used in Litter Is Tested In Sopping Up Nuclear Contaminants

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: WEST VALLEY, N.Y.

 BODY:
Here at the opposite end of New York State from the site of the Indian Point nuclear accident on Feb. 15 lies one of the country's biggest radioactive stains, left behind at a long-mothballed recycling plant for spent nuclear fuel rods.
An army of nearly 1,000 scientists and engineers has spent 18 years and $1.5 billion so far on a cleanup involving custom-designed robots and remote-controlled ovens that bake liquid wastes into solid glass cylinders. 
 Now they are testing the ultimate in low technology: a mineral better known as a prime ingredient in cat litter.
Federal and state energy experts and a task force of residents are closely watching the project, which involves digging a deep trench and burying a wall of zeolite -- the same stuff found in millions of cat boxes -- to sop up radioactive material tainting the ground water. The contaminant is seeping toward a stream that feeds Lake Erie.
"There are an awful lot of things that are simple that turn out better," said Joe Patti, the owner of a West Valley hardware store and a member of the task force. "It's too early to say whether it's going to work, but if they don't try to do something, we're going to have a problem."
Zeolite is actually a family of 48 minerals that absorb odors and moisture. They are commonly found in many varieties of animal litter, and it turns out that the most abundant one, clinoptilolite, has a strong affinity for strontium 90, the radioactive isotope that tainted ground water beneath the plant when acid ate through a concrete and steel foundation several decades ago.
Some scientists and officials involved in the test are eager to play down the latest strategy's quirky pedigree.
"Zeolites are used for all kinds of things, and one of those markets happens to be cat litter," said Alan J. Rabideau, an associate professor of engineering at the State University at Buffalo who ran the laboratory studies and is monitoring the pilot project.
At the university and the West Valley plant site, the cat litter connection has often dominated discussions, he said, adding, "That has sort of trivialized the science."
After Dr. Rabideau's lab tests in the spring of 1999 were successful, cleanup managers began a field test of the buried zeolite wall in December. The 3,300-acre West Valley site sits on a rural, windswept slope 30 miles south of Buffalo.
If the test goes as planned, for at least the next 25 years the porous mineral wall, 30 feet across and 26 feet deep, will act like a giant molecular sieve, letting water flow downhill but capturing any strontium 90 molecules.
The method could not only be expanded at the West Valley site, but could also help restore water quality at many other nuclear waste sites, federal energy officials said. The approach could sharply reduce the need for costly pumping systems for treating ground water.
Results should be evident by the spring, said Beth A. Fallon, the project manager for West Valley Nuclear Services, a subsidiary of Westinghouse that is handling the cleanup for the Department of Energy and the state, which owns the land.
The state built the fuel-processing plant in the early 1960's in hopes that the emergent atomic power industry would revive the economy of western New York. But the plant ran for only six years, from 1966 to 1972, chopping up spent fuel rods and extracting uranium and plutonium in acid baths. The process left all manner of radioactive residue above and in the ground.
Over all, the underground strontium leak, totaling about 200 curies of radiation, represents a minuscule fraction of the contamination at the West Valley site, which harbors 30 million curies.
(A curie is the amount of radiation given off by one gram of radium. The 12 radium dots on the dials of the radium watches popular in the 1920's emitted about three one-thousandths of a curie of radiation. By comparison, the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant released about 50 curies into the air; Chernobyl released tens of millions of curies. And if any radiation escaped in the brief puff of steam and gas that was released from the Indian Point 2 reactor in Westchester County on Feb. 15, engineers say it would have been measurable only in millionths of a curie, if that.)
About two-thirds of the radioactive waste at the West Valley site has been contained in the solid glass blocks, but the remaining waste includes radioactive sludge in rusting underground tanks and the contents of two nuclear waste dumps, which hold a melange of chopped-up casings for fuel rods, old gloves and other debris.
The underground plume of strontium was detected about seven years ago, Ms. Fallon said. The leak was stopped years ago, plant officials said, but the strontium has been slowly spreading ever since.
The leading edge of the 700-foot-long amoeba-shaped plume -- which is spreading downhill from the old factory -- has approached the surface of the gravelly soil in some places and, if nothing is done, could eventually make its way into several creeks and possibly Lake Erie, the officials said.
Private environmental groups, the nearby Seneca Indian Nation and neighboring towns have long been concerned about that possibility.
Several years ago, West Valley Nuclear Services began drilling wells and pumping the contaminated water through filters to capture the strontium 90, but the method costs nearly $400,000 a year and creates its own new batch of radioactive waste each time the filter material has to be replaced, Ms. Fallon said.
"In some ways," she said, "you're creating more of a problem than you're solving."
Two years ago, engineers began searching for an alternative and quickly focused on an emerging toxic cleanup method: allowing ground water to pass through underground berms of materials that can catch or break down hazardous chemicals. One variation of this technique, using buried walls of iron filings, is increasingly being used to remove harmful chlorinated solvents, like dry-cleaning fluid, from ground water.
Small tests of zeolite as a strontium snare at the nuclear site in Hanford, Wash., were successful, and the material has been used for decontamination at Chalk River, a nuclear site in Ontario. But Dr. Rabideau said the West Valley test was the first large-scale effort to use the mineral in a completely passive way.
Engineers hope that the zeolite will not have to be replaced for a relatively long time, eliminating the need for frequent pumping and treating of ground water, and for the disposal of newly created radioactive waste. And over time, the strontium will decay and lose much of its radioactivity.
The project is still in its early stages. Water samples are taken every other week, Ms. Fallon said, and by March the team should have enough preliminary data to see if the project is working. The goal is to see a rise in concentrations of strontium in the wall, and a drop in the ground water downstream.
Not everyone is enthusiastic about the mineral wall. Ray Vaughan, who lives halfway between the plant and Buffalo and has been tracking the cleanup for 22 years as a member of several community groups and the citizens' task force, said the test "appears to be a useful idea."
But he added that he and other residents wanted the cleanup to proceed as rapidly as possible. They think that it has to include pumping and treating of the most heavily contaminated water from the center of the plume.
A formal report on the test is to be issued in late spring, Ms. Fallon said, adding that if it works, the wall will be extended for about 100 feet to intercept the leading edge of the entire plume. The total cost is expected to be less than $1.5 million, she said, far less than it would cost to continue pumping and treating the water year after year.
If the technique catches on, it will mean a new line of business for Glen and Marie Teague, who own the mine in eastern Oregon that supplied the mineral being used for the test -- at $180 a ton.
Mrs. Teague said she and her husband sold their zeolite mainly as an additive for poultry and livestock feed -- it improves the health of the animals by absorbing some toxins -- and as a deodorizer for horse stalls.
And, of course, as cat litter. The Teagues sell it in 40-pound sacks.

HEADLINE: Feud Over How Port Authority Spends Money Creates an Impasse

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
When the 12-member board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey holds its monthly meeting today, the agenda will be limited to routine capital expenditures instead of the grand bridges, tunnels, airports and development projects the agency has pursued in its 79 years.
Such initiatives exist in abundance, but a long-simmering civil war between New York and New Jersey members has made agreement on them impossible. As a result, the agency has all but halted for the last year actions that could generate billions of dollars from such things as the privatization of the World Trade Center, the leasing of air rights over the Port Authority Bus Terminal and the approval of a long-term lease meant to keep the container terminal at Port Elizabeth competitive with other East Coast ports. 
 Historians, former agency officials and some board members call the stalemate the worst in the history of the agency, which is the nation's oldest congressionally approved compact between two states.
The current impasse grows out of a squabble between New York and New Jersey about the allocation of Port Authority expenditures, which have amounted to $14 billion over the years. As a complicating sidelight, the agency has become the target of New York City's mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. While other mayors have silently suffered the Port Authority's presence in their midst, Mr. Giuliani has publicly lacerated it as an unaccountable and unnecessary anachronism that ought to be dismantled.
Contributing to the situation is the makeup of the board, which is top- heavy with members politically tied to the two governors.
The result has crippled the authority and significantly dimmed its reputation as a businesslike body able to rise above politics and bureaucratic red tape to get things done.
The port agency's board has met only five times in the last 10 months, with New York members actually boycotting the December meeting. A repeat of such acrimonious tactics is not likely today, said Charles A. Gargano, the vice chairman and a New York representative. But he added: "There are minor things on the agenda, and none of our major resolutions. So the impasse continues."
Already, internal efforts to sort out differences have slowed to a crawl, said the chairman, Lewis M. Eisenberg, a New Jersey appointee, and some other top officials have openly talked of the need for an outside study to see if major changes must be made in the compact or whether alternatives to the agency are needed.
The agency was created in 1921 to coordinate the two states' transportation and port projects and enhance commerce in the metropolitan region. The authority built and operates all of the tunnel and bridge crossings between New Jersey and New York City, manages airports and seaports in both states, operates the PATH rapid transit system and owns the World Trade Center.
The argument about the share of expenditures in each state is a complicated one, depending largely on how benefit is defined and how the spending is categorized.
One such accounting by staff members at the agency was based on each project's location and whether it was a transportation link between the two states. The study found that between 1928 and 1998, 43 percent of the capital spending had been in New York, 27 percent in New Jersey and 29 percent on interstate linkages.
New York disputes this accounting while New Jersey generally agrees with it. And Mr. Gargano notes that it fails to take into account the agency's continued subsidizing of such money-losing interstate operations as the PATH trains and the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan, which together lost $234 million last year alone -- expenditures that New York representatives insist disproportionately benefit New Jersey.
The focus of the impasse is a dispute over a 30-year lease between the port agency and Sealand Maersk to operate a major containerized cargo terminal at Port Elizabeth. New York commissioners charge that it amounts to yet another deeply subsidized project benefiting an operation based in New Jersey.
New Jersey and authority staff disagree and say that the lease arrangement and its attendant dredging and channel-widening is crucial to maintaining the region's competitiveness and thousands of jobs in New Jersey and New York.
Mr. Eisenberg, at the direction of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, has, in drafting the agenda for recent meetings, insisted that the port lease be approved as part of a package that includes items such as the World Trade Center privatization effort and the bus terminal air rights that are important to New York commissioners. Mr. Gargano and his other New York members, acting at the direction of Gov. George E. Pataki, have refused to approve the package.
In a letter sent yesterday to Governor Pataki, Governor Whitman noted the long-pending Sealand Maersk lease as well as her support of projects in the agency's pending budget that are in New York and "will benefit the Port Authority and the region." She called on Governor Pataki to "respect the need to proceed with all of these projects."
Behind the conciliatory tones, said one New Jersey official, was actually a threat by Governor Whitman to add the agency's entire capital budget to the current bargaining over the Port Elizabeth lease.
In the past, when parochialism or politics reared its head within the agency, the independent business people on the board or its professional staff, which was insulated from patronage and political pressures, could be counted on to resolve things, said Robert Yaro, executive director of the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit group specializing in transportation and planning issues.
In extreme cases, he said, public bickering was short-circuited: the governors of the two states could be counted on to sit down behind closed doors to compromise.
But today, the 12-member board is largely dominated by cabinet members or top aides of the two governors. And the voice of Robert E. Boyle, the current executive director and an appointee of Governor Pataki, is often not as loud and authoritative as those of other important New York appointees, like Mr. Gargano, head of the Empire State Development Corporation, and Brad Race, Mr. Pataki's chief of staff.
Mr. Yaro said distrust between the governors had grown so intense that they had not met to discuss port issues since 1997, and more recent meetings between their respective chiefs of staff had proven futile. In short, he said, there is "no shared strategic vision" for the agency.
Stanley Brezenoff, who served as executive director of the port agency from 1990 to 1995, had a similar assessment. "You go through the Sturm und Drang but you get to a point where people can sit down and reason together," he said. "But now these disputes seem to go on and on."
Not since the early 1970's, when New Jersey Gov. William T. Cahill refused to approve the agency's minutes and effectively stopped all its activity, have things been so paralyzed, said Jameson W. Doig, a Princeton University historian whose book on the agency is due out this year. But even then, Mr. Cahill was acting as the consummate cosmopolite, trying to pressure New York and the board into paying more attention to regional mass transit issues. He and Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, a fellow Republican, eventually met secretly and negotiated a compromise.
"But everything is emerging in the public eye now and governors are digging in their heels," Professor Doig said. "In the last seven years or so I see Governor Pataki as the one who seems to care much less about regional growth issues. Whitman's problem is less a lack of understanding of those issues but a failing to take a strong position for the integrity of the Port Authority."
Professor Doig also took note of the silence from business and corporate interests on the stalemate and termed it "puzzling."
It is on this point that many cite the "Mayor Giuliani effect."
One official of a civic group who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that business leaders in the city who would have spoken up for the port agency in the past have been afraid to now for fear of antagonizing the mayor. "Any support of ending the impasse at the agency might be seen by the mayor as giving aid and comfort to an entity that he would just as soon see disappear from the face of the earth," the official said.
The dispute at the Port Authority comes at a time when the agency is more flush with cash than at any time in its history. Spurred by operating efficiencies and a racing economy, revenues from everything from tolls to airport activity have ballooned cash to $2.6 billion in 1998 from $1.5 billion in 1996, according to agency financial statements.
Mr. Yaro and others suggested that this factor might explain some current maneuvering and tactics. Both Republican governors have cut taxes, limiting the money available for new capital projects. Consequently, he said, the port agency's resources, are "very attractive" to both governors.
The situation sets up a competition for money that would seem to be the antithesis of real regionalism. But the agency is not new to open horse trading. Over the years, it has created "development banks," or pools of money derived from excess revenues and divided it between the states. The two governors saw it as a way to get a direct benefit from Port Authority projects.
Some see that idea -- quietly providing extra funds to both states -- as a way to defuse the current situation. But others say the hard feelings run so deep that no easy resolution is in sight.
New York commissioners, said Mr. Eisenberg, seem to be nursing an unfounded grievance that they lost out in agency spending. And New Jersey commissioners, said Mr. Gargano, cannot seem to move on any project without "orders from Trenton."
