HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:

CNN Anchor Goes Coast to Coast
CNN is accommodating its half of a two-network couple. WILLOW BAY, who became a co-anchor of "Moneyline" after LOU DOBBS quit last year, will move from Manhattan to Los Angeles and do the program from there. 
 CNN says this change will make "Moneyline" "the first bicoastal evening news program of its kind." That is the kind of accomplishment networks like to brag about. But the move will also let Ms. Bay live in the same city as her husband, ROBERT A. IGER, who was promoted to president of the Walt Disney Company last month.
Mr. Iger, who was chairman of the ABC Group, has been traveling between coasts. "He's pretty much kept his commuting to Monday through Wednesday or Monday through Thursday," an ABC executive in New York said, "and they spend every weekend together here."
A CNN spokeswoman, CHRISTA ROBINSON, said, "We are accommodating Willow's relocation, but this dovetails nicely with Shelby Coffey's plans to expand our West Coast presence, and the new economy." She added, "If it makes us more family friendly, so be it." (SHELBY COFFEY III is the president of CNN Business News and CNNfn.)
 
Mercy Mission
When they learned their 2-year-old daughter had a rare liver disease that could be treated only in New York, JOYBELLE and DEORTIME JAMANDRE of the Philippines sold their house, their clothes, even their kitchen utensils.
But when their daughter, NICOLE, undergoes surgery at New York Presbyterian Hospital next week, she will have a police escort, and her hospital bills will be fully paid, thanks in part to POLICE COMMISSIONER HOWARD SAFIR, who has taken an interest in her case.
Mr. Safir is on the board of the Forum Club's Children of the World Foundation, an organization based in New York that arranges for sick children from around the world to see world-class medical specialists. Nicole's case is the most difficult the foundation has dealt with; she will receive a piece of one parent's liver.
"With the other cases, it is simply a question of getting a doctor and getting a hospital," Mr. Safir said. "In this case, we have a child who needs significant resources and medications." The drugs she needs cost about $70,000.
"The thing that appeals to me about this little girl is the same thing that appeals to me with all these kids," Mr. Safir said. "They are going to die without help, and being able to help them is as good a thing as anyone could do in this world."
 
Living Proof
ROBERT CLAYTON has been quoting Mark Twain ("the reports of my death are greatly exaggerated"), but in Mr. Clayton's case, there was only one report. It appeared in his college alumni magazine, Columbia College Today.
How did an obituary on Mr. Clayton, who is 74 and who graduated in 1948 with a degree in political science, make it into the magazine? "I would rather not go into it," said ALEX SACHARE, the magazine's editor. "An error was made."
Mr. Clayton said the magazine had apologized, sending letters saying it had erred to his classmates. The magazine apparently sent similar letters to members of a secret society known as the Nacoms, which is pronounced like "knock 'em dead," except that Mr. Clayton isn't.
"It gives me the rare opportunity to nitpick my own obituary and get things straight up there," said Mr. Clayton, who, as the article noted, was a real estate executive and held class office as a loyal alumnus. "My God, I was president of my class. They say I was first vice president. This was in the 60's, maybe even the early 70's." For a while, as the obituary said, he was also his class of 1948's correspondent for the very magazine that reported his death, a mistake that he said would not have happened on his watch. "Heavens, no," he said. "I am a religious reader of The New Yorker. They have one of the best checking departments in the world. Checking is, in my opinion, very important."
 JAMES BARRON with Jennifer Steinhauer

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Were Lower Last Month

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Orders to the nation's factories for big-ticket manufactured goods fell in January, led by the steepest decline in orders for electronic and other electrical equipment in two and a half years.
The Commerce Department reported today that orders for durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- dropped 1.3 percent last month, the first decline since October, to a seasonally adjusted $214.8 billion. 
 That followed a sizzling 6.3 percent advance in December -- the biggest gain in seven years. The December increase had been reported earlier at 5.5 percent.
Even with the drop, January's performance was stronger than the 2 percent decline many analysts were forecasting.
Still, economists, who were predicting a decrease, have cautioned that a drop in durable-goods orders should not be viewed as weakness in the industrial sector. Economists said the underlying trend in orders remained firm, and they expect manufacturers to perform well this year.
Over all, orders in January were 6.5 percent higher than in January of last year.
Strong business and consumer spending is fueling the red-hot economy. On Friday, the government will release a revised estimate for the economy's growth in the last three months of 1999 and some economists believe it will be much stronger than the 5.8 percent rate the government initially estimated.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits last week fell by 7,000, to 278,000, suggesting that employers continue to have trouble finding workers to fill openings.
The Federal Reserve has bumped up interest rates four times since June, totaling a full percentage point. Even though those actions made borrowing more expensive for businesses and consumers, the higher rates still have not had much impact in terms of significantly slowing the economy. Given that, many economists widely expect the central bank to raise rates again on March 21.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
In Making I.M.F. Choice, U.S. Must Decide Whom to Offend

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton administration found itself at the center of a clash today that will force it to choose between angering close European allies or the world's developing nations in appointing the chief of one of the world's important financial institutions -- the International Monetary Fund.
The battle has echoes of the administration's move in 1996 to oust the head of the United Nations and replace him with Kofi Annan. This job, too, is sensitive and complex: chief trauma manager for the world's economic crises. 
 The White House must now decide whether to vote for a German candidate it regards as unsuited for the job, or for Stanley Fischer, the highly regarded deputy director of the I.M.F. Mr. Fischer, an American Jew who was born in Africa, has emerged as the choice of developing nations. These include much of Africa and most Arab nations -- including Iraq, Syria and Libya, not exactly friends of United States policy. The Arab countries have never before supported a Jewish nominee for such a high international post.
American officials say they have nothing but the highest regard for Mr. Fischer, who was backed for the No. 2 post at the I.M.F. by Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers, a former student of Mr. Fischer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But Mr. Summers seems unlikely to be able to cast America's decisive vote -- it has 19 percent of the voting shares of the I.M.F., more than any other country -- for his old friend and economic colleague.
The top I.M.F. post has customarily been Europe's to fill, and the White House fears angering Europe, and particularly Germany, by taking the choice out of its hands. Germany's candidate is Caio Koch-Weser, its deputy finance minister and a former World Bank official.
The White House argument goes like this: Washington traditionally chooses the head of the World Bank -- it just succeeded in gaining reappointment of James D. Wolfensohn -- and it is already accused of dominating major international institutions.
Yet many inside and outside the government fear that backing Europe's choice, and rejecting that of developing nations, would be a great mistake.
"Here, the U.S. has this incredible chance to do what it said it wants to do -- make a new partnership with the developing world -- and vote for the man who is obviously most qualified for the job," said Robert O. Boorstin, who left the Treasury last year after acting as an international policy adviser to former Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "It says volumes that the developing world," which has often been at odds with the economic strictures of the I.M.F., "has found itself able to back someone like Stan," Mr. Boorstin said.
As the No. 2 official of the fund, Mr. Fischer runs its day-to-day operations. He was the field commander from the early stages of the Asian financial crisis in 1997, and he was criticized for imposing too much austerity in Thailand, Indonesia and other nations. But he changed gears and the formula he put together for economic recovery, while still controversial, has brought about results. Thailand, even with some overcapacity, is back in business; South Korea has largely recovered, and Indonesia's pain is chiefly a result of continuing political ferment.
Never before, however, has the top job at the I.M.F. been filled from its lower ranks. And if Mr. Fischer loses in his surprise bid for the top job, it raises questions about whether he could continue as the deputy.
In an interview today, though, he said: "If the members choose to appoint me, I will be honored to fill the job. I have every intention of continuing in this job if I am not elected."
The movement to nominate Mr. Fischer appears to have originated with South Africa and other African countries. He was formally nominated by Angola, which represents 20 African nations on the I.M.F. board.
Support quickly grew, and now includes India, Mexico and other major developing nations.
The American strategy now appears to be to persuade the Europeans to drop Mr. Koch-Weser and come up with another candidate from a list that includes Gordon Brown, the British chancellor of the exchequer, and a small group of other European finance officials. France is unhappy with the choice of Mr. Koch-Weser and has been trying to come up with an alternative -- though it appears unlikely to support Mr. Fischer.
"We have not supported or encouraged any of the nominations to date," said Michelle Smith, spokeswoman for Mr. Summers. "Our position has been, and continues to be to work toward a strong European candidate who can command widespread respect and support, including from the emerging markets. We want to work with Europe toward that objective."
But one of Mr. Fischer's main backers, Shakour Shaalan, an Egyptian member of the I.M.F. board who represents 12 other countries as well, said his group was trying to do more than block the European candidate. "Stan has gained the respect of the developing nations and has been sensitive to its concerns," he said. And he noted the oddity of the Arab countries' nominating a Jew, but said: "Members of my constituency are not looking at him as Jewish or non-Jewish. That's not the issue."
There is a third candidate, as well: Eisuke Sakakibara, the outspoken, sometimes nationalistic former vice minister of finance for international affairs in Japan. He has Tokyo's support, and support in some other Asian capitals, but is not considered a viable candidate for the job. After an initial, secret vote in a straw poll, probably next week, he may drop out. In that case, Japan and some of the other Asians would presumably choose between the European candidate and Mr. Fischer.

HEADLINE: After a Pardon and 39 Years, a Black Exile Comes Home

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Ga., Feb. 24

 BODY:
After 39 years of exile in Britain, Australia and Africa, Preston King finally woke up at home today in America.
And while the day was marked by the solemn tasks of visiting his parents' graves for the first time and attending his oldest brother's funeral, Mr. King also found himself experiencing feelings of wonder at the sea changes in the social order of his southern Georgia hometown, where he had not set foot since 1961. 
 "It really is like being Rip Van Winkle," said Mr. King, 63, a professor of politics at the University of Lancaster in Britain.
Mr. King was a 24-year-old graduate student in the early 1960's when the draft board here, after learning that he was black, stopped referring to him as Mr. King and began addressing him as Preston. Mr. King said at the time that he was willing to serve in the military as long as the board called him by the same respectful title it had used in correspondence when it assumed he was white.
The board refused, and Mr. King was convicted of draft evasion by an all-white jury and sentenced to 18 months in prison. While on bail, he fled to Britain, where he enrolled at the London School of Economics.
"I took that action against the segregationist backdrop of the time," Mr. King said today. "Sometimes you have to take a stand and say no to guys who are not even prepared to make the most minimal concessions of respect to you."
As a consequence, Mr. King could not return to the United States until President Clinton issued a pardon on Monday. Even though President Jimmy Carter, a fellow Georgian and political ally of Mr. King's family, issued a blanket pardon in 1977 for all draft evaders during the Vietnam war, it extended back only to 1964 and so did not cover Mr. King's 1961 conviction.
Family members said they had tried to gain a pardon from previous administrations, but it was not until the current effort, spearheaded in part by Mr. King's daughter, Oona King, a member of the British Parliament, that they felt hopeful. In addition, the judge in the case, William A. Bootle, now 97, wrote a letter in December asking President Clinton to grant Mr. King a pardon.
One of Mr. King's lawyers, Elizabeth Holtzman, a former Democratic congresswoman and Brooklyn district attorney who had worked for a brother of Mr. King while she was a law student, said, "When we began this, I was hearing, 'This has been looked at before and it doesn't fit into the paradigm for a pardon.' "
"It seemed crazy to me that he was still paying the price for standing up to racism," said Ms. Holtzman, who was in Georgia for Mr. King's homecoming.
But that kind of action was a family tradition for Mr. King. The brother whose funeral he attended today, Clennon W. King Jr., was briefly committed to an insane asylum because he had tried to enroll in the all-white University of Mississippi in the 1950's. Other brothers and sisters, as well as his father, were leaders in the civil rights movement, working with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., who was not related, to organize voter drives and desegregate public accommodations.
Mr. King got a chance today to marvel at some of the fruits of that labor. When he walked into a McDonald's restaurant this morning, he said he was pleased to see the integrated staff and customers.
"One of the images I have of my last time here," he said, "is going to that part of town and seeing black men, who were very poor, waiting in the early dawn to be picked up for work in the fields. They were looking very crumpled.
"And I go to that same area today, to McDonald's, and it's brightly lit and the people there, they are black and white and they are all mixed up together and a little bit more buoyed up, and I think, yeah, that's better, much better."
The Albany that Mr. King left behind with its separate drinking fountains for blacks and whites is indeed gone. The town, which was then run by whites, now has a black police chief, a black city manager and black members of the City Council. Mr. King said today, "I am dying to talk to the town officials and see, how do these guys think."
Mr. King said that he had monitored changes in the United States from abroad, but he said: "There's something kind of bloodless about it. You can see the statistics. There are more black mayors, black representatives, the external indications that segregation is gone, but you can't get a feel for things from a distance. There is no substitute for seeing with your own vision, smelling, hearing, feeling things, talking to people."
And while many in this city of 78,000 people are pleased by Mr. King's return, not everyone thinks he should have been pardoned. At Pearly's Famous Country Cooking on North Slappey Boulevard, some patrons were discussing his return over breakfast today.
Ted Cahill, 62, who is white and served in the Navy, said: "There's something that just isn't quite right about this. I can't remember whether anyone called me 'mister' at the time, but I went and he didn't. I just don't like the idea of a pardon. I resent it for the guys who are still over there dead in Vietnam, that they went and he didn't."
But to supporters, Mr. King's civil disobedience was not about the draft, because his family has a tradition of military service. His father was a World War I veteran. Two brothers served in World War II, and one served in Korea. To them, Mr. King was acting on his conscience.
Richard P. Thornell, a professor of law at Howard University who was Mr. King's roommate at Fisk University in the 1950's, helped with the battle to win the pardon. And Professor Thornell traveled from Washington to Georgia for Mr. King's homecoming, which will last until Saturday, when he returns to England.
"Preston is my hero," Professor Thornell said. "What moves me so much is the simple greatness of this family. In all of these towns across the South there are these kinds of families with a great commitment to social justice who have given so much to move their communities forward."
At the funeral today of Mr. King's brother, who had a successful career as a history professor, the Rev. Daniel Simmons spoke of an "inward cry" that he said must have been embedded in the King family, one that said, "You can't sit still being marginalized."
Evoking images from the civil rights movement, Mr. Simmons suggested that the same spirit that moved Mr. King in 1961 continued to spur change today.
"It's a desire," he said, "to be treated the same. It says, I can't be satisfied to just sit at the lunch counter. I want to own the lunch counter. I can't be content only to argue cases in court. I want to be a judge in court. I want it all.
"So we will keep on demanding our rights, until every valley and mountain and hill of discrimination is made low."

HEADLINE: Lautenberg Backs Corzine As His Successor in Senate

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 24

 BODY:
Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who won election 18 years ago as a millionaire businessman who had never held elective office, tonight endorsed Jon S. Corzine, another wealthy newcomer to politics, as his successor, over former Gov. Jim Florio.
Mr. Lautenberg, who is retiring, said at the convention of Bergen County Democrats here that Mr. Corzine, the former cochairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, was best prepared to confront national economic issues and should be the party's nominee for the United States Senate. 
 "We have an economy that looks like there's no top to it," Mr. Lautenberg said, adding that with the stock market jitters the last few days, "I know I'm going to feel very good with Jon Corzine on the budget committee, on the finance committee and on the banking committee."
Mr. Corzine's aides said Senator Lautenberg's support would help immunize Mr. Corzine from two of Mr. Florio's most frequent lines of attack -- particularly that Mr. Corzine is making or steering campaign contributions to powerful Democrats to win their endorsements.
"Every day, Jim Florio claims that Jon Corzine's buying support," said Mr. Corzine's spokesman, Steven Goldstein. "He can't possibly claim that about Frank Lautenberg."
In addition, Mr. Florio has said Mr. Corzine's views -- he opposes the death penalty and welfare reform, and he supports an increase in the minimum wage to $8 an hour -- make him too liberal to win election.
Tonight, Mr. Florio appealed to Democrats at the Bergen County convention to support him because of his experience in the State Legislature, in Congress and as governor. "That's experience that money can't buy," he said.
But Mr. Lautenberg said he planned to work with Mr. Corzine to make him a better candidate in a general election. Acknowledging that Mr. Corzine's position on the minimum wage might not be workable, the senator said, "he's a quick study. I am going to try to help him refine his positions in a way that gains support."
Mr. Lautenberg and Mr. Florio have never been close, aides to both men said, but the senator's decision to back Mr. Corzine shocked Mr. Florio's campaign staff. W. Michael Murphy Jr., a Florio spokesman, said he had expected Mr. Lautenberg to remain neutral in the race.
Advisers to Mr. Corzine said Mr. Lautenberg's endorsement would mark a new phase in the campaign, from locking up the endorsements of Democratic officials and the support of county organizations to beginning to mobilize the party's electorate. In secret balloting tonight, the Bergen County delegates voted 578 for Mr. Corzine, to 335 for Mr. Florio -- 63 percent to 37 percent. Bergen County, considered a swing county in the general election, is New Jersey's most populous, with one-tenth of its voters and one-tenth of its Democrats.
Mr. Corzine's advisers have also said that he is likely to begin running TV advertisements soon after the March presidential primaries. Aides to Mr. Florio, who trails well behind Mr. Corzine in the race to raise money, say he expects to be able to afford only about two weeks of TV commercials before the June 6 primary.

HEADLINE: Owner Is Killed at His East Side Restaurant

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS 

 BODY:
One of the owners of an Upper East Side trattoria was found dead in the restaurant's kitchen yesterday, the victim of an apparent slashing attack, the police said.
Nicolo Orobello, 62, was discovered on the kitchen floor of Erminia Ristorante Italiano at 250 East 83rd Street about 11:30 a.m. by a linen deliveryman who noticed the door to the restaurant was ajar, the police said. A meat cleaver was found resting on Mr. Orobello's chest. A long kitchen knife was at his side. 
 The police said Mr. Orobello, of Queens, had died in a desperate struggle. His throat had been slashed, and his arms and hands were covered with scrapes, bruises and cuts.
The police said they were not sure when the attack had occurred, and did not know if the knife and cleaver found with Mr. Orobello had been used against him or if he had used them to defend himself.
"Nothing has been identified as the murder weapon at this time," said Capt. Robert Iovino of the Manhattan detective bureau.
Sgt. Andrew McInnis, a police spokesman, said the initial investigation turned up no motive for the attack or evidence of a robbery. "At this point there doesn't seem to be anything missing from the restaurant," he said.
However, a police official said last night that detectives were interviewing the restaurant's former employees, and that the investigation was making progress.
Erminia, on the south side of 83rd Street between Second and Third Avenues, has been a cozy neighborhood standby for much of two decades, and is one establishment in a wide-ranging family restaurant empire.
Relatives of Mr. Orobello's wife, immigrants from Italy, have also owned and operated restaurants in San Diego and Miami, and such popular restaurants as Baci on the Upper West Side and Lattanzi in Midtown.
Over the years, observers and critics marveled at the family's ability to endure the vagaries of the restaurant industry and downturns in the economy, all the while maintaining loyal client bases.
Erminia opened in 1983. It received favorable reviews as a romantic cafe that specialized in wood-grilled entrees. Mr. Orobello was remembered by patrons yesterday as a gracious restaurateur.
"It's a tragic loss for the neighborhood," said Stanley Poll, who lives on the East Side. "This is a great restaurant, very cordial, intimate. It was a romantic hideaway. He was a wonderful host."
Mr. Orobello's relatives clustered at the restaurant yesterday, but declined to comment on the case.

HEADLINE: In Return to University, Clinton Focuses on China and Economy

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24

 BODY:
In 1992, the last time Bill Clinton talked economics at the University of Pennsylvania, he was a governor, times were tough, and his campaign manager kept saying, "It's the economy, stupid."
President Clinton returned to the same campus today, with just 11 months to go in his second term, to gloat a bit about his economic stewardship and suggest, without naming names, that Gov. George W. Bush's approach to economics might not be any more successful than that of his father. 
 Mr. Clinton's 1992 economics speech laid out his strategy of emphasizing education, investment tax credits and an overhaul of the nation's infrastructure. At the time, he was down in the polls, his throat was raspy and he pulled no punches in condemning his opponent, President George Bush.
When he talked of the state of the economy, Mr. Clinton derisively labeled it the "Bush recession."
Today, Mr. Clinton took no similar shots at the younger Mr. Bush, who is engaged in a fierce battle for the Republican presidential nomination. But Mr. Clinton suggested that Vice President Al Gore best understood how to keep the current prosperity going and he made clear his preference for paying down the debt rather than making large cuts in taxes.
"We have to maintain our fiscal discipline," Mr. Clinton said. Back in his campaign speech, which presidential aides distributed to reporters today, Mr. Clinton spoke of a battle to stay competitive in a world where Japan and Germany were "beating our brains in" with smarter investment and growth decisions.
Today, however, Mr. Clinton ignored those nations and focused on the need to admit China into the World Trade Organization. Addressing critics, he said differences between the United States and China should not prevent a deal.
"If we do this, 20 years from now we'll look back and wonder why we ever even debated it," he said. "And if we don't, 20 years from now we'll still be kicking ourselves in the seat of the pants."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton made a vigorous pitch to the Business Council, a coalition of corporations that is pushing for congressional passage of China's admission to the World Trade Organization. Vowing "a full-court press from our administration," the president again took on the detractors.
"Most members of Congress don't question the economic benefits," he said. "Critics are more likely to say things like this: China is a growing threat to Taiwan and other neighbors. We shouldn't strengthen it. China is a drag on labor and environmental market rights and, if you put them in the W.T.O., they will block further progress on those issues. Or, China is an offender of human rights and we shouldn't reward it. Or China is a dangerous proliferator. We shouldn't empower it."
Mr. Clinton called the concerns legitimate but said "the problems will be worse if we do not bring China into the W.T.O."
Mr. Clinton's powers of prediction in his 1992 speech proved a mixed bag. He said, for instance, that bullet trains would be shuttling 500,000 passengers a day at speeds of up to 300 miles an hour. That did not happen.
But Mr. Clinton pointed out today that he had emphasized back in 1992, when the Web was in its infancy, the importance of a national informational network. "Just as the interstate highway system in the 1950's spurred two decades of economic growth," Governor Clinton had said, "we need a door-to-door fiber optics system by the year 2015 to link every home, every lab, every classroom and every business in America."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Cat Now and for 17 Years (Nearly Forever)

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
HERE we have a woman who has been in the cast of "Cats" the length of its lengthy run: 17 years, 9 months of putting on the yak hair wig and the tail, painting on the whiskers, crawling around the stage on all fours and being flung thither and yon in a junkyard set.
One would think the title of her autobiography would be "I Wake Up Howling," and with the show scheduled to close in June she would feel free to admit it, but this is not the case. How has Marlene Danielle -- who would like you to pronounce her name Mar-LAY-nuh and who portrays, on stage, the glamour puss Bombalurina -- managed to keep doing the same role over and over? 
 "I'm an alien," says Ms. Danielle, big grin, punching it, who does an interview like a performance and would never, ever, phone anything in, and who looks, whatever her mysterious age, as good as the 20-year-old dancers. "I have an excessive amount of energy and stamina and determination."
And if people think, "That poor dancer"?
"Poor would not be the right word," says Ms. Danielle dryly. "Challenged, maybe, but certainly not poor."
You know what the nice thing is about the dressing room of a Broadway baby? It's one of the few things in New York that looks as it did in a 1930's movie, unless you get finicky and consider the Polaroid snaps. The one where Ms. Danielle is chatting is Room 16 in the Winter Garden. The names of the 12 women who share the room are on detachable nameplates on the door. Leotards hang from a rack. Ms. Danielle's space, after her 17 years, is a section of the dressing table about two feet wide.
The best stuff, of course, is stuff you can't see, the stories of all the women who shared that room. Ms. Danielle, who has seen a marriage come apart and a son grow to adulthood since joining the show, thinks they would make a great television series, which she has been writing.
Some of the things she remembers from the room: the understudy who dealt real estate and was always on the phone and would stomp off in a rage if she was called to go on; the time the girls looked out the window and saw a man "butt naked" on Broadway; the dancer who married a man against her mother's wishes and found, sadly, that her mother had been right. Eventually, everyone moved on. The woman Ms. Danielle dances with now is 20, five years younger than Ms. Danielle's son. Ms. Danielle is the cat who stayed.
The mom cat in this story -- Ms. Danielle's mother, not Ms. Danielle or any of the seven felines she has at home -- had wanted to be an opera singer, but roles for black women, she feared, would be scant. So she married a waiter, settled in a nice house in St. Albans, Queens, and had two daughters. Ms. Danielle was named for Dietrich, for her mother foresaw -- and maternal foresight may often be destiny -- careers in the arts for her girls.
WHEN Ms. Danielle was 7, her parents divorced and Ms. Danielle's mother went to work for the Bulova watch company. "She would come home with all these metal shavings in her hair," Ms. Danielle says.
Factory work? "Yeah," Ms. Danielle says. "There were definitely times it was hard to pay the bills, a few times we had to burn pieces of furniture to keep warm. Once there was a water main burst, and the plumber told my mother we could save money if we dug a new ditch ourselves. A friend of my mother's came by when she was digging and she said, 'You need to get up off your knees, dust that dirt off, paint your nails, and find yourself a life.' "
Ms. Danielle's mother moved the family to a railroad flat in the Village. The rent was $35 and Ms. Danielle and her mother and sister slept in triple bunk beds, but there were artists and there was music, which made everything all right.
Ms. Danielle studied dance, married a French painter after graduating from high school and lived for two years in France, where her son was born. She returned to New York, worked in a few shows, and had cashed her last unemployment check when she landed "Cats."
Some opportunities have come up since then, but nothing has been quite right. How could a glamour puss take that role as a hyena in "The Lion King"? And of course, there are the brownstone in Jersey City and the property in Pennsylvania, which a regular gig has enabled her to have.
"Home is really important to me," Ms. Danielle says often. Security seems to be very important to her, Ms. Danielle is told. "If you want to get down to it, I've seen twice in my life homes that were very precious to me and my family stolen from us. I decided I would never again let that happen to our family."
There is also something else.
"I've seen so many people who have stellar careers go through such highs and lows. The star does fade, and ultimately it's about how happy you are as a human being."
This said, it is not surprising to hear that Ms. Danielle has been with a fellow for 15 years.
What does he look like?
There is a photo in the dressing room, where the younger dancers have come and gone, come and gone. Ms. Danielle laughs when she shows it, for all you can see of her boyfriend is his back. The picture was taken one Columbus Day, after she had performed in the parade. It shows a big man, in a leather jacket, walking down a street in Manhattan, holding hands with a tall, glamorous cat.

HEADLINE: What's Behind Economy's Boom

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Dishonest Truth" (column, Feb. 23), by Paul Krugman: This is not Bill Clinton's economy. This economy is the one produced by the American people. No American president can claim credit for the increased productivity of American workers, the explosion in electronic commerce, the power of our technological revolution, and -- despite Al Gore's assertion -- the birth of the Internet. Government might help, but more often than not Ronald Reagan was right: government should get out of the way to let this country's creative talent make us all proud.
 
TOM PALERMO
Tallahassee, Fla., Feb. 23, 2000

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Tenant-Leaning City Council Prepares to Continue Rent Rules

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
With little echo of the protracted, headline-stirring bombast of the 1997 rent-regulation struggle in Albany, the New York City Council is to hold its first public hearing this morning on legislation required to extend rent control and rent stabilization for 1.1 million city apartments for three more years.
Given the powerful voting bloc represented by that measure of housing stock, all groups concerned, including the city's leading landlord group, have predicted that the Council will pass the extension by its March 31 deadline, along with one change that would protect the rights of tenants moving into deregulated apartments. 
 Placed on the back burner, however, were several proposals to strengthen rent protections. Those proposals came as a new housing survey indicated that the city's vacancy rate dropped to 3.19 percent from 4.01 percent over the last three years -- with 5 percent the statutory level required for declaring a housing emergency and extending rent regulation.
Calling the legislation time-sensitive, Councilman Steven DiBrienza, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said, "You extend the baseline system with the protections as they are and then, in the long range, you fight for the other improvements."
In 1969, the City Council created rent stabilization, intended as a less restrictive system than rent control, which now applies to buildings of three or more units built before Feb. 1, 1947, and occupied by the same tenant since July 1, 1971. Rent stabilization applies to buildings of six or more units built before Jan. 1, 1974.
Under rent control, rents are set through a complex formula administered by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. For years, increases have consistently been 7.5 percent a year, with a $15 a month surcharge for those apartments with rents under $500. Under stabilization, rent increases for one- and two-year leases are set by the Rent Guidelines Board, appointed by the mayor. In recent years, the increases have been roughly 2 to 3 percent.
Today's hearing at City Hall, and another scheduled for March 6, will be held amid lingering bitterness over past Council votes that tenant advocates have argued severely weakened the system.
"Oh, yes! Oh, yes!" said Michael McKee, associate director of one tenant organization, New York State Tenants and Neighbors, when asked whether his members would be turning out in force for today's hearing. "We've been phone-banking just to get people there."
In 1994, the Council passed a law that allows apartments to be decontrolled when the rent reaches $2,000 a month. Laws that allow a landlord to renovate a vacant apartment and then add one-fortieth of the renovation cost to the apartment's monthly rent, when combined with a statutory vacancy increase of at least 18 percent enacted by the Legislature in 1997, are now readily pushing rents beyond that $2,000 level.
"What we're seeing now," Mr. McKee said, "is that for apartments that were renting for $800 before a vacancy, it's very easy for a landlord to get over $2,000 a month" -- and see it decontrolled.
Jack Freund, executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's largest landlord group, protested the direction the Council appeared to be taking.
"There's no question that the City Council will extend the rent laws because of a housing shortage," he said. "But it would be irrational for them to do so without also taking steps to create additional housing. The R.S.A. is proposing that the Council focus instead on a broad new middle-income housing initiative, primarily for the boroughs outside Manhattan, that will create sorely needed housing and eventually end the housing shortage. We are a little sorrowful that the City Council can only muster a knee-jerk reaction."
No statistics were available on how many apartments had been deregulated specifically because of the vacancy decontrol law. But the 1999 Housing and Vacancy Survey, compiled by the federal Census Bureau for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, showed that there were 1,122,872 rent-regulated apartments in the city in 1996, and by last year that figure had dropped to 1,098,939, a 2.1 percent decrease. Breaking out rent-controlled apartments from those overall totals, the survey showed that there were 70,572 rent-controlled apartments in the city in 1996 and 52,562 in 1999, a 25.5 percent drop.
As part of his proposed extension package, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has included a measure that would require landlords to give a detailed explanation of how they achieved the $2,000 rent level required to decontrol an apartment.
Of Mr. McKee's concerns, Mr. Vallone said: "Mike McKee needs an issue, so he'll find one if there's not one there. Suffice it to say we sharply disagree."
Mr. DiBrienza, conceding that his legislation would not come up for consideration by the March 31 extension deadline, said he was proposing that rent-controlled apartments no longer be administered by the state, but by the Rent Guidelines Board, which sets stabilized rents.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
State Pension Money To Leave the Market

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
New York's comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said yesterday he planned to shift almost $5 billion of the state's $120 billion pension fund out of the stock market and invest it overseas or in real estate.
Mr. McCall, who is in the midst of his first asset allocation study in five years, said he wanted to reduce New York's "exposure to domestic equity markets" in reaction to the Federal Reserve Board's efforts to slow the nation's economic growth. 
 The move, to be undertaken this spring, will reduce the pension fund allocation in domestic equities to 45 percent from 50 percent. New York has the second-biggest United States government pension fund, behind California's.
While noting that $5 billion is not a substantial amount of the pension fund, John McCann, an economist at Pace University in New York, said Mr. McCall's move was a prudent reaction to resurgent foreign economies.
Last month, Mr. McCall announced he had committed $250 million of the fund to venture capital investments, specifically "new media and high technology."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Donning the Reagan Mantle

BYLINE: By JOHN BRODER

 BODY:

Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain both tried to wrap themselves in the mantle of Ronald Reagan in television commercials that began running today in the primary states of California, New York, Virginia and Washington. Mr. McCain calls himself a "proud Reagan Republican," while Mr. Bush promotes his $1.3 trillion tax cut plan as "Reaganesque."
 
THE BUSH COMMERCIAL
 
PRODUCER -- Maverick Media
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The commercial uses now-familiar soft-focus pictures of Governor Bush with schoolchildren, veterans, the elderly and his wife, Laura. Snatches of the commercial's text appear in bright type near the bottom of the screen.
 
VOICE-OVER -- The commercial begins with an announcer saying: "Gov. George W. Bush. He's a once-in-a-generation leader with a bold agenda, a successful governor with a fresh leadership style.
 
"So every child reads, he'll fight for education reforms hailed as the most sweeping in a decade.
 
"While Washington deadlocked, he delivered a patients' bill of rights that's a model for America.
 
"He's the candidate with a tax cut called 'Reaganesque' and 'worthy of a new president.' "
 
The advertisement closes with Mr. Bush saying, "I fight for what I believe in, and I get results."
 
THE McCAIN COMMERCIAL
 
PRODUCER -- Stevens Reed Curcio & Company
 
ON THE SCREEN -- A smiling Mr. McCain is standing in a living room as the camera slowly zooms in on his face. Excerpts of the narration flash on the bottom of the screen.
 
VOICE-OVER -- Mr. McCain: "You can't turn on your TV without seeing an ad from the establishment trying to fool you about me. Here's some straight talk. I'm a proud Reagan Republican. I'll tear up the 44,000-page tax code that benefits special interests.
 
"Stop the outrageous waste and pork barrel spending that steals your money. Use the surplus to secure Social Security, cut middle class taxes and pay down the debt.
 
"Give me your vote, and we'll give you back your government."
 
SCORECARD -- Mr. McCain's commercial seems intended to reassure mainstream Republican voters that he resides squarely in the conservative, Reagan wing of the party, even though Republican voters have overwhelmingly preferred Mr. Bush in the primaries held so far. At the same time, Mr. McCain continues his appeal to independent and Democratic voters by emphasizing his opposition to wasteful government spending and his dedication to securing Social Security.
 
Mr. Bush also makes a play for moderate voters, highlighting his record on education and health care reform and emphasizing his "fresh" leadership style. But he caters to core Republican voters with a reference to his tax proposal that The Washington Post called "Reaganesque" in a headline. The Post did not intend the term to be complimentary; its article described the tax cut as so large that it would choke off money for most government programs. The reference was to Mr. Reagan's supply-side approach of using large income tax cuts to stimulate economic activity and limit the growth of government.
 
The Wall Street Journal, in an editorial last December, called Mr. Bush's economic agenda "worthy of a new president." The paper's editorial page has long been an advocate of tax cuts and supply-side economics.
 JOHN BRODER

HEADLINE: As Putin Campaigns, Tape Raises Issues on War

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 26

 BODY:
As Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, opened his election campaign today pledging a new Russia based on the rule of law, new furors erupted over the conduct of the Chechnya war that is the signature of Mr. Putin's Kremlin rule.
In Moscow, Russian officials bitterly attacked a German television station, N24, which released a videotape showing Russian troops conducting a mass burial of Chechen soldiers, some of them mutilated and others bound by the limbs. There was footage of a dead Chechen being dragged by a truck. 
 The Kremlin spokesman on Chechnya issues, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, called the film "the falsification of the year," and the daily Izvestia maintained that its contents had been distorted. The station stood by its depiction of the burial, saying it could not say whether the events shown constituted an atrocity.
Late today in Dagestan, a Russian province neighboring Chechnya, Russian officials said they had found and arrested Andrei Babitsky, a Russian correspondent for the American network Radio Liberty whose treatment at the hands of the Russian military had become an international issue.
Last month Russian officials seized Mr. Babitsky, whose reports on the Chechen war were frequently skeptical of Moscow's positions, on the ground that he lacked proper accreditation. They later suggested that he was working in league with Islamic rebels in Chechnya, and said they had traded him to Chechen guerrillas, with his consent, for Russian prisoners of war.
Mr. Babitsky's disappearance prompted sharp protests by human rights groups and journalists' organizations, and eventually by American diplomats. Radio Liberty officials speculated that he had been murdered or tortured. But until tonight, there was no real evidence of his whereabouts.
Mr. Babitsky spoke by telephone tonight with his wife, Lyudmila, who is in Prague. He apparently offered no hint of what had happened during his captivity, except that he had been held in Chechnya, and was safe and in good condition.
The volatile videotape of a mass burial of Chechen rebels was broadcast on the nongovernmental television network NTV, a frequent critic of the Kremlin. The network said the film had been shot outside Chechnya's capital, Grozny, on Feb. 22, and quoted a German correspondent, Frank Hoefling, as saying that Russian soldiers had allowed the filming because they were unhappy with their burial duty.
The graphic film, shown on Russian and European television, showed the bound bodies of men in military uniforms being dumped into pits and covered with earth. The bindings suggest that the men had been held captive, rather than being shot in battle.
But Izvestia claimed today that one of its reporters, Oleg Blotsky, had shot the film on Feb. 14 as Russian soldiers conducted a supposedly temporary burial of Chechen guerrillas in the Grozny suburbs of Roshni-Chu and Goiti. The newspaper said the soldiers' bodies were bound to ease their transport, and said the bodies were to be exhumed later for identification.
Russian officials said they would conduct an independent inquiry into the videotape and would prosecute anyone found to have violated the law. At the same time, they expressed doubt that the tape was authentic, and said they had no intention of allowing any outside oversight of their inquiry.
The issue overshadowed the unofficial kickoff of Mr. Putin's election campaign, a full-page advertisement in Izvestia in which he repeated many of his earlier promises to bring a market economy and the rule of law to Russia.
Mr. Putin said, as he has before, that no one need fear that his call for a "strong" presidency is a harbinger of a new dictatorship in Russia. "It is the task of a leader to tune people into common goals; to put everyone into their proper place and to help them acquire confidence in their own strength," he stated.
"A great country cherishes its own freedom and respects that of others," he wrote. "The stronger the state, the stronger the individual."
Mr. Putin's campaign manifesto offered few specifics. His previous writings have suggested that he favors a strong state and a western-style economic system governed by a strict set of laws.

HEADLINE: U.S. Surprise: 6.9% Growth In 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The economy barreled ahead at a breathtaking 6.9 percent annual rate in the last three months of 1999, the most rapid rate of quarterly expansion in more than three years, the Government reported yesterday.
The figures released by the Commerce Department are revised estimates from a month ago, when gross domestic product was estimated at a 5.8 percent rate. 
 The 6.9 percent rate matches a similar growth spurt recorded in the second quarter of 1996. It is the fastest rate since the fourth quarter of 1987, when the economy grew at an annual rate of 7.2 percent.
Private economists had expected the figures to show that growth was stronger than forecast, because over the last month figures from important parts of the economy -- particularly retail sales -- have been revised upward. But the size of the increase came as a surprise.
"The economy is screaming ahead," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management. "No one has come close to forecasting this kind of growth coupled with this kind of low inflation."
Notably, the faster rate of growth was not accompanied by an upward revision in key price measures.
An inflation gauge tied to the gross domestic product, the so-called personal consumption expenditure price index, rose at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, unchanged from the previous estimate and only slightly above the 1.8 percent rate recorded in the third quarter.
Despite tame inflation, Mr. Fine and other analysts said the report only served to reinforce the expectation that the Federal Reserve Board would raise short-term interest rates on March 21, when its Open Market Committee next meets to consider changes in monetary policy.
That increase would be the fifth since last June. In order to rein in growth to a more acceptable level, the Fed may have to do even more, analysts said.
"The economy has an awful lot of momentum and the Fed will have to tighten policy by a substantial amount," said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs.
The bond market, which normally reacts badly to news of rapid economic growth, took the report in stride. Indeed, market interest rates on most Treasury securities fell a bit yesterday.
But the stock market, which has spent the last two weeks listening to warnings from the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, that it is responsible for much of the excess growth in spending and therefore in the economy, swooned again yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 230.51 points and closed below 10,000 for the first time since April 6.
Should the stock market retreat further -- the Dow is now off more than 14 percent this year, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down more than 9 percent -- the Fed might not have to be as aggressive in trying to cool the economy, analysts said.
"It is clear that the Fed is in a tightening mode," Mr. Fine said. "But if the stock market declines enough, they might put off any further tightening, just to see how that affects the economy."
A number of factors contributed to the fourth-quarter performance, including robust consumer and government spending and a strong buildup in inventories at businesses. Several analysts say that much of this spending was higher than it otherwise might have been because of concerns about the Year 2000 date change. With that event now over, the pace of growth is probably at least a bit slower in the current quarter, they said.
"A reversal of these increases all point to substantially slower growth in the first quarter," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "But even if the growth rate slows a good bit, when averaged with the fourth quarter the number is still going to be very strong."
The upward revisions in gross domestic product virtually ensure that workers were even more productive than previous data suggested.
"These numbers will cause the productivity numbers to go up even further," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities.
"It is ironic to get this kind of number when Mr. Greenspan is raising questions about whether productivity gains we have seen are sustainable. Rather than aberrations, we may be on the verge of a productivity revolution."
Instead of tightening monetary policy to shut off rapid growth in the economy, Mr. Yardeni argued that the Fed should allow what he called "this new-economy experiment" to continue until it becomes clear that inflation has picked up.
"We don't have an inflation problem right now," he said. "If we get more compelling evidence, then they could act quickly and squelch it pretty rapidly."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Jerry Brown Backs Gore; Rivals Attack G.O.P.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR with JAMES DAO

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, the buttoned-up moderate who has tried to loosen up, today picked up the endorsement of Jerry Brown, the quirky liberal who is sounding more conservative lately.
Mr. Brown, a former Democratic presidential candidate, is now an independent and mayor of this city. 
 He endorsed Mr. Gore tonight at a rally of more than 150 people at a union hall here. "Al Gore cares about poverty and the environment," Mr. Brown said. "He cares about those who are falling between the cracks. He has a philosophy of equality, a philosophy of economic justice. He knows something about technology and the environment."
Called Governor Moonbeam when he was California's chief executive 20 years ago, Mr. Brown has lately been promoting a public military academy for young people and talking tough on crime.
Mr. Gore, appearing in Cleveland earlier today, and his Democratic opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, who was in Washington State, were as tough on their potential Republican opponents as they were on each other.
"Both of the Republican candidates are courting the extreme right wing," Mr. Gore said at a senior citizens center. "Both of them have been opposed to the patients' bill of rights. Both of them have been opposed to an increase in the minimum wage. Both of them supported the Newt Gingrich 'Contract With America,' which was so harmful. So there is not a choice on the Republican side. They just echo one another."
Mr. Gore expounded on his vision of health policy and described the Clinton administration's proposals to expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs. Many people in the audience said they went without drugs prescribed by their doctors because they could not afford them.
Picking up on a theme sounded by House Democrats in recent weeks, Mr. Gore said that elderly people and animals often used the same drugs, but that veterinarians paid lower prices.
"Why should the dog and the cat get cheaper medicines?" he asked. "Large pharmaceutical companies have a great deal of power in the marketplace and precious little competition. They use some of their wealth to block or delay the approval of generic versions of the medicines that could come in and compete with them."
In the second day of a five-day tour of Washington, Mr. Bradley appeared this morning with environmentalists near Seattle.
At a state park overlooking Puget Sound and the snow-capped Olympic Mountains, Mr. Bradley -- who was introduced by a woman whose 18-year-old son died in an oil pipeline accident last year -- vowed to increase pipeline safety and to require that oil tankers entering Puget Sound be guided by tugboats.
He said Mr. Gore "has never seen a dam he didn't like." (Many environmental groups in the Pacific Northwest want to tear down dams to make it easier for salmon to spawn.)
Mr. Bradley also accused Senator John McCain of being no friend to environmentalists.
"John McCain's a reformer, I'm a reformer," Mr. Bradley said. "But when it comes to the environment, there is a vast difference between John McCain and me."
In particular, Mr. Bradley criticized Mr. McCain as deriding federal spending to protect salmon.
Mr. Bradley, who views Washington as his last best chance to build momentum for his campaign before the Super Tuesday primaries on March 7, plans to campaign there exclusively through Monday and has brought dozens of aides from around the country to work in the state.
Mr. Gore plans to campaign in Washington State on Saturday.

HEADLINE: RELIGION JOURNAL;
The Clergy and the Confederate Flag Unfurled

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

 BODY:
When Bishop Dorsey F. Henderson Jr., the Episcopal bishop in Columbia, S.C., steps out the door of Trinity Cathedral there, he need only lift his gaze a bit to see the object of a bitter controversy that has spilled over into national politics.
Across the street from the attractive, 19th-century cathedral stands the South Carolina Statehouse, atop which flies the Confederate battle flag. 
 Bishop Henderson thinks state officials should remove the flag from the dome because, he said in an interview, the flag as a symbol has been "kidnapped by racists" like the Ku Klux Klan.
"I'm a Southerner, I grew up in small towns in Florida," said the bishop, the spiritual head of the Diocese of Upper South Carolina, which incorporates the state's mid- and northern sections.
Bishop Henderson said he understood that some South Carolinians regarded the flag fondly, as a symbol of their heritage and of military bravery in the Civil War.
But, he added, given that the flag "is such a symbol of racism in today's culture, I think we can find better ways of honoring heritage than flying this banner."
The bishop's remarks underline an important element in the flag controversy -- the involvement of religious leaders in seeking its removal to help the cause of racial reconciliation between whites and blacks, for whom the flag symbolizes a grim past of bondage and servitude.
State officials put up the battle flag, beneath the national and state flags on the Statehouse dome, in 1962 as the civil rights movement was gaining steam. Lately the flag has become the focus of intensifying controversy.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has called for an economic and tourism boycott of South Carolina until the Legislature removes it.
Earlier this month, as national attention focused on South Carolina and its Republican primary, the major presidential candidates -- Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona -- were asked what the state should do.
Mr. Bush said it was up to South Carolinians. Mr. McCain seemed to waver, at first calling it a symbol of racism, then saying it was a "symbol of heritage."
Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, suggested a compromise in which the flag would be moved to another place on the Capitol's grounds, near an equestrian statue of Wade Hampton, the Civil War general who was the state's first governor after Reconstruction and was then a United States senator. (Hampton is buried on Trinity Cathedral's grounds.)
Meanwhile, some religious groups have decided to honor the N.A.A.C.P.'s call for a boycott.
Last year the bishops of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, acting at the recommendation of Bishop David A. Donges of the church's South Carolina Synod, canceled plans to meet in Charleston, S.C., and rescheduled their gathering for Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
And in January, Bishop Henderson announced the Episcopal diocese would honor the boycott, too, by shortening its annual convention in February from two days to one, so that delegates would not have to stay overnight in hotels.
The convention was already on record, through votes in 1994 and 1997, calling for the flag to be moved from the Statehouse to "a more appropriate location."
Bishop Henderson reflected on that in a letter to parishioners last September. "Not everyone who is interested in the history of the Old South, including its banners, is a racist," he wrote. "But whatever else the flag may mean to us, it cannot be separated entirely from the shameful sin of slavery."
He asked Episcopalians to view the controversy within a biblical framework, keeping in mind that Jesus followed "a ministry of reconciliation" and that the apostle Paul warned Christians "not to put any stumbling block or obstacle in your brother's way."
In January, Bishop Henderson joined a march held on the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that ended in a rally near the Statehouse, where participants called for the flag's removal.
The bishop said he looked down his row of marchers and saw the state's Lutheran and Methodist bishops and representatives from the Roman Catholic diocese, the local jurisdiction of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) and the Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina, which has its headquarters in Charleston.
But Bishop Henderson said he did not think that moving the Confederate flag from the Statehouse would ultimately be enough because eliminating racism demanded dedicated effort. "You'd like to think the flag goes down and it's over," he said. "It's not."
"Reconciliation is not just the absence of conflict about this," the bishop continued. "We've got to recognize the problems and deal with them in a significant way, or that dreadful sin will plague us forever."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Jones Falls 230 Points, To End the Week at 9,862
The Dow Jones industrial average, which last month reached a peak of 11,723, closed below the 10,000 mark for the first time in 10 months and is down 14.22 percent for the year. The Nasdaq composite index fell 27.15 points, to 4,590.50, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 20.07 points, to 1,333.36.
Previously the Nasdaq has been impervious to the selling pressures seen in the Dow. But now investors believe Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is serious about raising interest rates until he has curbed the economy's growth, and that these rate increases will hurt some industry groups far more than others. Page A1.
 
Automakers Form Online Venture
General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler said they would set up the world's biggest online marketplace, a giant auction site like eBay that they plan to use for buying the nearly $250 billion worth of auto parts and other goods that they need each year. The automakers hope that the move will save time and money and make it easier to build cars to order. A1. 

Priceline Set to Offer Cheaper Gas
Priceline.com said it will extend its discount price system to gasoline. Using essentially the same business model it already relies on to sell airline tickets and hotel rooms, Priceline said that it would begin offering people a way to shop around, via the Internet, for the lowest gasoline prices in their neighborhoods. Priceline promised savings of 10 cents to 20 cents a gallon if consumers are flexible about the brand. C2.
 
Canadian Television Company Bid
The owner of Canada's largest phone system, BCE, made a $1.6 billion cash bid for the country's No. 2 television network, CTV, in an attempt to acquire more programming to compete with cable television and other providers of communications and media services. Some analysts were calling the BCE bid for CTV a Canadian version of America Online's $165 billion deal to buy Time Warner. C2.
 
Carnival Withdraws Bid for Fairfield
Carnival, the cruise ship operator, withdrew a bid of $775 million to acquire Fairfield Communities, which managed vacation time-share properties. C3.
 
Little Hope Seen for Mexican Airline
Doubts have grown that Taesa, the Mexican airline, will recover from the financial collapse that grounded it three months ago. This week Taesa was ordered into bankruptcy protection, and banking officials said at least a third of its $380 million in debt would never be repaid. Taesa amassed the debt as part of an effort to offer cut-rate fares. C2.
 
Japan Replaces a Bank Reformer
The chairman of the government agency responsible for resurrecting Japan's troubled banking system was dismissed after telling a group of local bankers that he would protect them from inspections their managers considered too harsh. He was replaced by Sadakazu Tanigaki, a member of Parliament, who is likely to favor more vigorous reform. C2.
 
Slow Progress for Women in Japan
Women have been joining the professional career ranks in Japan recently, but their numbers are small, and many women complain that everything from social mores to the tax code conspire to keep things that way. A3.
 
F.B.I.'s Web Site Was Attacked
The Federal Bureau of Investigation said that electronic vandals shut down its Internet site for hours last week in the same type of attack that disrupted some of the Web's major commercial sites. The bureau's Web site remained inaccessible for more than three hours on Feb. 18 because vandals overwhelmed it by transmitting spurious signals. C4.

HEADLINE: CARMAKERS TO BUY PARTS ON INTERNET

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich., Feb. 25

 BODY:
General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler announced today that they would set up the world's biggest online marketplace for the auto industry's private use, a giant auction site like eBay through which they plan to buy the nearly $250 billion worth of parts and other goods they need each year. The site would dwarf all previous commercial activity on the Web.
The automakers said they hoped to cut costs and save time by streamlining their purchasing operations and putting them online. The new system would also help them build more cars to customer specifications by allowing them to order parts for assembly plants far more quickly. 
 Auto executives predicted that they could cut purchasing costs up to 10 percent over several years with the new system by making it easier for more companies to bid on each contract and by eliminating the need for many of the meetings now required before a parts order is placed.
Since half the cost of a $20,000 car lies in purchased parts, the new system could reduce the cost of producing a typical automobile by $1,000. This could slow inflation in car prices by offsetting part of the cost of new features like compact disc changers.
G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler said they had begun talking to other automakers, notably Toyota, about joining the new business, and would strongly encourage their suppliers and dealers to channel purchases through the online marketplace as well. As a result, the new marketplace's business volume could become several times as large as the automakers' own purchasing budgets.
Retail sales over the Internet, including everything from Amazon.com to eBay, are estimated to have been $10 billion to $15 billion last year.
The automakers said that while they would use the new Internet system for soliciting bids and awarding contracts, they would not actually combine their purchasing budgets, a step that might raise antitrust concerns. Instead, each automaker will use separate areas of the Internet marketplace to post requests for bids on everything from tires to steering wheels. Security software will be designed to prevent access by anyone except automakers and authorized suppliers, and to prevent automakers from viewing one another's contracts and suppliers from viewing one another's bids.
The automakers have worked together before on shared computer standards for purchasing and for the design of common auto parts, without objections from antitrust regulators. Justice Department officials declined to comment on today's deal.
While automakers have begun using e-mail for some purchases, much of the industry's procurement is still done in ways that have changed little in a century. An automaker's purchasing representatives call suppliers that have bid on similar contracts in the past, telling them to send sales representatives to a meeting in the Detroit area to discuss the contract. Preliminary engineering specifications are exchanged, and suppliers are given a deadline for sending in bids and detailed blueprints. Further meetings are then held to work out the details and award the contract.
The automakers hope the new system will reduce costs and save time. Engineering data will be exchanged electronically, and suppliers from all over the world will be able to bid on any contract, possibly increasing competition.
"It will drive a lot of the inefficiencies out of the system," said Harold R. Kutner, G.M.'s group vice president for worldwide purchasing.
The new marketplace, which the automakers plan to spend about $200 million to set up, will also automatically convert currencies, keep track of export regulations around the world and even perform some language translation of bids. Suppliers and dealers will be able to use the marketplace to pool orders for products like photocopiers, so as to reap some of the same economies of scale the automakers already have.
G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler were the world's three largest companies in 1998 in terms of sales and share of global economic output. G.M. alone employs 3,000 purchasing representatives around the world. Mr. Kutner said the new system would allow automakers to shrink their purchasing staffs, but declined to speculate on when or how this might occur.
G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler have done fairly little hiring in the last two decades, except for engineers, so they usually resort to early-retirement programs, rather than layoffs, to reduce white-collar employment, and are sometimes able to retrain employees to work in other divisions.
Internet businesses have enjoyed an advantage in retail sales because they are exempt from sales taxes. But most corporate purchases are not covered by sales taxes, so the electronic marketplace will mean few losses in tax revenue.
G.M. and Ford had already announced plans three months ago to set up their own separate online marketplaces. But when DaimlerChrysler began talking about creating yet another Internet system for its purchasing, suppliers began complaining vehemently and demanded that the automakers agree on a common standard.
"They said, 'What the heck are you doing here, why are you going to create a third standard, and that encouraged us to think about it," said Peter Weiss, DaimlerChrysler's project manager for electronic purchasing, at today's news conference in G.M.'s car engineering center in this Detroit suburb.
G.M. and Ford agreed to combine their systems and give DaimlerChyrsler a stake in the combined company, which has not yet been named. G.M.'s system has been designed by Commerce One and Ford's by Oracle. The two technology companies will also have stakes in the new company, which the automakers said they planned to spin off as an independent business once it had "significant" revenues from administering services like language translation and bid processing.
Automakers plan to use the new system over the next several years to help them undertake a radical change in the way they build and distribute cars. The manufacturers now assemble and paint most cars based on guesses of what combinations of options and colors will interest consumers, then ship them to dealers, which keep huge numbers of cars available, an expensive undertaking. A few cars are assembled and equipped to customers' orders, but because of the logistical difficulties in ordering the correct combinations of parts from thousands of suppliers, these take a month or two to deliver, a lag that discourages most buyers.
The new purchasing system will make it much easier to take customers' orders for specific models with specific options and colors, allowing the completed automobile to be shipped within 10 to 20 days.
Now, for example, if an automaker receives an order for 100 extra cars with leather seats, it forwards the order to a seat maker, which in turn sends an order to a leather supplier. In the new system, auto makers will relay sales data and orders from dealers to the new marketplace almost instantly, so that even second-tier suppliers, like a leather vendor, can receive this information immediately.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
STOCKS IN TURMOIL AS WORRIES GROW ON HIGHER RATES

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average, which reached a peak of 11,723 last month, closed below the 10,000 mark yesterday for the first time in 10 months as investors dumped shares of companies most vulnerable to higher interest rates. The other popular stock indexes followed suit.
The Dow finished the week down 3.5 percent. It is off 14.22 percent for the year, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has lost 9.25 percent of its value. The Nasdaq composite index, which has been impervious to the selling pressures seen in the Dow and is dominated by shares of technology and other so-called new-economy companies, fell yesterday but is up 12.81 percent this year. 
 This extraordinary divergence in the market reflects two views held by investors: that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, continues to be deadly serious about raising interest rates to curb the economy's growth and that these rate increases will hurt some industry groups far more than others.
The older, more established companies that make up the broader market indexes will be hurt by rising interest rates, investors believe, because these companies' borrowing costs may rise substantially. But because the fledgling technology companies found in the Nasdaq composite do not rely as heavily on banks for capital, these concerns will not face rising costs as a result of a few interest rate increases.
The bifurcated market indexes pose something of a quandary for Mr. Greenspan, stock strategists say. He has made it clear that rising stock prices have fueled an already rocketing economy as investors increased their spending to reflect higher net worths. Thus, if the Nasdaq continues to generate significant wealth for investors, Mr. Greenspan could feel compelled to raise rates even as the Dow and the S.& P. are falling.
"The Fed wants a slower economy, and the stock market is interfering with this policy goal," said Christine A. Callies, chief United States stock strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Since no one has made any real money in any sectors except tech, when he talks about wealth effect he's talking about the tech sector."
Investors are clearly realizing that Mr. Greenspan appears committed to raising interest rates as high as he must to curb economic growth. The government's report yesterday of a 6.9 percent increase in gross domestic product in the final quarter of 1999 only bolstered this belief.
The Dow declined 230.51 points, or 2.28 percent, to 9,862.12, yesterday; the Nasdaq fell 27.15 points, to 4,590.50, and the S.& P. 500 dropped 20.07 points, to 1,333.36.
Investors expect Mr. Greenspan to act soon on rates. The Fed's Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet on March 21; investors expect short-term rates to be raised by one-quarter of a point at that meeting.
Though Mr. Greenspan has said that he is not trying to make the stock market a target of monetary policy, strategists agree that if stock prices fall over all, he will feel more comfortable that the effect of new wealth on the economy will then be muted. Accordingly, a less aggressive stance on interest rates might be enough to dampen the economy.
"If he sticks to his guns, he not only has to continue to raise rates until he's confident that economic figures are coming down but also that he's confident he's affected the stock market," said Alan W. Kral, vice president at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen, a money management firm in New York. "The only thing I am confident of is the Fed can raise rates high enough to affect all stocks. Hopefully it can get the economic response it wants without having to go that far."
The effect of rising rates on some stocks, particularly financial services, has already been brutal. American Express fell 4 percent yesterday, bringing its loss for the year to 25 percent. Citigroup, which lost 2.5 percent, is down almost 14 percent this year. Consumer goods stocks continued their declines, as did retailers, shares in basic materials concerns and oils.
"Some of the companies that represented the strong part of the old world -- G.E., Home Depot, Wal-Mart -- have had significant corrections this year," said James E. Moltz, vice chairman at International Strategy and Investment, an investment research firm. "Something's happened. The growth is narrower; the island of insulation seems to be shrinking some."
Even among favored technology stocks, investors are becoming choosier. One aspect of yesterday's trading action that rattled some investors was that the selling extended to former technology darlings like I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and Cisco Systems. Investors seem worried that earnings at these large companies are no longer growing fast enough to guarantee future gains in their stock prices. They are selling these shares and going into much smaller, untested companies in biotechnology and health care, for example, that are thought to be in the early stages of growth.
Investment managers said their customers were not panicked by the Dow's fall. Instead, they were dispirited by continued declines in established, profitable companies. "People that have held off as long as they can are finally selling out of some of their nontechnology stocks," said David Eidelman, a money manager at Eidelman, Finger & Harris in St. Louis. "They are so frustrated they are throwing in the towel and buying technology stocks."
Money flowing into mutual funds confirms the all-technology all-the-time mood of investors. In the week ended Wednesday, $1.6 billion went into technology stock funds, $1.2 billion flew into biotechnology and $1 billion was earmarked for aggressive growth stock funds, according to AMG Data Services. Meanwhile, investors took more money out of funds that mirror the performance of the S.& P. 500 index -- a previous favorite -- than they put in.
With investor interest in technology riding high, the Nasdaq is likely to stay on a roll. "It is very hard to make a case that higher interest rates will bring Nasdaq down," said Douglas Cliggott, chief United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "The catalyst for that is a combination of two things, a slower rate of inflows into mutual funds, which might start happening in a few weeks, and if we start to see some negative earnings surprises. My guess is you'll see more cracks in the earnings picture."
As big-name stocks fell, investors sought safety in short-term Treasury securities. Yields on the two-year Treasury note fell to 6.40 percent from 6.50 percent Thursday as investors exited stocks.
